Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

Hello all

   I went to the 2nd annual one a few years back at Cell Space
to do a write-up for a failed website and we didn't recognize
any of the names, either.  All of the artists ended up being
mainly sound-art artists, lots of noise and custom electronic
instruments...far beyond what you'd call IDM, even.  Not really
what we usually for at other electronic fests that are more well
known.  
      Despite the high noise content, don't confuse it with the
annual Noise Fest, either....take care...

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Wiring the Vast Left-Wing Conspiracy

--=====================_13284442==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Been a week behind on my reading, and just studied the article below this 
morning.  Struck a cord with me.  I think this is where things are going 
for those of us who see ourselves as "progressive" and are disenchanted 
with the old Democratic machine.

I have been active with moveon.org and other organizations described in the 
article, and it is only now that I've seen this "movement" well covered.

Love,

Apollo

Wiring the Vast Left-Wing Conspiracy
By MATT BAI

Published: July 25, 2004, New York Times Magazine

Andy Rappaport made his millions as a venture capitalist,searching out what 
he calls ''ideas that change the world.'' About six years ago, for 
instance, when most everyone else in the high-tech industry thought 
wireless communication was going to depend on new, exotic semiconductors, 
Rappaport threw $2.5 million into a start-up called Atheros Communications, 
whose founders were focusing instead on building low-cost radios using 
common chip technology. It was a smart move. When the company went public 
last February, the initial investment by Rappaport and his partners was 
worth more than $60 million.

Rappaport is also, increasingly, an avid investor in liberal causes, and in 
this context he might be called a political venture capitalist. Rappaport 
and his wife, Deborah, whose philanthropic activities in recent years 
include several million dollars in donations to art museums and 
after-school music programs, have committed at least $5 million this year 
-- so far -- to support a bevy of fledgling liberal groups, like Music for 
America and Punkvoter.com, aimed at mobilizing younger voters.

I met Rappaport, who is 46, in early June in his firm's offices on Sand 
Hill Road, Silicon Valley's answer to Wall Street. As we talked in a plush 
conference room flanked by a sunlit terrace on one side and a pool table on 
the other, events in the world outside seemed to be tilting strongly in the 
Democrats' favor. Public support for President Bush's handling of the war 
in Iraq was dropping precipitously. The price of oil had shot up to $42 a 
barrel. Only hours earlier, voters in South Dakota sent a Democratic woman, 
Stephanie Herseth, to the U.S. House in a special election -- a race widely 
viewed as a potential harbinger for November.

But if all of this made John Kerry a good bet to become the next president, 
it did nothing, in Rappaport's view, to solve the Democrats' underlying 
problems. When I asked if he was skeptical about the direction of the 
party, he smiled, then said dryly, ''If you've been able to discern a 
direction on which to be skeptical or optimistic, then you're doing pretty 
well.''

Rest of 
article: 
http://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/25/magazine/25DEMOCRATS.html?pagewanted=all&position=


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

X-ELNK-Trace: 3dff75ed0343effeee26750b534f88a60a9da525759e2654657ff0826e81a7f6aa62bdeb842bb5aa0ca2637590cc961d350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 67.101.148.49

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

The SFEMF is much more of an academic computer-music festival, with strong
ties to the electronic-music program at Mills College.

I don't know all the artists in this year's lineup, but Ramon Sender is a
Bay Area legend as one of the founders of the SF Tape Music Center with
Morton Subotnick (computer music pioneer) and, I think, Pauline Oliveros,
back in the late 60s. Joan Jeanrenaud was cellist in the Kronos Quartet for
20 years. Ikue Mori was in the seminal no wave group DNA in the late 70s,
alongside Arto Lindsay, and went on to do extremely experimental drum
machine recordings on John Zorn's label. Wobbly is a local computer musician
who's released some really interesting things on Kid606's Tigerbeat6 label,
including one disc entirely made up of samples sourced from KMEL and other
commercial R&B stations. Basically, it's in the tradition of John Oswald's
Plunderphonics. And Keith Fullerton Whitman is best known as Hrvatski, and
he's recorded crazy breakcore mayhem for a number of labels, including (I
think) Planet Mu and Tigerbeat6.

For what it's worth, I don't recognize most of the DJs whose names I see on
the sfraves list. It's a big world out there and there are lots of distinct
electronic music scenes... including plenty that have little or no relation
to "raving," per se.

Philip


----

philip sherburne

Subject: Re: [sfraves] HELP ME PLEASE

I used to live in Chicago, I wasn't a big partier at the time but you
can find a ton of stuff to do. Just go to Gramaphone Records and
you'll be set. Gramaphone Records was basically the store that
launched house during the days when Chicago created it. House used to
own Chicago, as in it was mainstream. It's still pretty strong there
although I get the impression that jungle is more of the thing. Also
look for Tim Xavier and DJ Rush, do a Google thing for their sites,
techno DJs based in Chicago I think. (I know Rush is, I think Xavier
as well.)

Seriously tho finding dance music in Chicago is about as difficult as
finding cowboy hats in Texas. Probability is on your side.

Giles/Soundwave


ps: go to Renalli's on Clark & Division for the double-decker pizza,
this is actually a pepperoni pizza which contains another pepperoni
pizza. seriously it is a pepperoni pizza which has another pepperoni
pizza listed as one of its ingredients. it is the world's only
recursive pizza. or, if you want the best pizza in Chicago, which in
other words means the best pizza on earth, and you don't mind visiting
a bad neighborhood, go to Medici's near the University of Chicago.
this pizza is so good that living your entire life without ever
tasting it is like living your entire life without ever having an
orgasm. and I don't mean an "oh I think I came" orgasm. I mean a
seeing purple spots and swearing in Latin orgasm. it's GOOD. seriously
I feel sorry for anyone who's never had real Chicago pizza. anyway
when I say "bad neighborhood" I don't mean you'll actually get shot at
or anything, but the pizza is so good that if you had to risk getting
shot at just to taste it, it would be worth it.

From: =?iso-8859-1?B?T6dieSBKYW16 ?= <osby@hellokitty.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Sun, 01 Aug 2004 22:19:44 -0800
X-Originating-Ip: 198.144.214.85
X-Originating-Server: ws5-3.us4.outblaze.com
Message-Id: <20040802061944.707FF23C0B@ws5-3.us4.outblaze.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Saturday: The Softball game... then TELIC... mmhmm... yeah.. (Post 1)

So Saturday MONRING.. I went 2 school 4 tutoring.. I mean.. yeah Math sucks, but i am learing 2 appreciate it & (i seriously can't belive I"m sayin' this) having like some kinda mondo fun w/ it actually... Hello 2Day... 

So after tutoring.. I was originally suppose 2 like hook up w/ an Ooooooooold school friend from sooooooooo back in the day.. but there was hella miscommunication & I ended up goin' 2 the the "DJ ALL STARS & PROMOTERs" 2nd annual or something like that softball game... LoL.. it was fun.. Red team won & ironically, my hair it some kinda sunshine pomogranite, blonde, & deep grape plum purple colors.. but still all in all.. it was a fun time @ the baseball field hangin' out w/ Bros & Sistas I ain't seen in a looooooong time & esp gotta kick it w/ the bruised & happily injured Dragnfly lady.. LoL.. Love U Dina... send me some pixes of those injuries & that Dope side hottie profile pix =)

OK.. so yeah.. I was like kinda flutter 4 the 1st like 1/2 hour i was there 'cause I just got there FROM SCHOOL & well.. living the weekend raver gypsy (& usually broke) lifestyle i been havin' the past few years now ever since my car got stolen la la la never knowing where i'm gonna end la la... so after the game... Hello 2day.. I ended kickin it w/ LoL... these Mondo Super Duper Prideful Candy Kids & headed down 2 their headquarters in Freemont...

So back on BART I went w/ these playful creatures, made candy braclets 4 like a few hours although i only made 3, almost got my asskicked by some1 'cause I walked in2 the wrong apartment.... then went 2 TELIC... OK.. yeah

OK.. I'm gonna save a few things 4 Post 2 'cause I got some real big huge birds on my shoulders about TELIC that mondo fuckin' urked & I'll focus this post on the event itself... I mean... OK.. my choices 4 the night were either TELIC or this underground Jungle thingie that was goin' on in the City actually that was pretty close 2 my school,, but ya know.. I mean... as much as Frankie Bones comes out here.. I still like 2 pay him my respect 'cause he did spin @ the 1st Rave I went 2 la la la.. so yeah... & I do like his Techno sets esp more so since I been falling more in Love w/ it 4 the past 2 years.. hmmmm.. maybe a year longer...  So i was really ANXIOUS 2 hear a bangin' Techno set from him...

TELIC is a really nice venue... old school 'cause it's just 1 huge wherehouse room... but i dunno man.. i went through some shit b4 i went inside which put me in a totally fucked up mood & I dunno.. hearin' Foo foo trance 4 hella long & my mood mixing 2gether really made me feel like I was in Hell... Brandon (if you're reading this).. U remember that 1 party??? LoL.. yeah.. well... I felt like i was in hell wondering WTF i was doing there & I dunno... I was probably like that 4 like 2 hours...

Slowly the venue was hella packin' up & honestly, seein' Family, old friends, & makin' new friends (I made a new friend name Thumper lastnight.. LoL) & well.. alota touching things happened... 1 of my okd Homeboys Thanked me 4 like well.. a few yrs ago.. I helped him out when he was throeing up & sick after this 1 party & i helped him get home & he kept coming up 2 me lastnight & Thanking me...
I dunno... i started feelin' kinda plurie 'cause seein' people from like baaaaack in the day pop up... oh yeah.. another thing that made it bearable was spending 1/2 th3 night w/ Sean G & maki'n fun of people, the Horny Tards, The Meanie Tards, the ummm... well.. there were a few Groove the Movie moments (literally) that we experienced & talki'n 2 homeboy =) LoL  But honest 2 God man.. seein' every1 i saw lastnight really made me feel better & it was Awesome.. Thanks y'all!

OK.. Sets... ummmmm... well.. i wasn't really fond of AAAAAAAAAALL the Foo Foo Trance i heard lastnight & there was alota that from the DJs when 1st got there.. but ok.. Morgans set was pretty Dope.. I mean.. I guess he spun some playful stuff @ the begining, but then his Trance towards the 2nd part of his set on out was well.. there was alota old school stuff, the good stuff, I heard him spin if I'm right about that, & some Cyber Trancey tunes, & some preogreesive stuff....

Frankie Bones was really what I expected.. I mean.. I admit his set was really good, but not what i expected or wanted from him.. he kept it @ a totally well not mondo but kinda slwor BPM set. he started out HOuse, swtiched around alot w/ some Tech HOuse, Trance, some house... then he kept the 2nd part of his set w/ some hardcore strait up (4give me if I get this wrong,but I guess being totally influenced w/ Techno DJs here) Eastcoast Techno groove.. totally hard bass beat thumpin shit... it was Good 4 what it was, but i dunno... what I'm used 2 having my Techno w/ like more Percussion  emphasized songs... Frankie Bones spun alota Techno w/ whiney sounding melodies & I dunno.. it was slow... there's this 1 Frankie BOnes CD i got where he spins this bad ass Techno mix & I dunno... like i said, it was a Groovy set 4 what it was.. but it wasnt really in my boat lastnight or taste from what he spun... 

I feel kinda guilty 4 bein' let down by his set, but I also try 2 remind myself that when he spun @ the 1st Rave i ever went 2... he spun alot vocal booty house & Robin S opened 4 him.. i dunno.. la la la...  Also, I mean.. I Love My AndyW, Catharsis, ChrisJ, Raf1, Clarity, Forest Green, Kent, Jbot, even Shazbot Techno & it was I been totally living on 4 the past few years, so yeah... I guess I have a preferrence in term of Techno, but i know i know i know.. he coulda tore it up harder, but he made it soft 4 the candy kids... whatever.. lol

Todd Phrofet went on Next after him.. I actually Looved this set more better than the headliner.. LoL. I mean.. he started out some really hard bass heavy techno.. a few tracks with the whiney melodies like Frankie's, but he mixed in alooooota progreesive trance... really simialar 2 was Keitth Edwards does (wait... is that his name.. i 4got...ooops) & Mike Lui...  I did manage 2 dance

OK... now YUM... Madame Mercury really tore it up... i mean.. she tagged w/ sokme1.. i 4got who.. but fuck man.. i loved it... MM was all like New School breakbeats from the start, she got in some well.. there was this like ?epic? kinda sounding track.. LoL.. it was fun, & then this old skool brak beats track... I Loved it!!

I danced as much as could lastnight, but by MM set I was kinda man.... tired... LoL...

Some dude i 4got his name spun the closing set.. Trance again... it waxs fun.. but I was tired @ delirious by that point...

Yeah... LoL



Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] TELIC.. Post #2- Am i wrong about this?

OK... so I usually have no problems w/ security ever since I became friends w/ like some of the bouncers @ 1015 back in the day & well.. ok yeah.. i'm the biggest pack rat in the world la la la...

But OK... I knew I was gonna have my problems w/ my back pack 'cause I went 2 SCHOOL in the morning & just had a back pack w/ me with all my school shit.. i knew before hand that i was gonna have some problems with my back pack & the party.. but yeah.. no biggie.. or so i thought... Hello 2Day

I got 2 TELIC...  OK.. Security basically RAPED me (in a matter of speaking).. not only did they do the full body search thingie.. but they checked everything everything everything...  the inside of my notebooks night have acid sheets in them... oh yeah.. my homeowrk might possibly ehatever the the fuck man...  my back pack was throughly ramsacked...my walkman sould contained pills side the motor..let's pull that apart... 

the security gaurd who searched my body actually cupped my balls through my pants & pressed hard if i moved... wouldn't that count as like sexual harassment or something???

My wallet chain(s) had 2 consficated & held 'til the end of the party.. understandable... but when U tell me that I have 2 put eveerything in my car & I tell U that I don't hagve a car... i (in a matter of speaking) took bart here from school & i don't have a car, sorry..  then I don't need a security gaurd fuckin' yelling @ me LITERALLY telling me I'm stupid then 4 having all my stuff w/ me & havin'g no place 2 put it & insulting me 4 being @ the party.. then what's up w/ that man???

In the morning when I left w/ Jaze, well wheni got my wallet chains back from security.. i got in2 a lil' arguement w/ the security lady & totally didn't mean 2.. she totally blew everything i was asking & sayin'g outta proportion....  she told me well.. yelled 2 me, "Wha the hell is your problem, we had 2 take your wallet chain to save your life & that's what our job is here to make this event safe for you" la la la she went on... OK.. yeah.. whatever...

But is her taking my wsallet chain saving the life of the kid who dropped 5 pills of E in a venue that has no air ventilation, over priced water, & the kid starts havin' seizures in the corner???  Their out there savcing lives when kids still find ways 2 get drugs in???  I mean.. seriously... how did she save my life & why should i be "Thankful" 4 the way secirty treated... yeah... their paid 2 B there 2 do their shit whatever.. Hello 2day... but fuck, c'mon now.. I was Verbally harrassed by security, possibey sexually harrassed (I'm still ike totally questioning that), & i dunno... is their job 2 do that harrassing on top of all the "security" shit they do??

I know this shit is 2 fold 'cause they know the have 2 know that the event that they do security 4 is illegal, but still man.. WTF... are they walkin' around the venue takin' care of etards makin' it safe 4 me???  Are they taking care of those potential situations that might fuck things up???  How exactly are they saving my life by doing all that shit 2 me.. I know it's not their job 2 care about my situation & how i got there & my school stuff.. whatever... but don't fuckin' make fuckin rude ass comments 2 me in line & not expect a comeback from me & fduckin' interupt my talkin' in repspone 2 your fuckin' comments... is that saving my life w/ your rude as fucki'n mouth???

I'm sorry, but I really had 2 bent this crap... this is what made my 1st TELIC event really sour man... I'm even questioning if i ever wanna go 2 another event there 'cause I don't need 2 b treated that way by security @ all... fuckin' bouncers everywhere else ain't got that kinda ghetto fuckin' style of treating the event guests...

But ami wrong 4 feeling the way I do about how i was treated?




Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

The jungle scene out there is and has been very small and tight knit for
years now, espeically since the rave scene died.  House and progressive rule
the city based on what all my friends tell me, and it seems to ring true
every time I go back.

-Andrew

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "DJ Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: <emode@cwazy.co.uk>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Sunday, August 01, 2004 6:09 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] HELP ME PLEASE


> I used to live in Chicago, I wasn't a big partier at the time but you
> can find a ton of stuff to do. Just go to Gramaphone Records and
> you'll be set. Gramaphone Records was basically the store that
> launched house during the days when Chicago created it. House used to
> own Chicago, as in it was mainstream. It's still pretty strong there
> although I get the impression that jungle is more of the thing. Also
> look for Tim Xavier and DJ Rush, do a Google thing for their sites,
> techno DJs based in Chicago I think. (I know Rush is, I think Xavier
> as well.)
>
> Seriously tho finding dance music in Chicago is about as difficult as
> finding cowboy hats in Texas. Probability is on your side.
>
> Giles/Soundwave
>
>
> ps: go to Renalli's on Clark & Division for the double-decker pizza,
> this is actually a pepperoni pizza which contains another pepperoni
> pizza. seriously it is a pepperoni pizza which has another pepperoni
> pizza listed as one of its ingredients. it is the world's only
> recursive pizza. or, if you want the best pizza in Chicago, which in
> other words means the best pizza on earth, and you don't mind visiting
> a bad neighborhood, go to Medici's near the University of Chicago.
> this pizza is so good that living your entire life without ever
> tasting it is like living your entire life without ever having an
> orgasm. and I don't mean an "oh I think I came" orgasm. I mean a
> seeing purple spots and swearing in Latin orgasm. it's GOOD. seriously
> I feel sorry for anyone who's never had real Chicago pizza. anyway
> when I say "bad neighborhood" I don't mean you'll actually get shot at
> or anything, but the pizza is so good that if you had to risk getting
> shot at just to taste it, it would be worth it.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

LOL I have to say, I got a little confused about this last year.  I
actually go to Mills, where  a lot of the electronic music from the
70s and 80s was coming from (Maggi Payne and Fred Frith are teachers
there... if that rings a bell) anyway, I signed up for the electronic
music course thinking, alright, I'll finally learn to use cakewalk or
finalscratch.... HAHA nope not quite the same thing :)  We basically
ended up doing our entire class on the Moog.  Which is incredible ....
the only thing that sucked about it was that the oscillators were too
unstable to keep any sort of beat and so making techno like we love it
was pretty out of the question.  Cool stuff, though.  Definately be
worth checking out the festival
sabra

On Sun, 1 Aug 2004 22:51:45 -0700 (PDT), dr_XeNo <dr_xeno@pacbell.net> wrote:
> Hi there, all
> 
>    Cheers to that, Philip...there's more out there than can be
> known...which is a good thing, I think.  Thank you for the
> background on some of these artists.  Take care...
> 
> 
> 
> --- Philip Sherburne <psherburne@mindspring.com> wrote:
> > The SFEMF is much more of an academic computer-music festival,
> > with strong
> > ties to the electronic-music program at Mills College.
> >
> > I don't know all the artists in this year's lineup, but Ramon
> > Sender is a
> > Bay Area legend as one of the founders of the SF Tape Music
> > Center with
> > Morton Subotnick (computer music pioneer) and, I think,
> > Pauline Oliveros,
> > back in the late 60s. Joan Jeanrenaud was cellist in the
> > Kronos Quartet for
> > 20 years. Ikue Mori was in the seminal no wave group DNA in
> > the late 70s,
> > alongside Arto Lindsay, and went on to do extremely
> > experimental drum
> > machine recordings on John Zorn's label. Wobbly is a local
> > computer musician
> > who's released some really interesting things on Kid606's
> > Tigerbeat6 label,
> > including one disc entirely made up of samples sourced from
> > KMEL and other
> > commercial R&B stations. Basically, it's in the tradition of
> > John Oswald's
> > Plunderphonics. And Keith Fullerton Whitman is best known as
> > Hrvatski, and
> > he's recorded crazy breakcore mayhem for a number of labels,
> > including (I
> > think) Planet Mu and Tigerbeat6.
> >
> > For what it's worth, I don't recognize most of the DJs whose
> > names I see on
> > the sfraves list. It's a big world out there and there are
> > lots of distinct
> > electronic music scenes... including plenty that have little
> > or no relation
> > to "raving," per se.
> >
> > Philip
> >
> >
> > ----
> >
> > philip sherburne
> > full sentences on demand
> >

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: tonight, throwdown.com; tomorrow, Hugger-Mugger

I smoked a bit too much last week and totally missed my monday night gig
from the red room at In House... sorry if any of y'all tuned in hoping
to hear me and saw Neon Leon on the decks ;)

Anyway, this week I'm back at it. 6-8pm PST, live on the interweb.
Throwdown.com has redesigned their site with frames, so now it's
impossible to link directly to the stream... but go here:

<http://www.throwdown.com/throwdown/live/live.asp>

And click on the "LISTEN NOW" link on the left, under the red room logo.

And tomorrow night, I'll be making my first appearance at Hugger-Mugger,
on its first night as a new Tuesday weekly (that's right: no more third
Saturdays conflicting with undergrounds!). Juan Segovia and Li Sasaki
provide the residential beats.

Hugger-Mugger takes place from 9ish - 2am at Lit, on 6th at Mission in
San Francisco. Stop by and say hi, we don't bite.

Cornflakes,

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

yeah, there's actually a number of methods developed for emulating the
irregular auto-detuning of synths like that. but it's difficult to
imagine creating an entire track on just one machine, especially the
Moog.

I have mixed feelings about this. I think an overly academic focus is
kind of iffy, but on the other hand, holy shit, look at this:

MUS 252
Seminar in Electronic Music Performance ( 1 )
Real-time performance systems, concert audio, and interactive
electronics: sound diffusion, MIDI controllers, analog-to-digital
interfaces, electronic instrument building, interactive sound
installations, composition languages, and computer music networks.
Presentation and discussion of student works of electronic music;
development of experimental compositional strategies made possible by
electronic technology. Spring

Instructor(s): Chris Brown
Limit 15 students.
Open to graduate students only.


from the Mills course catalog. that's awesome! I want to go to Mills now.


Giles/Soundwave

> > incredible ....  the only thing that sucked about it was that the
> > oscillators were too unstable to keep any sort of beat and so making
> > techno like we love it was pretty out of the question.

> on the sounds of randomly detuned oscillators... :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

Well, music inherently requires a blend of art and math, and i think
whichever way you tend to think (whether you consider yourself more
art person than math person) will naturally lead you to focus on a
related area.  But you are constantly using them both with music...
it's kinda like wondering which foot is leading the other, or whether
this is a question of genetics or exposure, they both influence each
other, and it's kindan impossible to seperate.  However, I will say
that in my class, about a third of the women seemed to be 'math
people' , that is their compositions were very orderly and patterned,
and a third were very loose, more 'artistic'  ... but a lot of them
were in the middle.  There was only one guy in the class and his stuff
was just wierd.  Cool, but friggin strange.

>  >

>  > Seminar in Electronic Music Performance ( 1 )
>  > Real-time performance systems, concert audio, and interactive
>  > electronics: sound diffusion, MIDI controllers, analog-to-digital
>  > interfaces, electronic instrument building, interactive sound
>  > installations, composition languages, and computer music networks.
>  > Presentation and discussion of student works of electronic music;
>  > development of experimental compositional strategies made possible by
>  > electronic technology. Spring

>  > Instructor(s): Chris Brown

>  > Open to graduate students only.

From sfraves-return-114318-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Aug 02 20:24:38 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114318-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 50942 invoked by uid 1103); 2 Aug 2004 20:24:37 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 50928 invoked from network); 2 Aug 2004 20:24:37 -0000
X-Authentication-Warning: freke.odin.pdx.edu: srg owned process doing -bs
Date: Mon, 2 Aug 2004 13:24:33 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sean G <srg@pdx.edu>
X-X-Sender: srg@freke.odin.pdx.edu
To: partykids <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0408021323450.27284-100000@freke.odin.pdx.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] re: Telic

Telic. Telic telic telic.

I was kickin it at my girl's work last week and this azn kid I recognized
from some function or another strolled in. Began chattering -- animated,
to say the least -- about raves. I was talking shit about something, being
a negative little fuck, and he started talking about the dungeon. "It the
best because it never get busted!"

What's the exchange rate on freedom, anyway?

I think everyone had the same experience with security that night. And
it's funny, because... what exactly is the fucking point, aside from
making us feel violated? Maybe pretending to placate the cops, so paranoid
promoters feel safe about their profits in the face of equipment seizure
and the rave act? My first comment to the girl on door, upon getting
through the thigh-pawing gauntlet (I have new, strange stirrings in my
loins whenever I see a brinks truck now):

"Crazy security. I feel like I'm going into jail."
"You want to be safe, don't you?"
"I guess..."

I think the fault lies within the nuskool kids' desire to just have a safe
place to roll, get their massage on, and bounce around for a few hours.
They are the majority, and they are totally willing (being used to it) to
be treated this way. The entire ethos surrounding raves -- the allure of,
you know, being up past your bedtime and breakin da law seems to be gone.
Might as well start holding 'electronic music dance events' at the
Fillmore.

I dunno. Security didn't seem to do much. I felt like if I yawned for too
long, a passerby might hurl a handful of pills down my throat -- not that
those little buggers need any help getting down there. Security didn't
stop the dozen or so E dealers, did they? What exactly were they trying to
protect us from? Bioweapon attacks against frankie bones? Clockwork orange
rejects with straightrazors concealed in the soles of their shoes?

Where the fuck is the next big thing, already? Where are the kids pushing
the envelope and innovating? Where's the next crazy eye-opening drug? Why
aren't the latest wave of potential brilliant youngins out till 7am
thrashing to terrible, hypnotic beats that totally blow your mind? These
ain't ravers. They're just consumers.

For christ sakes. If raves (as people keep telling me) are dead... where
the fuck is the new wave? It seems my options when I go out are:

 - Candy party. Annoying e-tards. Bad environment to do anything but eat
lots of drugs, and not the best conditions to do drugs in anyway, given
the atmosphere's penchant for vicious fixer/leg-breaker security guards
and random thugz.

 - Old-skool 'rave' that I have to network for 3 days to find out about,
only to get there and find everyone sittin around talking shit and
drama-whoring. Get ugly looks if I happen to have a couple plastic beads
on my wrist. Smoke a blunt and pass out.

 - Trendy breaks/deep house 'underground' (ie club kids in a warehouse)
where I feel like I'm on the set of Party Monster II. Lots of people in
hideous post-punkrock attire trying to convince themselves how hip they
are. Swingers on eezy and people chasing the dragon in the corner. Good
place to pick up syphilis.

 - Go to a club. Get depressed over the meat market. Begin drinking. Blow
80 dollars on watered down drinks. Go outside, scrounge for empty 40s,
hurl them at cop cars. Flee through the mission. (Hey, clubs are pretty
fun)

You guys see what I mean? Where the fuck is the action?

Report your neighbors,

Sean


---
Griffin
Department of Disinformation

http://www.DefSF.com - 97.4% techno

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

At 12:22 AM 8/2/2004, O§by Jamz wrote:


>I got 2 TELIC...  OK.. Security basically RAPED me (in a matter of 
>speaking).. not only did they do the full body search thingie.. but they 
>checked everything everything everything...  the inside of my notebooks 
>night have acid sheets in them... oh yeah.. my homeowrk might possibly 
>ehatever the the fuck man...  my back pack was throughly ramsacked...my 
>walkman sould contained pills side the motor..let's pull that apart...
>
>the security gaurd who searched my body actually cupped my balls through 
>my pants & pressed hard if i moved... wouldn't that count as like sexual 
>harassment or something???
>
>My wallet chain(s) had 2 consficated & held 'til the end of the party.. 
>understandable... but when U tell me that I have 2 put eveerything in my 
>car & I tell U that I don't hagve a car... i (in a matter of speaking) 
>took bart here from school & i don't have a car, sorry..  then I don't 
>need a security gaurd fuckin' yelling @ me LITERALLY telling me I'm stupid 
>then 4 having all my stuff w/ me & havin'g no place 2 put it & insulting 
>me 4 being @ the party.. then what's up w/ that man???
>

I think you should feel violated, Osby.  I've seen ads for the Telic 
parties.  The impression they give is that:  "...we are bring back that old 
love and vibe from back in the early days of raves."

For those who did not experience the anarchic, free-spirited days of raving 
this may work.  But in reality, there was no "security" at these 
events;  no pat down;  no confiscation of personal property.  These actions 
would be antithetical to the whole concept of a "temporary autonomous 
zone."  Now we have parties where one is required to surrender personal 
freedoms for safety.  Kinda like a microcosm of the whole of society these 
days, eh?

Intrusive security has nothing to do with "raving."  When promoters throw 
parties like these where you are required to endure personal humiliation to 
enter they should at least disclose this after the "love and vibe" headers 
in their advertising.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

the ones who stood out to me were the ones who could use both... the
ones who had incredible artistic vision but also were anal retentive
enough to record the track 8 times until they had it just right.  :) 
for me that was always the problem... i'm plenty creative but not too
patient.   So my stuff was always kind of messy.  But then there was
this girl, a math major, and she would make these intricate, rythmic
pieces that just.,... lacked soul or something... even though she'd
been in the studio for hours.  So, yeah, it can be kind of a toss-up,
and you'd find great pieces all over the place from one week to the
next.

On Mon, 02 Aug 2004 13:31:09 -0700, Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com> wrote:

> split between left and right brained girls.. or does it fall to one or the

> 
> 
> 
> 
> SFR: Ranger
> Santa Cruz
> plurranger@hotmail.com
> Who knows where the night leads
> It's dark and no one can see
> 
> From: Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com>
> To: Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com>
> CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??
> Date: Mon, 2 Aug 2004 12:44:23 -0700
> 
> Well, music inherently requires a blend of art and math, and i think
> whichever way you tend to think (whether you consider yourself more
> art person than math person) will naturally lead you to focus on a
> related area.  But you are constantly using them both with music...
> it's kinda like wondering which foot is leading the other, or whether
> this is a question of genetics or exposure, they both influence each
> other, and it's kindan impossible to seperate.  However, I will say
> that in my class, about a third of the women seemed to be 'math
> people' , that is their compositions were very orderly and patterned,
> and a third were very loose, more 'artistic'  ... but a lot of them
> were in the middle.  There was only one guy in the class and his stuff
> was just wierd.  Cool, but friggin strange.
> 
> On Mon, 02 Aug 2004 12:10:54 -0700, Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com> wrote:

Subject: Re: [sfraves] re: Telic

--=====================_11400983==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 01:24 PM 8/2/2004, Sean G wrote:
>Telic. Telic telic telic.
>
>I was kickin it at my girl's work last week and this azn kid I recognized
>from some function or another strolled in. Began chattering -- animated,
>to say the least -- about raves. I was talking shit about something, being
>a negative little fuck, and he started talking about the dungeon. "It the
>best because it never get busted!"
>
>What's the exchange rate on freedom, anyway?

Ask those around you, Sean.  Seems people are willing to give away freedom 
for practically nothing these days.


>"Crazy security. I feel like I'm going into jail."
>"You want to be safe, don't you?"
>"I guess..."

Those who trade safety for security end up with neither.


>Where the fuck is the next big thing, already? Where are the kids pushing
>the envelope and innovating? Where's the next crazy eye-opening drug? Why
>aren't the latest wave of potential brilliant youngins out till 7am
>thrashing to terrible, hypnotic beats that totally blow your mind? These
>ain't ravers. They're just consumers.

It was exactly this level of dissatisfaction that led to raves in the first 
place.  You are not alone.  I go to very few parties these days, and I have 
to have much assurance that I will be treated with respect and love at any 
event I do attend.

Increasing numbers of dancers will become bored with the current offerings 
(I see this happening) and more folks will go back to the DIY ethic.  I 
truly wish that Moksha could do more parties;  we've been on the "safe and 
happy" venue search lately.  But many many more of us, I think, need to be 
more involved in the art of party giving.

Pain and unhappiness fuels change.  Dancers get pissed off enough things 
will move in a better direction.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_11400983==.ALT--

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 78108 invoked from network); 2 Aug 2004 21:35:03 -0000
Message-ID: <20040802213500.84098.qmail@web50303.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 2 Aug 2004 14:35:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Monikat <technoslut303@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] miss kittin...

Miss Kittin rocked!  that was absolutely the best set
i've heard all year, and i'm including everything i
heard at sonar and movement (detroit) in the running. 
damn!  she mixed styles brilliantly, flawlessly. 
mills, hawtin, pump up the jam, green velvet, dj rush,
hip hop, her own stuff - live, madonna, work it
motherfucker, new order... plus lots more i can't
remember off the top of my head or couldn't trainspot
because i was too tranced out dancing.  the crowd was
pretty good, too - actually a mix of queer and
straight, too.  and once the drinkers left after 2, it
was even better.  it was amazing.  

matthew dear was, uh, kind of pretentious and boring,
imho.  he did a set of playing live and singing w/
another performer, and while some of his beats were
good, i just couldn't get into it.  wasn't terribly
into the earlier performers, either.  but that's ok,
cuz i needed all my energy to dance to miss kittin!  
fuck yeah! i haven't had a club night like that in SF
since hawtin last year.  i hope there's more to come. 


monikat

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [NRR] How Long Does Magic Mushrooms Stye In Your System For???

Actually, I used to work for a medical lab and we did do urine tests for
shrooms.  When I started at the lab in 97 they were unable to test, but
about 6 months in for some unknown reason one of the older lab techs
came and told my friend and I that they just started testing for
shrooms.  It felt kinda weird with him singling us out because he knew
we went to raves but at that time of my life I was sober due to random
drug tests.  Although I was a little ticked to find out that I could've
gotten away with it.  They're not tested in a normal screen unless they
have reason to test for it specifically.

>From Erowid:
Tested for in Standard Drug Tests? 	NO
Tested for in Extended Drug Tests? 	Sometimes
Possible to test for? 	YES
Detection Period in Urine 	1-3 days

-Rayn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

but how would you control for socializing factors?

the intersection of music and the mind is potentially very
interesting. for literally years I wanted to do a hypnosis CD called
"how to dream techno." it would put the user in a trance and have them
hallucinate the greatest music they ever heard. in theory it should be
easy to do but in practice I never got around to it. I even got a
bunch of training in hypnosis but to do something like that you really
need to have a lot of practical real-world experience. I finally told
a hypnotist about it, literally last night, and she got back to me
today and told me she would start working on it before September. I
was like woot! anyway...I think it'd be really interesting if somebody
could find out how much of the emotional and physical power of music
is culturally conditioned and how much of it built-in. as in, is there
some kind of musical equivalent to Chomsky's linguistic structures?



On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 14:00:32 -0700, Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com> wrote:
> i think it would be interesting to do a study on this...  you could
> see which musical tones and patterns emerged in each group, see if
> they  have any association at all...
> sorry,.... you asked the wrong  (or the right?) question to a psych
> major raver :P
> 
> On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 13:58:03 -0700, Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com> wrote:
> > the ones who stood out to me were the ones who could use both... the
> > ones who had incredible artistic vision but also were anal retentive
> > enough to record the track 8 times until they had it just right.  :)
> > for me that was always the problem... i'm plenty creative but not too
> > patient.   So my stuff was always kind of messy.  But then there was
> > this girl, a math major, and she would make these intricate, rythmic
> > pieces that just.,... lacked soul or something... even though she'd
> > been in the studio for hours.  So, yeah, it can be kind of a toss-up,
> > and you'd find great pieces all over the place from one week to the
> > next.
> >
> >
> >

Rayn McCormick <rayn@anubismedia.net> wrote:
Actually, I used to work for a medical lab and we did do urine tests for
shrooms. When I started at the lab in 97 they were unable to test, but
about 6 months in for some unknown reason one of the older lab techs
came and told my friend and I that they just started testing for
shrooms. It felt kinda weird with him singling us out because he knew
we went to raves but at that time of my life I was sober due to random
drug tests. Although I was a little ticked to find out that I could've
gotten away with it. They're not tested in a normal screen unless they
have reason to test for it specifically.

>From Erowid:
Tested for in Standard Drug Tests? NO
Tested for in Extended Drug Tests? Sometimes
Possible to test for? YES
Detection Period in Urine 1-3 days

-Rayn

Man thats some funny ass shit!

Was security over board... well that was the hardest i have been searched 
ever!  i congratulated the security guard for being the first person ever to 
open my back left butt pocket, since in the 4 years i have had these shorts 
i don't believe i have ever used it (not very convinient of a pocket really) 
i wasn't joking and he didn't find it very funny.  It seemed like they 
weren't looking for weapons but more for drugs. i mean come on now, a simple 
pat over my butt pocket would suffice but actually undoing the velcro and 
pulling the pocket out might have been a little too far.

but did it affect my time.  mmm... no.  why hold onto things like that. i 
understand what your saying apollo, but if thats the way the run their venue 
thats the way the do it.  but other then that I had a blast!  took me 5 
years back at least.  but then again i missed all the NRG stuff, so it was 
Techno, progressive trance  and then breaks for me.  so i really enjoyed it. 
  it was great to hear Techno really loud in a wherehouse and the bpm was 
just right for me.  had to be about 138 or so.  but it was intense and 
driving. yummy!  i had a blast. it was great to be dancing to some good 
tunes in a large wherehouse, seemed proper to me.  but i got there late. 
Frankie was awesome.  nice to hear Todd Prophet playin as well. Haven't seen 
him in a couple of years.  good stuff!

Venue: Thumbs Up
Security: Thumbs Down
Party: Thumbs Up
Music: Thumbs Up
Overall Experience: Thumbs Up

It was really nice to be partying in a large wherehouse with some Techno. 
For a moment i thought it was 97 again.





RE:

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For christ sakes. If raves (as people keep telling me) are dead... where
the fuck is the new wave? It seems my options when I go out are:

- Candy party. Annoying e-tards. Bad environment to do anything but eat
lots of drugs, and not the best conditions to do drugs in anyway, given
the atmosphere's penchant for vicious fixer/leg-breaker security guards
and random thugz.

- Old-skool 'rave' that I have to network for 3 days to find out about,
only to get there and find everyone sittin around talking shit and
drama-whoring. Get ugly looks if I happen to have a couple plastic beads
on my wrist. Smoke a blunt and pass out.

- Trendy breaks/deep house 'underground' (ie club kids in a warehouse)
where I feel like I'm on the set of Party Monster II. Lots of people in
hideous post-punkrock attire trying to convince themselves how hip they
are. Swingers on eezy and people chasing the dragon in the corner. Good
place to pick up syphilis.

- Go to a club. Get depressed over the meat market. Begin drinking. Blow
80 dollars on watered down drinks. Go outside, scrounge for empty 40s,
hurl them at cop cars. Flee through the mission. (Hey, clubs are pretty
fun)

You guys see what I mean? Where the fuck is the action?

Report your neighbors,

Sean

Money. http://special.msn.com/money/0407debt.armx

References: <BAY16-F37SJBBAsZ8zi00073a90@hotmail.com> <c045cd5e04080213587954ba6d@mail.gmail.com> <c045cd5e0408021400f2d52e0@mail.gmail.com> <4688f3110408021651657c5a57@mail.gmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

yeah for sure... I still think that a lot of the reason we love techno
is because our ancestors have been using ritualistic drumming and
psychedellics to attain other levels of consciousness for so many
years that, by now,  it touches something primal in us... but i can
never be sure that we didn't just learn it from our parents (in one
form or another).  But that's always the problem... how to control fpr
social factors?  You can't really get twins separated at birth, and
look at their differences and similarities, because music is so widely
listened to, one would have to grow up in a vacuum to escape it's
influence, and then they'd be all fucked up anyway so you'd have to
throw out the data :)
On a random note, another interesting aspect to study would be how
someone's self perception correllates with the music they like, say,
'I see myself as a math person, and I like trance', versus
correllating their actual thinking methods (this can differ...i guess
they have some tests that can objectively tell you which side of the
brain you're using or whatever, versus how you percieve yourself)
because i bet that when you're actively thinking "I'm a such'and
such', your answer will be different.  You know, like when your
grandma asks you what I'm listening to lately, the brazilian singer
comes to mind first, whereas if one of my peeps asks me, I'll think of
the dj shadow album i just ripped.  I think a test like that is one
way to help figure out the cultural bias...

On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 16:51:30 -0700, DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote:
> but how would you control for socializing factors?
> 
> the intersection of music and the mind is potentially very
> interesting. for literally years I wanted to do a hypnosis CD called
> "how to dream techno." it would put the user in a trance and have them
> hallucinate the greatest music they ever heard. in theory it should be
> easy to do but in practice I never got around to it. I even got a
> bunch of training in hypnosis but to do something like that you really
> need to have a lot of practical real-world experience. I finally told
> a hypnotist about it, literally last night, and she got back to me
> today and told me she would start working on it before September. I
> was like woot! anyway...I think it'd be really interesting if somebody
> could find out how much of the emotional and physical power of music
> is culturally conditioned and how much of it built-in. as in, is there
> some kind of musical equivalent to Chomsky's linguistic structures?
> 
> 
> 
> 
> On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 14:00:32 -0700, Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com> wrote:
> > i think it would be interesting to do a study on this...  you could
> > see which musical tones and patterns emerged in each group, see if
> > they  have any association at all...
> > sorry,.... you asked the wrong  (or the right?) question to a psych
> > major raver :P
> >
> > On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 13:58:03 -0700, Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com> wrote:
> > > the ones who stood out to me were the ones who could use both... the
> > > ones who had incredible artistic vision but also were anal retentive
> > > enough to record the track 8 times until they had it just right.  :)
> > > for me that was always the problem... i'm plenty creative but not too
> > > patient.   So my stuff was always kind of messy.  But then there was
> > > this girl, a math major, and she would make these intricate, rythmic
> > > pieces that just.,... lacked soul or something... even though she'd
> > > been in the studio for hours.  So, yeah, it can be kind of a toss-up,
> > > and you'd find great pieces all over the place from one week to the
> > > next.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > On Mon, 02 Aug 2004 13:31:09 -0700, Ranger - <plurranger@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > > > Wow.. that sounds like a split right down the middle (of the girls) anyway..
> > > > so would you say that the successfull projects or most talented are also
> > > > split between left and right brained girls.. or does it fall to one or the
> > > > other sides? I mean.. when you think back on your classmates.. who really
> > > > stood out as talented.. and do you think they were critical thinkers or

> > > > Well, music inherently requires a blend of art and math, and i think
> > > > whichever way you tend to think (whether you consider yourself more
> > > > art person than math person) will naturally lead you to focus on a
> > > > related area.  But you are constantly using them both with music...
> > > > it's kinda like wondering which foot is leading the other, or whether
> > > > this is a question of genetics or exposure, they both influence each
> > > > other, and it's kindan impossible to seperate.  However, I will say
> > > > that in my class, about a third of the women seemed to be 'math
> > > > people' , that is their compositions were very orderly and patterned,
> > > > and a third were very loose, more 'artistic'  ... but a lot of them
> > > > were in the middle.  There was only one guy in the class and his stuff
> > > > was just wierd.  Cool, but friggin strange.
> > > >

> > > >  >  > Seminar in Electronic Music Performance ( 1 )

> > > >  >  > electronics: sound diffusion, MIDI controllers, analog-to-digital
> > > >  >  > interfaces, electronic instrument building, interactive sound
> > > >  >  > installations, composition languages, and computer music networks.
> > > >  >  > Presentation and discussion of student works of electronic music;
> > > >  >  > development of experimental compositional strategies made possible by
> > > >  >  > electronic technology. Spring
> > > >  >  >

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

Actually there are many many books written about the
social and psychological impacts of music.  An
aquaintance of mine William Benzon wrote one recently
called Beethoven's Anvil in which he conjectures that
music creates a shared brain state among a group of
people.  FWIW I talked to him a bit about raves and
electronic music while he was finishing it.  See
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/tg/detail/-/0465015441/qid=1091515636/sr=8-2/ref=sr_8_xs_ap_i2_xgl14/104-3669827-5895930?v=glance&s=books&n=507846
 

FWIW William is a jazz musician so he's coming from
that perspective.

You might also want to check out Jardain's book
*Music, The Brain, And Ecstasy : How Music Captures
Our Imagination* but be forewarned its mostly about
the brain and is focused on classical music.   

And then there's this recent conference:
http://www.wesleyan.edu/music/sacredspace/about.html

FWIW there are lots of books out there about the
cultural impacts and importance of electronic dance
music too.  While there are several worth reading, I
haven't been hugely impressed with any of them
frankly.

Its been interesting to watch rave culture evolve over
the past 10 years (I went to my first in late 1993 or
early 1994 gasp!) but its a shame that some of this
sort of knowledge seems to have left the scene.  Its
more about getting laid than getting wisdom today.  I
know there are still a few promoters (some of whom are
on this list) that understand these ideas and are
trying to put them to use so please turn the
flamethrowers OFF.

Best,

Peter

--- Sabra Melamed <yosabra@gmail.com> wrote:

> yeah for sure... I still think that a lot of the
> reason we love techno
> is because our ancestors have been using ritualistic
> drumming and
> psychedellics to attain other levels of
> consciousness for so many
> years that, by now,  it touches something primal in
> us... but i can
> never be sure that we didn't just learn it from our
> parents (in one
> form or another).  But that's always the problem...
> how to control fpr
> social factors?  You can't really get twins
> separated at birth, and
> look at their differences and similarities, because
> music is so widely
> listened to, one would have to grow up in a vacuum
> to escape it's
> influence, and then they'd be all fucked up anyway
> so you'd have to
> throw out the data :)
> On a random note, another interesting aspect to
> study would be how
> someone's self perception correllates with the music
> they like, say,
> 'I see myself as a math person, and I like trance',
> versus
> correllating their actual thinking methods (this can
> differ...i guess
> they have some tests that can objectively tell you
> which side of the
> brain you're using or whatever, versus how you
> percieve yourself)
> because i bet that when you're actively thinking
> "I'm a such'and
> such', your answer will be different.  You know,
> like when your
> grandma asks you what I'm listening to lately, the
> brazilian singer
> comes to mind first, whereas if one of my peeps asks
> me, I'll think of
> the dj shadow album i just ripped.  I think a test
> like that is one
> way to help figure out the cultural bias...
> 
> On Mon, 2 Aug 2004 16:51:30 -0700, DJ Soundwave
> <dj.soundwave@gmail.com> wrote:
> > but how would you control for socializing factors?
> > 
> > the intersection of music and the mind is
> potentially very
> > interesting. for literally years I wanted to do a
> hypnosis CD called
> > "how to dream techno." it would put the user in a
> trance and have them
> > hallucinate the greatest music they ever heard. in
> theory it should be
> > easy to do but in practice I never got around to
> it. I even got a
> > bunch of training in hypnosis but to do something
> like that you really
> > need to have a lot of practical real-world
> experience. I finally told
> > a hypnotist about it, literally last night, and
> she got back to me
> > today and told me she would start working on it
> before September. I
> > was like woot! anyway...I think it'd be really
> interesting if somebody
> > could find out how much of the emotional and
> physical power of music
> > is culturally conditioned and how much of it
> built-in. as in, is there
> > some kind of musical equivalent to Chomsky's
> linguistic structures?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Review of Astral Projection  (7/31 at 550)

I think a ton of folk on this list were at the FnF campout so I'll share my
thoughts but I'm not too good at the party reviews.  Plus I played upstairs
that night and I'm a Thump boy so my views are kinda biased.  :)  I'm a much
bigger fan of Thump at 550 than at DNA in general, I think it fits their
vibe and variety of music they're into.

The crowd Saturday was a mix of regulars and random folk, but I generally
got really good vibes from everyone, seemed to be a happy atmosphere.  The
party didn't really fill in until 1, but the main room stayed packed until I
left at 5, and Astral Projection definitely rocked it, people were letting
go and gettin down.

The breaks room cleared out kinda early but the house room kept good energy
for most of the night (that's where I spent most of my time).  Only heard
the Ambient Mafia outside right towards the end, but when I walked out they
were jamming Brass Monkey and singing along so I think they had fun.

On the whole I had a much better time than the last few times I went to the
DNA for their parties there, everyone was smiles and no attitude.  I believe
their 5 year is coming up soon, should be off the hook!

-Andrew

>
>I think you should feel violated, Osby.  I've seen ads for the Telic 
>parties.  The impression they give is that:  "...we are bring back that old 
>love and vibe from back in the early days of raves."
>
>For those who did not experience the anarchic, free-spirited days of raving 
>this may work.  But in reality, there was no "security" at these events;  
>no pat down;  no confiscation of personal property.  These actions would be 
>antithetical to the whole concept of a "temporary autonomous zone."  Now we 
>have parties where one is required to surrender personal freedoms for 
>safety.  Kinda like a microcosm of the whole of society these days, eh?
>
>Intrusive security has nothing to do with "raving."  When promoters throw 
>parties like these where you are required to endure personal humiliation to 
>enter they should at least disclose this after the "love and vibe" headers 
>in their advertising.
>
>Love,
>
>Apollo

>corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
>will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong

>aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
>-Abraham Lincoln

>rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
>visible."
>-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
>life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
>beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
>party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to 
>that..."
>-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Rayn McCormick <rayn@anubismedia.net> wrote:Actually, I used to work for a medical lab and we did do urine tests for
shrooms. When I started at the lab in 97 they were unable to test, but
about 6 months in for some unknown reason one of the older lab techs
came and told my friend and I that they just started testing for
shrooms. It felt kinda weird with him singling us out because he knew
we went to raves but at that time of my life I was sober due to random
drug tests. Although I was a little ticked to find out that I could've
gotten away with it. They're not tested in a normal screen unless they
have reason to test for it specifically.

>From Erowid:
Tested for in Standard Drug Tests? NO
Tested for in Extended Drug Tests? Sometimes
Possible to test for? YES
Detection Period in Urine 1-3 days

kids find out. Then the security need can be eliminated.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  FARLEY JACKMASTER FUNK SATURDAY

--=====================_1232762==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

SATURDAY, Aug 7th

Club 6 presents:

LEGENDS OF HOUSE 13.0: FARLEY JACKMASTER FUNK

When a new style of music first cracks the pop charts, the hit is usually a 
deliberate crossover by an artist having little to do with the music's 
original pioneers. The first house single to reach the charts, however, was 
recorded by seminal Chicago DJ and producer, Farley Jackmaster Funk. His 
cover of Isaac Hayes' "Love Can't Turn Around" made the Top Ten in mid-1986 
? ironically, not in his home country but in the U.K. ? at the same time 
that he was one of the biggest names in Chicago house. Born in 1962, Farley 
began DJing while still a teenager.

He first made his name in 1981, broadcasting on Chicago's WBMX-FM with 
Ralphi "The Razz" Rosario, Kenny "Jammin" Jason, Mickey "Mixin" Oliver and 
Scott "Smokin" Seals as the Hot Mix 5 ? the legendary DJ team which broke 
house music for a wider Chicago audience. Farley also appeared at the 
legendary Warehouse club (mixing alongside Frankie Knuckles ) and then 
began a residency at the Playground (later the Candy Store) which set in 
stone his reputation as one of the city's top DJs.

Downstairs:
Jesse Saunders (the orginator of house, justsayagency)

Upstairs:
Dusty Crates (electric soul)

PRICE: $10 b4 11pm,
$15 after
TIME: 10pm-4am
MUSIC: House & Soul





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SF Electronic Music Festival??

Yea - on the muinimal techno tip, I saw Jeff Mills @ Twilo a number of years
back (4 or 5?), and man...what a set. Most of what I have ever heard from
him as far as live sets never impressed me, and to be quite honest, for the
1st hour of his set at Twilo, I wanted to kill him. A bass kick ALONE for
like 20 minutes is NOT cool. However - after he started building it, geezus
christ - it sucked you in and just tweeked yer melon like nothing else.

Too bad most techno DJ's can't do anything remotely close to that. I know
I'll get the massive flaming for this - but I seriously think most techno
DJ's I have ever heard couldn't understand the concept of beatmatching,
phrasing, or emotion through music to save their lives. If it's gonna
pound - give it flavor, if it's gonna throb, give it feeling. Make it
fucking GO SOMEWHERE....

M-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] techno DJs

Well - let's put it this way, since a lot of techno is so minimal in
samples/synths, etc., it's a LOT more noticeable. For instance, I can't tell
you how many times i have heard a techno DJ rockin' it out, and maybe it's
just that they have REALLY shitty track selection, but it sounds like a
non-stop trainwreck. With genres like house, as long as you stay away from
vocals, you can fudge your way through a lot better, and unless you really
ARE trainwrecking, it's not so bad. But when all you have to hear are beats,
man there better be some fucking coherency to it....

M-

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 03 Aug 2004 19:05:30.0860 (UTC) FILETIME=[D88B32C0:01C4798C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] techno DJs

Yes, I know what I am talking about, thank you very little.

I have heard enough DJ's PERIOD to know the difference between someone who
knows what they are doing at ALL, as opposed to a person who thinks that the
awful racket they are making on the decks is worthwhile "music".

You can think you're the coolest techno DJ on the block, but if you can't
put the bleeps and clicks together in any remotely listenable way, then
you're just making noise.

I am more specifically targeting "minimal" techno, or some of the glitchier
hard/german style techno when I say this (of course, I am not very versed as
far as subgenres of techno, so I am being very general here). The "housier
stuff" seems to not suck as bad. Or rather, the DJ's that spin it seem to
work it better.

I could say the same about the glitchier side of breaks, which is my
personal favorite genre. It seems the more experimental the sound (for lack
of a better term), the worse the DJ. They think they are being artsy and
creative, but really, it just sounds like ass.

Now this is *not* a constant. I have heard some folks rock the holy hell out
of the minimal, glitchy or experimental styles of EDM - but it's MUCH fewer
and farther between.

Just an observation. I am always open to be proven wrong in my opinions!

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd question

Hydrocodone is the main active ingredient in Vicodin. It also contains
acetaminophen, aka Tylenol. Acetaminophen happens to be pretty toxic for
your liver in high doses. So people who abuse Vicodin are harming
themselves in more than one way.


On Tue, 3 Aug 2004, Jonas R. wrote:

> http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/122839p-110349c.html

Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd question

Again talk to my ex.  She's currently taking vicodin,
soma, and fiorecet on top of the 4 or 5 psychiatric
medications she's required to take all prescribed by
supposedly legitimate doctors.  She says she no longer
"abuses" alcohol but that doesn't mean she's not
drinking at least as I interpret it. 

This is the thing about drugs people.  Some people can
handle them and some just can't.  The problem is that
you don't know which group you fall into until its too
late to stop.  In the case of my ex a family history
of alcohol abuse should have tipped us off to the
trouble ahead for her, but growing up in the seventies
in Berkeley nobody thought about the risks of doing
this sort of stuff.

Peter

From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: electrofunk138 <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>, Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>,
  "Jonas R." <djjonas@sf-vibe.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd question

Yup.  She's become quite frightening actually.  Last
time I saw her she couldn't remember what year we got
married or when she graduated from college.  Its a
very very sad situation especially as we have two
children.

I'm not a prude about this stuff, again growing up in
Berkeley and all, but my experience with her problems
has made me question a lot of things that I thought
about these sorts of substances.  I'm not talking
about social drinking or smoking here, or probably
even certain ritual uses of psychedelic substances,
although those things clearly have consequences also.

Think before you put a chemical into your body.  Will
you be a better person afterwards or are you simply
covering up problems you don't want to face?  Try
meditation and dancing without chemicals and you might
find that its OK actually.  Again not to preach to
anyone or be a prude about it.  

Its just something worth thinking about...

peace,

peter

have a new one very soon, but until then, enjoy.
http://www.djcarceri.com/audio.html

4_10_04 Tracklisting: 
Morgan Geist - How Beep is Your Love [Environ] 
The Moderator - Sliding To Midnight [Down Low] 
Joey Beltram - The Vertical(Ghost in the Shell PS
Soundtrack) [Sony Japan]

Records]

Deluxe]

[Twisted Funk]

H. Brunner - Senses [KMS]

Gemini - Crossing Mars rmx [Planet e]

Thrill] 

And please come check out the Codec party @ RX on the
20th.
Mike

Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd question

Too many people just don't understand the concept of moderation, and they
often times find themselves in the middle of a nasty habit which either they
CAN'T break (due to lack of willpower), or they are in too much denial to
even notice it.

I am all for having a fun time, but keep it occasional, and special - not as
kith and kin to whatever you do.

M-

> Yup.  She's become quite frightening actually.  Last
> time I saw her she couldn't remember what year we got
> married or when she graduated from college.  Its a
> very very sad situation especially as we have two
> children.
>
> I'm not a prude about this stuff, again growing up in
> Berkeley and all, but my experience with her problems
> has made me question a lot of things that I thought
> about these sorts of substances.  I'm not talking
> about social drinking or smoking here, or probably
> even certain ritual uses of psychedelic substances,
> although those things clearly have consequences also.
>
> Think before you put a chemical into your body.  Will
> you be a better person afterwards or are you simply
> covering up problems you don't want to face?  Try
> meditation and dancing without chemicals and you might
> find that its OK actually.  Again not to preach to
> anyone or be a prude about it.
>
> Its just something worth thinking about...
>
> peace,

Actually, it's slightly offensive that Soma got used by a pharmaceutical 
company for a product - Soma is "the" name for the drug combo/plant/?
used, as mentioned in the Rig Vedas et al, for invoking/communicating with 
the gods - no one is quite sure what it is/was, but Amanita Muscaria
is the leading candidate.  but pharm companies are bastards, by and large....

so Aldous didn't make it up, but he knew what he was referencing

Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd question

Its a prescription drug, a muscle relaxant, and highly
addictive.  Its often prescribed in conjunction with
vicodin for back injuries which is how my ex started
getting it.  

Yes its also mentioned by Huxley in a Brave New World
as you, and yes it is also the name of a beverage
consumed in an ecstatic ritual described in the vedas.
 I have a recent article somewhere that says the soma
described in the vedas is not mushrooms however but a
brewed herb extract.  

The article describes the modern soma ritual, which
apparently is ongoing in India to this day, in very
great detail including the collection of the plants,
brewing of the drink, ritual serving and drinking
vessels, altar placements, and so forth.  I'm moving
so I don't know where that book is exactly but I'll
see if I can find it and post something if people are
interested.

Peter

At 03:17 PM 8/3/2004, Peter Rothman wrote:

>Yes its also mentioned by Huxley in a Brave New World
>as you, and yes it is also the name of a beverage
>consumed in an ecstatic ritual described in the vedas.
>  I have a recent article somewhere that says the soma
>described in the vedas is not mushrooms however but a
>brewed herb extract.

the definition apparently has morphed over time - the most
logical explanation is that "soma" has been used as the label
for many different things (as society, the rituals, etc changed)
sort of like "Ecstasy == MDMA" (which is hardly the case)

so nowadays it may be a brewed herb extract (one theory
had Ephedra as the plant... yeah, right....) but back in the day,
it could have been mushrooms, or bhang, or opium, or ....
Lots and lots or scholarly... arguments.... over it

>The article describes the modern soma ritual, which
>apparently is ongoing in India to this day, in very
>great detail including the collection of the plants,
>brewing of the drink, ritual serving and drinking
>vessels, altar placements, and so forth.  I'm moving
>so I don't know where that book is exactly but I'll
>see if I can find it and post something if people are
>interested.

I heard the modern day stuff is not psychoactive... so why do
they bother?  Because religion sucks

I would certainly be interested in the book/article.  thanks

doug

From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: Douglas Fraser <doug_fraser@microcinema.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] we were both right, Re: [sfraves] really wierd  question

Plate O' Shrimp

As it turns out it was on top of an open box.  The
book is actually a quarterly journal, *Social
Research*, and its the Fall 2001 issue devoted to
Altered States of Consciousness.  Volume 68, No. 3 if
anyone wants to find it.  The article is called "How a
Psychactive Substance Becomes a Ritual" and the author
is Frits Staal.  A quick perusal (and this article
isn't written for that mind you) and I think I was
wrong about his conclusions.  He discounts the ephedra
claim, reviews a few possible herbs (mountian rue),
and concludes it might have been mushrooms but not
fresh ones or perhaps more likely an unknown mountain
plant.  he reaches this conculsion because the vedas
describe soma coming only from specific places (i.e
high mountains) and the mushrooms grow in many other
locations.

Apparently the vedas and the soma ritual include
descriptions of soaking the soma stalks in water under
which condition they swell.  So if someone wants go
trekking around the moutnains of Iran (where the
origianl vedic peopel and soma came from) you might
after extensive collection and research find such a
plant.  

As you point out, and this article goes into detail
about it, the modern event is a religious ritual and
may not include consuming any psychoactive substance
whatsoever.  Staal's point is in fact to try
understand the underlying social process by which this
conversion from ritual use of a drug to simply a
religious ritual occurred.

With all of that said, as a practicing Buddhist, I
can't agree that religion "sucks" though YMMV ;)

best,

peter

At 03:50 PM 8/3/2004, Peter Rothman wrote:

>As you point out, and this article goes into detail
>about it, the modern event is a religious ritual and
>may not include consuming any psychoactive substance
>whatsoever.  Staal's point is in fact to try
>understand the underlying social process by which this
>conversion from ritual use of a drug to simply a
>religious ritual occurred.

oh that sound like an interesting article!

>With all of that said, as a practicing Buddhist, I
>can't agree that religion "sucks" though YMMV ;)

well, there's religion, Religion, and spirituality.
As a Gnostic (what, I'm not quite sure), I have little
patience for the stereotypical Religion (more properly viewed as
a vehicle for social control etc) which adheres to the tenets of
religion and claims to be spiritual...   It's the "dumbing down"
that I was referring to - if the Eucharist was actually psychoactive,
all those fundy "Christians" out there might actually turn into ones.

the Catholic Church is worried about all the New Age stuff (mostly
nonsense, but some useful stuff) precisely because it's, at the heart,
the resurgence of Gnosticism

and Buddhism is more a philosophy, is it not?  but over the years,
it has become more of a religion

doug
