Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

Ahh, you are still upset that we put Chris Jackson on from 4-6 at Paradigm
Shift.  We were hoping that putting him on last, plus serving breakfast at
4:30, would keep people at the party all night.  It didn't really work out
that way.  Few people seem willing to stay out past 3 these days. <sigh>
We were really grateful that Chris was willing to be a good sport and play
last, although I don't think we would do that again.  We are still a young
crew, and every party is a learning experience.

Plus, it's really hard to find DJs to play the dreaded first and last
slots. All the DJs that play at our parties are really talented and
experienced, and generally expect headlining slots.  It's really hard for
us to figure out who will play the unwanted slots. I don't think this
means we should find mediocre DJs to put on first and last.  Why not have
great techno DJs all night?

Perhaps I am wrong, perhaps I just don't get it.  (I'm trying to get it
though!)

Love Chelsea

X-OriginalArrivalTime: 03 Aug 2004 23:59:58.0803 (UTC) FILETIME=[FB755A30:01C479B5]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

I always wanted to have the lineup start at 11pm since no one shows up until
11/11:30pm anyway. But... Advertise the party as starting at 10pm and have
the first hour be open decks. That way someone that *wants* to spin early
gets to and the rest of the lineup that *you* want to spin gets to when
there is a good sized crowd around. As for closing time slots you're right
that people all seem to bail at 3am. My guess? A lot of us are drinkers now
since the majority of those attending parties are 21+ these days. Kids grew
up and are hitting the bottle rather than taking a hit. Toss in a bit of
complacency and stagnation and I think you have your answer.

:: r ::

> until
> 11/11:30pm anyway. But... Advertise the party as starting at 10pm and have

Ouch, thats a pretty harsh thing to say, i don't know you at all but come 
on, you can't say something like that then say thats constructive.  "you're 
scenesters who don't really *get* it." Thats just lame.

I don't want to start some big flame war here, but i think thats a bit rash, 
not everybody does parties the same, and you shouldn't shoot people down who 
are tryin something new, or taking risks.  you can't say its constructive at 
the end of a statement like that, the only reason youd do it is so you don't 
feel like a total asshole for saying stuff like that.  in turn it almost 
sounds like your the scenster tellin people where they are in the scene.

It sometimes seems like a lot of the people on this board straight shun you, 
if you haven't been playing techno for 15 years or somethin, and aren't best 
friends with everyone and go to all the "in" parties.

hence the reason i don't post very often.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

Upset?  No, I just questioned it.

Your lineup for that party at the Cell Space was atrociously concocted.  So
maybe Paradigm's Shift miscues were learning experiences, but to make the
same sorta mistakes twice kinda sucks.  :/  And while yes I am a bonafied
fan of Chris Jackson, my opinion is not solely based upon him.

Part of my misgivings with DEFSF also include how "Sean Ocean" portrayed
DEFSF as representative of the bay area techno scene on the So Cal Techno
list.  If you're still trying to figure techno out, why try to unify the
west coast techno scene?  Does the west end want to be unified in such a
way?  And by DEFSF?

Thankfully I don't think the droid.behavior folks bought it and I genuinely
hope they pass on your solicitation to participate in your Love Parade
float.  I wanted to send an e-mail to a few of them and tell them not to
base assumptions on the SF techno community (if one exists) on your crew or
your parties

But back to your lineup thing.  Yes, it's hard to choose who should play
when, but it looked like politics played too large a role in your most
recent efforts.  There didn't seem to be any sort of coherent flow.  No
organizational logic.

To imply I was butthurt that I had to wait until 4am to hear Chris play is a
good educated guess but still off.  :/  Scratch underneath the surface.
Then you'll get techno.  ;)

love always

n i c o

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

Nico, man, I don't want to get too "constructive" here, but you're too
passionate about techno not to be doing more about it. Sooner or later
you're going to realize what it is you want to do with techno and then
you're gonna be like, oh, shit, in order to do what I need to do, it
would be easier if I hadn't totally pissed off these techno promoters
by being all high and mighty and shit.

Then again you might not experience such a realization, shit, what do
I know, but seriously, you care this much, you should spin, or
produce, or something.

And don't be getting mad at me, either, cause I don't want to have to
ask any tall gorgeous women to bust out their fists of fury on you...


G/DJS

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

----- Original Message -----
From: "DJ Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

>>> etc etc etc

I have and always will be a fierce supporter of techno.  Isn't that enough?
(specifics are for resumes)

DJ Shockwave, I don't need to do anything for techno to thrive ... except
support.  The genre, and any respective regional scene in the world, is
strong enough on its own.  Techno artists will continue to produce it
whether it's profitable or not because they *love* it that much.  There's
more in a techno record than the track, there's also heart.

Last thing I'm stressing is whether or not I'm in the favor of party
promoters.  I have ambition but more importantly I have principles and
standards.  And a reverence for people who remain true to those, like all
the techno artists and likeminded lionhearts I've been fortunate enough to
get to know.

love always

n i c o

p.s. Say sup to the Constructocons, Starscream, and Megatron (not Mikey) for
me.

> by being all high and mighty and shit.

> Then again you might not experience such a realization, shit, what do
> I know, but seriously, you care this much, you should spin, or
> produce, or something.
>
> And don't be getting mad at me, either, cause I don't want to have to
> ask any tall gorgeous women to bust out their fists of fury on you...
>
>
> G/DJS

Subject: [sfraves] techno misgivings and impressions

In a message dated 8/3/2004 9:15:26 PM Pacific Daylight Time, 
sfraves-digest-help@hyperreal.org writes:


> Message-ID: <022501c479bb$91c5c880$920a030a@nns>
> From: "n n s" <nico@viberation.com>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Cc: <maximil420@hotmail.com>
> Date: Tue, 3 Aug 2004 17:39:58 -0700
> MIME-Version: 1.0
> Content-Type: text/plain;
>     charset="iso-8859-1"
> Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????
> 
> 
> 
> Upset?  No, I just questioned it.
> 
> Your lineup for that party at the Cell Space was atrociously concocted.  So
> maybe Paradigm's Shift miscues were learning experiences, but to make the
> same sorta mistakes twice kinda sucks.  :/  And while yes I am a bonafied
> fan of Chris Jackson, my opinion is not solely based upon him.

there are alot of policies and new rules to cellspace that few people have 
yet experienced. our initial goal was to have a two room party with an electro 
room in the gallery and a techno room in the main. we learned late that the 
gallery space was unavailable and had to painfully cancel alot of our talent and 
put all of us in a tight spot. combined with the fact that nobody i knew had 
issues with the date, even though it was exactly before easter, made us 
somewhat confident we could pull through anyway. call it overconfidence but we all 
mistakes and then we move on. no one is born as an established crew.


> 
> Part of my misgivings with DEFSF also include how "Sean Ocean" portrayed
> DEFSF as representative of the bay area techno scene on the So Cal Techno
> list.  If you're still trying to figure techno out, why try to unify the
> west coast techno scene?  Does the west end want to be unified in such a
> way?  And by DEFSF?


by creating DEFsf i saw it as a unifying point for so many isolated crews 
hammering away at starting their own techno scenes in their cities then fading 
out.. frustrated they made only a small impact. DEF is a method for all these 
crews to communicate and support each other. i am not DEF, i am one small active 
part who maybe naively but enthusiasticly wants to see the techno scene 
survive. thats for you, me & anybody who agrees with that goal.  

> 
> Thankfully I don't think the droid.behavior folks bought it and I genuinely
> hope they pass on your solicitation to participate in your Love Parade
> float.  I wanted to send an e-mail to a few of them and tell them not to
> base assumptions on the SF techno community (if one exists) on your crew or
> your parties
> 

i'm really happy for what the droids have done in L.A. they should be a model 
for all other techno crews. from what it seems, they also support our ideas 
and continue to do so. 

i agree that i'm not sf techno. `;) that would be silly. nor is DEF 
clearchannel or groove radio `;P there are sooo many great techno artists that never 
get heard in the bay but are internationally known. SF has some of the most 
forward thinking techno producers in the world, bar none. i hope that last 
statement remains true and SF becomes a future techno world leader. but if only 
people can think that can happen, is when it does. that's why i think there could 
be a west coast techno scene. people out here have a different take on what 
techno is and can be. the possibility assisting in creating this new techno sound 
from the west with all these people (as few as they are now) coming together 
to talk about it is why DEF exists. and for me that's exciting. `;) call it 
political but that's why DEF is what it is.

 i could have easily just been that dj with that soundsystem sending out mp3s 
hoping to reel in that promoter or agent. dealing with DEF is pain in the ass 
`;) but i love techno and want to see it flourish.

> But back to your lineup thing.  Yes, it's hard to choose who should play
> when, but it looked like politics played too large a role in your most
> recent efforts.  There didn't seem to be any sort of coherent flow.  No
> organizational logic.
> 
> To imply I was butthurt that I had to wait until 4am to hear Chris play is a
> good educated guess but still off.  :/  Scratch underneath the surface.
> Then you'll get techno.  ;)
> 
> love always
> 
> n i c o
> 

we should talk about this more face to face to get your imput on how to 
improve ourselves and the scene. like you've said, constructively. i agree with 
alot of your misgivings of what you've seen of us, but i'm positive they are just 
improper impressions so far. anything you have seen of us that you feel is 
negative, please let us know, and right away. i'm always willing to hear it str8 
up. 

thanks for your interest in DEF and hope to see you at the next one.`;)



> Cc: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Tuesday, August 03, 2004 4:54 PM
> 
> 


++spects++
-Sean Ocean-


+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

a west coast techno alliance.

http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3
> 
> original breaks tracks and remixes:
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/out_there.mp3
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3
> 
> original drum and bass tracks:
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/fremont.mp3
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3
> 
> political underground hip-hop track:
> http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3
> 
> graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
> http://www.bowkett.net
>

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0408040019260.18426@localhost>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] techno DJs

quoth Daniel Kox:
> I've heard some great house in SF since I moved from NYC, but I have
> yet to hear a good local techno DJ... Where do I hear em???

Watch the BSP's on this list, fer cryin' out loud. Hugger-Mugger is a
Tuesday nigth weekly now, you have no excuse to miss it. It's a damned
shame there were only 10 people listening when I played last night!

I'm not bitter, mind you... I've certainly played for less. But c'mon,
people whine on this list about the lack of "good" techno, then they
can't be bothered to go out and actually try something new. I've already
listed a couple of these in a very recent thread, but here are a couple
of regular events to watch out for:

Hugger-Mugger @ Lit Lounge, 6th and Mission, SF
Techno, electro, breaks, gettotech. Kick-ass residents include AndyW, Li
Sasaki, Forest Green, Clairity and Juan Segovia. Rumor is they'll have
me back soon, but don't let my absence stop you from going (hah).
Hugger-Mugger is EVERY TUESDAY NIGHT!

SODA @ the Rx Gallery, Eddy and Mason, SF
Philip Sherburne runs this one. It's branded as "minimal techno", but
this party covers much more ground than that. Philip writes for
XLR8R--check the new issue's interview with Michael Mayer for a sample
of his most excellent work. SODA's every third Saturday of the month,
but I don't see any mention of it on the Rx Gallery site now. Philip,
what's the score?

Shazbot on Throwdown.com,
<http://www.throwdown.com/throwdown/live/live.asp>
I do an internet broadcast from In House records every Monday night from
6-8pm focusing on the deep, minimal end of techno, with a splash of
house to placate the store's regulars. Listen and watch, and don't be
afraid to join in the chat if you have something to say. Remember,
that's EVERY MONDAY NIGHT.

Somebody add to this list. There's got to be some shit out there that I
don't know about. And if anyone's interested in putting something new
together, let the list know! There are many very talented, ambitious
tech heads here just itching to unleash their music on the unsuspecting
bay area populace.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Yea man - cuz like, Techno is PURE man - it's the REAL DEAL man. I am down
for the techno posse homie.

Without further adieu - the lyrics to "Sensitive Artist" by King Missile

I am a sensitive artist.
Nobody understands me because I am so deep.
In my work I make allusions to books that nobody else has read,
Music that nobody else has heard,
And art that nobody else has seen.
I can't help it
Because I am so much more intelligent
And well-rounded
Than everyone who surrounds me.
I stopped watching tv when I was six months old
Because it was so boring and stupid
And started reading books
And going to recitals
And art galleries.
I don't go to recitals anymore
Because my hearing is too sensitive
And I don't go to art galleries anymore
Because there are people there
And I can't deal with people
Because they don't understand me.
I stay home
Reading books that are beneath me,
And working on my work,
Which no one understands
I am sensitive...
I am a sensitive artist...

"jesus was way cool." oh my god that song was so great.

"Jesus was way cool
Everybody liked Jesus
Everybody wanted to hang out with him
Anything he wanted to do, he did
He turned water into wine
And if he wanted to
He could have turned wheat into marijuana
Or sugar into cocaine
Or vitamin pills into amphetamines

He walked on the water
And swam on the land
He would tell these stories
And people would listen
He was really cool"

From sfraves-return-114430-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 04 17:54:24 2004

Received: (qmail 788 invoked from network); 4 Aug 2004 17:54:24 -0000
User-Agent: Microsoft-Entourage/10.1.0.2006
Date: Wed, 04 Aug 2004 10:54:06 -0700
From: Philip Sherburne <psherburne@mindspring.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <BD3670CE.1CDC6%psherburne@mindspring.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-ELNK-Trace: 3dff75ed0343effeee26750b534f88a60a9da525759e2654fe893d775b407fc1da9bb81b31baf09a773bb16c9ad91485350badd9bab72f9c350badd9bab72f9c
X-Originating-IP: 68.167.206.235
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] techno DJs

Shawn, thanks for the mention (and sorry I didn't make it to Hugger Mugger
-- I was here, pounding away at a feature on Thomas Melchior, as it
happens). Soda is most definitely still going on every third Saturday at Rx
Gallery. And in fact this week we've got a special installment: Tomorrow
night we'll be hosting the after-party (if, uh, you can call something that
begins at 9pm an "after") for the Multiverse opening at Rx. Come one come
all!

With techno, part of the problem is always that no one really agrees on what
"techno" is -- admittedly what we play tends to hew to the more minimal end
of the spectrum, and that's where it even picks up aspects of house music
along the way (esp with the Perlon/Playhouse releases). For my money, that's
where most of the innovation is these days -- in labels like Traum, Trapez,
Musik Krause, all these cats really reinventing the "minimal" from the
inside out, with tight microsyncopations, layers upon layers of interlocking
grooves, and wild tone color. For the poster that thought minimal techno was
harder to mix (or easier to mix poorly) simply because it was so spacious,
I'd guess that these tracks are very different from what you're thinking of
as minimal bangers. That said, it still isn't easy to mix! (And I still
think you can tell when a house DJ flubs it as well.)

Anyway, come on down. In addition to the minimal we're playing lots of
sassy, more electro-ish, punkish stuff (Black Strobe, et al) with a healthy
dose of acid.

And anyone who's really down to throw a proper warehouse techno party, I'd
love to work on that.

Philip

----

philip sherburne
full sentences on demand

a blog: http://www.philipsherburne.com
subscribe: http://www.flavorpill.net
subscribe: http://www.earplug.cc

On Wed, 04 Aug 2004 18:29:42 +0000, Macadio G. <macadio@hotmail.com> wrote:

> it.. Now keep on mind missle also produced alot of Shitty techno!! or what
> some of you tecno geeks might call "Intelligent techno" Which I thought was
> un-dance floor friendly crap.. it is "CD" music or "Cleaning your house

for your listening pleasures while you're doing your chores...

some of that stuff works well in chillrooms. oddly enough though I
have a great-aunt in Santa Rosa who is 92 years old and her fridge
actually makes some of the best chillroom techno I've ever heard. it
basically sounds like a forest of robot birds, or some kind of ambient
dub made with a series of cascading, heavily reverbed 303s. honestly
you could hook this thing up to a PA and straight up own the
chillroom.

plus your beer would stay cool.

--

when you are sitting in the main administration office area. I've wanted
to sample that for ages. It's this neat reverberated "whooooshhh" sound.

> basically sounds like a forest of robot birds, or some kind of
> ambient
> dub made with a series of cascading, heavily reverbed 303s. honestly
> you could hook this thing up to a PA and straight up own the
> chillroom.

From sfraves-return-114441-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 04 22:34:08 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114441-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 12142 invoked from network); 4 Aug 2004 22:34:08 -0000
Date: Wed, 4 Aug 2004 15:34:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: electrofunk138 <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
cc: Chel-C Faith <chelcfaith@defsf.com>, n n s <nico@viberation.com>,
  SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV11kSmLAztxc0006604d@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0408041453140.8499-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????


On Tue, 3 Aug 2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
-&e->Most dj's should be grateful to play, let alone get a headline spot - if
-&e->they EXPECT to get one, they need a 'tude check.

We're DJs, not monks.  Some people do certain things better.  I started
out playing last/morning slot at almost every party I played, and worked
my way up from there.  I've been doing this long enough to know what I do
well.  If you're doing me a favor by booking me, don't.  Book me because
what I offer is what you want.  Your DJs should be doing you the favor by
playing.

Me, personally, I totally hear that some people are more "peak hour"
material than others.  Chris Jackson for example, can totally drive the
bus peak hour and deserves that slot... or just prior... his sound is
really energetic and compelling and almost never goes flat on a crowd.  I
have a different style, and usually find my groove a little later in the
night (I'm just a weirder monkey I guess).  At a party, that means 3-4am,
where I can land the UFOs.  At a club, lemme close it down and own last
call and that's my best work usually.  That's not ego, it's where I've
seen me do my best and I think it's dumb to apologize for that.  Book me
at another hour, and you'll get my best attempt at meeting the needs of
that time of evening, but it's ok to believe I'm better at some things
than others.

It SUCKS when you know you could totally take people there but your set is
at like 9pm or 5am, and you're watching some jackoff just not cut it
right when people need to get their shit worked.  Yes, it happens, but
it's a disservice to the crowd, to the flow... it's a sign the promoter
either made an error (usually a result of not listening to DJs prior to
booking them), or has the wrong priorities (values favor network and
personal relationships over presenting a quality event to their
attendees).

That said, another big consideration a lot of people miss is playing to
the slot you're assigned.  Nosebleed kick yer arse shit shouldn't be
played at 10pm, it's just dumb (well, most of the time, sometimes it's a
good idea, a good DJ can tell).  Don't play trippy goony stuff at a club
at 10pm where nobody is high.  Don't play the same records the DJ before
you played. If the room is hitting 1000 degrees, make some space in the
music so people can breathe for a second before taking the energy up
again.

I'd really like to recommend people consider this for lineups:

10-12 opening slot
12-1:30 compelling raise the energy level stuff
1:30-3:30 headliner
3:30-5:00 lower but sustained energy, but solid dj with maybe more soul
5:00-7:00 more cerebral,emotional stuff, slower

You give your opener and closer 2 hours each.  All the other slots are 1.5
hours (if your headliner is from outside the area kick em a 2 hour set
too, they'll love it).  You place your headliner in the most appropriate
slot.

Stop worrying so much about politics and friendships and book people where
they belong, not where they "deserve" cause they booked you last month..
that's a total disservice to the crowd (who is who you should be doing
this for).  The favor network is how we get the same lineups over and over
and over here... which is exactly why we get kids dropping out of the
scene thinking they've seen it all after only a couple months.  And who
can blame them, the last 5 parties they attended were identical...

If I could see one major change in the way that parties are done here, I'd
like it to be less DJs, change em up more, better DJs, longer slots and
stop booking 8 DJs that all play peak hour stuff and calling that a
lineup.  Yes, that probably means we all get booked less often... but it
would make for better parties.  This shit where we have sub-one hour slots
is fucked up... that's how you get a lot of names on the flyer, but it
doesn't serve those people who just start to get into a DJs groove just
before they're kicked off for DJ #5848383.

Quality not Quantity, Altitude not Attitude, pave new ground but learn
from those who came before.

andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

> 10-12 opening slot

> 1:30-3:30 headliner
> 3:30-5:00 lower but sustained energy, but solid dj with maybe more soul
> 5:00-7:00 more cerebral,emotional stuff, slower
>
> You give your opener and closer 2 hours each.  All the other slots are 1.5
> hours (if your headliner is from outside the area kick em a 2 hour set
> too, they'll love it).  You place your headliner in the most appropriate
> slot.
>
> Stop worrying so much about politics and friendships and book people where
> they belong, not where they "deserve" cause they booked you last month..
> that's a total disservice to the crowd (who is who you should be doing
> this for).  The favor network is how we get the same lineups over and over
> and over here... which is exactly why we get kids dropping out of the
> scene thinking they've seen it all after only a couple months.  And who
> can blame them, the last 5 parties they attended were identical...
>
> If I could see one major change in the way that parties are done here, I'd
> like it to be less DJs, change em up more, better DJs, longer slots and
> stop booking 8 DJs that all play peak hour stuff and calling that a
> lineup.  Yes, that probably means we all get booked less often... but it
> would make for better parties.  This shit where we have sub-one hour slots
> is fucked up... that's how you get a lot of names on the flyer, but it
> doesn't serve those people who just start to get into a DJs groove just
> before they're kicked off for DJ #5848383.
>
> Quality not Quantity, Altitude not Attitude, pave new ground but learn
> from those who came before.
>
> andyw
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>


-- 
Save Bob, Sat. August 28th.  This time with new and improved Kissing
Booth.  No, for reals this time.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

I would agree with most of this, because really - you make all extremely
valid points.

I guess it's just that I have been to so many parties where lineups were
rock solid, and one or two dj's act like primadonnas about spots. This is
typically where I'd agree with you and say that any quality promoter should
be able to figure out what style/energy level goes best where - but then if
you have a pissy DJ who still thinks he/she should be elsewhere on the
lineup - what do you do? (and there are more than plenty of these type folks
around)

That's more why I was saying "you should be grateful you're fucking playing"
than any other reason. I personally feel folks liek that should get the big
heave-ho - but that's just me. I'm fairly intolerant of snotty people.

All that being said - I'm w/ Jonas R - if any of you folks need an opener,
or closing DJ - never hesitate to hit me up, cuz I will play anywhere, and
have material that fits in any time slot you stick me in.... :)

M-


----- Original Message -----
From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
To: "electrofunk138" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
Cc: "Chel-C Faith" <chelcfaith@defsf.com>; "n n s" <nico@viberation.com>;
"SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 04, 2004 3:34 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????


>
> On Tue, 3 Aug 2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
> -&e->Most dj's should be grateful to play, let alone get a headline spot -
if
> -&e->they EXPECT to get one, they need a 'tude check.
>
> We're DJs, not monks.  Some people do certain things better.  I started
> out playing last/morning slot at almost every party I played, and worked
> my way up from there.  I've been doing this long enough to know what I do
> well.  If you're doing me a favor by booking me, don't.  Book me because
> what I offer is what you want.  Your DJs should be doing you the favor by
> playing.
>
> Me, personally, I totally hear that some people are more "peak hour"
> material than others.  Chris Jackson for example, can totally drive the
> bus peak hour and deserves that slot... or just prior... his sound is
> really energetic and compelling and almost never goes flat on a crowd.  I
> have a different style, and usually find my groove a little later in the
> night (I'm just a weirder monkey I guess).  At a party, that means 3-4am,
> where I can land the UFOs.  At a club, lemme close it down and own last
> call and that's my best work usually.  That's not ego, it's where I've
> seen me do my best and I think it's dumb to apologize for that.  Book me
> at another hour, and you'll get my best attempt at meeting the needs of
> that time of evening, but it's ok to believe I'm better at some things
> than others.
>
> It SUCKS when you know you could totally take people there but your set is
> at like 9pm or 5am, and you're watching some jackoff just not cut it
> right when people need to get their shit worked.  Yes, it happens, but
> it's a disservice to the crowd, to the flow... it's a sign the promoter
> either made an error (usually a result of not listening to DJs prior to
> booking them), or has the wrong priorities (values favor network and
> personal relationships over presenting a quality event to their
> attendees).
>
> That said, another big consideration a lot of people miss is playing to
> the slot you're assigned.  Nosebleed kick yer arse shit shouldn't be
> played at 10pm, it's just dumb (well, most of the time, sometimes it's a
> good idea, a good DJ can tell).  Don't play trippy goony stuff at a club
> at 10pm where nobody is high.  Don't play the same records the DJ before
> you played. If the room is hitting 1000 degrees, make some space in the
> music so people can breathe for a second before taking the energy up
> again.
>
> I'd really like to recommend people consider this for lineups:
>
> 10-12 opening slot
> 12-1:30 compelling raise the energy level stuff
> 1:30-3:30 headliner
> 3:30-5:00 lower but sustained energy, but solid dj with maybe more soul
> 5:00-7:00 more cerebral,emotional stuff, slower
>
> You give your opener and closer 2 hours each.  All the other slots are 1.5
> hours (if your headliner is from outside the area kick em a 2 hour set
> too, they'll love it).  You place your headliner in the most appropriate
> slot.
>
> Stop worrying so much about politics and friendships and book people where
> they belong, not where they "deserve" cause they booked you last month..
> that's a total disservice to the crowd (who is who you should be doing
> this for).  The favor network is how we get the same lineups over and over
> and over here... which is exactly why we get kids dropping out of the
> scene thinking they've seen it all after only a couple months.  And who
> can blame them, the last 5 parties they attended were identical...
>
> If I could see one major change in the way that parties are done here, I'd
> like it to be less DJs, change em up more, better DJs, longer slots and
> stop booking 8 DJs that all play peak hour stuff and calling that a
> lineup.  Yes, that probably means we all get booked less often... but it
> would make for better parties.  This shit where we have sub-one hour slots
> is fucked up... that's how you get a lot of names on the flyer, but it
> doesn't serve those people who just start to get into a DJs groove just
> before they're kicked off for DJ #5848383.
>
> Quality not Quantity, Altitude not Attitude, pave new ground but learn
> from those who came before.
>

On Wed, 4 Aug 2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
-&e->I would agree with most of this, because really - you make all extremely
-&e->valid points.
-&e->

-&e->I guess it's just that I have been to so many parties where lineups
-&e->were rock solid, and one or two dj's act like primadonnas about
-&e->spots. This is typically where I'd agree with you and say that any
-&e->quality promoter should be able to figure out what style/energy level
-&e->goes best where - but then if you have a pissy DJ who still thinks
-&e->he/she should be elsewhere on the lineup - what do you do? (and there
-&e->are more than plenty of these type folks around)

You can their shit and get someone else that does what you had in mind.

Hint:

promoter (pro-mo-ter) n. - a meta DJ, who creates a set that lasts for the
entire party using DJs as a unit of expression the same way a DJ would use
records.  Should they encounter a fucked up DJ, treat exactly as a DJ
would treat a skipping record.

I'm not opposed to working with people, but I'll be honest and state that
when I do a lineup, I schedule the slot and unless their reason is damn
good (i have to get a babysitter, i can't be in town then cause I have a
bris I must attend, etc) they get DA DICK [tm].  That goes back to the
friend's network I talked about.  If you're a promoter, and you're in it
for the right reasons, that shit shouldn't sway you whatsoever.

andyw

Subject: Re: [sfraves] techno DJs

Some of the best music I've ever heard in any genre
was a tag team on four decks by Derrick May and Kevin
Saunderson at a Club called Red at WMC a few years
back (maybe 2000?).  They played some glitchy techno,
tech house, and I don't know some other shit that
totally rocked.  Saunderson came out on the floor and
danced himself.  Ken Ishii (sp?) followed and rocked
also.  Of course the fact that I got in for free and
was given several gigantic red bulls and vodka didn't
hurt either.

Good techno is good, damn good.

Peter

Yea - I feel the same about almost every tiem I've seen John Aquaviva jam.
That mofo is on like Tron. I know some people consider him to be more on the
house side of things - but only once out of the 5 or 6 times I have seen
him, has he spun housier shit. Normally he plays really throbby, sexy,
thumping shit.

I'm used to techno being more pounding tho - like Hawtin, Chris Liberator
(guess that's "acid" techno), Mistress Barbara, Jon Williams, Adam Beyer,
Rush and a mess of others.

One of the links someone sent to me yesterday sounded WAY more like house
than it did techno - albeit more like glitchy type house, but it just didn't
sound like techno to me. Then again - I play the gamut of breaks -
everything from super-bangin', almost jungly nuskool, to acid breaks,
electro, prog - even some tranced out shit.

I'm excited to be in an area where there's a varied selection of sounds to
be exposed to, rather than the cookie cutter club formula everywhere you go.

woot.

Thanks for the links thus far tho people - keep 'em coming!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Techno party you say?????

	I'll chime in here and agree with you guys. Line-up space is too 
limited to waste it on jerks -- they should be invited to take a 
one-way flight out of town on Flying Fuck Airlines. I'd rather go to a 
party with no-name DJs who have good attitudes than to an event with a 
bunch of stuck-up superstars. The fact that the DJs are cool people 
means the party is more likely to have a good vibe, because probably 
some of their friends will be there too, and nice people tend to have 
nice friends. And conversely if they are jerks, what kind of friends 
are they likely to have? When it comes to raves, decent music and a 
great vibe definitely beats terrific music and no vibe in my book.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

> I would agree with most of this, because really - you make all 
> extremely
> valid points.
>
> I guess it's just that I have been to so many parties where lineups 
> were
> rock solid, and one or two dj's act like primadonnas about spots. This 
> is
> typically where I'd agree with you and say that any quality promoter 
> should
> be able to figure out what style/energy level goes best where - but 
> then if
> you have a pissy DJ who still thinks he/she should be elsewhere on the
> lineup - what do you do? (and there are more than plenty of these type 
> folks
> around)
>
> That's more why I was saying "you should be grateful you're fucking 
> playing"
> than any other reason. I personally feel folks liek that should get 
> the big
> heave-ho - but that's just me. I'm fairly intolerant of snotty people.
>
> All that being said - I'm w/ Jonas R - if any of you folks need an 
> opener,

>>
>> On Tue, 3 Aug 2004, electrofunk138 wrote:
>> -&e->Most dj's should be grateful to play, let alone get a headline 
>> spot -
> if
>> -&e->they EXPECT to get one, they need a 'tude check.
>>
>> We're DJs, not monks.  Some people do certain things better.  I 
>> started
>> out playing last/morning slot at almost every party I played, and 
>> worked
>> my way up from there.  I've been doing this long enough to know what 
>> I do
>> well.  If you're doing me a favor by booking me, don't.  Book me 
>> because
>> what I offer is what you want.  Your DJs should be doing you the 
>> favor by
>> playing.
>>
>> Me, personally, I totally hear that some people are more "peak hour"
>> material than others.  Chris Jackson for example, can totally drive 
>> the
>> bus peak hour and deserves that slot... or just prior... his sound is
>> really energetic and compelling and almost never goes flat on a 
>> crowd.  I
>> have a different style, and usually find my groove a little later in 
>> the
>> night (I'm just a weirder monkey I guess).  At a party, that means 
>> 3-4am,
>> where I can land the UFOs.  At a club, lemme close it down and own 
>> last
>> call and that's my best work usually.  That's not ego, it's where I've
>> seen me do my best and I think it's dumb to apologize for that.  Book 
>> me
>> at another hour, and you'll get my best attempt at meeting the needs 
>> of
>> that time of evening, but it's ok to believe I'm better at some things
>> than others.
>>
>> It SUCKS when you know you could totally take people there but your 
>> set is
>> at like 9pm or 5am, and you're watching some jackoff just not cut it
>> right when people need to get their shit worked.  Yes, it happens, but
>> it's a disservice to the crowd, to the flow... it's a sign the 
>> promoter
>> either made an error (usually a result of not listening to DJs prior 
>> to
>> booking them), or has the wrong priorities (values favor network and
>> personal relationships over presenting a quality event to their
>> attendees).
>>
>> That said, another big consideration a lot of people miss is playing 
>> to
>> the slot you're assigned.  Nosebleed kick yer arse shit shouldn't be
>> played at 10pm, it's just dumb (well, most of the time, sometimes 
>> it's a
>> good idea, a good DJ can tell).  Don't play trippy goony stuff at a 
>> club
>> at 10pm where nobody is high.  Don't play the same records the DJ 
>> before
>> you played. If the room is hitting 1000 degrees, make some space in 
>> the
>> music so people can breathe for a second before taking the energy up
>> again.
>>
>> I'd really like to recommend people consider this for lineups:
>>
>> 10-12 opening slot
>> 12-1:30 compelling raise the energy level stuff
>> 1:30-3:30 headliner
>> 3:30-5:00 lower but sustained energy, but solid dj with maybe more 
>> soul
>> 5:00-7:00 more cerebral,emotional stuff, slower
>>
>> You give your opener and closer 2 hours each.  All the other slots 
>> are 1.5
>> hours (if your headliner is from outside the area kick em a 2 hour set
>> too, they'll love it).  You place your headliner in the most 
>> appropriate
>> slot.
>>
>> Stop worrying so much about politics and friendships and book people 
>> where
>> they belong, not where they "deserve" cause they booked you last 
>> month..
>> that's a total disservice to the crowd (who is who you should be doing
>> this for).  The favor network is how we get the same lineups over and 
>> over
>> and over here... which is exactly why we get kids dropping out of the
>> scene thinking they've seen it all after only a couple months.  And 
>> who
>> can blame them, the last 5 parties they attended were identical...
>>
>> If I could see one major change in the way that parties are done 
>> here, I'd
>> like it to be less DJs, change em up more, better DJs, longer slots 
>> and
>> stop booking 8 DJs that all play peak hour stuff and calling that a
>> lineup.  Yes, that probably means we all get booked less often... but 
>> it
>> would make for better parties.  This shit where we have sub-one hour 
>> slots
>> is fucked up... that's how you get a lot of names on the flyer, but it
>> doesn't serve those people who just start to get into a DJs groove 
>> just
>> before they're kicked off for DJ #5848383.
>>
>> Quality not Quantity, Altitude not Attitude, pave new ground but learn
>> from those who came before.
>>
>> andyw
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TELIC.. Post #2- Am i wrong about this?

Wow...  Osby, formerly the ardent supporter and defender of security=20
types, (including the worst, most thug-like, examples of the lot...=20
1015's) finally sees their kind for what they truly are.

This whole thread reminded me of a realization I came to not long ago. =20=

And I spent some time wondering if I should even post on the topic,=20
given my earlier history of doing little but get pissed off and rant.

I realized when entering "Different", a party thrown by a promoter=20
whose parties I had enjoyed in the past, and whom I used to have a lot=20=

of respect in his capacity as a promoter, that I was putting up, at=20
parties, with exactly the same kind of door gauntlet bullshit that led=20=

me to swear off clubs, way back when.  That realization just totally=20
fucked up my whole night, and I left the party after only the first=20
hour or so.  Just no way I was going to be able to have a good time,=20
after that.

The difference is, I guess, that when I first moved to SF and started=20
going to 1015 with my dotcom buddies, it came as a rude shock to me. =20
The way 1015 treats their customers was unheard-of in Florida's live=20
punk and ska music scene (where I got my music fix before I got to SF).=20=

  So getting felt up, and the "you vill empty your pocket or ve vill=20
open fire" routine, at 1015 was a rude shock.  I gave them more chances=20=

than they deserved to rectify their behavior, with no change.  So=20
eventually I just started finding excuses not to go out clubbing; and=20
finally decided to give it up.

Not long after that, I met Osby, and through him, just about everyone=20
in the bay area (That is to say, I was introduced, Osby-style, to just=20=

about everyone.  Knowing any more than "that's someone Osby pointed out=20=

to me sometime" came much later.).  And I seriously started to fall=20
into the rave scene.  And, at that time, and at least at the parties=20
*I* found myself at, even the "candy" side of the scene rarely asked=20
anything more than a quick pat-down.

But over the intervening years, promoters seemed to forget what the "R"=20=

in plur stands for: RESPECT.

Security at parties got worse and worse.  Worse than that, I found=20
myself modifying my OWN habits to make the security process less of a=20
hassle.  And it hit me, just after getting in the door at "Different",=20=

that, except for conspiring with, and threatening to sell people out=20
to, the pigs themselves; security at (many) parties had turned into the=20=

same thuggery I despised about clubs.

I've only been to a couple of parties since then; and then only at the=20=

insistence of friends that I *MUST* go.

I wonder if I've finally crossed the threshold into jadedness.


cya,
john

> I think you should feel violated, Osby.  I've seen ads for the Telic=20=

> parties.  The impression they give is that:  "...we are bring back=20
> that old love and vibe from back in the early days of raves."
>
> For those who did not experience the anarchic, free-spirited days of=20=

> raving this may work.  But in reality, there was no "security" at=20
> these events;  no pat down;  no confiscation of personal property. =20
> These actions would be antithetical to the whole concept of a=20
> "temporary autonomous zone."  Now we have parties where one is=20
> required to surrender personal freedoms for safety.  Kinda like a=20
> microcosm of the whole of society these days, eh?
>
> Intrusive security has nothing to do with "raving."  When promoters=20
> throw parties like these where you are required to endure personal=20
> humiliation to enter they should at least disclose this after the=20
> "love and vibe" headers in their advertising.

Subject: [sfraves] bsp - phase 1 - friday, aug 13 - 5 uk hard dance headliners!!!

--0-1203288328-1091721040=:44888
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

alright here we go kids... check this out...
all confirmed now, d&a and phase 2 have teamed up to make sure it happens: just confirmed are 5 of the uk's hotest hard dance djs. this event is going to be at one of everyones favroite venues... if you buy presales you can go to the other show the next night too for $20, thats right only $20 to see even more uk hard house headliners...
you will get 2 nights of partying with a total of 7 uk headliners and 4 national!!!
our goal is to bring the best for the scene.. this is a milestone for the sf hard dance and trance scene. be there as the story unfolds...

the full line-up is done, check it out...

Eufex - Birmingham, UK - Nukleuz, Vicious Circle, Honey Pot
The name Eufex might not ring a bell from the go for everyone, but he has been around since HardHouse was in its mere infancy. Strangely, he is by far THE most under rated producer that Hard Dance has ever seen. Sean Stanley is the force behind many brilliant releases on early HH labels such as Arriba & TYT as well as prominent labels Nukleuz, Vicious Circle, Honey Pot & his now defunct Ravage Records. He has also collaborated with Jay-B for classic releases like Hypnotica on Kaktai Records, the massive anthem Vacuum Packed on Pump, plus tracks on Chris Cs now defunct projects, Aztec & Nile. 
Even though Sean has awe-inspiring skills as a producer & engineer, releases on very reputable labels, an involvement in the scene spreading over many years & one of the most professional attitudes in the industry, there was never a massive following of his music. Somehow people were overlooking a genius. 
Sean shocked many when he decided to take a break and concentrate his energy elsewhere. However, he couldnt shelf his love for the genre and wrote more original tracks & remixes whilst also working with various artists outside of Hard Dance. Hes back in 2004 with two remixes on Scottish hard label Lit Up and he has a promising Live PA with a host of new material and remixes ready to unleash in the coming months. 
Please come out and help us welcome him for his first Inernational set and out of retirement!!!!

Banga Matt - London, UK - Arktik, Sketcha, DP, Nile
Banga has been a staple dj and producer in the massive London scene for quite some time now. With he unique approach to the hrad nrg sound he has gained support the world over.. Just coming off his tour of oz and new zealand Matt is going to touch down and blow the place up! 

Phil Able - London, UK - Antiworld, Smile, Cyberdog, D&A Music S.F.
After Phils massive 2 hour set at 4 the People last November we had to have him back Only now as a resident for D&A. For those who were at 4 the People know what is in store as there is still a buzz about his set, dont miss out this time..
 
Nicki S - London, UK - Endophin, Quality Trax
Nicki is a dj who means bussiness. her hard tech sounds have gained her fame all over the UK clubs. 

Little Miss Natalie - Manchester, UK - Fist
This fireball from the north brings it hard and fast.. No mercy is the name of the game here.. with recent tracks with none other than the Testube Babies, she is no joke. SF need to propare to for an onslaught of the hardest upfornt and classic dark nrg sounds...

Viticus

Offering accross the board local tallent...

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "John B" <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Cc: "O§by Jamz" <osby@hellokitty.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 05, 2004 12:37 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] TELIC.. Post #2- Am i wrong about this?


Wow...  Osby, formerly the ardent supporter and defender of security
types, (including the worst, most thug-like, examples of the lot...
1015's) finally sees their kind for what they truly are.

This whole thread reminded me of a realization I came to not long ago.
And I spent some time wondering if I should even post on the topic,
given my earlier history of doing little but get pissed off and rant.

I realized when entering "Different", a party thrown by a promoter
whose parties I had enjoyed in the past, and whom I used to have a lot
of respect in his capacity as a promoter, that I was putting up, at
parties, with exactly the same kind of door gauntlet bullshit that led
me to swear off clubs, way back when.  That realization just totally
fucked up my whole night, and I left the party after only the first
hour or so.  Just no way I was going to be able to have a good time,
after that.

The difference is, I guess, that when I first moved to SF and started
going to 1015 with my dotcom buddies, it came as a rude shock to me.
The way 1015 treats their customers was unheard-of in Florida's live
punk and ska music scene (where I got my music fix before I got to SF).
  So getting felt up, and the "you vill empty your pocket or ve vill
open fire" routine, at 1015 was a rude shock.  I gave them more chances
than they deserved to rectify their behavior, with no change.  So
eventually I just started finding excuses not to go out clubbing; and
finally decided to give it up.

Not long after that, I met Osby, and through him, just about everyone
in the bay area (That is to say, I was introduced, Osby-style, to just
about everyone.  Knowing any more than "that's someone Osby pointed out
to me sometime" came much later.).  And I seriously started to fall
into the rave scene.  And, at that time, and at least at the parties
*I* found myself at, even the "candy" side of the scene rarely asked
anything more than a quick pat-down.

But over the intervening years, promoters seemed to forget what the "R"
in plur stands for: RESPECT.

Security at parties got worse and worse.  Worse than that, I found
myself modifying my OWN habits to make the security process less of a
hassle.  And it hit me, just after getting in the door at "Different",
that, except for conspiring with, and threatening to sell people out
to, the pigs themselves; security at (many) parties had turned into the
same thuggery I despised about clubs.

I've only been to a couple of parties since then; and then only at the
insistence of friends that I *MUST* go.

I wonder if I've finally crossed the threshold into jadedness.


cya,
john

> I think you should feel violated, Osby.  I've seen ads for the Telic
> parties.  The impression they give is that:  "...we are bring back
> that old love and vibe from back in the early days of raves."
>
> For those who did not experience the anarchic, free-spirited days of
> raving this may work.  But in reality, there was no "security" at
> these events;  no pat down;  no confiscation of personal property.
> These actions would be antithetical to the whole concept of a
> "temporary autonomous zone."  Now we have parties where one is
> required to surrender personal freedoms for safety.  Kinda like a
> microcosm of the whole of society these days, eh?
>
> Intrusive security has nothing to do with "raving."  When promoters
> throw parties like these where you are required to endure personal
> humiliation to enter they should at least disclose this after the
> "love and vibe" headers in their advertising.
>

name and artist of a record i heard a long time ago, i think it was probably 
around 96 or 97.  I dont remember much about it.  i just remember that on 
the label on the record it said "Crazy Acid Shit" all over it, and the 
sample in the song said "Crazy Acid Shit" but it would be all tripped out 
and stuff.  That's about all the info i have on it, since i was on crazy 
acid shit at the time...I've tried Gemm.com but couldnt find it there, so i 
figured maybe one of you guys out there in SFR land would have heard it or 
seen it or something.  hopefully one of you has.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TELIC.. Post #2- Am i wrong about this?

I don't think you have gone to the "darkside" (being jaded). You just don't
want to tolerate bullshit, and really, who can blame you?

I tend to (like Apollo) only frequent spots that DON'T do a patdown. Not
because I like to smuggle in drugs (I rarely do them at clubs, if ever), but
because I think it's ridiculous. I mean - if they are THAT PRESSED about
guns, install metal detectors like Twilo had. But any smart person is
getting the drugs in regardless of whether or not security feels up your
balls or not on the way in the door. Shit - I used to do security at punk
clubs and strip bars, and I know how easy it is, no matter how thorough you
are - to miss things coming through the door. Real security takes care of
the problem when it happens. Real security is stealthy enough to roam the
dancefloor and nab people "in the act". They don't harass the shit out of
everyone on the assumption that every person walking through the door is a
drug toting gangsta. That's just silly.

Anyhoo...bla bla bla.
----- Original Message -----
From: "John B" <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Cc: "O§by Jamz" <osby@hellokitty.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 05, 2004 12:37 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] TELIC.. Post #2- Am i wrong about this?


Wow...  Osby, formerly the ardent supporter and defender of security
types, (including the worst, most thug-like, examples of the lot...
1015's) finally sees their kind for what they truly are.

This whole thread reminded me of a realization I came to not long ago.
And I spent some time wondering if I should even post on the topic,
given my earlier history of doing little but get pissed off and rant.

I realized when entering "Different", a party thrown by a promoter
whose parties I had enjoyed in the past, and whom I used to have a lot
of respect in his capacity as a promoter, that I was putting up, at
parties, with exactly the same kind of door gauntlet bullshit that led
me to swear off clubs, way back when.  That realization just totally
fucked up my whole night, and I left the party after only the first
hour or so.  Just no way I was going to be able to have a good time,
after that.

The difference is, I guess, that when I first moved to SF and started
going to 1015 with my dotcom buddies, it came as a rude shock to me.
The way 1015 treats their customers was unheard-of in Florida's live
punk and ska music scene (where I got my music fix before I got to SF).
  So getting felt up, and the "you vill empty your pocket or ve vill
open fire" routine, at 1015 was a rude shock.  I gave them more chances
than they deserved to rectify their behavior, with no change.  So
eventually I just started finding excuses not to go out clubbing; and
finally decided to give it up.

Not long after that, I met Osby, and through him, just about everyone
in the bay area (That is to say, I was introduced, Osby-style, to just
about everyone.  Knowing any more than "that's someone Osby pointed out
to me sometime" came much later.).  And I seriously started to fall
into the rave scene.  And, at that time, and at least at the parties
*I* found myself at, even the "candy" side of the scene rarely asked
anything more than a quick pat-down.

But over the intervening years, promoters seemed to forget what the "R"
in plur stands for: RESPECT.

Security at parties got worse and worse.  Worse than that, I found
myself modifying my OWN habits to make the security process less of a
hassle.  And it hit me, just after getting in the door at "Different",
that, except for conspiring with, and threatening to sell people out
to, the pigs themselves; security at (many) parties had turned into the
same thuggery I despised about clubs.

I've only been to a couple of parties since then; and then only at the
insistence of friends that I *MUST* go.

I wonder if I've finally crossed the threshold into jadedness.


cya,
john

> I think you should feel violated, Osby.  I've seen ads for the Telic
> parties.  The impression they give is that:  "...we are bring back
> that old love and vibe from back in the early days of raves."
>
> For those who did not experience the anarchic, free-spirited days of
> raving this may work.  But in reality, there was no "security" at
> these events;  no pat down;  no confiscation of personal property.
> These actions would be antithetical to the whole concept of a
> "temporary autonomous zone."  Now we have parties where one is
> required to surrender personal freedoms for safety.  Kinda like a
> microcosm of the whole of society these days, eh?
>
> Intrusive security has nothing to do with "raving."  When promoters
> throw parties like these where you are required to endure personal
> humiliation to enter they should at least disclose this after the
> "love and vibe" headers in their advertising.
>

> close to that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

dave synth (aka d syn) CAN play incredible techno sets
- dark, minimal and pounding.  but it's no guarantee
he'll play a set like that when he plays, and might
play more electro-y.  also, if he's playing last,
it'll be more experimental.  catch him at spaz
parties.  

i heard dj yap play a great set at, uh, was it the
party where adam x played last year?  (adam x sucked,
by the way. )  though i did hear it was one of his
best sets, so i don't know if he consistently plays
that well or not.  

unfortunately, i find a lot of the sf techno i've
heard to be kind of boring, just the same relentless,
repetitive beat, and not at all trance-inducing or
intricate.  

haven't heard forest green play lately but i hear good
things about her.  

i've also heard that sutekh live has been amazing.  

wish kit clayton played out more often.  last time i
heard him dj (at the top, last year, i think, at an
early riot), he was great.  

monikat

Subject: Re: [sfraves] more on sf techno

I like Kenji Ogura's "Kreissage Typ B" over top of Armand Van Helden's
"Neccessary Evil". I'm not 100% sure either track is straight up techno, but
together they make one storming techno monster. Maybe not entirely trance
inducing - but holy shit does it devastate a dancefloor.

	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20040805005601.5162.qmail@web21526.mail.yahoo.com> <BAY8-DAV3Qhgmw2xoVT00072df1@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV3Qhgmw2xoVT00072df1@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

quoth electrofunk138:
> One of the links someone sent to me yesterday sounded WAY more like
> house than it did techno - albeit more like glitchy type house, but it
> just didn't sound like techno to me.

I don't know if this was directed at me or not, but I wouldn't take
offense if it were. The question is: where do you draw the line? Techno
overlaps house in tempo and structure. Most people refer to me as a
house DJ, but I don't really think I am... I may play things on the
housier end when it's appropriate, but I'd much rather play what I think
of as techno. However, because most people just think of drum trax when
they hear the word "techno", I can't refer to myself as a "techno DJ". I
want to change that perception.

"Tech-house" is a convenient term, but nobody seems to know what the
hell it is. I can't get booked at house events *or* techno events when I
refer to my style as "tech-house". :\

So when I draw the line, I err on the side of techno. Stuff on labels
like Poker Flat doesn't necessarily fall on either side, but Steve Bug
is most certainly a techno icon. Kompakt is another label that defies
even the most simple classifications, right up to the latest EP by
SCSI-9 (which discogs files under "Minimal, Ambient, House"). John
Tejada produces a wide variety of styles, but I'd call even his housiest
efforts (stuff on Palette and Playhouse) techno. Terms like "microhouse"
attempt to distance the most minimal techno from the tougher stuff, but
I don't see any need for that distinction. I'd like to think that
peoples' tastes are diverse enough that they would appreciate both ends
of the spectrum.

I'd say that house is really just a style of techno--one defined by a
more narrow tempo range and a smaller subset of instruments and
structures. Under that classification scheme, it's easy for me to call
most of what I play "techno". ;)

Cheerio,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 6757 invoked from network); 5 Aug 2004 22:11:17 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [68.126.42.241]
X-Originating-Email: [electrofunk138@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: electrofunk138@hotmail.com
From: "Van Mundegaarde" <electrofunk138@hotmail.com>
To: shawn@alterior.net, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 05 Aug 2004 15:10:16 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY8-F87FRaqbC8wSA100000003@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Aug 2004 22:11:14.0546 (UTC) FILETIME=[1F863D20:01C47B39]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

Twasn't you I was referring to  - it was that Carceri fellow.

Personally, I'm not versed enoguh in what is or is not techno to be able to 
distinguish between the subgenres, or the extreme ends of the spectrum. I 
just knows what I hear, and what sounds more like what to me. The mix I 
listened to that the kid posted was labled as techno - and sounded liek 
house to me. It wasn't at all bad - I liked it, but (like I said earlier) 
techno to ME has always been the more pounding, almost industrial sounding 
shit. No, I don't mean it all sounds like Front 242 or Frontline Assembly - 
but I mean, a very mechanical, pounding, machine-like sound. Chock full o' 
909's, those wacky rewind-sounding samples, driving basslines, etc.

I guess tech-house would make sense - because it had elements of "techno" 
(as I'm familiar with it), but had a much more house-like feel. Melodies, 
pads, a smidge funky, lower BPM, etc.

Anyhoo...

M-



>From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs
>Date: Thu, 5 Aug 2004 14:43:33 -0700
>
>quoth electrofunk138:
> > One of the links someone sent to me yesterday sounded WAY more like
> > house than it did techno - albeit more like glitchy type house, but it
> > just didn't sound like techno to me.
>
>I don't know if this was directed at me or not, but I wouldn't take
>offense if it were. The question is: where do you draw the line? Techno
>overlaps house in tempo and structure. Most people refer to me as a
>house DJ, but I don't really think I am... I may play things on the
>housier end when it's appropriate, but I'd much rather play what I think
>of as techno. However, because most people just think of drum trax when
>they hear the word "techno", I can't refer to myself as a "techno DJ". I
>want to change that perception.
>
>"Tech-house" is a convenient term, but nobody seems to know what the
>hell it is. I can't get booked at house events *or* techno events when I
>refer to my style as "tech-house". :\
>
>So when I draw the line, I err on the side of techno. Stuff on labels
>like Poker Flat doesn't necessarily fall on either side, but Steve Bug
>is most certainly a techno icon. Kompakt is another label that defies
>even the most simple classifications, right up to the latest EP by
>SCSI-9 (which discogs files under "Minimal, Ambient, House"). John
>Tejada produces a wide variety of styles, but I'd call even his housiest
>efforts (stuff on Palette and Playhouse) techno. Terms like "microhouse"
>attempt to distance the most minimal techno from the tougher stuff, but
>I don't see any need for that distinction. I'd like to think that
>peoples' tastes are diverse enough that they would appreciate both ends
>of the spectrum.
>
>I'd say that house is really just a style of techno--one defined by a
>more narrow tempo range and a smaller subset of instruments and
>structures. Under that classification scheme, it's easy for me to call
>most of what I play "techno". ;)
>
>Cheerio,
>--
>shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen
>

From sfraves-return-114477-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Aug 05 22:35:29 2004

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Message-ID: <20040805223524.42113.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 5 Aug 2004 15:35:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040805214333.GO575@hubble>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

--- shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net> wrote:
> I'd say that house is really just a style of techno--one defined by a
> more narrow tempo range and a smaller subset of instruments and
> structures. Under that classification scheme, it's easy for me to
> call
> most of what I play "techno". ;)

I'd agree with most of what you said, but I would tend to classify the
two as parallel branches of the same tree- the 4-on-the-floor tree. 
House, I think has as wide or wider a pallete of acceptable sounds than
techno does.  There is organic, live-playing-laden house, there's
rough, techy house, there's house that can hardly even be called
"House" but for sharing the signature bounce and mindframe house comes
from.  Techno by its very definition, is "techy", as in, largely
created out of synthetic or greatly altered sounds.  There are live
instruments in techno here and there, but I think they appear mainly
for contrast or novelty's sake.  Techno, also, is known for its rigid,
unswung timing- machine-like.  When techno swings, people call it
tech-house (or funky techno), because house's biggest defining factor
is just that, its swing.  It starts with that and then the sounds that
follow that pattern take on an attitude from that rythmic "soul", so to
speak.

..and then, when you flatten out the timing of house, to make it latin,
or more techy, those very sounds that earlier were informed by the
swing that house embodies are what keeps ties to the "house" sound.  So
you have house that feels like techno and sounds like house, and house
that feels like house but sounds like techno.  In the end, because of
the inclusion of one or more elements from the other genre, the
boundaries are stretched- but everyone's got a line in them that once
something crosses to this side, the left brain says "house!", and to
that side, "techno!".

To me, it's the swing, and the mood, that delineates them.  Then again,
maybe it's best not to give a shit! :)

GeorgeC
www.djorigami.com

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: Carceri <booking@djcarceri.com>
Reply-To: booking@djcarceri.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY1-F33x1kLwxTQTYk00000e37@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

I'm glad you checked out the mix. My posting was a bit
tongue in cheek... I don't actually think of myself as
a shitty "techno" dj. Techno for lack of a better
term. I think it applies to most of the electronic
music that I enjoy. I stopped using the term
tech-house. Although i play techno and house, there
was just too much bullshit music coming out labeling
itself "tech-house". I think any of the
"micro-genre's" get boring when layed down for an hour
straight.

Techno =
Electro
Banging Loop Techno
Soulful Melodic Techno
Micro-Glitch whatever
ElectroClash haha
Acid House
House (Tech or not)
Broken Beat/Nu Jazz
Beat Down
Boogie Disco
Disco Punk
All kinds of Wave
Down Tempo
D&B
Neptunes
Missy Elliot
Outkast
Dance Hall/Reggae

It's all techno to me. GeorgeC gave a pretty good
interpritation of relation between 4/4 house and
techno, but once it goes past the 4/4 it's back to the
drawing board. So fuck it.

From sfraves-return-114482-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Aug 06 01:20:04 2004
