Received: (qmail 67308 invoked from network); 6 Aug 2004 01:20:01 -0000
Date: Thu, 5 Aug 2004 18:19:57 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040806011957.GQ575@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20040805214333.GO575@hubble> <20040805223524.42113.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
In-Reply-To: <20040805223524.42113.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

Heh, part of me just wants to play the devil's advocate here because I
just love talking about music. But this is a genuinely interesting
discussion, and I think it needs to be continued...

quoth newstylesound:
> --- shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net> wrote:
> > I'd say that house is really just a style of techno--one defined by
> > a more narrow tempo range and a smaller subset of instruments and
> > structures. Under that classification scheme, it's easy for me to
> > call most of what I play "techno". ;)
> 
> I'd agree with most of what you said, but I would tend to classify the
> two as parallel branches of the same tree- the 4-on-the-floor tree.
> House, I think has as wide or wider a pallete of acceptable sounds
> than techno does.

I don't agree with that at all! Techno includes in its palette all the
sounds of house, *in addition to* the infinite number of derivative
sounds that can be formed from various effects and manipulations.
Instruments shared by both styles are (for the most part) limited to
specific uses in house music, whereas techno prides itself on the
ability to misuse and abuse them.

Historically, techno was built on the sounds of house music, some of
which ended up getting twisted into completely new sounds that separated
the music they were part of from the realm of house. But then house
ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both styles
have been collectively referred to by the public as "techno", for better
or for worse.

> There is organic, live-playing-laden house, there's rough, techy
> house, there's house that can hardly even be called "House" but for
> sharing the signature bounce and mindframe house comes from.

Well, the same can be said for any style of electronic music. :)

> Techno by its very definition, is "techy", as in, largely created out
> of synthetic or greatly altered sounds.  There are live instruments in
> techno here and there, but I think they appear mainly for contrast or
> novelty's sake.  Techno, also, is known for its rigid, unswung timing-
> machine-like. 

OK, how about so-called "UK tech", then (Grant Dell, Gideon Jackson,
Richard Grey, et al): house or techno? By your definition, most of the
stuff these guys put out is techno because it uses "techy" percussion
and lacks swing. But I don't really know anyone that would refer to it
as "techno". I'd call it "tech-house", but...

> When techno swings, people call it tech-house (or funky techno),
> because house's biggest defining factor is just that, its swing.  It
> starts with that and then the sounds that follow that pattern take on
> an attitude from that rythmic "soul", so to speak.

First of all, there's a ton of house that lacks any swing whatsoever
(see above). There's also a ton of techno that's swung to all hell
(albeit, sometimes just for the sake of being off-kilter). And as for
"soul", the term itself is open to much interpretation. Attitude is a
much more worthy delineating factor, since house generally tends toward
the happier, more celebratory end of the emotional spectrum. But
obviously, all but the most contrived styles of electronic music are
capable of conveying a wide variety of emotions, so that's no good.

> So you have house that feels like techno and sounds like house, and
> house that feels like house but sounds like techno.  In the end,
> because of the inclusion of one or more elements from the other genre,
> the boundaries are stretched- but everyone's got a line in them that
> once something crosses to this side, the left brain says "house!", and
> to that side, "techno!".

That's exactly right. What I'd like to do is move that line further to
the left... because I think a lot of people are missing out on a ton of
really great music that suffers from being difficult to categorize. I
think house heads would appreciate a lot of what I refer to as "techno",
and I'm sure that some techno elitists would be into some of the stuff
that's often labeled as "house".

In general, I think people need to be more open-minded about electronic
music. Too many parties focus specifically on one style, neglecting
large swaths of the musical landscape because they don't match a certain
tempo range or "attitude". DJs cling to certain structures and sounds...
we're all guilty of it.

Sure, we've all got preferences, but I think there's a complacency among
performers and listeners alike that we need to escape. Personally, I
don't go out that much because I can't stand to hear the same shit all
night, good or not. Variety is the spice of life, you know.

I think Jack Triumph was actually on to something a couple of months
ago... we need more music reviews on this list. Let me offer up some of
my more recent ones:

Echopilot - I Don't Think So (Traum Shallplatten; Traum V49)
Bernhard Pucher is best known as the founder of the groundbreaking US
label Iron Box Music. Under his Echopilot guise, he tends to explore the
same themes as he does as Brian Aneurysm: particularly, loneliness. On
"Schwamm", Pucher displays a surprising vocal talent, pining "wie kann
es sein; wie kann ich so allein sein" (essentially, "I'm so alone") over
interlocking synths, bleeps and stuttering percussion. "Optical Centre"
(my favorite of the four) is a similarly rare moment of sublime
happiness that pairs his trademark quirky percussion with a bouncey
bassline and airy, freestyle keyboard flourishes. Both the title track
and "Finstere Zeiten" are more typical Brian Aneurysm material, with
Pucher's omninous, barely-sung vocals anchored by distorted scratches,
detuned drones and shuffled drum patterns. While a far cry from the
emotive sonic landscapes of his work with vocalist Cristy Jordan, these
two tracks are nonetheless useful tools in the hands of a capable DJ
looking to darken the mood a bit.

Audion - Kisses (Spectral Sound; SPC-15)
IMO, Matthew Dear missed the mark completely with his two most recent
attempts, "Anger Management" and the "Backstroke" mini-LP. There were
highlights, sure, but the overall quality of the releases made me wonder
whether or not Dear (and Spectral, for that matter) had simply lost his
steam. Well, if this release is any indication, Matthew and his label
seem to have found their stride once again. "Kisses" catches Dear at his
hardest and meanest yet, combining a relentless sub-bass and aggressive
modulating synth drone with his signature wild percussion--make no
mistake, this is one serious peak-time rollercoaster. On the flip, the
aptly-named "Titty Fuck" is an awkward, lumbering number that slowly
ratches up the mood with equal parts percussion and atonal synthesis,
building to an almost anticlimactic plateau of evil, grinding confusion.
"The Great Compromise" is only a compromise if you're debating the
merits of breakbeat and four-on-the-floor drum patterns. It starts off
with the former, injecting klanging mechanical stabs into the offbeat,
then evolves into the latter, forming a relentless minimal techno jam
reminiscent of his work on Richie Hawtin's Plus 8 label. This release
bodes well for the future of Spectral Sound. My only hope is that Mr.
Dear and his patronly label can muster the courage to release more stuff
like this.

John Tejada & Arian Leviste - Psycho Happiness (Palette; PAL-30)
What is John Tejada, if not consistent? Well, he's quirky as all hell of
late. Whether composing solo, or paired with like-minded composers like
Arian Leviste and Justin Maxwell, Tejada's style shines through as
uniquely interesting, deftly combining the techniques of more
experimental artists with a solid understanding of dance music theory.
"Psycho Happiness" is no exception, working equally well as either a
stand-alone piece or a DJ tool. The title track is a jacking long
player, rife with microsampled snippits lovingly arranged between
percussive elements for maximum dancefloor damage. On the flip, "Ghetto
Platypus" is a much more Perlon-esque adventure, with its downsampled
bleeps and scratches. "Me Always Want Go There" goes there, much more
funkily than the rest of the EP, notching up the chunk factor with a
saturated bass tones, and filling in the empty spaces with noisy (in a
good way) percussive flair. Tejada has made a name for himself by
consistently pulling off the stoney vibe of dubby techno with a
completely different sonic palette (hah). Much respect.

Rob Acid - Something (Treibstoff 2044)
Cologne's Robert Babicz isn't somebody I would've expected to see on
Treibstoff, and I was curious to hear what he's been up to. This EP
works, but it isn't for everybody. Neither of the tracks is very
DJ-friendly, with over-saturated compositions that lack traditional
build-ups and tear-downs, and lots of synths that are hard to get rid of
in the mix. That said... "Something" is my pick of the two, with its
deep, rolling bass and driving kick supporting the ever-present
discordant synth stabs and bizarre cello (?) croon. On the flip,
"Ceremony" is a spacey deep techno number with lots of airy synth
elements occupying a good deal of the frequency range--in fact, it gets
a bit too "tonal" for my tastes. This isn't your typical Treibstoff
fare, but I'm sure there's a time and a place for stuff like this...
Probably at home at night, baked out of your mind.

Monne Automne - Introducing Light & Sound (Lofi Stereo 026)
Lucien Nicolet heads the cast of a new outfit with WMF Records artist
Bucci and the little-known vocalist Argenis Brito, who collaborated with
SeÃ±or Coconut on his Latin Kraftwerkremake project, "El Baile AlemÃ¡n"
("The German Dance"). Their first release is a mini-LP of sorts,
containing a nice mix of minimal house and electro. "Teco" opens the A
side, pairing filtered electro percussion and bass with soft synth
stabs, for a distinctly retro feel that's probably more appropriate for
the lounge crowd than big dancefloors. On the inside, "Automne" is a
deep, dubby number that should be at home in the box of Mosaic fans,
with understated tribal percussive bits and a rolling, spacey vibe. On
the flip, "Argelulupier", "Mago" and "El Salvador" combine clicky
breakbeats with detuned IDM-style synths and subtle arrangements that
float from start to finish. Like Rob Acid's, this release isn't for
everyone... especially those that can't be bothered with much more than
the most straightforward club tracks. But for those of you looking for
something a bit more interesting, this should be a treat.

Anyone else? ;)

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

a tiny apartment in a dangerous neighborhood.

BlankI'm so down with this....

"In general, I think people need to be more open-minded about electronic
music. Too many parties focus specifically on one style, neglecting
large swaths of the musical landscape because they don't match a certain
tempo range or "attitude". DJs cling to certain structures and sounds...
we're all guilty of it."

I myself have been trying to find different genres that I can =
succesfully mix into my sets to give them more spice. Of course, I still =
mainly stick to braks - but some tech-house, prog., techno ,house and =
other assorted things give it zest...

Nothing wrong with mixin' it up a bit.

M-

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Great Point Shawn!

On 5 August 2004, electrofunk138 wrote:

> BlankI'm so down with this....
>
> "In general, I think people need to be more open-minded about electronic
> music. Too many parties focus specifically on one style, neglecting
> large swaths of the musical landscape because they don't match a certain
> tempo range or "attitude". DJs cling to certain structures and sounds...
> we're all guilty of it."
>
> I myself have been trying to find different genres that I can
> succesfully mix into my sets to give them more spice. Of course, I
> still mainly stick to braks - but some tech-house, prog., techno
> ,house and other assorted things give it zest...
>
> Nothing wrong with mixin' it up a bit.

I ended up doing exactly this at a gig in the midwest this past weekend,
even though it was unintentional. :)  I noticed the crowd looked to be a
bit more on the mellow/older tip, so I started off with house.  Saw that
wasn't getting a reaction, so I started ramping it up through
progressive house, tech house and then ended with straight up bangin'
techno.  THAT was what they wanted all along.

Should have known that the midwest was still into the harder stuff. :)



http://www.jcthedj.com

I'll be waking up very soon safely back on my own planet, I just know it

From: DJ Soundwave <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>
To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040806011957.GQ575@hubble>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <20040805214333.GO575@hubble> <20040805223524.42113.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com> <20040806011957.GQ575@hubble>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno" DJs

shawn said:
> the music they were part of from the realm of house. But then house
> ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both styles
> have been collectively referred to by the public as "techno", for better
> or for worse.

sorry, is this actually true? maybe it's just a Chicago thing, maybe
it's just a me thing, but in the late 80s there were only two types of
people I knew who couldn't tell the difference between house and
techno -- grade-obsessed hyper-competitive nerdy types, and people
over 35. I mean even conservative guys who I knew through my parents'
church, suburban high school kids who loved Led Zeppelin and hated
both house **and** techno, they still knew that there was a difference
between them. but the guys I'm thinking of, one of them's an engineer
for rock bands now, and the other is a professional opera singer. so
they had more musical background than the average member of the
public, so maybe they're not a representative sample. I'm not sure.
but this statement that I'm quoting here, honestly, it just doesn't
feel true to me at all. something about that statement just feels so
totally wrong to me. I don't know. anyway. whatever.

-- 
DJ Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com

http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3

original breaks tracks and remixes:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/out_there.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3

original drum and bass tracks:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/fremont.mp3
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3

political underground hip-hop track:
http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3

graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
http://www.bowkett.net

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: "DJ Soundwave" <dj.soundwave@gmail.com>

> shawn said:
> > the music they were part of from the realm of house. But then house
> > ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both styles
> > have been collectively referred to by the public as "techno", for better
> > or for worse.
>
> sorry, is this actually true? maybe it's just a Chicago thing, maybe
> it's just a me thing, but in the late 80s there were only two types of
> people I knew who couldn't tell the difference between house and
> techno -- grade-obsessed hyper-competitive nerdy types, and people
> over 35. I mean even conservative guys who I knew through my parents'
> church, suburban high school kids who loved Led Zeppelin and hated
> both house **and** techno, they still knew that there was a difference
> between them. but the guys I'm thinking of, one of them's an engineer
> for rock bands now, and the other is a professional opera singer. so
> they had more musical background than the average member of the
> public, so maybe they're not a representative sample. I'm not sure.
> but this statement that I'm quoting here, honestly, it just doesn't
> feel true to me at all. something about that statement just feels so
> totally wrong to me. I don't know. anyway. whatever.
>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Bang the Drum

--=====================_1234404==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

It's time to Bang The Drum, as we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the 
World's Longest-Running Hip-Hop Radio Show. The particulars:

When: Sunday, August 8th, 1 PM - 5 PM
Where: Casino Meadow (a/k/a Bunny Meadow).  Enter Golden Gate Park at the 
6th Ave. and Fulton entrance, and follow the signs and sounds.  For a map 
of the Casino Meadow location and driving directions, check 
<http://www.mapquest.com/maps/map.adp?country=US&countryid=US&addtohistory=&searchtab=address&searchtype=address&address=6th+Avenue+%26+Fulton&city=San+Francisco&state=CA&zipcode=&search=++Search++>mapquest.com. 


What: An incredible celebration for the world's longest-running Hip-Hop 
radio show: The Drum, at KZSU Stanford.
Cost: Free.  That's right.  FREE.

Come be a part of history, as 20 MCs, 20 DJs, a host of lunatics and you 
and yours descend on Casino Meadow and represent lovely for 20 years of 
mayhem on air. Some of the madmen performing include:

Chuck D, Rasco, Felonious, RZA, Hieroglyphics, Davey D, Beni B, Friendly 
Traveler, Apollo, Vinroc, Planet Asia, Foreign Legion, LCJ, Derrick D, 
Noble House, Third Sight, Motion Man, Paris, The Greans Crew, and more and 
more and more. . .

Yiiiiikes. Make no mistake, this will be one for the ages; with a 
B-Boy/B-Girl exhibition, Graf Showcase, and outdoors, all-ages, love 
vibe.  And don't forget the afterparty at Milk: 1840 Haight St in San 
Francisco, from 10PM -2AM.  Don't Miss It; and feel free to forward this 
email to all your friends, folks, cousins and peoples.





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

> > > > ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both styles
> > > > have been collectively referred to by the public as "techno", for
> better
> > > > or for worse.
> > >
> > > sorry, is this actually true? maybe it's just a Chicago thing, maybe
> > > it's just a me thing, but in the late 80s there were only two types of
> > > people I knew who couldn't tell the difference between house and
> > > techno -- grade-obsessed hyper-competitive nerdy types, and people
> > > over 35. I mean even conservative guys who I knew through my parents'
> > > church, suburban high school kids who loved Led Zeppelin and hated
> > > both house **and** techno, they still knew that there was a difference
> > > between them. but the guys I'm thinking of, one of them's an engineer
> > > for rock bands now, and the other is a professional opera singer. so
> > > they had more musical background than the average member of the
> > > public, so maybe they're not a representative sample. I'm not sure.
> > > but this statement that I'm quoting here, honestly, it just doesn't
> > > feel true to me at all. something about that statement just feels so
> > > totally wrong to me. I don't know. anyway. whatever.
> > >
> > > --
> > > DJ Soundwave
> > > www.djsoundwave.com
> > >
> > > 20 minute mini breaks mix:
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/short_sharp_shock.mp3
> > >
> > > original breaks tracks and remixes:
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/out_there.mp3
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/word_up.mp3
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/example.mp3
> > >
> > > original drum and bass tracks:
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/fremont.mp3
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/coffee.mp3
> > >
> > > political underground hip-hop track:
> > > http://www.djsoundwave.com/docs/gangsta.mp3
> > >
> > > graphic design, paintings, space bunnies:
> > > http://www.bowkett.net

From sfraves-return-114508-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Aug 06 18:41:27 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114508-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 79665 invoked by uid 1103); 6 Aug 2004 18:41:27 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 79650 invoked from network); 6 Aug 2004 18:41:27 -0000
Message-Id: <6.1.2.0.2.20040806114001.0243fa48@localhost>
X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.2.0
Date: Fri, 06 Aug 2004 11:41:27 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_2152074==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Pimping, Music and Muscle Ripping

--=====================_2152074==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

A couple of days ago I sprained my ankle.  Level 2 sprain, it seems, with 
swelling and significant pain.  So I'm chair-bound with an ice pack on my 
ankle, chock full of pain killers and anti-inflammatory drugs, pretty 
spaced out, importing tracks from my CD collection into I Tunes.  Forgive 
any drug-induced errors:)  Since I have nothing else I can do, I thought 
I'd write to you whilst listening to all this amazing music -- much of 
which I haven't heard in many years.

I have lots of music on CDs, but I was surprised at the number of excellent 
old school hip hop and rap tracks in the collection.  Practically every 
musical genre is represented in the stacks, with a heavy emphasis on house 
(of course), industrial and punk rock.  Good heavens, I've discovered CD 
house compilations from the late 80's that feature covers advertising 
"underground" dance music with tattooed guys in combat boots dancing 
pictured in the art.

Ah yes...and Motown.  Listening to "First I Look at the Purse" by the 
Contours right now.  The lyrics describe a gold digger.  Used to play this 
stuff at high school dances.

I'm sampling each CD, taking out the tracks I really like and classifying 
them for use in Final Scratch, Ableton Live, some serious remixing, etc., 
and just enjoyment on the I POD.  I've become disenchanted at the sound 
quality delivered by the I Trip device and I think I required a better way 
to listen to this music in my ride.

Segue.  Pimping my ride.

The past few weeks have been dark and stressful for me.  My only brother 
had two heart attacks, "died" twice, had six valves replaced in his heart 
and returned home to find his heroin-addicted son had attempted 
suicide.   The very intimate communications with my brother recently have 
warped me back to my teenage years.  Back then, my brother and I loved 
three things:  music, cars and sex.  We may have disagreed on the sex, but 
we worked on the music and cars together.  We organized a rock band, the 
Undertakers, with Greg on keyboards and me on drums and, often, bass 
guitar.  I also DJed with my friend Bill.  As  for cars, they were powerful 
and neither of us were interested in "stock" offerings.  My pimped up 1960 
Buick Invicta Convertible --- there was a ride.  Several GTOs.  The '69 
Firebird Transam.  Old Vets.

So....I have not indulged my automotive "weaknesses" for many years, 
focusing on more gas-saving, practical vehicles.  A few years ago I began 
to notice, however, the wonderful things Asian boys were doing to their 
Hondas.  One could achieve some compromise here.  Then, one fateful 
evening, Jim, a veritable bellwether of pop culture, came for his regular 
Monday evening dinner with us.   After dinner, we are "forced" to watch 
makeover shows, reality TV and such.  I rarely watch TV these days, but one 
show that came on after some crazy  bi dudes in the nude fighting with 
snakes or something caught my interest:  "Pimp My Ride."  There are many 
other shows that document auto personalization, I discovered, but this was 
the first I watched.  On this particular episode they took a truly wack 
1985 Datsun station wagon owned by a DJ and transformed it into a most 
amazing vehicle, complete with turntables, amps, DAT recorder and many 
other visually artistic enhancements.

I began research to pimp my Toyota Matrix XRS that very night.  Good car 
with which to work.  She already has a Celica GT engine, and TRD (Toyota 
Racing Development) has made a number of aftermarket enhancements 
available, including suspensions, turbochargers, cold air intakes and tuned 
exhausts.  Further, others make all manner of fun things that can be added 
to the body and interior.

Started with the wheels, and went for advice to a shop managed by those 
experienced in this area.  I decided on G games light weight racing 
wheels:  the 2-piece Falcons http://www.i-m-racing.com/ggamesbyrays.html. 
Very nice.  Tires are Bridgestone high performance Potenza S03 pole 
position.  The back wheels are slighting bigger than the front.

Inside I replaced the dash and other facings with some high tech looking 
stuff, had some aluminum cut for the floors, put racing pedals on the 
clutch, break and throttle, and a few TRD enhancements.

Next the sound system.  This is where MP3 players come in.  I wanted a 
device that could play MP3 CDs that I burned on the computer and interfaced 
with my I Pod, so I selected the Blaupunkt Seattle as a receiver.  I also 
installed an Alpine MRP-M350 amp under the seat and put a JL Audio 10" 
subwoofer in the cargo area.  Sweet.  There is apparently a whole 
subculture devoted to JL Audio products.  The subwoofer is enclosed and I 
can easily remove it if I wish to free up hauling space.

I see this as a work in progress.  What next?:)  I'm also feeling guilty as 
hell about all this at times.  Catholic guilt.  One side of me positions 
this pimping as artistic expression;  the practical, thrifty side of my 
soul, however, sees this as pure, silly self-indulgence.

All in all, though, I'm having much fun pimping my ride.

Love,

Apollo



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_2152074==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Great Point Shawn!

quoth J.C.:
> Should have known that the midwest was still into the harder stuff. :)

Obviously, the environment in which people live affects their tastes a
lot. Techno originated in the abandoned warehouses of post-industrial
Detroit. And let's not forget the Swedes: there's nothing like days
without sunshine and constant sub-zero temperatures to bring out some of
the most aggressive music on the planet. I discovered IDM ("techno", I
suppose) when I was living in Nebraska, of all places. 

Heh, now that I think of it, maybe that's one of the reasons why techno
isn't so popular out here in the Bay Area. It's temperate and
comfortable, diverse in ethnicity, and lush in plant and wildlife.
Living is relatively easy out here if you can afford it, and it's hard
to be bored when there's so much art and culture within a stone's throw
of wherever you are. When I think of the people I know that grew up
here, I can't imagine any of them being angry, spiteful kids.

Not that you have to be angry or spiteful to appreciated it (I'm sure
not), but like punk, goth and industrial, I think techno appeals to
people that are more inclined to express and explore their dark side.
"Live evil", so they say.

Cheerio,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

Date: Fri, 6 Aug 2004 12:42:19 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040806194219.GA575@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20040805214333.GO575@hubble> <20040805223524.42113.qmail@web60305.mail.yahoo.com> <20040806011957.GQ575@hubble> <4688f311040806111333dbf845@mail.gmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <4688f311040806111333dbf845@mail.gmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

quoth DJ Soundwave:
> shawn said:
> > the music they were part of from the realm of house. But then house
> > ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both
> > styles have been collectively referred to by the public as "techno",
> > for better or for worse.
> 
> sorry, is this actually true? maybe it's just a Chicago thing, maybe
> it's just a me thing, but in the late 80s there were only two types of
> people I knew who couldn't tell the difference between house and
> techno -- grade-obsessed hyper-competitive nerdy types, and people
> over 35.

Heh yeah, I was talking more about the public at large. I'm 23, so it's
probably unfair for me to be making blanket statements about how people
viewed music in the late 80's. But that's what I've gathered from my
reading, and from my own experience. At least, by the time I was into
electronic music ('93), everything was being referred to collectively as
"techno".

We ravers are a bit more meticulous in our classification, but my point
is that even in our community there's a debate over what really
qualifies as techno. What I should have said in the the previous email
was that maybe it's not so wrong to label everything as "techno",
because it seems to me that historically, techno has had a more
long-lasting influence on other styles than they've had on it. House and
trance are getting "techier". Breaks and hip-hop are increasingly
"glitchy". Rock bands are using analog drum machines and synthesizers
again. For crying out loud, Two Lone Swordsmen did an instrumental
version of Ricardo Villalobos' "Dexter" for his "Alcachofa Remixes" EP.

I'm not saying that what's traditionally referred to as "techno" (i.e.,
the harder drum trax) will usurp all the other styles of EDM. But I do
think that soon, people will have to stop thinking of techno as the ugly
duckling of electronic music. Because at some point, it may become
difficult to distinguish your favorite styles from some of the "techno"
that's being produced today. Does that make any sense? :)

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Is a "drug dealer" a pharmacist or a petty criminal? 

--=====================_13692518==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Love this Jon Carroll that appeared in the SF Chronicle this morning:

<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/08/06/DDGIJ7OAF91.DTL>JON 
CARROLL
- <mailto:jcarroll@sfchronicle.com>Jon Carroll
Friday, August 6, 2004

Sometimes, when my tiny head is spinning with disinfotainment and other 
artifacts of the mediasphere, I try to think what archaeologists and social 
historians 2,000 years from now might make of our particular little epoch. 
How, for instance, would they parse the word "drug"?

Is a "drug dealer" a pharmacist or a petty criminal? When we talk about 
"reasonably priced drugs for seniors," are we discussing marijuana or 
Lipitor? What would they make of the fact that the last four 
administrations have declared a "war on drugs" while taking money from drug 
companies?

Why is it bad when residents of Colombia build mansions from profits on the 
sale of drugs, but it's good when residents of Newport, R.I., do the same 
thing?

When one person cannot live without "lifesaving drugs," we express great 
sympathy, unless that person is a "drug addict," in which case we may even 
throw him in jail. When a mood-altering drug is sold in pill form in 
stores, it's called an antidepressant and hailed as a medical breakthrough. 
When a mood-altering drug is sold on the streets, it's called felony drug 
trafficking and subject to stiff criminal penalties.

Because we are native speakers of American, we can wend our way through the 
contradictions. We know that the bad drugs are the ones the cause euphoria 
and impair judgment, unless the drug is alcohol, but that's not ever called 
a drug, so there's no confusion there. We know that the good drugs are the 
ones that cure diseases or relieve symptoms, except sometimes the good 
drugs are ineffective or even counterproductive in achieving those goals. 
Street dealers do not finance experimental trials on the effectiveness of 
the drugs they sell. Drug companies do, but they fudge the results. Street 
dealers have a small feedback loop because customers can tell pretty 
quickly whether they're loaded or not. Drug companies have a long feedback 
loop because human beings can't instantly tell whether their cholesterol is 
being lowered or their blood thinned or their insulin production stimulated.

A drug with a long feedback loop is clearly more profitable than one with a 
short feedback loop because the dealer can keep an ineffective drug on the 
shelves much longer. Interestingly, the people who sell ineffective drugs 
are generally said to have made "honest mistakes."

If a street dealer sold you an ineffective drug, you could take five of 
your friends and go back and have a brisk conversation with him. If a 
behind- the-counter dealer sold you an ineffective drug, you'd have to hire 
a lawyer and file a lawsuit and maybe, maybe, 10 years later you'd get some 
money, although probably you'd be dead by then.

Street dealers don't have patents on their drugs, which means that they'll 
always have plenty of competition. Drug companies do have patents, so they 
can set their prices without worrying about market economics. And when 
their patents run out, they can put out a drug with a slightly different 
formulation, promote it like mad and sell the new drug in a monopolistic 
setting.

You have to wonder when street dealers are going to come up with Cocaine XR 
or LSD Reditabs.

Since the street dealer works in a competitive atmosphere, he has to keep 
his prices relatively low. In order to increase his profitability, he can 
"step on" his product, that is, dilute it. It would be unwise for a drug 
company to adulterate its product, but since it owns a monopoly, it can set 
prices artificially high and achieve the same profitability levels.

A street dealer who knowingly poisons his clientele is called "the scum of 
the earth." A drug corporation that knowingly poisons its clientele is 
called "a tobacco company."

People who sell illegal drugs often rot in jail for 20 or 30 years. People 
who sell legal drugs are often forced to attend tedious daylong board 
meetings. People who take illegal drugs are called "losers." People who 
take legal drugs are called "everyone in America."

Glad I'm not an archaeologist in 4040; my brain would ache a whole lot.

----------
One pill makes you larger, and one pill puts you in jail, and please do not 
operate heavy machinery with the ones that mother gives you.

Driving that train, high on ethyl 4-1-piperidinecarboxylate, just like 
<mailto:jcarroll@sfchronicle.com>jcarroll@sfchronicle.com.

Page E - 24
URL: 
http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/08/06/DDGIJ7OAF91.DTL 




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] Rick James Bio, Etc.

--=====================_16826435==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Rick James (February 1, 1948 - August 6, 2004) was a U.S. funk and
soul recording and performing artist. He was born James Johnson, Jr.

He was most prolific during the late 1970's and early 1980's. He was
a singer, keyboardist, bassist, producer, arranger, and composer. He
performed mostly with his back-up band, the Stone City Band.

James' breakthrough single was "You And I", an eight-minute magnum
opus from his debut album Come Get It. But the song he is most
famous for is his 1981 hit "Superfreak" (from his 1981 concept album
Street Songs), which served as the basis for MC Hammer's 1991 Grammy
award-winning song "U Can't Touch This." His other hits
include "Give it to Me Baby," "Cold Blooded," and "17." He recorded
primarily for Gordy and Motown Records.

But it was the dark side of James' life that overpowered his music.
He was an occasional drug addict, addicted mostly to cocaine. In
1993, James was convicted of assulting two women (one of the assults
was during one of his cocaine binges). Serving two years in Folsom
Prison did not stop him from writing new songs, even if he did it
behind bars. James was released in 1995.

James attempted a comeback with a new album and tour in 1997, but
suffered a mild stroke during a concert in Denver, effectively
ending his musical career.

Before his stroke, James was interviewed for the VH1 series Behind
The Music, and for the first time spoke openly about his life and
his battle with drugs.

Ironically, a Behind the Music-style skit on the sketch comedy show
Chappelle's Show looked back on interactions between Charlie Murphy
and James in the 1980s. The skit depicted Rick James as an
egotistical, misogynistic cocaine addict who constantly reminded
people "I'm Rick James, bitch!" which has become something of a
catch phrase. The skit starred Dave Chappelle as James and Charlie
Murphy playing himself, with interspersed interview segments with
James.

Rick James was found dead on August 6, 2004 in his home by his
caretaker. James died presumedly of natural causes. He leaves behind
three children, Tazman, Ty, and Rick James, Jr.

Scheduled for release in September/October 2004 is the DVD Rick
James: Rockpalast Live, which features a 1982 concert performance
from Essen, Germany.

Discography:

Come Get It (1978)
Bustin' Out of L Seven (1979)
Fire It Up (1979)
Garden of Love (1980)
Street Songs (1981; deluxe edition released 2001)
Throwin' Down (1982)
Cold Blooded (1983)
Reflections (1984)
Glow (1985)
The Flag (1986)
Wonderful (1988)
Bustin' Out: The Very Best of Rick James (1994)
Urban Rapsody (1997)
Anthology (2002)






Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Actually this matter bounced around a little bit on
the 313 list. They were from Detroit. They all went to
school in Belleville for a few years. It wasn't until
they moved back to Detroit that they started to
produce tracks.

> dude, techno originated in the SUBURBS of
> post-industrial Detroit.
> seriously, Juan Atkins, Derrick May, these kids were
> from a suburb
> nearby called like Belleville or something. they had
> to steal their
> mom's cars just to get into the city.
>

quoth Carceri:
> > dude, techno originated in the SUBURBS of post-industrial Detroit.
> > seriously, Juan Atkins, Derrick May, these kids were from a suburb
> > nearby called like Belleville or something. they had to steal their
> > mom's cars just to get into the city.

> Actually this matter bounced around a little bit on the 313 list. They
> were from Detroit. They all went to school in Belleville for a few
> years. It wasn't until they moved back to Detroit that they started to
> produce tracks.

Regardless, I was speaking generally... not of where the actual tracks
were produced, but where they were *experienced* originally and gained
popularity with nerdy white boys. :)

FWIW, here are some quotes from the book "Modulations" that might be of
some interest:

"Detroit's an industrial city. It's a wasteland of ideas. Detroit is the
type of place where you can only dream of what the rest of the world is
like."
-- Derrick May

"It's all called techno or dance music now, 'cause it's all electronic
music created with technological equipment. Maybe that should be the
only name, 'dance music', because everybody has a different vision of
what techno is now."
-- Kevin Saunderson

Cheers,

  aim://shawnpallen

At 04:21 PM 8/6/2004, shawn allen wrote:

>FWIW, here are some quotes from the book "Modulations" that might be of
>some interest:

Good book.


>"It's all called techno or dance music now, 'cause it's all electronic
>music created with technological equipment. Maybe that should be the
>only name, 'dance music', because everybody has a different vision of
>what techno is now."
>-- Kevin Saunderson

Pretty much sums up my position these days.  Dance music is what we started 
with back in the seventies, and that seems to be the essence of what we do 
-- now with technology rather than expensive studios.

Some of the genre/subgenre charts folks produce these days look like the 
work of librarians:)  Does it move your ass and soul?  That's all that 
really matters.

Love,

Apollo




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_20157414==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] Drugged and Keys missing at Space 550, Barneveld - Astral Projections

------=_NextPart_000_003B_01C47C13.6537E000
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Dear all,

This is probably something most of you already know, but for those who =
dont, please read on:

I attended Astral Projections at Space 550 - Barneveld last Saturday - =
July 31st and like a complete idiot took my Mercedes Benz and parked it =
right outside Barneveld before
going in.=20

Later, I believe I was drugged, something put in my drink while I was
dancing - because I fell to the ground onto my knees, and couldn't even =
stand up
straight; I practically had to crawl to my car. That night I had a total =
of 2.5 double gins with redbull through a period of a few hours - not =
enough alcohol to make me crumble like a rag doll; my car keys were =
missing from my pocket, and I later found that my registration docs. had =
been taken from my car.

I told the lady who helped me into my cab that I thought my keys had =
been stolen and also the cab driver, and by some wonderful stroke of =
luck - probably because my car was parked directly in front of =
Barneveld, and maybe because they might have told the bouncers up front, =
that my car was still there the next morning.=20

Space 550 has not returned a single one of my phone calls, Thump Radio =
suggested I call Space 550 and Astral Projections people were not to be =
heard from. So much for the peace and love feeling.

A complete police report has been filed on this incident. Trance dancing =
is
something that is supposed to let you be free and be yourself, I think =
there
are people who are trying to take advantage of us while we are doing our
thing and trusting everyone around us.=20

I hope this doesn't happen to others elsewhere, and I'm hoping this is =
just something related to Barneveld, which very well could be, given =
it's Bayview address... I actually didn't know Space 550 was in a "bad" =
neighbourhood; I do now and I'm not going back.

Please be careful and look out for each other when you're having fun, =
there are seriously evil people lurking in the shadows. Part of my =
problem was that I went alone, dont make the same mistakes I did.

Vidur
------=_NextPart_000_003B_01C47C13.6537E000--

>knees, and couldn't even stand up straight; I practically had

>gins with redbull through a period of a few hours - not enough 
>alcohol to make me crumble like a rag doll; my car keys were 
>missing from my pocket, and I later found that my registration 
>docs. had been taken from my car.
>

>keys had been stolen and also the cab driver, and by some 
>wonderful stroke of luck - probably because my car was parked 
>directly in front of Barneveld, and maybe because they might 
>have told the bouncers up front, that my car was still there 
>the next morning. 
>
>Space 550 has not returned a single one of my phone calls, 
>Thump Radio suggested I call Space 550 and Astral Projections 
>people were not to be heard from. So much for the peace and 
>love feeling.
>
>A complete police report has been filed on this incident. 
>Trance dancing is something that is supposed to let you be 
>free and be yourself, I think there are people who are trying 
>to take advantage of us while we are doing our thing and 
>trusting everyone around us. 
>
>I hope this doesn't happen to others elsewhere, and I'm hoping 
>this is just something related to Barneveld, which very well 
>could be, given it's Bayview address... I actually didn't know 
>Space 550 was in a "bad" neighbourhood; I do now and I'm not 
>going back.
>
>Please be careful and look out for each other when you're 
>having fun, there are seriously evil people lurking in the 
>shadows. Part of my problem was that I went alone, dont make 
>the same mistakes I did.
>
>Vidur

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  SF Man Fakes Execution Video

--=====================_1424518==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

American admits to hoax execution video
Sat August 07, 2004 12:13 PM ET

By Adam Tanner and Barbara Grady

SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - A tech-savvy young San Francisco man who staged 
his own mock beheading on the Internet duped international media today into 
believing Islamist kidnappers had executed an American hostage in Iraq.

The video, which appeared on a Web site used by Islamic militants, showed a 
man who identified himself as Benjamin Vanderford appealing to the United 
States to leave Iraq. The Web format was that used by al Qaeda ally Abu 
Musab al-Zarqawi and was introduced by a headline that said it showed 
Zarqawi killing an American.

"If we don't (leave Iraq), everyone is gonna be killed in this way ... I 
have been offered for exchange for prisoners here in Iraq," the 
terrified-looking man said, rocking back and forth in his chair, his hands 
tied behind his back.

The video showed a hand with a large knife apparently slicing through the 
neck of a limp body.

But it was all a hoax.

The blood was dye, the setting was a friend's garage, the Koran reading was 
a tape and the knife was held by a friend. Mutilated bodies and sound 
effects were edited in from photos on Web sites and the video was 
purposefully blurred to make it seem even more amateur, Vanderford said.

A major motivation for his action, an unrepentant Vanderford told Reuters, 
was to see how the world media would react and to see if they would be 
fooled. "It really illustrates the potential that this kind of thing would 
happen," he said.

Vanderford, 22, said he worked at branch of Wells Fargo bank. A college 
drop-out, he was a candidate for the local city council earlier this year 
but had since dropped out of the race. His Web site also says he is a video 
game programmer and works with a local record label.

INTERNET EXPERIMENT

He said the video parody of actual beheadings of hostages in Iraq posted on 
Islamist Web sites was made and posted on the Web about three months ago, 
intended as an experiment into how quickly videos spread on the Internet. 
He was surprised at how long it took.

"It is unfortunate that it had to be the type of video that was offensive 
and shocking, but it was necessary to see how quickly this kind of thing 
would spread," he said.

Local police and FBI officials arrived at his door early on Saturday, but 
had no immediate comment as to whether he would face criminal charges. A 
police official said it was a matter for the city's special investigations 
unit.

Vanderford said he distributed the staged video on Kazaa and other Internet 
peer-to-peer networks which are popular swapping forums for films, music 
and software. He said if his staged death appeared on any terror-related 
Web sites it was the work of others who found the video on the peer-to-peer 
networks.

Scores of hostages from two dozen countries have been seized in the last 
four months. Most have been freed but at least 10 have been killed, and at 
least 20 are still being held in Iraq.

Vanderford expressed the hope that his stunt would not affect his bank job.

© Reuters 2004. All rights reserved. Users may download and print extracts 
of content from this website for their own personal and non-commercial use 
only. Republication or redistribution of Reuters content, including by 
framing or similar means, is expressly prohibited without the prior written 
consent of Reuters. Reuters and the Reuters sphere logo are registered 
trademarks or trademarks of the Reuters group of companies around the world.

me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

> going in.

> dancing - because I fell to the ground onto my knees, and couldn't even stand up
> straight; I practically had to crawl to my car. > 
> I told the lady who helped me into my cab that I thought my keys had been stolen and also the cab driver, and by some wonderful stroke of luck - probably because my car was parked directly in front of Barneveld, and maybe because they might have told the bouncers up front, that my car was still there the next morning.

>

> 
> Vidur

with some other vehicle that they stole previously?

	I've sometimes wondered how expensive tracking devices are. If you 
have a pricey car like a Mercedes, maybe it would be worth investing in 
something like that to leave in a hidden place in or on the vehicle, 
just in case it does disappear some day? Wouldn't it be fun to round up 
a posse and go surprise the shit out of the thieves a day or two later 
after they thought they'd clean got away?  8)

	A cheaper alternative might be to keep a long-range walkie talkie or 
something turned on in the car when you leave it parked in a dangerous 
area, and carry another one on you. Then as soon as you spotted it 
missing, you'd call up and say something like, "All right motherfucker, 
you better stop and pull over right now and get the fuck away from the 
vehicle in a big hurry, or your ass is going to jail. You stole an 
undercover cop car with a tracking device on it, and in a few minutes 
we are going to be all over you like jam on toast." Of course even if 
they heard you and it freaked them into taking off, it might only buy 
you a bit of time until they checked back later and realized the car 
was still sitting where they left it.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Saturday, August 7, 2004, at 12:13  AM, Vidur Sood wrote:

> Dear all,
>
> This is probably something most of you already know, but for those who 
> dont, please read on:
>
> I attended Astral Projections at Space 550 - Barneveld last Saturday - 
> July 31st and like a complete idiot took my Mercedes Benz and parked 
> it right outside Barneveld before
> going in.
>
> Later, I believe I was drugged, something put in my drink while I was
> dancing - because I fell to the ground onto my knees, and couldn't 
> even stand up
> straight; I practically had to crawl to my car. That night I had a 
> total of 2.5 double gins with redbull through a period of a few hours 
> - not enough alcohol to make me crumble like a rag doll; my car keys 
> were missing from my pocket, and I later found that my registration 
> docs. had been taken from my car.
>
> I told the lady who helped me into my cab that I thought my keys had 
> been stolen and also the cab driver, and by some wonderful stroke of 
> luck - probably because my car was parked directly in front of 
> Barneveld, and maybe because they might have told the bouncers up 
> front, that my car was still there the next morning.
>
> Space 550 has not returned a single one of my phone calls, Thump Radio 
> suggested I call Space 550 and Astral Projections people were not to 
> be heard from. So much for the peace and love feeling.
>
> A complete police report has been filed on this incident. Trance 
> dancing is
> something that is supposed to let you be free and be yourself, I think 
> there
> are people who are trying to take advantage of us while we are doing 
> our
> thing and trusting everyone around us.
>
> I hope this doesn't happen to others elsewhere, and I'm hoping this is 
> just something related to Barneveld, which very well could be, given 
> it's Bayview address... I actually didn't know Space 550 was in a 
> "bad" neighbourhood; I do now and I'm not going back.
>
> Please be careful and look out for each other when you're having fun, 
> there are seriously evil people lurking in the shadows. Part of my 
> problem was that I went alone, dont make the same mistakes I did.
>
> Vidur

DJ Soundwave,

Thanks for your very erudite piece of lit. lets not waste people's time: I
will stick to the facts, rather than have them get side tracked by some
history toting, rapper DJ with glib sound bites to wow his audience:

The police have informed me that there is always bad stuff happening at
Space 550 because of the neighbourhood, and another friend just told me that
women (usually) out there have been known to get raped with Rohypnol in the
bathroom. Ya yaay! Just your kind of place DJ Rapper Soundwave.

And that about sounds right, Rohypnol or something - 'cos my knees just gave
way, and I fell to the ground, and I totally lost track of time and just
knew I had to get the hell out of there asap.. so I somehow crawled and
scuttled across the road to my car. Thank God I was parked real close.

My initial email was simply a heads up to all who go out and expect they are
surrounded by well meaning people. Aint true. So sad, in this holy land of
breaks and liberal thinking, the Taliban have arrived here to terrorize us,
dressed as Mercedes haters... yes? Car jackers? Or just plain jealous
pusses? You decide for your own self, 'cos you may be next.

Vidur

From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Drugged and Keys missing at Space 550, Barneveld - Astral Projections

Vidur I obviously don't know the truth of your
situation, but I'll give you the benefit of the doubt.
 WIth that said, its not news that there are some
fuckers and dangerous people in both the rave and club
scenes.  Whether at 550 or elsewhere you can't assume
its OK.  Sorry folks.  Of course some places are safer
than others and this changes over time.  I'm not going
say anything about specific venues or promoters but
you can often tell which kind of party you're at if
you pay attention.  Look people in the eye and see.

But I'm not suggesting that any of you get negative
out there.  Keep going out and dancing.  Just take
care of yourselves, develop safe habits, and don't
take any chances.  If  you make this a standard
practice you won't need to worry about this sort of
shit at all.  Vidur I'm not trying to attack or
criticize you; just want to offer some advice to those
who might need to hear it.  

Please people, just don't leave your drinks unattended
at a club or rave.  Its not smart.  If you get in the
habit of keeping your drink with you (whether it be
H2O or alcoholic) you'll really never need to worry
about being slipped anything. 

And don't get so wasted that you can't pay attention
to what's happening around you.  If have one too many
drinks you might not notice when someone slips you
one.

And there are other dangers lurking out there besides
getting drugged and robbed...

Be careful!

Peter
(feeling like the old fart Dad that I am)

From sfraves-return-114547-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Aug 08 18:08:31 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114547-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft Exchange V6.0.6487.1
content-class: urn:content-classes:message
Message-ID: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A9D@djpat.dyndns.org>
X-MS-Has-Attach: 
X-MS-TNEF-Correlator: 
Thread-Topic: [sfraves] "techno"
Thread-Index: AcR77X1WGmJfU5M7S1ye7UScxTKU4gBfR11w
From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "shawn allen" <shawn@alterior.net>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] "techno"

Huh?

Man...  no wonder people have such trouble with my music here in the
states...   they don't even know the history of their own music (house +
techno).

How can anybody say that techno has had a more lasting influence on EDM
than house?  Now don't get me wrong... I've always loved techno and its
only in the last two years or so that I've been able to truly appreciate
house (maybe because I'm getting so old) ... but techno has always been
the bastard step child of house.  Techno is by definition inhuman, cold,
elitist and arrogant.  These very traits that make techno "techno" are a
big turn-off for the majority of potential EDM listeners.

"techno" as we call it started in 1983.  Its often said that the early
electro works by juan atkins (like "clear") were the first proper
"techno" tunes.  Ever hear these?  About the only thing they have in
common with house music is that they were pressed on vinyl.  Clearly
house music has had more influence on techno than vice versa.  Techno
was so frowned upon here that the artists (who were absolutely brilliant
producers no matter how strange one thought their music to be) basically
had to go to berlin to find an audience for their music (tresor, etc.)

And I don't understand what you are saying about house and trance
getting techier?  If I listen to an old trax record...  it sounds far
more "techy" to me than any "techno" record ever has.  That's just my
personal opinion and we all hear what we want to hear.  One thing tho
that really isn't debatable is the fact that the "techy" ness of the
original house music is one of the things announced its split from the
disco scene.  In fact if you go back and listen to some trax from the
late 80s... strings of life by Rhythim Is Rhythim (which was a ripoff of
an old beetles tune) is FAR LESS "techy" than a house record released at
the same time, like say "box energy" by DJ Pierre.  And if you wanna
hear some really fuckd up shit, go check out "Hot Hands" by hula which
was also released on Trax.  Its in no uncertain terms the blueprint for
every "acid techno" record ever made... its HOUSE.  Seriously I'm not
trying to get all oldskool on your buttocks here or anything, but go
peep some old trax records and some old transmat records and you'll
clearly see what I'm talking about... house music in the 80s was techier
than techno.  Sure at the same time you had steve hurley and david
morales pumping out the garage anthems on a daily basis... but house
music also had DJ Pierre and the other cats doing their thing. =20

And now to what made me wanna reply to this message...  how on earth can
you say that trance is getting techier?    No matter how "techy" trance
gets it will never, ever, ever come even close to being as "techy" as it
started out.  Trance began in 1989 in communist east germany.  It was an
experiment (obviously gone awry) to inject some much needed emotion into
the mindless crap being played by the Detroit folks in berlin (at places
like tresor).  In fact, even though trance proper was born in 89, it
wasn't until MFS started using the word trance that people even picked
up on it.  In fact the first TRANCE record ever was "House in the
desert" by alien nation (orgon records, 1988).  It was produced by Mark
Reeder who founded MFS records the following year.  Go find it and
listen to it... its techno with a minimal melody.. a melody clearly
inspired by the house music coming out of Chicago and London.  In 1990
MFS picked up some more "techno" artists like Mijk van Dijk, Humate,
etc.  Go back and listen to their early works... a blueprint for modern
day techno.  The success of MFS and their instant takeover of the
European dance music market spawned a number of cloned trance labels.
Some of these may be familiar to you:  Harthouse, Superstition,
Overdrive, etc.  Its funny... in 1991 these were all "trance" labels...
yet today they are recognized as being "techno" labels.  "trance" in the
early years was just techno with an influence from acid house.  It
wasn't the other way around.  Trance over the years has morphed into
something completely evil and out of touch with its roots. I guess
popularity can do that.  But in the beginning, it was techno.  It was
made by techno artists and enjoyed by the techno fans.  No matter how
"techy" trance gets in the future, it will never ever be "techno"
again... for it will be trance.  In fact, not only is trance not getting
techier... its completely lost its techno roots altogether and will
never get that influence back no matter how hard anybody tries.  Trance
is over 15 years old now.  Its too late to turn back... its too late to
become techno again. =20

"For crying out loud, Two Lone Swordsmen did an instrumental version of
Ricardo Villalobos' "Dexter" for his "Alcachofa Remixes" EP"

Did I miss something?  What the heck does this have to do with anything?
Andrew Weatherall was at first and still is a techno artist.  The same
goes for Ricardo.  What does one techno artist remixing another techno
artist have to do with anything?  How does that prove any influence of
one style over another?

And if you are saying that in the future all music will sound "techy"
then EDM is doomed.  If anything EDM needs to be made more human.  It is
the "techyness" that has turned people off of EDM over the last few
years.  It is the "techyness" that has caused techno label after techno
label to completely disappear over the last two years.  It is the
"techyness" that has brought down every major European distributor in
the last two years.  People are sick of "techno".  Its elitist, arrogant
and in most cases dreadfully boring.  People simply aren't interested in
the zapping sounds of a swarm of robotic hornets.  And the record sales
prove this.    Sure techno will live on, but if people keep insisting
upon techno being "techy" it will return to its roots... 300 kids in
Detroit and another 300 kids in berlin and no fans anywhere else on the
planet.  Is that what you want for techno?  I surely hope not.  I hope
techno is kept alive by people like chris Jackson and andy w... who
aren't exactly techno snobs.  Shit when any plays a 'techno' set
sometimes...  I have to wait an hour just to hear a 'techno' track.
That willingness to 'break the rules' is what will keep techno alive...
because clearly following the elitist techno rules has nearly killed
techno.

Keep it Wet & Hard...
XXX,
p a t

> -----Original Message-----
> From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net]
> Sent: Friday, August 06, 2004 12:42 PM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"
>=20
> quoth DJ Soundwave:
> > shawn said:
> > > the music they were part of from the realm of house. But then
house
> > > ended up taking cues from techno, and since the late 80's both
> > > styles have been collectively referred to by the public as
"techno",
> > > for better or for worse.
> >
> > sorry, is this actually true? maybe it's just a Chicago thing, maybe
> > it's just a me thing, but in the late 80s there were only two types
of
> > people I knew who couldn't tell the difference between house and
> > techno -- grade-obsessed hyper-competitive nerdy types, and people
> > over 35.
>=20
> Heh yeah, I was talking more about the public at large. I'm 23, so
it's
> probably unfair for me to be making blanket statements about how
people
> viewed music in the late 80's. But that's what I've gathered from my
> reading, and from my own experience. At least, by the time I was into
> electronic music ('93), everything was being referred to collectively
as
> "techno".
>=20
> We ravers are a bit more meticulous in our classification, but my
point
> is that even in our community there's a debate over what really
> qualifies as techno. What I should have said in the the previous email
> was that maybe it's not so wrong to label everything as "techno",
> because it seems to me that historically, techno has had a more
> long-lasting influence on other styles than they've had on it. House
and
> trance are getting "techier". Breaks and hip-hop are increasingly
> "glitchy". Rock bands are using analog drum machines and synthesizers
> again. For crying out loud, Two Lone Swordsmen did an instrumental
> version of Ricardo Villalobos' "Dexter" for his "Alcachofa Remixes"
EP.
>=20
> I'm not saying that what's traditionally referred to as "techno"
(i.e.,
> the harder drum trax) will usurp all the other styles of EDM. But I do
> think that soon, people will have to stop thinking of techno as the
ugly
> duckling of electronic music. Because at some point, it may become
> difficult to distinguish your favorite styles from some of the
"techno"
> that's being produced today. Does that make any sense? :)
>=20
> Cheers,

From sfraves-return-114550-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Aug 08 20:22:09 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-114550-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
