list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 93519 invoked from network); 8 Aug 2004 20:22:08 -0000
Date: Sun, 8 Aug 2004 13:22:00 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040808202200.GH575@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A9D@djpat.dyndns.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A9D@djpat.dyndns.org>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

quoth DJ Pat:
> Man...  no wonder people have such trouble with my music here in the
> states...   they don't even know the history of their own music (house
> + techno).

Oh brother... Pat, this wasn't intended to be a debate about the origins
of house or techno. All I'm saying is that *technically* (e.g., with
respect to basic structure and instrumentation), a lot more music is
sounding like techno these days. I'm saying this from experience: I got
into what's commonly referred to as "techno" via house, and eventually
came to realize that a lot of what I thought of as "house" was actually
more like techno than anything else. You probably don't agree with me
because you're not familiar with the type of music I'm talking about.

But like any Gemini, I guess I can see both sides of the issue: the fact
that I even refer to most of this fringe music as "techno" points to the
possibility that techno is really just informed by everything else--not
that everything else is informed by techno. But for now it sounds to me
like modern house (specifically the past 5-6 years' worth) is taking a
lot of cues from techno.

> How can anybody say that techno has had a more lasting influence on
> EDM than house? Now don't get me wrong... I've always loved techno and
> its only in the last two years or so that I've been able to truly
> appreciate house (maybe because I'm getting so old) ... but techno has
> always been the bastard step child of house. 

I think George was more correct in saying that techno and house are
parallel branches of the same tree. About all techno and house have in
common is the 4-on-the-floor beat, and if you think of electro as simply
a style of techno (as I do), then the only common factor (pun intended)
is the instrumentation: most notably, the traditional use of the TR-606
and TB-303.

> Techno is by definition inhuman, cold, elitist and arrogant.  These
> very traits that make techno "techno" are a big turn-off for the
> majority of potential EDM listeners.

You really don't know techno if that's what you think. The whole *point*
of this thread was to point out that there was more to techno than
mechanical drum trax. Regardless of which styles influence which, I
would still assert that the techno of today is much more accessible than
people probably think. It's certainly not all "inhuman, cold, elitist
and arrogant".

> "techno" as we call it started in 1983.  Its often said that the early
> electro works by juan atkins (like "clear") were the first proper
> "techno" tunes.  Ever hear these?  About the only thing they have in
> common with house music is that they were pressed on vinyl.  Clearly
> house music has had more influence on techno than vice versa.  Techno
> was so frowned upon here that the artists (who were absolutely
> brilliant producers no matter how strange one thought their music to
> be) basically had to go to berlin to find an audience for their music
> (tresor, etc.)

That's a very good point. But you're contradicting yourself: because
nobody embraced it stateside (unless you count Richie Hawtin), techno
had the opportunity to evolve outside the sphere of house music's
influence in places like Berlin.  German producers list among their
influences people like Carl Craig and Derrick May, who originally
developed their sounds as an *alternative* to house.

> ...

All good points, but nothing that really speaks to the more recent
evolution of techno. It's all semantics though, which is probably why I
never should have started this thread in the first place. Suffice it to
say that my definition of "techno" is a lot more liberal than yours. :)

> Its funny... in 1991 these were all "trance" labels...  yet today they
> are recognized as being "techno" labels.  "trance" in the early years
> was just techno with an influence from acid house.  It wasn't the
> other way around.  Trance over the years has morphed into something
> completely evil and out of touch with its roots. I guess popularity
> can do that.  But in the beginning, it was techno.  It was made by
> techno artists and enjoyed by the techno fans.  No matter how "techy"
> trance gets in the future, it will never ever be "techno" again... for
> it will be trance.  In fact, not only is trance not getting techier...
> its completely lost its techno roots altogether and will never get
> that influence back no matter how hard anybody tries.  Trance is over
> 15 years old now.  Its too late to turn back... its too late to become
> techno again.  

Point taken. Admittedly, I don't hear much trance these days, but what I
have heard has tended to sound increasingly more like EBM and hard
techno than what I was introduced to as "trance" 5 or 6 years ago.

> "For crying out loud, Two Lone Swordsmen did an instrumental version
> of Ricardo Villalobos' "Dexter" for his "Alcachofa Remixes" EP"
> 
> Did I miss something?  What the heck does this have to do with
> anything?  Andrew Weatherall was at first and still is a techno
> artist.  The same goes for Ricardo.  What does one techno artist
> remixing another techno artist have to do with anything?  How does
> that prove any influence of one style over another?

Heh, you haven't heard the new TLS album, have you? I was referring to
the influence of techno on rock--Weatherall and Tenniswood's remake of
"Dexter" is a live instrumentation (i.e. guitars and live drums) of a
minimal techno track. There have been a lot of remakes done in the other
direction, but labels like DFA are truly revolutionizing the
much-maligned "rock" genre by injecting it with electronics. The whole
"electroclash" style is, essentially, punk rock with techno
sensibilities. You would probably say they're just techno geeks getting
bored and deciding to make rock music, but I think it's actually the
other way around. The young people making this music didn't grow up
listening to Jimi Hendrix, they grew up with Kraftwerk and Depeche Mode.

> It is the "techyness" that has brought down every major European
> distributor in the last two years.

One word: Kompakt.

> People are sick of "techno".  Its elitist, arrogant and in most cases
> dreadfully boring.  People simply aren't interested in the zapping
> sounds of a swarm of robotic hornets.

Heh, I'm not either. That's why I like the really lush, emotive Detroit
techno. That's why I appreciate the warm production styles of Eric
Estornel, Bernhard Pucher, L'usine, and Claro Intelecto. I could go on
and on here... but trust me, there's much more to modern techno than
incessant zapping.

> And the record sales prove this.    Sure techno will live on, but if
> people keep insisting upon techno being "techy" it will return to its
> roots... 300 kids in Detroit and another 300 kids in berlin and no
> fans anywhere else on the planet.  Is that what you want for techno?

No, and that's why I'm trying to open people's eyes to the other side of
techno: the complex, emotional, thought-provoking side.

> I surely hope not.  I hope techno is kept alive by people like chris
> Jackson and andy w... who aren't exactly techno snobs.  Shit when any
> plays a 'techno' set sometimes...  I have to wait an hour just to hear
> a 'techno' track.  That willingness to 'break the rules' is what will
> keep techno alive...  because clearly following the elitist techno
> rules has nearly killed techno.

And that's my point: there's a lot of techno out there breaking the
rules. At some point, a small group of elitists decided that the only
style that qualified as "techno" was hard, banging stuff. I'm here to
tell you that it's not all like that. The techno community is growing
because people have opened their minds to new definitions of the word.
Again:

> > I'm not saying that what's traditionally referred to as "techno"
> > (i.e., the harder drum trax) will usurp all the other styles of EDM.
> > But I do think that soon, people will have to stop thinking of
> > techno as the ugly duckling of electronic music. Because at some
> > point, it may become difficult to distinguish your favorite styles
> > from some of the "techno" that's being produced today.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From sfraves-return-114555-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Aug 09 01:46:08 2004

Subject: RE: [sfraves] "techno"

--=====================_27127216==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 11:08 AM 8/8/2004, DJ Pat wrote:


>And if you are saying that in the future all music will sound "techy"
>then EDM is doomed.  If anything EDM needs to be made more human.  It is
>the "techyness" that has turned people off of EDM over the last few
>years.  It is the "techyness" that has caused techno label after techno
>label to completely disappear over the last two years.  It is the
>"techyness" that has brought down every major European distributor in
>the last two years.  People are sick of "techno".  Its elitist, arrogant
>and in most cases dreadfully boring.  People simply aren't interested in
>the zapping sounds of a swarm of robotic hornets.

I'm not sure I know what people mean by "techy," which is one reason I 
stayed clear of this discussion so far.  As you correctly observed, EDM 
arose when producers began to use technology to create dance music, rather 
than live musicians and vocalists in expensive studios.  Disco died, money 
for old production techniques disappeared, and innovative producers morphed 
expensively produced disco into electronic house music. All EDM, therefore, 
is "techy."  I think what folks mean by techy in this context is more 
qualitative than quantitative.

But you hit the beat on the box when you wrote "...EDM needs to be made 
more human."  Qualitative statement, but it on this level of emotion, 
passion and sensuality that I would like to comment here.  I believe we 
need to bring back the soul, sensuality, sex and funk to dance music.

Over the past few years  I have become increasing disenchanted with much of 
the dance music I've been buying, spinning and hearing out at parties and 
clubs.  Seemed to me --  and I feel like I'm dancing on hot coals here 
because this may appear deeply offensive to some -- that lots of this music 
arose from an engineer's soul rather than a musician's.  Others have made 
this observation.  When EDM was evolving the musician (DJ/producer) worked 
with an technical staff that knew the hardware and, eventually, software 
mandatories and helped actualize the musicians intentions.  The musician 
made most of the bucks and technical staff were on salary.  Many musicians 
were unwilling or  unable to master these new "instruments," and tech staff 
felt they might make more money eliminating the musician altogether.  So 
the rise of producer/technicians who often had little or no musical 
training and exposure to the long historical evolution of EDM and the 
influences that created it.  To be frank, many also lacked soul:)  So you 
have machines and people who know how to use them and they all start making 
music that sounds pretty much the same over time.  Lyrics disappear (who 
can write lyrics and record them? even worse, who can actually write a 
song?).  Lots of product, but very little with the "hook" that could get 
people dancing years ago.  This theory is, of course, an oversimplification 
but...

One started to go to parties where few danced.  There were wonderful 
displays of technical virtuosity behind the decks, laptops, and such but it 
began to feel to me more like an esoteric chamber music concert than a 
dance party.

Over the past few months I decided to try to divest myself of all the 
genre/subgenre stuff, go back and review the music of the past thirty 
years, and feel again just what made dancers really dance.

Segue to 1990 San Francisco dancefloors.  No need to go back to the 
seventies.  There were many tracks that made asses move.  One was "The 
Power" by Snap.  Big worldwide hip house crossover hit that rivaled "Pump 
Up the Jam" at the time.  Some German producers took a rather obscure rap 
track "Let the Words Flow" by Chill Rob G, rewrote and diluted the 
Afrocentric lyrics, got Turbo G and singer Penny Ford to execute the thing, 
and there was a song that EVERYONE danced to -- music snobs, hipsters, the 
uninitiated, house lovers -- they all waved their hands in the air, 
shouted, and danced madly to this "commercial" hit.  As a DJ one would 
sample slices of "The Power" throughout one's set letting the dancers know 
it was coming.  Very seductive foreplay.  Tease.  They all wanted it.  When 
you finally let it rip there was truly a collective orgasm on the 
dancefloor.  The you often followed it with "Gonna Make You 
Sweat"  (another hip house hit) and everyone sang along with the opening 
lyrics:  "Everybody dance now."  And they danced.  And they sweated.  How 
often do you see that happen today?  LOL, I was going to throw "The Power" 
into my next public set, but Doc Martin beat me to it last time he played 
at Club 6.  Never thought I'd hear that song on the dancefloor again.  And, 
by the gods, it had the same effect that it did fourteen years ago. There 
were many songs like this then;  "The Power" has just been on my mind lately.

Chill Rob G's original lyrics (much better than the vague commercial 
release) eloquently sum up what I think I'm trying to say here:  "It's wack 
to me when the beat is more hype than the MC cause what he's sayin is 
empty, dull, void, without substance or content.  You need to slow your 
speed, stop the nonsense..."

And that is happening from my perspective -- and I know we all hear what we 
want to hear.  What I see people dancing to these days is not more "techy" 
stuff.  Rather, they are lovin' the old funky, soulful stuff with content 
-- even disco -- and perceptive DJs and producers are bringing this human 
element back to the dancefloor.  Interesting that Juan Atkins last time he 
was in town opened his set with that most excellent recent remix of the 
disco classic "I Feel Love."  The kids can't seem to get enough of Jesse 
Saunders' old house classics.  Africa Bambaataa enflames the dancefloor 
with disco-infused hip hop.  One of the most successful parties in town 
brings back the music of the early nineties.  Hell, I've collected five 
excellent recent remixes of "Le Freak" and other old dancefloor 
classics.  Bring back the funk, yes.  Don't know what it is?  Listen to 
Sylvester's "Do You Wanna' Funk.":)  Bring back content, songs, lyrics, sex 
and soul.  Whatever one might think about commercial hip hop, it's so 
successful because it does just that.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_27127216==.ALT--

>>>straight; I practically had to crawl to my car. >>>
>>>I told the lady who helped me into my cab that I thought my keys had been stolen and also the cab driver, and by some wonderful stroke of luck - probably because my car was parked directly in front of Barneveld, and maybe because they might have told the bouncers up front, that my car was still there the next morning.
>>>
>>>Space 550 has not returned a single one of my phone calls, Thump Radio suggested I call Space 550 and Astral Projections people were not to be heard from. So much for the peace and love feeling.
>>>
>>>A complete police report has been filed on this incident. Trance dancing is
>>>something that is supposed to let you be free and be yourself, I think there
>>>are people who are trying to take advantage of us while we are doing our
>>>thing and trusting everyone around us.
>>>

>>>
>>>Please be careful and look out for each other when you're having fun, there are seriously evil people lurking in the shadows. Part of my problem was that I went alone, dont make the same mistakes I did.

Date: Mon, 9 Aug 2004 08:58:15 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040809155815.GB5066@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A9D@djpat.dyndns.org> <6.1.2.0.2.20040808155034.024470b0@localhost>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <6.1.2.0.2.20040808155034.024470b0@localhost>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

quoth Apollo:
> Over the past few months I decided to try to divest myself of all the
> genre/subgenre stuff, go back and review the music of the past thirty
> years, and feel again just what made dancers really dance.

That's quite noble, Apollo. It's difficult to market oneself as a DJ
without defining what you play. That's why I'm having such a hard time
with this techno thing... Rather than categorize everything, I should
probably just let the music speak for itself.

So I'll remind you all again, but if you want to hear what I'm talking
about, tune in to my weekly internet broadcast from 6-8pm tonight. House
heads should enjoy it. Fans of dub, electro and breaks should too. Even
elitist techno snobs might hear something they like.

<http://www.throwdown.com/throwdown/live/live.asp>

We could debate the merits of certain styles of electonic music until
we're blue in the face, but in the end it's all about making people
move. Not necessarily dancing--I know quite a few people that just don't
dance--but getting into the music *somehow*; if not physically, then
cerebrally.

I got into electronic music not because I needed to dance, but because I
needed to hear something different. I needed to find something that
could either support or influence my moods, without literal lyrics or
catchy hooks; something abstract that would allow me to reach my own
conclusions. And I eventually discovered, in the San Francisco rave
scene, that the styles tailored for either mental or more physical
consumption aren't necessarily mutually exclusive. There is such a thing
as "intelligent" dance music.

I'm in the hole tens of thousands of dollars for having bought thousands
of records and never getting paid more than cab fare for a gig. But I
started collecting records and DJing so that I could find new,
interesting music and share it with people that wouldn't hear it
otherwise--and in that respect, I've been somewhat successful. All I ask
in return is that you support your local DJs by challenging your tastes
every once in a a while. Discovering new music is a thrilling
experience, and there's too much of it out there (and in the Bay Area
alone!) to limit yourself to any specific style or structure. I've tried
in vain to convey the idea that "techno" isn't always cold and inhuman,
but the only way to find out for yourself is to listen. :)

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

back up singers. They came out with old school such hits as "Cadyman" "Ring My 
Bell" "In My House" and "All Night Long" (gonna give it to ya give it to ya 
give it to ya baby)    Listen to stations like 98.1 and 101.1 and 100.3 they play 
Mary Jane Girls more than they play Rick James. You can always hear the 
signature Rick James funk riffs behind their singing though. He's the man. Way way 
way funkier than James Brown if you ask me. Right up there with Parlement.

before James Brown there was no funk.  he didn't create it by himself, but
he was there before and after and during.  what about the "funky drummer"
or "say it loud"?  those are some funky choons. no?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Rick James Bio, Etc.

--part1_194.2be4d3e9.2e494ea9_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I like the funk track that built the foundation to today's funky house music. 
what james brown called "funk", sounds to me more like today's break beat and 
two-step. You can tell by the way he sang his lyrics and dances his style was 
very "huh! hit me!" *trumpet sounds* sparatic, it was not groovey smooth like 
house. but you gotta start somewhere and i'm not to say break beat can not 
also be funky, hip hop can even be funky and so can rock. I would say that Rick 
James, Parlement, and tracks like earth wind and fire's "Let's Groove Tonight" 
Michael Jackson's "Don't Stop Till You Get Enough", Roger   & Zapp and those 
uber funky tracks from the 80's & early 90's that we often times use the loose 
term "Old School" for, laid down a lot of progression and popularity for 
House music. There's a lot of house that stems from disco and there's latin house 
and just crappy club house and stuff but all the really good House tracks that 
I like seem to have a sound that comes from the funky foundation that was 
laid down by artist like Michael Jackson, Prince and Rick James bitch!
     I think a lot of it is that they weren't afraid to use electronic 
synthesizers and eletro beats. what they were experimenting with then, perhaps sped 
up and amplified a bit, is the type of house music that i listen to today. 

--part1_194.2be4d3e9.2e494ea9_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Petition for open presidential debates

	Open Debates is fighting to open up the debate process to alternative 
party candidates including the Libertarians. Please take a moment to 
visit their website and sign the petition, and pass the link along to 
anyone who wants real choice this year!

	Here is the text of their petition:

"We, the undersigned, support Open Debates' campaign to reform the 
presidential debate process. We believe that the presidential debates 
should serve the American people first, not political parties. We 
support replacing the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates 
with the nonpartisan Citizens' Debate Commission, so that inspiring 
formats can be
employed, pressing national issues can be addressed, and popular 
independent and third party candidates can be included."

	So far almost 10,000 people have signed. You can sign it here:

		http://opendebates.org/yourrole/petition/

Groove on,

*phase 1 - friday, aug 13
*phase 2 - saturday, aug 14
our guests will first appear at solid grooves in san jose this friday, aug 13, from 4-8 pm for a meet and greet: they will be dropping tracks, distributing promos, and signing records and other gear. of course, this will be free and hopefully many of you will come through to hang out with our guests. the atmosphere will be mellow as we pre-party before our 2 major events this weekend... once again, our guests include:
 
eufex - birmingham, UK - nukleuz, vicious circle, honey pot

banga matt - london, UK - arktik, sketcha, dp, nile

phil able - london, UK - antiworld, smile, cyberdog, d&a music S.F.
 
nicki s - london, UK - endophin, quality trax

little miss natalie - manchester, UK - fist
 
ali wilson - london, UK - nukleuz, honey pot, vicious circle

alex calver - london, UK - fidget, glitch, tripoli trax

matt k - atlanta, GA - east coast nrg, systematik tour

hardrive - miami, FL - east coast nrg

andrew innes - fevah records

yourself?"

"i am just in a hurry. i am in a hurry, because so is
everyone else." :)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ~*VERSUS 2*~ FRIDAY.September.10th.2004 (*ALL AGES/TWO AREAS/18 DJs*)(XTORT)*BSP*

Can't say it works for everyone, but something about the way Xtort does it
keeps people coming back - 5 years now or something and I've been booked for
all but maybe one or two of their events.

But then again, I'm one of them *special* people that does buy new tracks
each week - lots of them and well, I don't play *lame* trance... so maybe
that helps. ? ? ?

Gotta give credit where credit is due - and after 4 years of people
complaining, Xtort is still going strong, although I don't recommend anyone
else try to repeat the methods of his success.  Diversity IS a good and
NECESSARY thing for 99.9% of the world.  

~d

--0-46097614-1092177051=:23630
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Thanks everyone, but yes this is just the way we've done our events since people have been very happy with the lineup. Each crew has a way they do their events and generally their lineup doesn't massively change over because they each have a certain following and proven method. Sorry you feel the way you do Chris, but honestly have you attended one of our events? Your comments are appreciated, but honestly if you think that we're raking in the money when we did shows like our last event Plug-n-Play for $5 then you're seriously misinformed. We all have day jobs and we love this hobby. Obviously if people didn't like what we're doing, they wouldn't attend...
 
If you have more comments feel free to email us privately too, we're always willing to listen to your constructive criticism :)

Sascha
XTORT: http://www.xtortproductions.cjb.net

I'm DJ Rapper Soundwave
and I'm on the mike
was I drunk
was I stoned
or just high on life
I can't remember why on earth I wrote that shit
but
uh
word
and stuff
anyway
I'm like an elevator
I'm on the rise
and people speculate about my penis size
I don't get that
but if you really care
we can put a webcam in my underwear
cause when it comes to the bitches
I admit I'm a dick
all the bullshit and the drama
man it makes me sick
always asking stupid questions
like "tell me your name"
"do you have my number?"
"did you know that I came?"
bitch!
if you got questions then you better ask Jeeves
this kid's like a koala
he eats bushes and leaves
I float like a butterfly
I also stings
I'm funky like jalapeno onion rings
blah blah blah
word y0

honestly if what you're talking about ever happened in real life then
you have my sympathy but personally I really doubt it. I just find it
highly implausible. and to everybody out there who thinks driving a
Mercedes means having a big dick or rapping means raping, I don't even
know what to tell you, but I think you have a few things confused. I'm
not saying I don't have anything confused, there isn't a single person
on earth who knows me well and considers me sane, but still.

anyway, sorry for the freakout but it's not my fault you took it seriously...

--

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 96391 invoked from network); 11 Aug 2004 06:07:56 -0000
In-Reply-To: <6.1.2.0.2.20040808155034.024470b0@localhost>
References: <46474C2DBB20D645896D8102CC07EA690D1A9D@djpat.dyndns.org> <6.1.2.0.2.20040808155034.024470b0@localhost>
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v619)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Message-Id: <C6CEB6DF-EB5C-11D8-97CD-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Cc:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: John B <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 10 Aug 2004 23:07:51 -0700
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.619)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

I can think of at least one place where you'll routinely see exactly 
that.

Got to a Happy Hardcore party sometime.... one, that is, where they've 
booked DJs who play *HAPPY* hardcore, and don't just play plain old 
hardcore, thinking they've "moved beyond", or "are above" playing the 
good old cheezy stuff.  Then, just wait wait for the DJ to play one of 
the "anthem" HHC songs.

"Eyeopener" and "Ravers' Anthem" seem to work the best.  But either of 
those, and plenty others, will bring about exactly the circumstance you 
describe... everyone shivering with anticipation as they realize what 
song is coming up next, everyone singing along, everyone dancing, 
everyone sweating, everyone just so ludicrously ecstatic that "that 
special song" is playing that the "happiness" and "energy" and "joy" 
meters are pegged in the redline.

"Ravers' Anthem", in particular, is especially good for the sort of 
teasing and foreshadowing you describe.

I know Happy Hardcore has a bad rep on SFRaves.  And I don't know if it 
qualifies as having "soul" or not.  But it certainly motivates people 
in a way I seldom otherwise see.


cya,
john



On Aug 8, 2004, at 6:46 PM, Apollo wrote:

> As a DJ one would sample slices of "The Power" throughout one's set 
> letting the dancers know it was coming.  Very seductive foreplay.  
> Tease.  They all wanted it.  When you finally let it rip there was 
> truly a collective orgasm on the dancefloor.  The you often followed 
> it with "Gonna Make You Sweat"  (another hip house hit) and everyone 
> sang along with the opening lyrics:  "Everybody dance now."  And they 
> danced.  And they sweated.  How often do you see that happen today?

> I know Happy Hardcore has a bad rep on SFRaves.  And I don't know if it 
> qualifies as having "soul" or not.  But it certainly motivates people 
> in a way I seldom otherwise see.
> 
> 
> cya,
> john
> 
> 
> 
> On Aug 8, 2004, at 6:46 PM, Apollo wrote:
> 
> > As a DJ one would sample slices of "The Power" throughout one's set 
> > letting the dancers know it was coming.  Very seductive foreplay.  
> > Tease.  They all wanted it.  When you finally let it rip there was 
> > truly a collective orgasm on the dancefloor.  The you often followed 
> > it with "Gonna Make You Sweat"  (another hip house hit) and everyone 
> > sang along with the opening lyrics:  "Everybody dance now."  And they

Subject: [sfraves] *HAPPY TOGETHER 3! Saturday, September 4th! 2000+ Capacity - All Ages! [bsp]

Yeah, we know. It's been almost 2 years since the last one. There hasn't 
been a single party we get asked more about, so here it is, the finale.. 
Liquidvinyldjs.com is unbelieveably proud to present:

HAPPY TOGETHER 3
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH 2004
LABOR DAY WEEKEND
ALL AGES | 9:00pm-6:00am
2000+ CAPACITY BAY AREA LOCATION!


We've taken great pride in putting together this once in a lifetime lineup! 
Prepare for one of the biggest hard lineups the West Coast has ever seen!


SCOTT BROWN
|| Evolution Records - Scotland || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
Considered by many around the world as Hardcore's #1 DJ and Producer, Scott 
Brown has achieved more in his career than many in any other genre. He's 
developed his Evolution Records label into what many reguard as the top 
Hardcore label in the world, along with releasing tracks with many of 
Hardcore's top Producers. With massive hits like "ELYSIUM", "NOW IS THE 
TIME", "TURN UP THE MUSIC", and "ICE COLD", chances are if you've been to a 
party in the past 10 years, you've heard his music. As a DJ, he is known for 
his rock solid skills on the decks, often building his sets into energetic 
frenzies that result in mayhem after it's all said and done! This will be 
Scott Brown's first Bay Area Appearance, please join us to make it 
memorable!

DJ HIXXY
|| RaverBaby / HTID / Bonkers - U.K. ||
>From his novice DJ days in 1991 to his International Hardcore Superstar 
status of today, Hixxy has worked long and hard making a name for himself in 
the Hardcore circuit. From his early releases "TOY TOWN" and "WANTING TO GET 
HIGH" to his current hits "TANTRIC" and his remix of "FALLING IN", Hixxy has 
enjoyed enormous success as a Producer. As a DJ, Hixxy helped launch the 
enormously popular "BONKERS" series on React, which continues to break sales 
records for Hardcore CD compilations. His mixes are known to be uplifting 
and energetic, so be ready as we bring Hixxy for a very rare USA appearance!

TOMMYKNOCKER
|| Traxtorm Records - Italy || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
As one of the fastest rising Hardcore producers today, we are extremely 
excited to bring you Tommyknocker for his first Bay Area Appearance. Hailing 
from Italy, his unique sound has been in demand by all of the world's top 
Hardcore DJs, with hard hittin' releases like "THE AFTERMATH", "REVOLUTION", 
and "DEMOLITION". He is also an accomplished DJ, playing huge events like 
Love Parade, Hellraiser, Megarave, and Masters of Hardcore. If you like your 
Hardcore rough and rugged, Tommyknocker is your man!

DELTA 9
|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is widely 
respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his early 
releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE", to his 
present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER", he 
continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has appeared all 
around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd control, 
often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to 
present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

DJ VENOM
|| Volume Productions / Topaz Records - Providence, RI || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Looked upon as one of the most talented Hard DJ's in America, Venom's style 
and persona are only comparible to his music: wild and crazy! He goes 
seamlessly from US Hard House to Hardcore in his mixes, as showcased on such 
top-selling CD compilations as his "RAISE THE VOLUME" series, his "STRAIGHT 
BANGIN" series, and the immensely popular "HOUSE BLEND VOLUME 7-8". From his 
jaw-dropping scratching to his crowd rockin stage displays, it's no wonder 
why Venom is in such huge demand all around the country. We are hyped to 
bring you DJ Venom's first Bay Area Appearance!


CLOUDSKIPPER
|| Raw Elements / KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The one, the only. Cloudskipper is widely recognized and respected as one of 
the top Hardcore DJ's in America. With his recent tour of the U.K. as well 
as his very busy touring here in North America, crowds all around the world 
continue to be amazed and captivated by his upfront Hardcore sets. Often 
immitated, never duplicated, Cloudskipper sets the bar other Hardcore DJ's 
will be trying to reach... next year.

DJ TRONIC
|| Resistance Recordings / Liquidvinyldjs.com / BeatSupreme.com ||
Label owner. Producer. DJ. Promoter. Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not. DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.


THE NICE GUYS [NO LEFT TURN & DJ REESE]
|| KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
When they're not out being nice somewhere, they're out getting drunk. All 
jokes aside, these two are starting to make waves in the Hardcore world, 
with their two upcoming releases on KFA, as well as other material released 
on Raw Elements and Bedlam. Prepare for the Nice Guys, dropping a 
not-so=nice set!

THE NATURAL DISASTERS [THE DOCTOR & RECLIPSE]
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The Doctor and Reclipse, forces in their own right come together to form the 
Natural Disasters. While they're not wrestlers, they drop some of the 
hardest hittin material in the Bay, ranging from DrumNBass to Hardcore to 
Gabber, these two will be shaking the dancefloor HARD!

J-MARR & CARLOS ALFONZO
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com / Soop Recordings / BeatSupreme.com || 
[/b]
Alright, the last time we had these two together during a set, they did more 
passing out of food than actually playing. While we can't promise the same 
feast, we can promise a rockin set that only these two can bring!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

*shudders at the thought of happy hardcore*

damn straight, HHC is a poor excuse for a musical genre.  There's no better 
way to ruin a perfectly good song than to do a happy hardcore remix.  I dont 
get happy hardcore at all.  it's not music.  I dont even know what it is, 
all i know is it's about as annoying as your lil sister or brother pointing 
their finger at you and saying "i'm not touching you."  You just wanna turn 
around and smack em.  In case you didnt know what happy was, we'll force 
feed it to you with some high speed beats and cheezy chipmunk vocals.  there 
are you happy now?  well are you?  In case you didnt grow out of your barney 
lovin' stage, we now have a musical genre to lull your under-developed mind 
into a state of ecstacy.  One of the best places to hear old played out 
songs, that only the happiest of the hardcore still like.  i cant believe 
all these kids are happy with hearing the same old songs over and over and 
over, long enough to actually learn and like the "lyrics".  It just boogles 
my mind and makes me violently ill.  Who would have guessed happy music 
would make someone violent.  Nothin better than getting drunk and trash 
talking a bunch of happy candy kids.

Buck Murdock
"I've got a fever, and the only prescription is more cowbell!"

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <BAY15-F16J918jp1xsj0002ba3d@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

I totally agree. There is no soul in HHC. It all
pounds the same beat with hardly any melody or change
ups or originality. I bought 4 HHC records when it
first came out back in the early-mid 90's. Well at
least when I first heard of it. The music hasn't
evolved at all over the years. Friends from England
tell me all the K kids go to the gabber parties and
get babysit due to being on the babysitter. Kids love
it though. I know some kids who freak when they hear
this crap. I don't get it. Sometimes I will throw on a
HHC track for giggles to see if I missed something,
nope... I didn't miss anything... it still blows.   

Oh, another thing I have heard over the years is the
producers put out a couple HHC tracks make some money
then go bankrupt because they blow all their money on
tweak. I know the old HHC labels wouldn't last long at
all. Not sure about these days.

This is only my opinion to the music. 

~m  

--- Buck Murdock <sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com> wrote:

> *shudders at the thought of happy hardcore*
> 
> damn straight, HHC is a poor excuse for a musical
> genre.  There's no better 
> way to ruin a perfectly good song than to do a happy
> hardcore remix.  I dont 
> get happy hardcore at all.  it's not music.  I dont
> even know what it is, 
> all i know is it's about as annoying as your lil
> sister or brother pointing 
> their finger at you and saying "i'm not touching
> you."  You just wanna turn 
> around and smack em.  In case you didnt know what
> happy was, we'll force 
> feed it to you with some high speed beats and cheezy
> chipmunk vocals.  there 
> are you happy now?  well are you?  In case you didnt
> grow out of your barney 
> lovin' stage, we now have a musical genre to lull
> your under-developed mind 
> into a state of ecstacy.  One of the best places to
> hear old played out 
> songs, that only the happiest of the hardcore still
> like.  i cant believe 
> all these kids are happy with hearing the same old
> songs over and over and 
> over, long enough to actually learn and like the
> "lyrics".  It just boogles 
> my mind and makes me violently ill.  Who would have
> guessed happy music 
> would make someone violent.  Nothin better than
> getting drunk and trash 
> talking a bunch of happy candy kids.
> 
> Buck Murdock
> "I've got a fever, and the only prescription is more
> cowbell!"
> 
> 
> 
>

> W. Bush.

> >----- Original Message -----
> >From: "John B" <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
> >To: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> >Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> >Sent: Tuesday, August 10, 2004 11:07 PM
> >Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"
> >
> >
> > > I can think of at least one place where you'll
> routinely see exactly
> > > that.
> > >
> > > Got to a Happy Hardcore party sometime.... one,
> that is, where they've
> > > booked DJs who play *HAPPY* hardcore, and don't
> just play plain old
> > > hardcore, thinking they've "moved beyond", or
> "are above" playing the
> > > good old cheezy stuff.  Then, just wait wait for
> the DJ to play one of
> > > the "anthem" HHC songs.
> > >
> > > "Eyeopener" and "Ravers' Anthem" seem to work
> the best.  But either of
> > > those, and plenty others, will bring about
> exactly the circumstance you
> > > describe... everyone shivering with anticipation
> as they realize what
> > > song is coming up next, everyone singing along,
> everyone dancing,
> > > everyone sweating, everyone just so ludicrously
> ecstatic that "that
> > > special song" is playing that the "happiness"
> and "energy" and "joy"
> > > meters are pegged in the redline.
> > >
> > > "Ravers' Anthem", in particular, is especially
> good for the sort of
> > > teasing and foreshadowing you describe.
> > >
> > > I know Happy Hardcore has a bad rep on SFRaves. 
> And I don't know if it
> > > qualifies as having "soul" or not.  But it
> certainly motivates people
> > > in a way I seldom otherwise see.
> > >
> > >
> > > cya,
> > > john
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > On Aug 8, 2004, at 6:46 PM, Apollo wrote:
> > >
> > > > As a DJ one would sample slices of "The Power"
> throughout one's set
> > > > letting the dancers know it was coming.  Very
> seductive foreplay.
> > > > Tease.  They all wanted it.  When you finally
> let it rip there was
> > > > truly a collective orgasm on the dancefloor. 
> The you often followed
> > > > it with "Gonna Make You Sweat"  (another hip
> house hit) and everyone
> > > > sang along with the opening lyrics: 
> "Everybody dance now."  And they
> > > > danced.  And they sweated.  How often do you
> see that happen today?
> > >
> > >
> > >
>

I totally agree. There is no soul in HHC. It all
pounds the same beat with hardly any melody or change
ups or originality. I bought 4 HHC records when it
first came out back in the early-mid 90's. Well at
least when I first heard of it. The music hasn't
evolved at all over the years. Friends from England
tell me all the K kids go to the gabber parties and
get babysit due to being on the babysitter. Kids love
it though. I know some kids who freak when they hear
this crap. I don't get it. Sometimes I will throw on a
HHC track for giggles to see if I missed something,
nope... I didn't miss anything... it still blows.

Oh, another thing I have heard over the years is the
producers put out a couple HHC tracks make some money
then go bankrupt because they blow all their money on
tweak. I know the old HHC labels wouldn't last long at
all. Not sure about these days.

This is only my opinion to the music.

~m

Subject: RE: [sfraves] "techno"

Genre Bashing is GRATE!  cause everyone has their opinions on the musical 
genres and there are some that people like and some that people dont like 
and well this forum prides itself on free and open speech which is exactly 
what we're doing.  It's not our fault Happykore easily lends itself to 
hateful and humorous critisism.  Maybe if it had some sort of substance it 
wouldnt get bashed on so much.

Buck Murdock

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country. As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Nrr Vidoe games anyone?

quoth Steve Osteen:
> I even got to play John Kerry and won a medal by shooting an un-armed
> VC boy in the back as he ran away.

Funny, that's not how the people that were actually *there* remember it.
If you're stupid enough to believe that Kerry would have purposefully
shot an un-armed boy then you probably don't care about the facts, but
he was awarded a medal for shoring his boat to save his crew from an
rocket launcher ambush. He didn't win the Silver Star for shooting
anyone; rather, he was given the medal for the courage it took to beach
his boat in the face of an attacker, an action that quite possibly saved
the lives of his entire crew.

The "Swift Boat Veterans for Truth" are funded by the biggest Republican
campaign donor in Texas. None of the men in the ad that perpetrates
these lies served on Kerry's boat, and the guy that says he treated
Kerry's wounds didn't sign his medical forms. It's the same group that
criticized John McCain (who spent years as a POW in Vietnam) during the
2000 Republican primary. They're just a washed up bunch of bitter vets
willing to say anything to keep Bush in the white house, and if you
believe a word they say, you're an idiot.

But don't take my word for it:
<http://factcheck.org/article.aspx?docID=231>

Cheers,
--

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040811185902.53190.qmail@web51708.mail.yahoo.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

My two cents=E2=80=A6

Contrary to the the fact that my email address contains the word
'techno' (it's an inside joke), I can speak from an outsider's
perspective in regards to everyone that wants to sit here and slam
other people's music preference.

For the longest time I went to parties but never really got into the
music. My mantra was 'it's all techno' because it pretty much all
sounded the same to me and 'techno' was the first term I was exposed
to when referring to electronic music. I've faced heavy critisizm from
friends and aquaintences that judged me because I attended parties but
didn't dig the music. My whole reason for attending was to hang with
my friends (many of which were totally into 'techno') and to have a
good time in general.

In the scene, there seems to be an abundance of hostility between
supporters of different genres. It's like anything, from politics to
your style of dress to the food you like to eat. People have different
tastes, but that doesn't mean everyone except for you is wrong, bad or
distasteful just because they don't like what you like (except for
republicans, fucking hurry up and evolve already har har).

I used to make fun of my 'techno'-loving friends for liking it. I
wasn't really being serious about it, but I like to heckle. I listen
to primarily punk, indie, funk, industrial, alternative and
experimental stuff, so being submerged in a scene where I didn't know
or understand the music was a bit intimidating, and my natural
response was to talk shit.

Over time I learned to understand why people like 'techno' (still
using it as a general term). Some people like to dance to it, do drugs
while listening to it, sing along to the happy hardcore lyrics,
whatever. What I had to understand was that if I wanted to be so
submerged in the party scene, I might as well learn to at least
_listen_ to it. Now I'm at a point where whilst I still don't
particularly care for electronic music, I appreciate it a a form of
art. Some of it I even like, I can even recognize tracks that friends
of mine play out because I've heard them play the same record at home
while we're chillin or what not.

So this is getting really long, but my point is that I notice a lot of
hostility on this mailing list, and the hippy in me wants me to speak
out about it. We're all entitled to opinions and everyone will always
have one. We have to deal with because it's a part of human nature, so
feel free to speak out. But the minute you think someone is less of a
person because of their musical preference, you need to stop and take
a step back to judge yourself instead.

Hope I didn't piss anyone off - this message isn't being directed at
anyone in particular (I have much love for my lovely friend Buck
Murdock ;). I just get tired of opening my email and seeing people
talk shit to one another. Where's the love?! I know no one really
takes any of this seriously, so feel free to ignore and disregard my
message/opinion :o)

Peace/Love/Drugs/Techno/Punk Rock forever!!! I'll see y'all at the
next party with my pyramid-stud belt and tasteless tattoos.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"

Woohoo on the liking most forms of music (especially punk rock - I was into
punk before I ever hit a rave). But seriously - anyone who listens to and
appreciates a wide variety of music ought to be smart enough to know that
HHC sucks the big ol' horse weeny. Only slightly worse is gabber (can we say
"steel toe boots in the dryer" anyone?).

I think HHC would be great (or is it GRATE) to get little kids into EDM (by
little, I mean children under 6). But that shit is basically the EDM
equivalent of Barney the Big Purple Nightmare of a Dinosaur.

F'realz.
----- Original Message -----
From: "Techno Tala" <technotala@gmail.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 11, 2004 12:44 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"


My two centsâ¦

Contrary to the the fact that my email address contains the word
'techno' (it's an inside joke), I can speak from an outsider's
perspective in regards to everyone that wants to sit here and slam
other people's music preference.

For the longest time I went to parties but never really got into the
music. My mantra was 'it's all techno' because it pretty much all
sounded the same to me and 'techno' was the first term I was exposed
to when referring to electronic music. I've faced heavy critisizm from
friends and aquaintences that judged me because I attended parties but
didn't dig the music. My whole reason for attending was to hang with
my friends (many of which were totally into 'techno') and to have a
good time in general.

In the scene, there seems to be an abundance of hostility between
supporters of different genres. It's like anything, from politics to
your style of dress to the food you like to eat. People have different
tastes, but that doesn't mean everyone except for you is wrong, bad or
distasteful just because they don't like what you like (except for
republicans, fucking hurry up and evolve already har har).

I used to make fun of my 'techno'-loving friends for liking it. I
wasn't really being serious about it, but I like to heckle. I listen
to primarily punk, indie, funk, industrial, alternative and
experimental stuff, so being submerged in a scene where I didn't know
or understand the music was a bit intimidating, and my natural
response was to talk shit.

Over time I learned to understand why people like 'techno' (still
using it as a general term). Some people like to dance to it, do drugs
while listening to it, sing along to the happy hardcore lyrics,
whatever. What I had to understand was that if I wanted to be so
submerged in the party scene, I might as well learn to at least
_listen_ to it. Now I'm at a point where whilst I still don't
particularly care for electronic music, I appreciate it a a form of
art. Some of it I even like, I can even recognize tracks that friends
of mine play out because I've heard them play the same record at home
while we're chillin or what not.

So this is getting really long, but my point is that I notice a lot of
hostility on this mailing list, and the hippy in me wants me to speak
out about it. We're all entitled to opinions and everyone will always
have one. We have to deal with because it's a part of human nature, so
feel free to speak out. But the minute you think someone is less of a
person because of their musical preference, you need to stop and take
a step back to judge yourself instead.

Hope I didn't piss anyone off - this message isn't being directed at
anyone in particular (I have much love for my lovely friend Buck
Murdock ;). I just get tired of opening my email and seeing people
talk shit to one another. Where's the love?! I know no one really
takes any of this seriously, so feel free to ignore and disregard my
message/opinion :o)

Peace/Love/Drugs/Techno/Punk Rock forever!!! I'll see y'all at the
next party with my pyramid-stud belt and tasteless tattoos.

Troy,

	Don't you believe in people taking any personal responsibility for  
their actions? Even in the worst case scenario -- orders coming down  
from the top that not only is it OK to commit atrocities, but you are  
*required* to commit them -- doesn't the individual soldier still have  
some responsibility to say "No, I won't do that"?

	Also, soldiers accused of or admitting to having committed atrocities  
in Vietnam are a small minority, not the average person who went over  
there.

>"steel toe boots in the dryer" anyone?).

>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Techno Tala" <technotala@gmail.com>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Wednesday, August 11, 2004 12:44 PM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"
>
>
>My two cents=85
>
>
>Contrary to the the fact that my email address contains the word
>'techno' (it's an inside joke), I can speak from an outsider's
>perspective in regards to everyone that wants to sit here and slam
>other people's music preference.
>
>For the longest time I went to parties but never really got into the
>music. My mantra was 'it's all techno' because it pretty much all
>sounded the same to me and 'techno' was the first term I was exposed
>to when referring to electronic music. I've faced heavy critisizm from
>friends and aquaintences that judged me because I attended parties but
>didn't dig the music. My whole reason for attending was to hang with
>my friends (many of which were totally into 'techno') and to have a
>good time in general.
>
>In the scene, there seems to be an abundance of hostility between
>supporters of different genres. It's like anything, from politics to
>your style of dress to the food you like to eat. People have different
>tastes, but that doesn't mean everyone except for you is wrong, bad or
>distasteful just because they don't like what you like (except for
>republicans, fucking hurry up and evolve already har har).
>
>I used to make fun of my 'techno'-loving friends for liking it. I
>wasn't really being serious about it, but I like to heckle. I listen
>to primarily punk, indie, funk, industrial, alternative and
>experimental stuff, so being submerged in a scene where I didn't know
>or understand the music was a bit intimidating, and my natural
>response was to talk shit.
>
>Over time I learned to understand why people like 'techno' (still
>using it as a general term). Some people like to dance to it, do drugs
>while listening to it, sing along to the happy hardcore lyrics,
>whatever. What I had to understand was that if I wanted to be so
>submerged in the party scene, I might as well learn to at least
>_listen_ to it. Now I'm at a point where whilst I still don't
>particularly care for electronic music, I appreciate it a a form of
>art. Some of it I even like, I can even recognize tracks that friends
>of mine play out because I've heard them play the same record at home
>while we're chillin or what not.
>
>So this is getting really long, but my point is that I notice a lot of
>hostility on this mailing list, and the hippy in me wants me to speak
>out about it. We're all entitled to opinions and everyone will always
>have one. We have to deal with because it's a part of human nature, so
>feel free to speak out. But the minute you think someone is less of a
>person because of their musical preference, you need to stop and take
>a step back to judge yourself instead.
>
>Hope I didn't piss anyone off - this message isn't being directed at
>anyone in particular (I have much love for my lovely friend Buck
>Murdock ;). I just get tired of opening my email and seeing people
>talk shit to one another. Where's the love?! I know no one really
>takes any of this seriously, so feel free to ignore and disregard my
>message/opinion :o)
>
>Peace/Love/Drugs/Techno/Punk Rock forever!!! I'll see y'all at the
>next party with my pyramid-stud belt and tasteless tattoos.
>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Protest Songs Finally Get Airplay

--=====================_11209107==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed




Protest Songs Finally Get Airplay
By: Randy Dotinga - [San Diego] North County Times
Wednesday, August 4, 2004

More than three decades ago, artists such as Joan Baez,
Edwin Starr and Crosby Stills Nash & Young took on the
Vietnam War in their music. Many of their songs remain
staples of classic rock today, even if their meanings
are lost to new listeners who don't realize that
Creedence Clearwater Revival's "Who'll Stop the Rain"
is about long lists of dead soldiers or that Buffalo
Springfield's "For What It's Worth" celebrates dissent.

Now the country is at war again, and the nation turns
its lonely eyes to musicians, who have responded with
---- well, not a whole lot. If you hear a song about
the conflict on the radio these days, chances are good
that you're listening to a stirring patriotic tribute
on a country music station.

Not that there's anything wrong with that. But where
are the protest songs?

It turns out that they're out there, and they're slowly
getting more airplay. "The level of anti-war dissent on
the radio has been ratcheted up steadily over the last
year," says Sean Ross, a media analyst who monitors the
radio industry.

More 
at: 
<http://64.4.36.250:80/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=9e3972f4b35943a069269fc3502c77f4&lat=1092256752&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2enctimes%2ecom%2farticles%2f2004%2f08%2f05%2fentertainment%2fradio%2f8_4_0413_01_41%2etxt>http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2004/08/05/entertainment/radio/8_4_0413_01_41.<http://64.4.36.250:80/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=9e3972f4b35943a069269fc3502c77f4&lat=1092256752&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2fwww%2enctimes%2ecom%2farticles%2f2004%2f08%2f05%2fentertainment%2fradio%2f8_4_0413_01_41%2etxt>txt







Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Vietnam (was: Nrr Vidoe games anyone?)

Well in the military you do as your told...you're kinda forced to from day 
one.  If you dont you face consiquences.  And in war time you either face 
one consiquence or another.  You follow orders and you kill "threats" or you 
choose not to follow orders and not kill "threats" and you in turn get shot 
or killed.  so which is more important to you and your life?  Killing an 
"enemy" or letting them kill you?  Back then you could never trust the 
"enemy" whether he was armed or not.  They were sending lil "unarmed" kids 
with bombs attached to them....and making em run up to soldiers and give em 
a hug then detonate.  I'm sorry but when it comes down to that i'm all about 
looking after my own ass.  If it moves and it's not on my team...it's dead.  
plain and simple.  that war was serriously fucked up and i agree we should 
not have been there loosing our lives for such a petty cause.  it was 
definatly a political war, and should not have happened, but since it was 
happening the soldiers had to do what they could.  Hell for the first little 
bit of the war we couldnt shoot anyone unless we were given orders to shoot. 
  that's fucked up...once they start shooting at you and you get 
"permission" the fights nearly over.  So once we basically got the go ahead 
to fire back at will...it was us or them.  And since we werent supposed to 
be over there...why not make sure you stay alive so you can come home and 
back to your family.

Buck Murdock
"I've got a fever, and the only prescription is more cowbell!"

what do you think the set overlap is between the set of Vietnam
veterans and the set of homeless people?

what's the Arabic word for "Vietnam"?




On Wed, 11 Aug 2004 13:51:18 -0700, Buck Murdock
<sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com> wrote:
> Well in the military you do as your told...you're kinda forced to from day
> one.  If you dont you face consiquences.  And in war time you either face
> one consiquence or another.  You follow orders and you kill "threats" or you
> choose not to follow orders and not kill "threats" and you in turn get shot
> or killed.  so which is more important to you and your life?  Killing an
> "enemy" or letting them kill you?  Back then you could never trust the
> "enemy" whether he was armed or not.  They were sending lil "unarmed" kids
> with bombs attached to them....and making em run up to soldiers and give em
> a hug then detonate.  I'm sorry but when it comes down to that i'm all about
> looking after my own ass.  If it moves and it's not on my team...it's dead.
> plain and simple.  that war was serriously fucked up and i agree we should
> not have been there loosing our lives for such a petty cause.  it was
> definatly a political war, and should not have happened, but since it was
> happening the soldiers had to do what they could.  Hell for the first little
> bit of the war we couldnt shoot anyone unless we were given orders to shoot.
>   that's fucked up...once they start shooting at you and you get
> "permission" the fights nearly over.  So once we basically got the go ahead
> to fire back at will...it was us or them.  And since we werent supposed to
> be over there...why not make sure you stay alive so you can come home and
> back to your family.

> 	Also, soldiers accused of or admitting to having committed 
> 	atrocities  in Vietnam are a small minority, not the average person who 
> went over  there.

I guess the point is that even if this Kerry story has any truth to it
at all (which I pretty much doubt, seeing that the author is a right-wing
nut job: http://www.salon.com/books/wire/2004/08/11/slurs/index.html),
shooting somone in battle is hardly an atrocity.  Who could actually
say which direction a boy might be running?  Who could tell if he was
unarmed?  In the heat of battle, could you tell if he was a boy or 
a man?

I guess I am just sick of this kerry/vietman smear campaign.  It insults
everyone that had to endure that hellhole, including members of my own
family.

I am glad McCain had a small amount of balls to sort of speak up against
it.  But I wish he would have forced Bush to condemn the book.

-troy

>little, I mean children under 6). But that shit is basically the EDM
>equivalent of Barney the Big Purple Nightmare of a Dinosaur.

>F'realz.
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Techno Tala" <technotala@gmail.com>
>To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Sent: Wednesday, August 11, 2004 12:44 PM
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] "techno"
>
>
>My two cents.
>
>
>Contrary to the the fact that my email address contains the word
>'techno' (it's an inside joke), I can speak from an outsider's
>perspective in regards to everyone that wants to sit here and slam
>other people's music preference.
>
>For the longest time I went to parties but never really got into the
>music. My mantra was 'it's all techno' because it pretty much all
>sounded the same to me and 'techno' was the first term I was exposed
>to when referring to electronic music. I've faced heavy critisizm from
>friends and aquaintences that judged me because I attended parties but
>didn't dig the music. My whole reason for attending was to hang with
>my friends (many of which were totally into 'techno') and to have a
>good time in general.
>
>In the scene, there seems to be an abundance of hostility between
>supporters of different genres. It's like anything, from politics to
>your style of dress to the food you like to eat. People have different
>tastes, but that doesn't mean everyone except for you is wrong, bad or
>distasteful just because they don't like what you like (except for
>republicans, fucking hurry up and evolve already har har).
>
>I used to make fun of my 'techno'-loving friends for liking it. I
>wasn't really being serious about it, but I like to heckle. I listen
>to primarily punk, indie, funk, industrial, alternative and
>experimental stuff, so being submerged in a scene where I didn't know
>or understand the music was a bit intimidating, and my natural
>response was to talk shit.
>
>Over time I learned to understand why people like 'techno' (still
>using it as a general term). Some people like to dance to it, do drugs
>while listening to it, sing along to the happy hardcore lyrics,
>whatever. What I had to understand was that if I wanted to be so
>submerged in the party scene, I might as well learn to at least
>_listen_ to it. Now I'm at a point where whilst I still don't
>particularly care for electronic music, I appreciate it a a form of
>art. Some of it I even like, I can even recognize tracks that friends
>of mine play out because I've heard them play the same record at home
>while we're chillin or what not.
>
>So this is getting really long, but my point is that I notice a lot of
>hostility on this mailing list, and the hippy in me wants me to speak
>out about it. We're all entitled to opinions and everyone will always
>have one. We have to deal with because it's a part of human nature, so
>feel free to speak out. But the minute you think someone is less of a
>person because of their musical preference, you need to stop and take
>a step back to judge yourself instead.
>
>Hope I didn't piss anyone off - this message isn't being directed at
>anyone in particular (I have much love for my lovely friend Buck
>Murdock ;). I just get tired of opening my email and seeing people
>talk shit to one another. Where's the love?! I know no one really
>takes any of this seriously, so feel free to ignore and disregard my
>message/opinion :o)
>
>Peace/Love/Drugs/Techno/Punk Rock forever!!! I'll see y'all at the
>next party with my pyramid-stud belt and tasteless tattoos.
>

Walter Cronkite Speaks Out on Reform

Dear Steve,

 Walter
Cronkite<http://emailimages.ctsg.com/ImageLibrary/DPA/E2Action/cronkite9
0x90.jpg> Walter Cronkite has often been described as "the most trusted
man in America."=20

I am delighted to tell you that he has joined the Drug Policy Alliance's
new U.S. Honorary Board. Below is his most recent syndicated column
<http://actioncenter.drugpolicy.org/ctt.asp?u=3D47049&l=3D49872>  =
discussing
drug reform, which has run in nearly 180 papers nationwide.

Our efforts to build a national advocacy organization and political
movement to end the "war on drugs" benefit in all sorts of ways when
famous and highly respected citizens choose to associate themselves
formally with the Drug Policy Alliance.=20

If you have any suggestions regarding other people of distinction who
might be considered for our U.S. Honorary Board, especially those whose
names might surprise us and others, please let me know.

Very Truly Yours,

=20
<http://emailimages.ctsg.com/dpa/fundraising/signature_ethan_nadelmann.g
if>=20

  _____ =20

Prisons Needlessly Overpopulated With Drug Offenders

By Walter Cronkite

In the midst of the soaring rhetoric of last week's Democratic
Convention, more than one speaker quoted Abraham Lincoln's first
inaugural address, invoking "the better angels of our nature."

Well, there is an especially appropriate task awaiting those heavenly
creatures: a long-overdue reform of our disastrous "war on drugs." We
should begin by recognizing its costly and inhumane dimensions.=20

Much of the nation, in one way or another, is victimized by this
failure, including, most notably, the innocents, whose exposure to drugs
is greater than ever.=20

This is despite the fact that more than 500,000 people are housed in
federal and state prisons and local jails on drug offenses. Clearly, no
punishment could be too severe for that portion of them who were
kingpins of the drug trade and who ruined so many lives. But, by far,
the majority of these prisoners are guilty of only minor offenses, such
as possessing small amounts of marijuana. That includes people who used
it only for medicinal purposes. The cost to maintain this great horde of
prisoners is more than $10 billion annually.=20

And that's just part of the cost of this war on drugs: The federal,
state and local drug-control budgets last year added up to almost $40
billion.=20

These figures were amassed by the Drug Policy Alliance, one of the
foremost national organizations seeking to bring reason to the war on
drugs and reduce substantially those caught in the terrible web of
addiction.=20

There are awful tales of tragedy and shocking injustice hidden in those
figures -- the product of an almost mindlessly draconian system called
"mandatory sentencing" in which even small offenses can draw years in
prison.=20

Thousands of women, many of them mothers of young children, are included
among those minor offenders. Those children left without motherly care
are the most innocent victims of the drug war and the reason some call
it a "war on families" as well as on drugs.=20

Women are the fastest-growing segment of the U.S. prison population,
with almost 80 percent of them incarcerated for drug offenses.=20

The deep perversity of the system lies in the fact that women with the
least culpability often get the harshest sentences.=20

Unlike the guilty drug dealer, they often have no information to trade
for a better deal from prosecutors and might end up with a harsher
sentence than the dealer gets.=20

Then there are women such as Kimba Smith, in California, who probably
knew a few things but was so terrified of her abusive boyfriend that she
refused to testify against him.=20

( Those who agree to testify, by the way, frequently are killed before
they have a chance to do so. )

Smith paid for her terrified silence with a 24-year sentence.=20

Nonviolent first offenders, male and female, caught with only small
amounts of a controlled substance frequently are given prison sentences
of five to 10 years or more.=20

As a result, the number of nonviolent offenders in the nation's prisons
is filling them to overflowing, literally.=20

The resulting overcrowding is forcing violent felons onto the streets
with early releases.=20

The Drug Policy Alliance also points out other important areas of
injustice in the present enforcement system.=20

For instance, people of color -- blacks and Hispanics -- are far more
likely to be jailed for drug offenses than others.=20

And college students caught in possession of very small amounts of
illegal substances are denied student loans and even food stamps.=20

The Alliance and other organizations are working to reform and reframe
the war on drugs. And they are finding many judges on their side, who
are rebelling against this cruel system.=20

We can expect no federal action during the congressional hiatus in
activity ahead of the November elections, but it would be of
considerable help if, across the country, campaigning politicians put
this high on their promises of legislative action, much sooner than
later.=20

Walter Cronkite's column is distributed by King Features Syndicate and
originally appeared August 6, 2004.=20

=20
<http://emailimages.ctsg.com/dpa/fundraising/rule_dotted_fundraising.gif
>=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vietnam

On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 01:51  PM, Buck Murdock wrote (in 
part):

> Well in the military you do as your told...you're kinda forced to from 
> day one.  If you dont you face consiquences.  And in war time you 
> either face one consiquence or another.  You follow orders and you 
> kill "threats" or you choose not to follow orders and not kill 
> "threats" and you in turn get shot or killed.  so which is more 
> important to you and your life?  Killing an "enemy" or letting them 
> kill you?  Back then you could never trust the "enemy" whether he was 
> armed or not.  They were sending lil "unarmed" kids with bombs 
> attached to them....and making em run up to soldiers and give em a hug 
> then detonate.

	In John Kerry's case, he apparently wasn't being threatened when on 
his own initiative he chased down and killed an unarmed teenager. And 
no, I'm not defending Bush, and you're welcome to make whatever 
comparisons or attacks on him you want. I'll likely agree with you. But 
let's not make the mistake of saying "It doesn't matter that Kerry did 
X, because Bush did Y."

> I'm sorry but when it comes down to that i'm all about looking after 
> my own ass.  If it moves and it's not on my team...it's dead.  plain 
> and simple.  that war was serriously fucked up and i agree we should 
> not have been there loosing our lives for such a petty cause.

	It wasn't a "petty cause." Three countries (South Vietnam, Cambodia, 
and Laos) were overrun by the North Vietnamese communists or 
insurgencies supported by them and fell under oppressive communist 
regimes because the United States lost that war. Millions of people 
died as a consequence.

See http://www.hawaii.edu/powerkills/COM.TAB1.GIF (remember to add 
three zeros to each number, because the totals are in thousands).

	And if you ever get a chance, watch the film "The Killing Fields" for 
a graphic look at what happened in Cambodia under the communist Khmer 
Rouge.

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

From sfraves-return-114659-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 11 23:12:17 2004
