Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Re: Vietnam

Troy,

	Here are some details on what the authors of "Unfit for Command" are 
saying. I'll let you judge for yourself. In any case, it's not just one 
guy ("right wing nut job" or not) questioning Kerry's record in 
Vietnam. It's a whole group of veterans.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


http://drudgereport.com/ufd1.htm

VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL

Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village

**Exclusive**

A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
COMMAND:

"Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
Viet Cong in a loincloth."

"And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
never have recommended him for the medal."

The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
River.

MORE

The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
played on a candidate for the presidency."

The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
donor from Texas.

The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.

MORE

George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
"haunted" by the incident:

With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
required the boats to simply move on.

Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
burning up the entire hamlet.

Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.

MORE

UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
loincloth."

ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?

"They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
pay for play... How low can they go?"

Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.

MORE

John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."

According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
ashore to pursue the enemy.

Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."

Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.

Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
Stars.

O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
. . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
the back, behind a lean to."

O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
. . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."

DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:

"Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
fled."

"Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
(with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."

Developing....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vietnam

In John Kerry's case, he apparently wasn't being threatened when on
>his own initiative he chased down and killed an unarmed teenager. And no, 
>I'm not defending Bush, and you're welcome to make whatever comparisons or 
>attacks on him you want. I'll likely agree with you. But let's not make the 
>mistake of saying "It doesn't matter that Kerry did X, because Bush did Y."

  For one i'd like to know how anyone really knows he chased him down with 
out being provoked first.  it's all hear say unless you were there chillin 
in the jungle watching him.

>It wasn't a "petty cause." Three countries (South Vietnam, Cambodia, and 
>Laos) were overrun by the North Vietnamese communists or insurgencies 
>supported by them and fell under oppressive communist regimes because the 
>United States lost that war. Millions of people died as a consequence.

To me...that's a petty cause.  It aint our country who cares what's goin on 
over there.  We had serious probelms going on in our own contry...still do, 
but back then there were problems in the country that could have been taken 
care of or at least we could have tried to take care of em.  How many 
thousands of men and women died and how many millions of dollars were 
wasted, fighting someone elses fight.  If the south didnt want to be 
communist, then fight your own damn fight.  You'll either win and get what 
you want, or you'll be totally eliminated and it wont matter, at least you 
gave it your all to try and stop it.  We really had no business being over 
there other than to stop the spread of communisim...because of the Great Big 
Red Scare.  And that wasnt really an enemy of anyone but our government.  
And our government felt it was right to send off our children to die for a 
cause that didnt benifit them in anyway.

>	And if you ever get a chance, watch the film "The Killing Fields" for a 
>graphic look at what happened in Cambodia under the communist Khmer Rouge.

  Seen it, good movie...i dig it.  Sucks that shit was going on.  but you 
know what, that shit went on in other contries...and still does.  and again 
it all falls back on, if it doesnt benifit our country, then way waste lives 
and resources trying to stop it?  sure it's the nice thing to do...but is it 
really worth loosing all our own people over?  Or having the few that 
survived come home to a country that hates them for their actions, when all 
they were doing was following the chain of command and trying to survive so 
they could get the hell out of what they too felt was a pointless war to 
fight.  I'm sorry but if i somehow got stuck in a war that i didnt support, 
i would do anything and everything to ensure that i survived.  if that means 
possibly killing the occasional civilian or child or VC regular, than so be 
it.  When my life is on the line its the only life i look after.  Many of 
our soldiers felt the same way and had to do things that under normal 
circumstances would not do...and look how badly it's fucked some of them up. 
  and who do we have to blame?  our own dumbass chickenshit government.

Buck Murdock
"I've got a fever, and the only prescription is more cowbell!"

>>you choose not to follow orders and not kill "threats" and you in turn get 
>>shot or killed.  so which is more important to you and your life?  Killing 
>>an "enemy" or letting them kill you?  Back then you could never trust the 
>>"enemy" whether he was armed or not.  They were sending lil "unarmed" kids 
>>with bombs attached to them....and making em run up to soldiers and give 
>>em a hug then detonate.

>attacks on him you want. I'll likely agree with you. But let's not make the 
>mistake of saying "It doesn't matter that Kerry did X, because Bush did Y."

>>own ass.  If it moves and it's not on my team...it's dead.  plain and

>>been there loosing our lives for such a petty cause.

>	It wasn't a "petty cause." Three countries (South Vietnam, Cambodia, and 
>Laos) were overrun by the North Vietnamese communists or insurgencies 
>supported by them and fell under oppressive communist regimes because the 
>United States lost that war. Millions of people died as a consequence.

On Wed, 11 Aug 2004, Starchild wrote:

> Troy,
>
> 	Here are some details on what the authors of "Unfit for Command" are
> saying. I'll let you judge for yourself. In any case, it's not just one
> guy ("right wing nut job" or not) questioning Kerry's record in
> Vietnam. It's a whole group of veterans.
>
> Peace, love & liberty,
> 					<<< Starchild >>>
>
>
> http://drudgereport.com/ufd1.htm
>
> VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL
>
> Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village
>
> **Exclusive**
>
> A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
> military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
> COMMAND:
>
> "Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
> Viet Cong in a loincloth."
>
> "And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
> never have recommended him for the medal."
>
> The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
> slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
> River.
>
> MORE
>
> The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
> after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
> Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
> played on a candidate for the presidency."
>
> The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
> will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
> donor from Texas.
>
> The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
> Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.
>
> MORE
>
> George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
> numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
> particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
> "haunted" by the incident:
>
> With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
> three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
> peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
> no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
> obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
> required the boats to simply move on.
>
> Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
> Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
> heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
> officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
> burning up the entire hamlet.
>
> Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.
>
> MORE
>
> UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
> Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
> loincloth."
>
> ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?
>
> "They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
> a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
> pay for play... How low can they go?"
>
> Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
> Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.
>
> MORE
>
> John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
> Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
> through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
> days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
> boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
> and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."
>
> According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
> three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
> the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
> his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
> directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
> followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
> further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
> near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
> his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
> ashore to pursue the enemy.
>
> Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
> of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
> intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."
>
> Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
> crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
> boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
> involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
> writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.
>
> Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
> day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
> many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
> at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
> zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
> disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
> weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
> Stars.
>
> O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
> struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
> loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
> may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
> shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
> . . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
> perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
> the back, behind a lean to."
>
> O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
> armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
> war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
> not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
> are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
> details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
> that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
> the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
> who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
> . . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
> face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
> after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
> Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
> armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."
>
> DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
> officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:
>
> "Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
> to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
> discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
> that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
> single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
> to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
> operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
> fled."
>
> "Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
> Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
> the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
> Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
> loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
> that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
> (with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
> Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
> been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."
>
> Developing....
>
>

At 04:01 PM 8/11/2004, scosol@scosol.org wrote:
>First it's "boy", now it's "teenager"....
>
>This just smacks of propaganda-
>Bottom line- until you've been *in combat*, you have no platform from which
>to judge the man's action in combat, period.

Yes, I agree with you totally.  And the kind of "combat" we became involved 
with both in Vietnam and now Iraq is the worst.  Many of the "enemy" were 
not in uniforms.  Very young people, both male and female, carried weapons 
or were actively engaged in supporting their causes.

I really don't want to get involved in the sordid details of our "war" in 
Vietnam.  One lesson I took away from the whole mess:  had we become 
involved in constructive engagement, both political and economic, with the 
Vietnamese back then we would have had what we have now, without all the 
bloodshed -- a trade partner moving in the direction we would have 
preferred.  Something electronic I bought the other day had "Made in 
Vietnam" on it:)

Same with Cuba.  Castro came to us first for support after his just 
revolution and what did we do?  Attempted to assassinate him;  supported an 
invasion of Cuba; and pretty much gave him the finger.  So he turned to the 
Russians for aid and trade.  We still embargo that country.  Stupid.  Had 
we engaged Cuba's socialist regime in the early sixties we would all be 
smoking Cuban cigars now.

Yet we supported totalitarian regimes all over South America over the 
years, as long as they weren't "socialist."

Bottom line.  Constructive engagement should be preferred over military 
action, trade embargoes, and political isolation.  Certainly careful 
manipulation of Saddam, as we did prior to the Gulf War, could have 
achieved a better end than the current mess.  Engagement with Iran would 
produce much better short and long-term results than sabre waving.  And so 
on....  IMHO.

Love,

Apollo

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) Re: Vietnam

Did you even read that?

A bunch of boats are going down the river and are fired upon-
Both boats turn towards the assault and land on the beach.
Kerry's boat is hit by a rocket propelled grenade.
A teenage VC pops out of a hole in front of Kerry *clutching the grenade
launcher* and starts running away.
Kerry shoots him.
Uhm- what more justification do you personally need for shooting an enemy
combatant?
This guy just HIT THE FUCKING BOAT WITH AN RPG.

The text seems to focus more on the fact that the *rest* of all the boat
crewmen deserved medals for their actions too...

On 8/11/04 4:14 PM, "Starchild" <sfdreamer@earthlink.net> wrote:

> Troy,
> 
> Here are some details on what the authors of "Unfit for Command" are
> saying. I'll let you judge for yourself. In any case, it's not just one
> guy ("right wing nut job" or not) questioning Kerry's record in
> Vietnam. It's a whole group of veterans.
> 
> Peace, love & liberty,
> <<< Starchild >>>
> 
> 
> http://drudgereport.com/ufd1.htm
> 
> VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL
> 
> Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village
> 
> **Exclusive**
> 
> A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
> military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
> COMMAND:
> 
> "Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
> Viet Cong in a loincloth."
> 
> "And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
> never have recommended him for the medal."
> 
> The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
> slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
> River.
> 
> MORE
> 
> The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
> after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
> Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
> played on a candidate for the presidency."
> 
> The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
> will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
> donor from Texas.
> 
> The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
> Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.
> 
> MORE
> 
> George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
> numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
> particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
> "haunted" by the incident:
> 
> With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
> three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
> peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
> no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
> obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
> required the boats to simply move on.
> 
> Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
> Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
> heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
> officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
> burning up the entire hamlet.
> 
> Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.
> 
> MORE
> 
> UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
> Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
> loincloth."
> 
> ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?
> 
> "They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
> a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
> pay for play... How low can they go?"
> 
> Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
> Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.
> 
> MORE
> 
> John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
> Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
> through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
> days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
> boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
> and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."
> 
> According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
> three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
> the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
> his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
> directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
> followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
> further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
> near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
> his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
> ashore to pursue the enemy.
> 
> Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
> of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
> intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."
> 
> Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
> crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
> boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
> involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
> writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.
> 
> Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
> day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
> many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
> at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
> zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
> disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
> weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
> Stars.
> 
> O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
> struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
> loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
> may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
> shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
> . . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
> perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
> the back, behind a lean to."
> 
> O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
> armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
> war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
> not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
> are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
> details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
> that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
> the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
> who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
> . . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
> face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
> after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
> Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
> armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."
> 
> DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
> officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:
> 
> "Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
> to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
> discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
> that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
> single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
> to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
> operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
> fled."
> 
> "Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
> Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
> the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
> Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
> loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
> that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
> (with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
> Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
> been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."
> 
> Developing....
> 
>

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Vietnam

Now here's a solid fact you should consider Starchild.

The people who "served" with Kerry who your quoting about the teenager 
incident weren't even in his company. And by them saying "served" means they 
were in Vietnam at the same time. Most not even in the immediate range of 
the incident.

Also, you have to take into the deepest of consideration that if this EVER 
was as serious of an incident or issue then such "horrible acts" would have 
surfaced long before his run for presidency.
The group of pissed of veterans could have appealed to revoke his medals a 
very LONG time ago.

And only now b/c of the elections are such things "coming to light" b/c of 
the enormous amount of funds and paid testimonies.

Which makes more sense ?

A.) A blood thirsty soldier trigger happy to gun down anyone in his way with 
no remorse of concern for human life.
B.)Or vietnam soldier in a intense situation unsure of the safety of himself 
and his platoon.

Even if you pick A. and think that he did gun down an innocent teenager with 
no concern, don't you think him being that person would have had many more 
incidents like this.. thus flagging his actions and putting him in more 
scrutiny for his combat mentality.

Come on now. Your talking about a one time situation that could of easily 
been either side. We couldn't possibly validate to the fullest any argument. 
But you can use simple logic and determine; if he was that kind of person 
doesn't it make sense that there would be more incidents and more 
information proving his character was of a malicious murderer in war time.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vietnam

On 11 August 2004, Buck Murdock wrote:

>   Seen it, good movie...i dig it.  Sucks that shit was going on.  but you
> know what, that shit went on in other contries...and still does.  and again
> it all falls back on, if it doesnt benifit our country, then way waste lives
> and resources trying to stop it?  sure it's the nice thing to do...but is it
> really worth loosing all our own people over?  Or having the few that
> survived come home to a country that hates them for their actions, when all
> they were doing was following the chain of command and trying to survive so
> they could get the hell out of what they too felt was a pointless war to
> fight.  I'm sorry but if i somehow got stuck in a war that i didnt support,
> i would do anything and everything to ensure that i survived.  if that means
> possibly killing the occasional civilian or child or VC regular, than so be
> it.  When my life is on the line its the only life i look after.  Many of
> our soldiers felt the same way and had to do things that under normal
> circumstances would not do...and look how badly it's fucked some of them up.

I met one of them two weeks ago in Iowa.  A sniper (or a "sharpshooter",
as faux news heads have instructed their reporters to call them) of all
things.  He could barely function at a basic level.  Would almost
collapse to the ground for no appararent reason, other than the mind
fuck he had just gone through.  You could see it in his eyes.  You could
also see in his eyes, and from talking to him, that he was a good kid
overall.  Just sent into a foreign country to "murder for you guys."
Well, it wasn't "for" me, or for most people I know.

And these guys are given a two week break to come back home, see their
family and friends, before being shipped back to kill again.  I
certainly hope that guy makes it back home another time.

>   and who do we have to blame?  our own dumbass chickenshit government.

Greg Palast claims he interviewed someone with the Texas Natl. Guard who
admitted to destroying all those documents in Bush's guard duty record.
It's part of a BBC documentary available via the following series of
links:
http://freecache.org/http://www.fucksuvs.com/bush_family_fortunes_chunk_1.wmv
http://freecache.org/http://www.fucksuvs.com/bush_family_fortunes_chunk_2.wmv
http://freecache.org/http://www.fucksuvs.com/bush_family_fortunes_chunk_3.wmv
http://freecache.org/http://www.fucksuvs.com/bush_family_fortunes_chunk_4.wmv
(saving them to disk is probably your best bet)



http://www.jcthedj.com

FUTURE PROPHECIES
Future Prophecies, aka Richard Animashaun Thomas & Tony Anthun are Drum&Bass=
=20
artists from Norway. They perform as a DJ/live (Hybrid Session) act comprisi=
ng=20
of jazz musicians and DJs, culminating in a new sound breaking traditional=20
musical barriers. Their extensive knowledge stems from relentless work as cl=
ub=20
DJs and jazz musicians throughout Norway, the rest of Europe and the States.=
=20
Having had releases on Subtitles, Renegade Hardware, Moving Shadow, Certific=
ate=20
18, Outbreak, G2, Fabric Live 03 (DJ Hype), Boombox and Kickin, and remixes=20
with Mari Boine/Universal and Jamelia/EMI, they are a force to be reckoned w=
ith.=20
They are also starting their own label in the summer 2004.
Click here for a short clip of their hybrid/live act:=20
http://www.SublunaryAM.com/FuturePropHybridSession.wmv=20

=C2=B7         Paul B remix on Disturbed  Recordings summer 2004=20
Richard elaborates on the birth of Future Prophecies: "After doing a local=20
gig with his new project Poetry, Tony was DJ-ing at the same club and approa=
ched=20
me asking if I would be interested in doing some stuff on his project Huba=20
Buba". It was after this that they began work together and soon experienced=20=
the=20
magic of having musical knowledge and extensive DJing backgrounds, which=20
resulted in several 12" releases on labels such as Boombox, Kickin, Black Je=
sus and=20
Quiet Riot. It also led to them starting their own label, Domination, on=20
which they released Poetry's EP.
After some years of full studio work, playing regularly at local clubs and=20
touring Europe and the States as sidemen with different Norwegian bands and=20
projects, they started out by releasing material on Certificate 18 and Teebe=
e's=20
label, Subtitles.
They are now situated in Norway. Their sets, usually when not straight=20
DJ-ing, consist of turntablism, computers, and live acts on different settin=
gs=20
working with drums, saxophone, human beat box, synths, vocalists and tabla.
"Our music philosophy is not to have any boundaries. We try to make what=20
feels good at any given moment. Our aim is to create a freedom to do what we=
 want.=20
Our influences come from all genres; r&b, pop, rock, jazz, indian, breakbeat=
,=20
techno, house, and we believe people shouldn't forget where they are coming=20
from. A lot of people out there diss other styles, even before they really h=
ave=20
checked them out, just to follow some kind of trend. We feel that there is a=
=20
lot of good (and bad) music in all genres - so why miss out on the good stuf=
f=20
just for the sake of fitting in with the scene? We try to blend all kinds of=
=20
styles in our music, be it saxophone, flute, vocals, tabla, guitar and so on=
.=20
But in the end whatever we do, the main thing is to achieve a kind of=20
sensation, a feel that this is it - the moment".=20
And now Future Prophecies are here to challenge the way drum'n'bass is heard=
=20
- something so many are afraid to do.
=20

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:
 
"did you know that sometimes, image is everything, ig?"
"yea, that's why i am thinking about shaving my head." 
"lots of people shave their head. do you think i should marry you for it?"
"no, but i was hoping that you might be sort of into me since i won't have blonde hair like everyone else does lately."
"it will grow back, you know. i don't remember you being blonde either."
"i could be if i wanted to. my hair won't grow back... not if i can help it. i am going to eat as little folic acid as possible, and you'll see." :)

hello, this is a continuation of a fictional piece:

"do you follow the rules?"
"sometimes."
"why?"
"well, sometimes, i have no choice, and sometimes, i
just think the rules are pretty good, so i follow
them, and sometimes, i don't like the rules, but it
seems like the best thing to do at the time would be
to follow the rules."
"why is that?"
"well, sometimes, i get some extra money or an extra
five minutes of sleep if i follow the rules."
"so, you are driven by greed."
"no, i am just tired and hungry." :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Sj man is killed by Sj cops for chop lifting

Brandishing a knife to store employees?

Then lunging at the cops?
*After* they had already tried the non-lethal Taser?

There's always more to the story...
(no friend of SJPD myself)

Aug. 12 (BCN) =8B  Two San Jose police officers shot and killed a shoplifting
suspect this morning after the man allegedly lunged at them with a knife,
Sgt. Steve Dixon said today.

 Employees at a Radio Shack store at 779 Story Road called police to report
that there was a shoplifter in the store, who when confronted by employees,
had thrown merchandise at them and brandished a knife, Dixon said.

 Two officers arrived at the scene and attempted to detain the suspect,
described only as a man in his late 20s or early 30s, who resisted arrest,
according to police.

 The suspect began to run westbound on Story Road and officers deployed
Taser, but it didn't stop him and foot chase ensued, Dixon said. The suspec=
t
then allegedly lunged toward officers with a knife in hands, causing both
officers to open fire, killing the suspect, Dixon said.

 The suspect was shot just past intersection of Roberts Street and Story
Road.

choplifter was grate !  hell, i still got that sheite...  in fact i've
got probably every 68k game known to man.  some of my fav's are
Acolade's Gran Prix (amazing if only for the fact that you can get a
full-motion 3d-style driving game to run flawlessly on an 8MHz Mac
Plus !), loderunner, glider, crystal quest, OXYD, bolo, Star Wars, and
of course the ubiquotous Net-Trek (used to play that with all the
programmer geeks with sparc 1's whenever i wasn't workin'/commandering
the work computers to do my schoolwork on ;)

of course i think my absolute fav is a toss up between virtual valerie
or tony's girl =P

-=dave

ps - for the color games Maelstrom, Arashi, SpaceQuest, Prince of
Persia and Otherworld P0wn3d !

anyone in need of 68k shizzle, i have the key to your mecca. . .

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Re: Vietnam

	It seems reasonable to assume as you do that the young VietCong 
fighter who Kerry shot was the same individual who had fired at Kerry's 
boat, although the account doesn't actually say that. But several 
well-armed troops chasing down a lone fleeing teenager who had no 
weapon to fight back (you can hardly use a grenade launcher while 
running away from people who are shooting at you, even if one assumes 
it was loaded) and shooting him in the back isn't exactly the kind of 
heroic action deserving of a medal, now is it?

	And what can be said about these incidents?

>> George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
>> numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
>> particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
>> "haunted" by the incident:
>>
>> With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
>> three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
>> peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
>> no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
>> obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
>> required the boats to simply move on.
>>
>> Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
>> Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
>> heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
>> officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
>> burning up the entire hamlet.
>>
>> Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.

				<<< Starchild >>>


On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 04:40  PM, scosol@scosol.org wrote:

> Did you even read that?
>
> A bunch of boats are going down the river and are fired upon-
> Both boats turn towards the assault and land on the beach.
> Kerry's boat is hit by a rocket propelled grenade.
> A teenage VC pops out of a hole in front of Kerry *clutching the 
> grenade
> launcher* and starts running away.
> Kerry shoots him.
> Uhm- what more justification do you personally need for shooting an 
> enemy
> combatant?
> This guy just HIT THE FUCKING BOAT WITH AN RPG.
>
> The text seems to focus more on the fact that the *rest* of all the 
> boat
> crewmen deserved medals for their actions too...
>
> On 8/11/04 4:14 PM, "Starchild" <sfdreamer@earthlink.net> wrote:
>
>> Troy,
>>
>> Here are some details on what the authors of "Unfit for Command" are
>> saying. I'll let you judge for yourself. In any case, it's not just 
>> one
>> guy ("right wing nut job" or not) questioning Kerry's record in
>> Vietnam. It's a whole group of veterans.
>>
>> Peace, love & liberty,
>> <<< Starchild >>>
>>
>>
>> http://drudgereport.com/ufd1.htm
>>
>> VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL
>>
>> Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village
>>
>> **Exclusive**
>>
>> A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
>> military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
>> COMMAND:
>>
>> "Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
>> Viet Cong in a loincloth."
>>
>> "And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
>> never have recommended him for the medal."
>>
>> The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
>> slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
>> River.
>>
>> MORE
>>
>> The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
>> after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
>> Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
>> played on a candidate for the presidency."
>>
>> The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
>> will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
>> donor from Texas.
>>
>> The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
>> Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.
>>
>> MORE
>>
>> George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
>> numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
>> particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
>> "haunted" by the incident:
>>
>> With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
>> three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
>> peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
>> no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
>> obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
>> required the boats to simply move on.
>>
>> Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
>> Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
>> heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
>> officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
>> burning up the entire hamlet.
>>
>> Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.
>>
>> MORE
>>
>> UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
>> Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
>> loincloth."
>>
>> ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?
>>
>> "They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
>> a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
>> pay for play... How low can they go?"
>>
>> Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
>> Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.
>>
>> MORE
>>
>> John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
>> Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
>> through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
>> days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
>> boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
>> and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."
>>
>> According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
>> three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
>> the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
>> his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
>> directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
>> followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
>> further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
>> near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
>> his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
>> ashore to pursue the enemy.
>>
>> Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
>> of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
>> intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."
>>
>> Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
>> crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
>> boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
>> involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
>> writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.
>>
>> Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
>> day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
>> many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
>> at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
>> zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
>> disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
>> weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
>> Stars.
>>
>> O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
>> struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
>> loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
>> may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
>> shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
>> . . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
>> perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
>> the back, behind a lean to."
>>
>> O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
>> armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
>> war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
>> not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
>> are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
>> details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
>> that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
>> the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
>> who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
>> . . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
>> face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
>> after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
>> Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
>> armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."
>>
>> DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
>> officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:
>>
>> "Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
>> to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
>> discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
>> that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
>> single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
>> to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
>> operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
>> fled."
>>
>> "Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
>> Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
>> the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
>> Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
>> loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
>> that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
>> (with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
>> Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
>> been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."
>>
>> Developing....
>>
>>
>> On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 02:20  PM, Troy Sheets wrote:
>>

>>>> atrocities  in Vietnam are a small minority, not the average person
>>>> who

>>> at all (which I pretty much doubt, seeing that the author is a

>>> nut job:

>>> unarmed?  In the heat of battle, could you tell if he was a boy or
>>> a man?

At 07:06 PM 8/12/2004, Starchild wrote:
>         It seems reasonable to assume as you do that the young VietCong 
> fighter who Kerry shot was the same individual who had fired at Kerry's 
> boat, although the account doesn't actually say that. But several 
> well-armed troops chasing down a lone fleeing teenager who had no weapon 
> to fight back (you can hardly use a grenade launcher while running away 
> from people who are shooting at you, even if one assumes it was loaded) 
> and shooting him in the back isn't exactly the kind of heroic action 
> deserving of a medal, now is it?
>
>         And what can be said about these incidents?

What can be said?  That when you unleash the true evil of war you can 
expect evil in return.  When good souls enter the heart of darkness they 
can't help but be affected by this man made hell.  In combat one has little 
time to make decisions about whether one's actions are good or bad...one 
reacts swiftly to preserve one's ass and the butts of your comrades.

So...never ever enter this dark place of war unless it is absolutely 
necessary.  Everyone pays a heavy price.

This book about Kerry, BTW, is just more political bullshit.

Love,

Apollo

hypocrite fifth columnist
who isn't trying to disrupt the election so the GOP will win - he's an 
"idealist" committed
to combating the power of large corporations even though in his personal 
business areas,
he's just as bad as any cigar chewing fat cat slavedriver.....

when trying to figure what exactly happened, one has to examine not only 
facts, but the motivations,
integrity, and how well one story cross references with the others (minus 
the failings of witnesses'
memories)

it's just like with the law and trials - that's why lawyers get the big 
bucks - to nail down
inconsistencies (the defense) to get their client off or emotionally sway 
the jury
despite the "facts" (the prosecutors)

in such matters as Vietnam, the only person whom I'd believe was objective 
would be a time traveling
Martian

and this principle goes double for politics.  and 10x for Vietnam mixed 
with politics

and look at the diction used in accounting this "incident" - it is subtly 
inflammatory
and would sufficiently emotionally influence a naive reader towards viewing 
Kerry in a negative
light.  You only have to sway people ever so much - no really big time, but 
just enough to get
the subconscious processing going even though they may intellectually 
reject the information.
Enough subtle sources build up on top of one another - lots of little lies 
compound into a more
diffuse "Big Lie" - which can't be refuted as well as one sharp and crisp.

Karl Rove et al know exactly what they're doing.  They learnt from 
Goebbel's mistakes

not that I'm all for Kerry, mind you.  he's just a kinder, gentler fascist 
- a speed bump on the road
to hell America is going down and there's no u-turns, no exits, and this 
process America is going
thru can't be stopped.

"objective" book

all of Kerry's war record
is a big lie has an interesting history and has made a few inflammatory 
statements in the past:

On FreeRepublic.com, Corsi has, among other things, said
that "ragheads" are "boy buggers"; referred to "John F*ing
Kerry"; called Senator Hillary Clinton a "Fat Hog"; referred
to her daughter as "Chubby Chelsie" Clinton; referred to
Janet Reno as "Janet Rhino"; called Katie Couric "Little
Katie Communist"; suggested Kerry was "practicing Judaism";
and expressed the wish that a small plane that had crashed
into a building in Los Angeles had instead crashed into the
set of NBC'S The West Wing, thereby killing actor Martin
Sheen

>>>VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL
>>>
>>>Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village
>>>
>>>**Exclusive**
>>>
>>>A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
>>>military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
>>>COMMAND:
>>>
>>>"Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
>>>Viet Cong in a loincloth."
>>>
>>>"And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
>>>never have recommended him for the medal."
>>>
>>>The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
>>>slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
>>>River.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
>>>after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
>>>Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
>>>played on a candidate for the presidency."
>>>
>>>The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
>>>will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
>>>donor from Texas.
>>>
>>>The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
>>>Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
>>>numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
>>>particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
>>>"haunted" by the incident:
>>>
>>>With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
>>>three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
>>>peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
>>>no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
>>>obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
>>>required the boats to simply move on.
>>>
>>>Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
>>>Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
>>>heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
>>>officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
>>>burning up the entire hamlet.
>>>
>>>Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
>>>Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
>>>loincloth."
>>>
>>>ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?
>>>
>>>"They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
>>>a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
>>>pay for play... How low can they go?"
>>>
>>>Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
>>>Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
>>>Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
>>>through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
>>>days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
>>>boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
>>>and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."
>>>
>>>According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
>>>three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
>>>the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
>>>his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
>>>directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
>>>followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
>>>further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
>>>near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
>>>his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
>>>ashore to pursue the enemy.
>>>
>>>Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
>>>of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
>>>intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."
>>>
>>>Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
>>>crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
>>>boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
>>>involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
>>>writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.
>>>
>>>Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
>>>day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
>>>many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
>>>at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
>>>zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
>>>disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
>>>weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
>>>Stars.
>>>
>>>O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
>>>struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
>>>loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
>>>may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
>>>shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
>>>. . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
>>>perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
>>>the back, behind a lean to."
>>>
>>>O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
>>>armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
>>>war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
>>>not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
>>>are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
>>>details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
>>>that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
>>>the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
>>>who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
>>>. . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
>>>face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
>>>after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
>>>Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
>>>armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."
>>>
>>>DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
>>>officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:
>>>
>>>"Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
>>>to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
>>>discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
>>>that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
>>>single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
>>>to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
>>>operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
>>>fled."
>>>
>>>"Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
>>>Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
>>>the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
>>>Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
>>>loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
>>>that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
>>>(with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
>>>Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
>>>been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."
>>>
>>>Developing....
>>>
>>>
>>>On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 02:20  PM, Troy Sheets wrote:
>>>
>>>>>Also, soldiers accused of or admitting to having committed
>>>>>atrocities  in Vietnam are a small minority, not the average person
>>>>>who
>>>>>went over  there.
>>>>
>>>>I guess the point is that even if this Kerry story has any truth to it
>>>>at all (which I pretty much doubt, seeing that the author is a
>>>>right-wing
>>>>nut job: http://www.salon.com/books/wire/2004/08/11/slurs/index.html),
>>>>shooting somone in battle is hardly an atrocity.  Who could actually
>>>>say which direction a boy might be running?  Who could tell if he was
>>>>unarmed?  In the heat of battle, could you tell if he was a boy or
>>>>a man?
>>>>
>>>>I guess I am just sick of this kerry/vietman smear campaign.  It
>>>>insults
>>>>everyone that had to endure that hellhole, including members of my own
>>>>family.
>>>>
>>>>I am glad McCain had a small amount of balls to sort of speak up
>>>>against
>>>>it.  But I wish he would have forced Bush to condemn the book.
>>>>
>>>>-troy

Subject: RE: [sfraves] (nrr) Re: Vietnam

Continuing on from Apollo's statement...

Now think for a second that a fleeing soldier appears to be lugging a
bazooka with them.  Now RPG's are only one shot, why would the "teen" be
carrying it.  It almost sounds like a full on trap was about to be
sprung.  Put weapon in hand of someone visible and have them run towards
the VC's backup.  Why would a single teen be firing on 3 boats if had no
kind of alternative plan?  Second would be to try and get to shore asap
in case there is more, they will have the advantage on you since they're
hiding in thick jungle foliage.  This is speculation of course, but
these are also the decisions that need to run through a soldiers mind
when they are protecting the lives of three boatfulls of their own men.
Yes soldiers have the "option" to desert in battle for moral reasons.
But when you see your best friend next to you who has already saved your
life or you've sworn to protect them, anyone at that point who looks
like an enemy is going down.

Also, at this time the idea that our President could be very very wrong
in going to war without a just cause had just barely started coming into
people's minds.  Before this virtually every war had been 'just.'  The
Korean War started making people think twice about it then when Vietnam
happened, the peace movement was going in to full swing.  We had never
seen anything like this before.  America had always gone in, kicked
butt, had casualties but saved the day.  Here was this Red Threat.
Communists could destroy our very way of life.  People didn't have
access to the education we have now.  They had no internet.  These
people for the most part truly believed they were helping all of
humanity by fighting in Vietnam.  Stopping a new kind of Hitler.  At
least until they got there.

And honestly.. For this group to blame anything on Kerry for Vietnam and
not turn one finger towards Bush for giving the go on attacking Iraq, in
which his decision to drop the bombs killed many many innocents.  His
voice pulled the proverbial trigger.  He might as well have been flying
every mission.  He knew exactly what was going to happen to civilian
lives.  Just because Kerry was face to face with one that actually fired
on him and his men, doesn't mean Bush gets to hide behind his desk in
the Oval Office and wash his hands of it.  He lied to congress, the
American Public and the world about our reasons we were even going.
Regardless if his sources messed up, as president he answers for all
those who work for him.  If he commands them, then what they do under
his command is his direct personal responsibility.

Has anyone on the list been to the jungles of Vietnam?  I haven't but
I'm pretty sure that they're not a very bright place, probably very
dark, shapes are hard to discern, especially with natives who know how
to blend in.  Seeing a figure holding a stick from a boat would look
very much like anyone holding a gun.  You responsibility at that point
if you're still alive is to alert your superior so they can alert theirs
and try and make sure the person who just shot at you doesn't report to
their superior.  War is ugly.  I hate war.  I don't even really like
Kerry, but the political mudslinging on both sides of the fence this
year is making me absolutely sick.  I honestly can't see how the record
of a few isolated incidents in the vietnam war vs. what Bush has done
and is doing currently.

Voting for Jon Stewart,
Rayn

At 07:06 PM 8/12/2004, Starchild wrote:
>         It seems reasonable to assume as you do that the young 
> VietCong
> fighter who Kerry shot was the same individual who had fired at
Kerry's 
> boat, although the account doesn't actually say that. But several 
> well-armed troops chasing down a lone fleeing teenager who had no
weapon 
> to fight back (you can hardly use a grenade launcher while running
away 
> from people who are shooting at you, even if one assumes it was
loaded) 
> and shooting him in the back isn't exactly the kind of heroic action 
> deserving of a medal, now is it?
>
>         And what can be said about these incidents?

What can be said?  That when you unleash the true evil of war you can 
expect evil in return.  When good souls enter the heart of darkness they

can't help but be affected by this man made hell.  In combat one has
little 
time to make decisions about whether one's actions are good or bad...one

reacts swiftly to preserve one's ass and the butts of your comrades.

So...never ever enter this dark place of war unless it is absolutely 
necessary.  Everyone pays a heavy price.

This book about Kerry, BTW, is just more political bullshit.

Love,

Apollo

is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed." -Abraham
Lincoln

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
become 
visible."

party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to

>>>http://drudgereport.com/ufd1.htm
>>>
>>>VETS CHARGE: KERRY KILLED FLEEING TEEN; LIED FOR MEDAL
>>>
>>>Slaughters Animals, Burns Down Tiny Village
>>>
>>>**Exclusive**
>>>
>>>A veterans group seeking to deeply discredit Democrat John Kerry's
>>>military service will charge in the new bombshell book UNFIT FOR
>>>COMMAND:
>>>
>>>"Kerry earned his Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage
>>>Viet Cong in a loincloth."
>>>
>>>"And if Kerry's superiors had known the truth at the time, they would
>>>never have recommended him for the medal."
>>>
>>>The book also claims to detail how Kerry personally ordered the
>>>slaughter of small animals at a small hamlet along the Song Bo De
>>>River.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>The book, set for release next week, hit #1 on the AMAZON hitparade
>>>after the DRUDGE REPORT revealed details of the book -- a book the
>>>Kerry campaign believes is the "the dirtiest of all dirty tricks ever
>>>played on a candidate for the presidency."
>>>
>>>The Kerry campaign is planning to vigorously counter the charges and
>>>will accuse the veteran's groups of being well-financed by a top Bush
>>>donor from Texas.
>>>
>>>The vets have launched a blistering new TV commercial questioning
>>>Kerry's honor and calling him a liar.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>George Bates, an officer in Coastal Division 11, participated in
>>>numerous operations with Kerry. In UNFIT FOR COMMAND, Bates recalls a
>>>particular patrol with Kerry on the Song Bo De River. He is still
>>>"haunted" by the incident:
>>>
>>>With Kerry in the lead, the boats approached a small hamlet with
>>>three or four grass huts. Pigs and chickens were milling around
>>>peacefully. As the boats drew closer, the villagers fled. There were
>>>no political symbols or flags in evidence in the tiny village. It was
>>>obvious to Bates that existing policies, decency, and good sense
>>>required the boats to simply move on.
>>>
>>>Instead, Kerry beached his boat directly in the small settlement.
>>>Upon his command, the numerous small animals were slaughtered by
>>>heavy-caliber machine guns. Acting more like a pirate than a naval
>>>officer, Kerry disembarked and ran around with a Zippo lighter,
>>>burning up the entire hamlet.
>>>
>>>Bates has never forgotten Kerry's actions.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>UNFIT FOR COMMAND, DRUDGE has learned, claims Kerry "earned his
>>>Silver Star by killing a lone, fleeing, teenage Viet Cong in a
>>>loincloth."
>>>
>>>ARE THE VETS TELLING THE TRUTH?
>>>
>>>"They hired a goddamn private investigator to dig up trash!" charged
>>>a top Kerry adviser traveling with the senator late Tuesday. "This is
>>>pay for play... How low can they go?"
>>>
>>>Kerry supporters are comparing the effort by the veterans to the
>>>Arkansas State troopers tell-all against Bill Clinton.
>>>
>>>MORE
>>>
>>>John O'Neill, co-author of UNFIT FOR COMMAND, believes that "Kerry's
>>>Star would never have been awarded had his actions been reviewed
>>>through normal channels. In his case, he was awarded the medal two
>>>days after the incident with no review. The medal was arranged to
>>>boost the morale of Coastal Division 11, but it was based on false
>>>and incomplete information provided by Kerry himself."
>>>
>>>According to Kerry's Silver Star citation, Kerry was in command of a
>>>three-boat mission on the Dong Cung River. As the boats approached
>>>the target area, they came under intense enemy fire. Kerry ordered
>>>his boat to attack and all boats opened fire. He then beached
>>>directly in front of the enemy ambushers. In the battle that
>>>followed, the crews captured enemy weapons. His boat then moved
>>>further up the river to suppress more enemy fire. A rocket exploded
>>>near Kerry's boat, and he ordered to charge the enemy. Kerry beached
>>>his boat 10 feet from the rocket position and led a landing party
>>>ashore to pursue the enemy.
>>>
>>>Kerry' citation reads: "The extraordinary daring and personal courage
>>>of Lt. Kerry in attacking a numerically superior force in the face of
>>>intense fire were responsible for the highly successful mission."
>>>
>>>Here's what O'Neill and the Swiftees say: "According to Kerry's
>>>crewman Michael Madeiros, Kerry had an agreement with him to turn the
>>>boat in and onto the beach if fired upon. Each of the three boats
>>>involved in the operation was involved in the agreement." O'Neill
>>>writes that one crewman even recalls a discussion of probable medals.
>>>
>>>Doug Reese, a pro Kerry Army veteran, recounted what happened that
>>>day to O'Neill, "Far from being alone, the boats were loaded with
>>>many soldiers commanded by Reese and two other advisors. When fired
>>>at, Reese's boat--not Kerry's--was the first to beach in the ambush
>>>zone. Then Reese and other troops and advisors (not Kerry)
>>>disembarked, killing a number of Viet Cong and capturing a number of
>>>weapons. None of the participants from Reese's boat received Silver
>>>Stars.
>>>
>>>O'Neill continues: "Kerry's boat moved slightly downstream and was
>>>struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. . . .A young Viet Cong in a
>>>loincloth popped out of a hole, clutching a grenade launcher, which
>>>may or may not have been loaded. . . Tom Belodeau, a forward gunner,
>>>shot the Viet Cong with an M-60 machine gun in the leg as he fled. .
>>>. . Kerry and Medeiros (who had many troops in their boat) took off,
>>>perhaps with others, and followed the young Viet Cong and shot him in
>>>the back, behind a lean to."
>>>
>>>O'Neill concludes "Whether Kerry's dispatching of a fleeing, wounded,
>>>armed or unarmed teenage enemy was in accordance with the customs of
>>>war, it is very clear that many Vietnam veterans and most Swiftees do
>>>not consider this action to be the stuff of which medals of any kind
>>>are awarded; nor would it even be a good story if told in the cold
>>>details of reality. There is no indication that Kerry ever reported
>>>that the Viet Cong was wounded and fleeing when dispatched. Likewise,
>>>the citation simply ignores the presence of the soldiers and advisors
>>>who actually 'captured the enemy weapons' and routed the Viet Cong. .
>>>. . [and] that Kerry attacked a 'numerically superior force in the
>>>face of intense fire' is simply false. There was little or no fire
>>>after Kerry followed the plan. . . . The lone, wounded, fleeing young
>>>Viet Cong in a loincloth was hardly a force superior to the heavily
>>>armed Swift Boat and its crew and the soldiers carried aboard."
>>>
>>>DRUDGE learns from UNFIT FOR COMMAND that if Kerry's superior
>>>officers knew the truth, they would never have recommended the award:
>>>
>>>"Admiral Roy Hoffmann, who sent a Bravo Zulu (meaning "good work"),
>>>to Kerry upon learning of the incident, was very surprised to
>>>discover in 2004 what had actually occurred. Hoffmann had been told
>>>that Kerry had spontaneously beached next to the bunker and almost
>>>single-handedly routed a bunkered force in Viet Cong. He was shocked
>>>to find out that Kerry had beached his boat second in a preplanned
>>>operation, and that he had killed a single, wounded teenage foe as he
>>>fled."
>>>
>>>"Commander Geoge Elliott, who wrote up the initial draft of Kerry's
>>>Silver Star citation, confirms that neither he, nor anyone else in
>>>the Silver Star process that he knows, realized before 1996 that
>>>Kerry was facing a single, wounded young Viet Cong fleeing in a
>>>loincloth. While Commander Elliott and many other Swiftees believe
>>>that Kerry committed no crime in killing the fleeing, wounded enemy
>>>(with a loaded or empty launcher), others feel differently. Commander
>>>Elliott indicates that a Silver Star recommendation would not have
>>>been made by him had he been aware of the actual facts."
>>>
>>>Developing....
>>>
>>>
>>>On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 02:20  PM, Troy Sheets wrote:
>>>
>>>>>Also, soldiers accused of or admitting to having committed
>>>>>atrocities  in Vietnam are a small minority, not the average person
>>>>>who
>>>>>went over  there.
>>>>
>>>>I guess the point is that even if this Kerry story has any truth to it
>>>>at all (which I pretty much doubt, seeing that the author is a
>>>>right-wing
>>>>nut job: http://www.salon.com/books/wire/2004/08/11/slurs/index.html),
>>>>shooting somone in battle is hardly an atrocity.  Who could actually
>>>>say which direction a boy might be running?  Who could tell if he was
>>>>unarmed?  In the heat of battle, could you tell if he was a boy or
>>>>a man?
>>>>
>>>>I guess I am just sick of this kerry/vietman smear campaign.  It
>>>>insults

>>>>against

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vietnam

	The sources are other Vietnam veterans, as quoted in the 
aforementioned book "Unfit To Serve." I posted an article from Matt 
Drudge to the list which goes into some further detail about it. 
Whether it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally I 
do believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used cocaine, 
used improper influence to get out of being drafted and then skipped 
out on his National Guard service, etc.

	It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John Kerry is a 
cautious man by nature. He was in Vietnam for four months. Does it seem 
more likely to you that this careful guy engaged in such daring and 
heroism during that relatively brief time to earn a Silver Star and 
three Purple Heart medals, or rather that he had a political gift for 
self-promotion which he put to good use in making his combat record 
look more noble than it actually was?

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


On Wednesday, August 11, 2004, at 03:47  PM, shawn allen wrote:

> Can you PLEASE find me a credible source of this accusation? Or are you

User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
