Subject: Re: [sfraves] Vietnam (long NRR)

quoth Starchild:
> I just posted an article from Matt Drudge to the list which goes into
> some further detail about it.

Oh give me a break. Matt Drugde is a gossip monger, he'll publish
anything controversial if he can call it a "scoop". He's not even a
journalist, let alone credible.

> Whether it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally
> I do believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used cocaine,
> used improper influence to get out of being drafted and then skipped
> out on his National Guard service, etc.

What's interesting is that there's nobody to substantiate what Bush did
(or didn't do) during his National Guard service. Nobody even remembers
serving with him during the period in question, let alone whether he
showed up for a medical checkup. Kerry's got a bunch of men that served
directly under him to backup what his superiors later awarded him medals
for.

Furthermore, nobody on the left put up hundreds of thousands of dollars
to expose the truth about Bush's misadventures during Vietnam. The very
fact that this "controversy" appears all of the sudden, financed almost
entirely by one of the top donors to people like Tom DeLay, is quite
suspicious. Don't you think that if these men that were so "haunted" by
Kerry's actions, they would have said something back then--especially
after he returned home and became a vocal anti-war activist?

> It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John Kerry is a
> cautious man by nature.

So cautious that he enlisted to fight in Vietnam in the first place? So
cautious that he alienated many of his fellow soldiers by marching
alongside Jane Fonda when he returned home? He may be cautious when it
comes to delicate political matters (as are most politicians), but I
wouldn't go so far as to say that he was cautious enough to lie (which
is usually a pretty reckless thing to do) about his actions in Vietnam.

> He was in Vietnam for four months. Does it seem more likely to you
> that this careful guy engaged in such daring and heroism during that
> relatively brief time to earn a Silver Star and three Purple Heart
> medals, or rather that he had a political gift for self-promotion
> which he put to good use in making his combat record look more noble
> than it actually was?

As I see it, it's the word of the men that served him against the word
of the men that didn't. If you honestly believe that all his comrades
are as partisan as the vets that Republican donors sought out to
discredit one of the thing about Kerry that the GOP fears the most, then
you're a very cynical person. Don't you think that it would be a lot
easier to find war supporters who would say anything to keep a Democrat
out of the White House than it would to make every living man that
served under Kerry lie about what happened?

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

At 08:47 PM 8/12/2004, Starchild wrote:
>         The sources are other Vietnam veterans, as quoted in the 
> aforementioned book "Unfit To Serve." I posted an article from Matt 
> Drudge to the list which goes into some further detail about it. Whether 
> it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally I do 
> believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used cocaine, used 
> improper influence to get out of being drafted and then skipped out on 
> his National Guard service, etc.

I don't really care if Bush did coke (lots of Republicans do and did the 
white stuff:) or that he avoided service in Vietnam.  What disgusts me is 
that he presents himself on a carrier deck in a flight officer's uniform 
that he was afraid to wear in a war zone.


>         It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John Kerry 
> is a cautious man by nature. He was in Vietnam for four months. Does it 
> seem more likely to you that this careful guy engaged in such daring and 
> heroism during that relatively brief time to earn a Silver Star and three 
> Purple Heart medals, or rather that he had a political gift for 
> self-promotion which he put to good use in making his combat record look 
> more noble than it actually was?

Length of combat tours in Vietnam varied greatly, and were in part 
determined on the number of times one was wounded.  I believe, though I 
haven't researched it, that more bronze and silver stars were awarded 
relative to the number of active duty personnel in Vietnam than in either 
WW II or Korea.

The allegations against Kerry in Vietnam are that he only served four 
months, hyped his heroism and didn't earn his medals, particularly his 
first Purple Heart, presumably because if you got three you could leave 
early. Think for a moment of that logic. He was cited for a Purple Heart on 
Dec. 2, 1968, at the beginning of his swift boat tour of duty, after he had 
volunteered three times: once for the Navy, then for duty in Vietnam and 
then to command a swift boat; those four months were his second tour of 
duty. Somehow these political hacks want you to believe he faked the first 
injury, figuring he could get two more Purple Hearts in those treacherous 
waters -- getting wounded, mind you, not killed -- and then get out.

And his evaluations:

October 19, 1967, evaluation from Captain Allen W. Slifer:
A top notch officer in every measurable trait. Intelligent, mature, and 
rich in educational background and experience, ENS Kerry is one of the 
finest young officers I have ever met and without question one of the most 
promising.

September 3, 1968, evaluation from Captain E.W. Harper, Jr.:
LTJG KERRY is an intelligent and competent young naval officer who has 
performed his duties in an excellent to outstanding manner.

December 18, 1969, evaluation from LCDR George M. Elliott:
In a combat environment often requiring independent, decisive action LTJG 
Kerry was unsurpassed. He constantly reviewed tactics and lessons learned 
in river operations and applied his experience at every opportunity. On one 
occasion while in tactical command of a three boat operation his units were 
taken under fire from ambush. LTJG Kerry rapidly assessed the situation and 
ordered his units to turn directly into the ambush. This decision resulted 
in routing the attackers with several enemy KIA.

LTJG Kerry emerges as the acknowledged leader in his peer group. His 
bearing and appearance are above reproach. He has of his own volition 
learned the Vietnamese language and is instrumental in the successful 
Vietnamese training program.

During the period of this report LTJG Kerry has been awarded the Silver 
Star medal, the Bronze Star medal, the Purple Heart medal (2nd and 3rd 
awards).

Evaluation co-signed by Joseph Streuli and George M. Elliott on January 28, 
1969, and March 17, 1969, respectively:
 exhibited all of the traits of an officer in a combat environment. He 
frequently exhibited a high sense of imagination and judgment in planning 
operations against the enemy in the Mekong Delta.

March 2, 1970 evaluation from Admiral Walter F. Schlech:
 one of the finest young officers with whom I have served in a long naval 
career.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] bsp - phase 1 - tonight, friday aug 13 - hard dance overload!!!!

--0-957532447-1092411467=:361
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

5 of the uk's hotest hard dance djs. this event is going to be at one of everyones favroite venues... for $20 you get in tonite and can also go to the other show, phase 2, the next night; thats right only $20 to see even more uk hard house headliners for 2 nites!!!
you will get 2 nights of partying with a total of 8 uk headliners and 4 national!!!
our goal is to bring the best for the scene.. this is a milestone for the sf hard dance and trance scene. be there as the story unfolds...

the full line-up is done, check it out...

Eufex - Birmingham, UK - Nukleuz, Vicious Circle, Honey Pot
The name Eufex might not ring a bell from the go for everyone, but he has been around since HardHouse was in its mere infancy. Strangely, he is by far THE most under rated producer that Hard Dance has ever seen. Sean Stanley is the force behind many brilliant releases on early HH labels such as Arriba & TYT as well as prominent labels Nukleuz, Vicious Circle, Honey Pot & his now defunct Ravage Records. He has also collaborated with Jay-B for classic releases like Hypnotica on Kaktai Records, the massive anthem Vacuum Packed on Pump, plus tracks on Chris Cs now defunct projects, Aztec & Nile. 
Even though Sean has awe-inspiring skills as a producer & engineer, releases on very reputable labels, an involvement in the scene spreading over many years & one of the most professional attitudes in the industry, there was never a massive following of his music. Somehow people were overlooking a genius. 
Sean shocked many when he decided to take a break and concentrate his energy elsewhere. However, he couldnt shelf his love for the genre and wrote more original tracks & remixes whilst also working with various artists outside of Hard Dance. Hes back in 2004 with two remixes on Scottish hard label Lit Up and he has a promising Live PA with a host of new material and remixes ready to unleash in the coming months. 
Please come out and help us welcome him for his first Inernational set and out of retirement!!!!

Banga Matt - London, UK - Arktik, Sketcha, DP, Nile
Banga has been a staple dj and producer in the massive London scene for quite some time now. With he unique approach to the hrad nrg sound he has gained support the world over.. Just coming off his tour of oz and new zealand Matt is going to touch down and blow the place up! 

Phil Able - London, UK - Antiworld, Smile, Cyberdog, D&A Music S.F.
After Phils massive 2 hour set at 4 the People last November we had to have him back Only now as a resident for D&A. For those who were at 4 the People know what is in store as there is still a buzz about his set, dont miss out this time..
 
Nicki S - London, UK - Endophin, Quality Trax
Nicki is a dj who means bussiness. her hard tech sounds have gained her fame all over the UK clubs. 

Little Miss Natalie - Manchester, UK - Fist
This fireball from the north brings it hard and fast.. No mercy is the name of the game here.. with recent tracks with none other than the Testube Babies, she is no joke. SF need to propare to for an onslaught of the hardest upfornt and classic dark nrg sounds...
 
Local heros include:
 
Viticus
Reclipse
Dekota b2b Achilles
Apot
Fury b2b Dingo
A10
Jekyll & Hyde
 
Offering accross the board local tallent...

Tickets are avail at Skills, F-8 and Solid Grooves soon.. Remember only 20 bucks for both this and phase 2 the next night... Call the info line for updates 415 541 5607 and check the web site www.phase2promotions.com

this man needs no introduction the formost leader in cybertrance is going to be doing his thing on the ones and twos in our trance room alongside other great up and comming trace legends

years djing at some of the biggest gigs, including Ultra Music Festival and 
many more. He has recently been working hard in the studio putting together some new tracks with good friend Alex Calver. Be on the look out for Crackhead and Original Gangsta. Be prepared San Fran. to hear some phat ass beats!!!

Subject: [sfraves] Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

--=====================_15553965==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

Fri Aug 13, 9:39 AM ET

By Peter Cohen, MacCentral

Avid Technology Inc. on Friday announced plans to acquire Midiman Inc., 
doing business as M-Audio. The deal is valued at US$80 million in cash plus 
two million shares of Avid common stock and the assumption of all 
outstanding M-Audio stock options, worth approximately another 325,000 
shares of Avid stock.

Avid Technology Inc. is best known for their development and manufacture of 
video editing hardware and software, but the company also owns Digidesign, 
a maker of professional digital audio production systems used in music, 
broadcast, multimedia and film, and SoftImage, a developer of 
professional-grade 3D animation, 2D cel animation, compositing and special 
effects software. M-Audio manufactures audio hardware and develops audio 
software for professional and consumer markets in both the Mac and PC space.

Avid indicated that M-Audio will become a business unit of Digidesign, 
where it will continue to market its line of peripherals, sound cards, 
keyboard controllers and other products alongside Digidesign's own. Avid 
President and CEO David Krall said that the acquisition will help his 
company bolster its investment in the home studio market segment, which he 
called "the fastest growing portion of our audio business, where we 
achieved roughly 40 percent year-over-year growth in Q2 of 2004."

The deal has already been approved by the boards of directors of both 
companies and has received antitrust clearance; it is expected to close 
before the end of August.


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

On Thursday, August 12, 2004, at 09:31  PM, shawn allen wrote:

> quoth Starchild:
>> I just posted an article from Matt Drudge to the list which goes into
>> some further detail about it.
>
> Oh give me a break. Matt Drugde is a gossip monger, he'll publish
> anything controversial if he can call it a "scoop". He's not even a
> journalist, let alone credible.

  	Whether that's true or not is hardly relevant in this case, =
since=20
Matt Drudge was simply reporting what was in the book.

>> Whether it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally
>> I do believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used =
cocaine,
>> used improper influence to get out of being drafted and then skipped
>> out on his National Guard service, etc.
>
> What's interesting is that there's nobody to substantiate what Bush =
did
> (or didn't do) during his National Guard service. Nobody even =
remembers
> serving with him during the period in question, let alone whether he
> showed up for a medical checkup. Kerry's got a bunch of men that =
served
> directly under him to backup what his superiors later awarded him=20
> medals
> for.
>
> Furthermore, nobody on the left put up hundreds of thousands of =
dollars
> to expose the truth about Bush's misadventures during Vietnam.

	Let me see, now how much did Michael Moore spend making the =
anti-Bush=20
"Fahrenheit 9/11?"

> The very
> fact that this "controversy" appears all of the sudden, financed =
almost
> entirely by one of the top donors to people like Tom DeLay, is quite
> suspicious. Don't you think that if these men that were so "haunted" =
by
> Kerry's actions, they would have said something back then--especially
> after he returned home and became a vocal anti-war activist?

	There is that. Doesn't it remind you of how Anita Hill suddenly =
came=20
forward with her sexual harassment charges just when Clarence Thomas=20
was being nominated to the Supreme Court after being silent about it=20
except possibly to a few confidants up until then? Or how a bunch of=20
women all of a sudden came forward to say Arnold Schwarzenegger had=20
groped them, just when he was running for governor? Many leftists=20
seemed to have little trouble taking those stories at face value and=20
believing they weren't politically motivated though. What's different=20
this time? Hmm...

	I don't know why you put "controversy" in quotes. We are arguing =
about=20
it, aren't we?   8)  That would seem to meet the definition of a=20
controversy.

>> It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John Kerry is a
>> cautious man by nature.
>
> So cautious that he enlisted to fight in Vietnam in the first place? =
So
> cautious that he alienated many of his fellow soldiers by marching
> alongside Jane Fonda when he returned home? He may be cautious when it
> comes to delicate political matters (as are most politicians), but I
> wouldn't go so far as to say that he was cautious enough to lie (which
> is usually a pretty reckless thing to do) about his actions in =
Vietnam.

	I don't know. Maybe being drafted seemed less risky at the time =
than=20
trying to evade the draft. Cautious or not, marching alongside Jane=20
Fonda and testifying in Congress after leaving Vietnam made Kerry=20
famous and launched his political career. This appears to have been a=20
calculated move, tantamount to a lie. =46rom=20
http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/1067104/posts :

Kerry did not return from Vietnam a radical antiwar activist. According=20=

to the indispensable Stolen Valor, by H. G. "Jug" Burkett and Genna=20
Whitley, "Friends said that when Kerry first began talking about=20
running for office, he was not visibly agitated about the Vietnam War.=20=

'I thought of him as a rather normal vet,' a friend said to a reporter,=20=

'glad to be out but not terribly uptight about the war.' Another=20
acquaintance who talked to Kerry about his political ambitions called=20
him a 'very charismatic fellow looking for a good issue.'" Apparently,=20=

this good issue would be Vietnam...

...Kerry testified before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. His=20
speech, touted as a spontaneous rhetorical endeavor, was a tour de=20
force, convincing many Americans that their country had indeed waged a=20=

merciless and immoral war in Vietnam. It was particularly powerful=20
because Kerry did not fit the antiwar-protester mold =97 he was no=20
scruffy, wide-eyed hippie. He was instead the best that America had to=20=

offer. He was, according to Burkett and Whitley, the "All-American boy,=20=

mentally twisted by being asked to do terrible things, then abandoned=20
by his government."

Today, Sen. Kerry appeals to veterans in his quest for the White House.=20=

He invokes his Vietnam service at every turn. But an honest,=20
enterprising reporter should ask Sen. Kerry this: Were you lying in=20
1971 or are you lying now? We do know that his speech was not the=20
spontaneous, emotional, from-the-heart offering that he suggested it=20
was. Burkett and Whitley report that instead, "it had been carefully=20
crafted by a speech writer for Robert Kennedy named Adam Walinsky, who=20=

also tutored him on how to present it."

But the issue goes far beyond theatrics. If he believes his 1971=20
indictment of his country and his fellow veterans was true, then he=20
couldn't possibly be proud of his Vietnam service. Who can be proud of=20=

committing war crimes of the sort that Kerry recounted in his 1971=20
testimony? But if he is proud of his service today, perhaps it is=20
because he always knew that his indictment in 1971 was a piece of=20
political theater that he, an aspiring politician, exploited merely as=20=

a "good issue." If the latter is true, he should apologize to every=20
veteran of that war for slandering them to advance his political=20
fortunes.

	Another piece, from=20
http://frontpagemag.com/Articles/ReadArticle.asp?ID=3D11940 that calls=20=

Kerry's honesty into question:

John Kerry has told audiences that he =93once refused a direct order =
from=20
a far-away commander to open fire on a group of Vietnamese civilians=20
standing alongside a riverbank in the Mekong,=94 wrote unabashed Kerry=20=

supporter Joe Shea in the January 21, 2004, issue of The American=20
Reporter.

=93When [Kerry] got back to base, facing the threat of a court martial,=94=
=20
writes Shea, =93he defended himself with a tattered copy of the Rules of=20=

Engagement he kept handy in his hip pocket. He knew the rules, and he=20
won the day."

Put aside the fact that these Rules of Engagement were always changing,=20=

and that many believe these often-bizarre and arbitrary bureaucratic=20
restrictions on where, when and how our troops could fight were the=20
reason America lost in Vietnam.

If we take Kerry=92s story as true, we then face questions Shea =
neglected=20
to raise. Did not these rules that Kerry knew by heart also require a=20
soldier to report war crimes, or attempted war crimes, by others? Did=20
Kerry report this officer=92s illegal order to kill civilians to=20
superiors? =A0Or did Kerry remain silent, thereby becoming this =
officer=92s=20
ally and enabler, if not accomplice? =A0

If this story is true, then I hereby ask Senator Kerry to name the=20
officer who issued this illegal order and the officers before whom he=20
defended with that tattered rule book his refusal to obey it. =A0Surely =
a=20
memory so indelible as to play a role in young Kerry=92s anti-war=20
speeches can also recall the name of this officer who ordered him to=20
slaughter innocent civilians. (If 60-year-old Kerry=92s memory is now=20
failing, of course, this is evidence that he may have lost the mental=20
acuity to be President.)

The same questions could be asked about all the other routine=20
atrocities young Kerry alleged before a Senate committee. If he had=20
firsthand knowledge from witnessing who did these illegal things, why=20
did Kerry fail to turn in the criminals in accord with the Rules of=20
Engagement? =A0If he shielded those whose war crimes he witnessed, Kerry=20=

is an accomplice after the fact to these atrocities.

On the other hand, if his knowledge was only secondhand gossip, rumor=20
or intoxicated tales told by bored soldiers around jungle campfires =96=20=

what the law calls hearsay evidence =96 then Kerry was reckless,=20
irresponsible and almost treasonous to make such outrageous claims=20
under oath before the Senate, the press and the American people.

>> He was in Vietnam for four months. Does it seem more likely to you
>> that this careful guy engaged in such daring and heroism during that
>> relatively brief time to earn a Silver Star and three Purple Heart
>> medals, or rather that he had a political gift for self-promotion
>> which he put to good use in making his combat record look more noble
>> than it actually was?
>
> As I see it, it's the word of the men that served him against the word
> of the men that didn't.

	Exactly. Men who might allow personal loyalty, or their own =
complicity=20
in what Kerry did, to keep them from telling the truth, versus men who=20=

were witness to incidents without being personally connected to Kerry=20
in the chain of command. Whose word is more reliable?

> If you honestly believe that all his comrades
> are as partisan as the vets that Republican donors sought out to
> discredit one of the thing about Kerry that the GOP fears the most,=20
> then
> you're a very cynical person.

	Did you hear somewhere that these vets only spoke out after =
being=20
approached by Republican donors, or are you just making that assumption?

> Don't you think that it would be a lot
> easier to find war supporters who would say anything to keep a =
Democrat
> out of the White House than it would to make every living man that
> served under Kerry lie about what happened?

	I don't know. But I'd love to see the whole lot of them, for and=20=

against, testifying on a witness stand under penalty of perjury and let=20=

the chips fall where they may.

Cheers,

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam

	Among the generally pro-Kerry material on the Snopes web page =
someone=20
posted is a note that:

". . . two weeks after [Kerry] arrived in Vietnam, the swift boat=20
mission changed =97 and Kerry went from having one of the safest=20
assignments in the escalating conflict to one of the most dangerous"

	So it appears that John Kerry may not necessarily have =
volunteered for=20
a dangerous duty on purpose, but in fact volunteered for a duty he=20
expected would be safe, while still being able to say he went to=20
Vietnam and served his country. Unfortunately (or fortunately, as it=20
later turned out given his subsequent political career), the nature of=20=

that duty changed unexpectedly for the worse.

	I hadn't heard about the allegation you mention that Kerry faked =
his=20
first wound, but apparently none of wounds for which he got Purple=20
Heart medals were very serious. The worst of them only put him out of=20
action for one day. Generally, more and more medals have been awarded=20
relative to actual injuries or acts of heroism in each successive U.S.=20=

conflict. I know there were a whole lot given out in the Gulf War,=20
despite the low number of U.S. casualties in that conflict. You could=20
consider it the military version of grade inflation.

	For that matter, I wouldn't put too much stock in the glowing =
language=20
of Kerry's military evaluations. As a former Army Reservist, I often=20
helped draft such evaluations myself. Ninety-five percent of the time=20
they were loaded with the highest praise for the soldier being=20
evaluated. I wish I had one of mine here to read you.

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>


On Thursday, August 12, 2004, at 11:11  PM, Apollo wrote:

> At 08:47 PM 8/12/2004, Starchild wrote:
>>         The sources are other Vietnam veterans, as quoted in the=20
>> aforementioned book "Unfit To Serve." I posted an article from Matt=20=

>> Drudge to the list which goes into some further detail about it.=20
>> Whether it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally=20=

>> I do believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used=20
>> cocaine, used improper influence to get out of being drafted and then=20=

>> skipped out on his National Guard service, etc.
>
> I don't really care if Bush did coke (lots of Republicans do and did=20=

> the white stuff:) or that he avoided service in Vietnam.  What=20
> disgusts me is that he presents himself on a carrier deck in a flight=20=

> officer's uniform that he was afraid to wear in a war zone.
>
>
>>         It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John=20
>> Kerry is a cautious man by nature. He was in Vietnam for four months.=20=

>> Does it seem more likely to you that this careful guy engaged in such=20=

>> daring and heroism during that relatively brief time to earn a Silver=20=

>> Star and three Purple Heart medals, or rather that he had a political=20=

>> gift for self-promotion which he put to good use in making his combat=20=

>> record look more noble than it actually was?
>
> Length of combat tours in Vietnam varied greatly, and were in part=20
> determined on the number of times one was wounded.  I believe, though=20=

> I haven't researched it, that more bronze and silver stars were=20
> awarded relative to the number of active duty personnel in Vietnam=20
> than in either WW II or Korea.
>
> The allegations against Kerry in Vietnam are that he only served four=20=

> months, hyped his heroism and didn't earn his medals, particularly his=20=

> first Purple Heart, presumably because if you got three you could=20
> leave early. Think for a moment of that logic. He was cited for a=20
> Purple Heart on Dec. 2, 1968, at the beginning of his swift boat tour=20=

> of duty, after he had volunteered three times: once for the Navy, then=20=

> for duty in Vietnam and then to command a swift boat; those four=20
> months were his second tour of duty. Somehow these political hacks=20
> want you to believe he faked the first injury, figuring he could get=20=

> two more Purple Hearts in those treacherous waters -- getting wounded,=20=

> mind you, not killed -- and then get out.
>
> And his evaluations:
>
> October 19, 1967, evaluation from Captain Allen W. Slifer:
> A top notch officer in every measurable trait. Intelligent, mature,=20
> and rich in educational background and experience, ENS Kerry is one of=20=

> the finest young officers I have ever met and without question one of=20=

> the most promising.
>
> September 3, 1968, evaluation from Captain E.W. Harper, Jr.:
> LTJG KERRY is an intelligent and competent young naval officer who has=20=

> performed his duties in an excellent to outstanding manner.
>
> December 18, 1969, evaluation from LCDR George M. Elliott:
> In a combat environment often requiring independent, decisive action=20=

> LTJG Kerry was unsurpassed. He constantly reviewed tactics and lessons=20=

> learned in river operations and applied his experience at every=20
> opportunity. On one occasion while in tactical command of a three boat=20=

> operation his units were taken under fire from ambush. LTJG Kerry=20
> rapidly assessed the situation and ordered his units to turn directly=20=

> into the ambush. This decision resulted in routing the attackers with=20=

> several enemy KIA.
>
> LTJG Kerry emerges as the acknowledged leader in his peer group. His=20=

> bearing and appearance are above reproach. He has of his own volition=20=

> learned the Vietnamese language and is instrumental in the successful=20=

> Vietnamese training program.
>
> During the period of this report LTJG Kerry has been awarded the=20
> Silver Star medal, the Bronze Star medal, the Purple Heart medal (2nd=20=

> and 3rd awards).
>
> Evaluation co-signed by Joseph Streuli and George M. Elliott on=20
> January 28, 1969, and March 17, 1969, respectively:
> =85 exhibited all of the traits of an officer in a combat environment.=20=

> He frequently exhibited a high sense of imagination and judgment in=20
> planning operations against the enemy in the Mekong Delta.
>
> March 2, 1970 evaluation from Admiral Walter F. Schlech:
> =85 one of the finest young officers with whom I have served in a long=20=

> naval career.
>
>

> close to that..."

>	Among the generally pro-Kerry material on the Snopes web page someone 
>posted is a note that:
>
>". . . two weeks after [Kerry] arrived in Vietnam, the swift boat mission 
>changed  and Kerry went from having one of the safest assignments in the 
>escalating conflict to one of the most dangerous"
>
>	So it appears that John Kerry may not necessarily have volunteered for a 
>dangerous duty on purpose, but in fact volunteered for a duty he expected 
>would be safe, while still being able to say he went to Vietnam and served 
>his country. Unfortunately (or fortunately, as it later turned out given 
>his subsequent political career), the nature of that duty changed 
>unexpectedly for the worse.
>
>	I hadn't heard about the allegation you mention that Kerry faked his first 
>wound, but apparently none of wounds for which he got Purple Heart medals 
>were very serious. The worst of them only put him out of action for one 
>day. Generally, more and more medals have been awarded relative to actual 
>injuries or acts of heroism in each successive U.S. conflict. I know there 
>were a whole lot given out in the Gulf War, despite the low number of U.S. 
>casualties in that conflict. You could consider it the military version of 
>grade inflation.
>
>	For that matter, I wouldn't put too much stock in the glowing language of 
>Kerry's military evaluations. As a former Army Reservist, I often helped 
>draft such evaluations myself. Ninety-five percent of the time they were 
>loaded with the highest praise for the soldier being evaluated. I wish I 
>had one of mine here to read you.
>
>For liberty,
>				<<< Starchild >>>
>
>
>On Thursday, August 12, 2004, at 11:11  PM, Apollo wrote:
>
>>At 08:47 PM 8/12/2004, Starchild wrote:
>>>         The sources are other Vietnam veterans, as quoted in the 
>>>aforementioned book "Unfit To Serve." I posted an article from Matt 
>>>Drudge to the list which goes into some further detail about it. Whether 
>>>it's credible you will have to judge for yourself. Personally I do 
>>>believe it -- just as I believe that George W. Bush used cocaine, used 
>>>improper influence to get out of being drafted and then skipped out on 
>>>his National Guard service, etc.
>>
>>I don't really care if Bush did coke (lots of Republicans do and did the 
>>white stuff:) or that he avoided service in Vietnam.  What disgusts me is 
>>that he presents himself on a carrier deck in a flight officer's uniform 
>>that he was afraid to wear in a war zone.
>>
>>
>>>         It has been widely remarked during this campaign that John Kerry 
>>>is a cautious man by nature. He was in Vietnam for four months. Does it 
>>>seem more likely to you that this careful guy engaged in such daring and 
>>>heroism during that relatively brief time to earn a Silver Star and three 
>>>Purple Heart medals, or rather that he had a political gift for 
>>>self-promotion which he put to good use in making his combat record look 
>>>more noble than it actually was?
>>
>>Length of combat tours in Vietnam varied greatly, and were in part 
>>determined on the number of times one was wounded.  I believe, though I 
>>haven't researched it, that more bronze and silver stars were awarded 
>>relative to the number of active duty personnel in Vietnam than in either 
>>WW II or Korea.
>>
>>The allegations against Kerry in Vietnam are that he only served four 
>>months, hyped his heroism and didn't earn his medals, particularly his 
>>first Purple Heart, presumably because if you got three you could leave 
>>early. Think for a moment of that logic. He was cited for a Purple Heart 
>>on Dec. 2, 1968, at the beginning of his swift boat tour of duty, after he 
>>had volunteered three times: once for the Navy, then for duty in Vietnam 
>>and then to command a swift boat; those four months were his second tour 
>>of duty. Somehow these political hacks want you to believe he faked the 
>>first injury, figuring he could get two more Purple Hearts in those 
>>treacherous waters -- getting wounded, mind you, not killed -- and then 
>>get out.
>>
>>And his evaluations:
>>
>>October 19, 1967, evaluation from Captain Allen W. Slifer:
>>A top notch officer in every measurable trait. Intelligent, mature, and 
>>rich in educational background and experience, ENS Kerry is one of the 
>>finest young officers I have ever met and without question one of the most 
>>promising.
>>
>>September 3, 1968, evaluation from Captain E.W. Harper, Jr.:
>>LTJG KERRY is an intelligent and competent young naval officer who has 
>>performed his duties in an excellent to outstanding manner.
>>
>>December 18, 1969, evaluation from LCDR George M. Elliott:
>>In a combat environment often requiring independent, decisive action LTJG 
>>Kerry was unsurpassed. He constantly reviewed tactics and lessons learned 
>>in river operations and applied his experience at every opportunity. On 
>>one occasion while in tactical command of a three boat operation his units 
>>were taken under fire from ambush. LTJG Kerry rapidly assessed the 
>>situation and ordered his units to turn directly into the ambush. This 
>>decision resulted in routing the attackers with several enemy KIA.
>>
>>LTJG Kerry emerges as the acknowledged leader in his peer group. His 
>>bearing and appearance are above reproach. He has of his own volition 
>>learned the Vietnamese language and is instrumental in the successful 
>>Vietnamese training program.
>>
>>During the period of this report LTJG Kerry has been awarded the Silver 
>>Star medal, the Bronze Star medal, the Purple Heart medal (2nd and 3rd 
>>awards).
>>
>>Evaluation co-signed by Joseph Streuli and George M. Elliott on January 
>>28, 1969, and March 17, 1969, respectively:
>> exhibited all of the traits of an officer in a combat environment. He 
>>frequently exhibited a high sense of imagination and judgment in planning 
>>operations against the enemy in the Mekong Delta.
>>
>>March 2, 1970 evaluation from Admiral Walter F. Schlech:
>> one of the finest young officers with whom I have served in a long naval 
>>career.
>>
>>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Cannabis extract makes brain tumors shrink

--=====================_3873950==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Cannabis extract makes brain tumors shrink, halts growth of blood vessels

15 Aug 2004, Medical News

Researchers in Spain have discovered that a cannabis extract makes brain 
tumors shrink by halting the growth of blood vessels that supply the tumors 
with life. Cannabis has chemicals called cannabinoids, these are the 
chemicals that could effectively starve tumors to death, say the researchers.

The study was carried out at the Complutense University, Madrid, Spain.

The team used mice to demonstrate that the cannabinoids block vessel growth.

You can read about this latest research in the journal Cancer Research.

Apparently, the procedure is also effective in humans.

The Spanish team, led by Dr Manuel Guzmán, wanted to see whether they could 
prevent glioblastoma multiforme cancer from growing by cutting off its 
blood supply. Glioblastoma multiforme is one of the most difficult cancers 
to treat  it seldom responds to any medical intervention, such as 
radiotherapy, chemotherapy and surgery.

The scientists knew that cannabinoids will block the growth of blood 
vessels (to tumors) in mice  they wanted to find out whether the same 
thing would happen with humans.

The mice were given a cancer similar to the human brain cancer 
(glioblastoma multiforme). The mice were then given cannabinoids and the 
genes examined.

The genes associated with blood vessel growth in tumors through the 
production of a chemical called vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) 
had their activity reduced.

Cannabinoids halt VEGF production by producing Ceramide. Ceramide controls 
cell death.

Dr Guzmán said: "As far as we know, this is the first report showing that 
ceramide depresses VEGF pathway by interfering with VEGF production."

They then wanted to see if this would also happen with humans.

They selected two patients who had glioblastoma multiforme and had not 
responded to chemotherapy, radiotherapy or surgery. The scientists took 
samples from them before and after treating them with a cannabinoids 
solution  this was administered directly into the tumor.

Amazingly, both patients experienced reduced VEGF levels in the tumor as a 
result of treatment with cannabinoids.

The researchers said that the results were encouraging. In order to be sure 
about their findings they need to carry out a larger study, they said.

Dr Guzmán said "The present findings provide a novel pharmacological target 
for cannabinoid-based therapies."

So would I. Now here's how I look at it, and I'm wondering what your
opinion is from this perspective: knowing what you know about how *both*
parties work in an election year, don't you think that if the
Republicans had some confidence in the testimony of the "Swiftboat
Veterans for Truth", they would support them more directly? I just find
it really hard to believe that they wouldn't use this issue to its
fullest political advantage if they really believed it were true.
They've certainly stood behind much shakier issues in the past. 

As far as whether or not Kerry's whole tour of duty in Vietnam was just
a political move, that's a load of bullshit. Nobody volunteered for
potentially fatal swiftboat missions on the Mekong Delta as part of a
career move unless they were looking for a career in the military (which
Kerry obviously wasn't, if you believe everything you quoted in your
previous message).

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] CODEC Pres. Lucas Rodenbush & Christian Bloch This Friday! 8/20 @ Rx

CODEC Presents Lucas Rodenbush & Christian Bloch
This Friday! 8/20 @ Rx

Lucas Rodenbush a.k.a. E.B.E. Audio (Live PA)
--Transmat, Soma, Solid Trax recording artist. One of
the premier bay area techno/house producers is back 
in the Bay, bringing some exclusive new material,
Laptop stylee....

Christian Bloch (Live PA)
--Tresor, Matrix, Thinner recording artist. Christian
hails from Detroit via Denmark. His widespread talents
range from Berlin dub, classic Detroit beats, gritty
and textured German beats to an unmatched English
minimalism.

CODEC Resident DJs:
Tokyo Component
Scott Edmonds
Carceri

9pm-2am
Rx Gallery
132 Eddy Street @ Mason SF
21+ $5 before 12

http://www.rxgallery.com
Rx bar includes beer and wine, sake and soju cocktails

Bios, mixes and more:
http://www.ebeaudio.netfirms.com
http://www.christianbloch.com
http://www.djcarceri.com
http://www.scottedmonds.com

From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>

Subject: [sfraves] Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics

2 hour DJ set. I missed it, did anyone see it, comments???

This post on tranceaddict.com conveys my feelings about this:

"Originally posted by Ground_0=20

I think what Tiesto did was amazing! Not what songs he played, or how
good/bad his skills were, but at work today and even a little yesterday,
people were asking me questions. They know I do my dj thing and enjoy
trance music, but most of them (No matter how many cds I give them) dont
have a way to experience the good stuff, the stuff that isin't played on
the radio here. So back to my point, they were all asking questions
about the songs, the dj, the way it works. These people have never had a
"Trance Experience" in their life, but as tiesto played his songs in the
backround of the ceremonies, they had that experience. And aperently
they liked it too, and these are people from many cultures, ages,
religion and beliefs.=20

One way or another it doesn't matter how well he did, because he did as
well as he had to. The international exposure to trance has just BLOWN
up and maybe you all can't see that yet, but I saw it first hand when I
went to work today.

Cheers Tiesto!!! I'll admit that you fuk up just like all the rest of
em, but you do a damn good job of spreading the lovely music to people
who would otherwise not experience it. You just opened the biggest door
for trance in general, I beleive, that may have ever been opened."

I'll post up a link to a video when I can find one.

Steve Osteen
http://www.tussinspace.com

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]=20
Sent: Saturday, August 14, 2004 3:56 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

Fri Aug 13, 9:39 AM ET

By Peter Cohen, MacCentral

Avid Technology Inc. on Friday announced plans to acquire Midiman Inc.,=20
doing business as M-Audio. The deal is valued at US$80 million in cash
plus=20
two million shares of Avid common stock and the assumption of all=20
outstanding M-Audio stock options, worth approximately another 325,000=20
shares of Avid stock.

Avid Technology Inc. is best known for their development and manufacture
of=20
video editing hardware and software, but the company also owns
Digidesign,=20
a maker of professional digital audio production systems used in music,=20
broadcast, multimedia and film, and SoftImage, a developer of=20
professional-grade 3D animation, 2D cel animation, compositing and
special=20
effects software. M-Audio manufactures audio hardware and develops audio

software for professional and consumer markets in both the Mac and PC
space.

Avid indicated that M-Audio will become a business unit of Digidesign,=20
where it will continue to market its line of peripherals, sound cards,=20
keyboard controllers and other products alongside Digidesign's own. Avid

President and CEO David Krall said that the acquisition will help his=20
company bolster its investment in the home studio market segment, which
he=20
called "the fastest growing portion of our audio business, where we=20
achieved roughly 40 percent year-over-year growth in Q2 of 2004."

The deal has already been approved by the boards of directors of both=20
companies and has received antitrust clearance; it is expected to close=20
before the end of August.


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places

will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong

its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth
is=20
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
become=20
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the=20
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,=20
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam (long NRR)

Kerry supporters: please read "Dude Where's My Country?" by Michael
Moore. you will discover statistical evidence that the majority of the
country is more liberal than either Bush or Kerry.

any Bush supporter who draws you into a debate of Kerry vs. Bush is
wasting your time and tricking you with a deceptive time-wasting
tactic. the real issue is not Kerry vs. Bush. the real issue is voting
vs. not voting.

the majority of potential voters in this country are more liberal than
either candidate. however, the majority of potential voters in this
country do not actually vote.

this is why Bush led immediately with negative campaigning -- he knew
that the more people there were who felt so disgusted with politics in
general that they didn't even want to vote, the better his chances of
winning. this is also the reason for this Vietnam smear campaign. the
dirtier the tricks, the worse **each** candidate looks, and the less
motivated the average potential voter is to actually vote.

please realize that the smartest thing to do is motivate people to
vote. ignore arguments in favor of Bush, they are not worth your time.
we need to get non-voters to vote. if we do that, we win.


Giles aka Soundwave

Albertsons (Yes I did hear  some Electronic music while shopping for dinner) 
Just about every hip ad agency is promoting it, you can catch it on MTV. 
Sorry my friend your a bit late!  ;)

Now if there was a Trance olympic competition then I think ya might have 
something there..

But cheers for Trancey pants tiesto!

Mac

>From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
>To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: [sfraves] Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics
>Date: Mon, 16 Aug 2004 11:35:39 -0700
>
>2 hour DJ set. I missed it, did anyone see it, comments???
>
>This post on tranceaddict.com conveys my feelings about this:
>
>"Originally posted by Ground_0
>
>I think what Tiesto did was amazing! Not what songs he played, or how
>good/bad his skills were, but at work today and even a little yesterday,
>people were asking me questions. They know I do my dj thing and enjoy
>trance music, but most of them (No matter how many cds I give them) dont
>have a way to experience the good stuff, the stuff that isin't played on
>the radio here. So back to my point, they were all asking questions
>about the songs, the dj, the way it works. These people have never had a
>"Trance Experience" in their life, but as tiesto played his songs in the
>backround of the ceremonies, they had that experience. And aperently
>they liked it too, and these are people from many cultures, ages,
>religion and beliefs.
>
>One way or another it doesn't matter how well he did, because he did as
>well as he had to. The international exposure to trance has just BLOWN
>up and maybe you all can't see that yet, but I saw it first hand when I
>went to work today.
>
>Cheers Tiesto!!! I'll admit that you fuk up just like all the rest of
>em, but you do a damn good job of spreading the lovely music to people
>who would otherwise not experience it. You just opened the biggest door
>for trance in general, I beleive, that may have ever been opened."
>
>I'll post up a link to a video when I can find one.
>
>Steve Osteen
>http://www.tussinspace.com
>

i dunno, somebody had me watch a bunch of Ali G the other night and yeah i  
"get it" but I don't really find him all that funny. It's a good schtick at  
first but so repetitive. He uses the same questions on different guests. It's  
the same thing:  get some establishment guys on there and ask them  embarassing 
questions, using slang that they don't know is insulting.  
 
I mean, he's ok ... if he was a recurring character on Saturday Night Live  I 
could see it, but i don't find him some major talent. Yeah i know he's an  
actor who has other roles. This role is, um, he's an English Arab who tries to  
act like an American rapper, but talks with a Jamaican accent?  Sure, there  
are people in England who are just like that, but the joke wears thin fast. I'd 
 rather put the same people on there and grill them about their thoughts and  
policies, not just call them "bellends" (penis ends) and childish stuff like  
that. It's not clever. 
 
yeah go ahead and throw tomatoes ... i could use a salad. 

-------------------------------1092687429--

VINTAGE
Saturday, August 21st
Oakland
all night, all ages


EMUOR is proud to present "Vintage". A all age's event celebrating the 
Vintage sound of the yester years in a safe and secure indoor / outdoor 
venue with capacity over 2000. Fully permitted event, 21 + drinking area and 
on site secure parking. Vintage will be the kickoff event to EMUOR events 
that will be held every third Saturday of each month from 9pm to 5am, 
commencing in August. These events will be all ages and will feature 
national & international acts for all to enjoy. Vintage will be held at The 
Mandela center 1357 5th St. Oakland, Ca 94607.

The line-up is as follows:

Area 1

Grandmaster Flash
The Turntable Legend
New York

2 Bad Mice
EMUOR / Sm:)e Records / United Kingdom
Creator of Bombscare the classic breakbeat anthem.

(Broken Floor CD Tour)

(Broken Floor CD Tour)
EMUOR / Streetbeat Records

DJ Ghost
Ghostribe Krew

Aaron Jae

Area 2

Versatile Entertainment

Area 3

Justin Martin
Classic / Buzzin Fly

Barclay Crenshaw
Intellect / Rook Records

Christian Martin
Dirty Bird / Lions Pub

Worthy
Dirty Bird / Audible Colors

Tickets will be a flat $25 and will be available at:

and at www.emuor.com

For more information call the EMUOR line at 415-646-0566.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

Myabe Digidesign is opening up ProTools to non-Digidesign hardware? I
think they'll at least make ProTools lE compatible with the M-Audio
profolio, which makes the M-Audio line of I/O products even more
versatile.

It might also be a sign of them moving away form TDM hardware.

- Jeff

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
> Sent: Saturday, August 14, 2004 3:56 PM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: [sfraves] Avid Technology acquires M-Audio
> 
> Avid Technology acquires M-Audio
> 
> Fri Aug 13, 9:39 AM ET
> 
> By Peter Cohen, MacCentral
> 
> Avid Technology Inc. on Friday announced plans to acquire Midiman Inc.,
> doing business as M-Audio. The deal is valued at US$80 million in cash
> plus
> two million shares of Avid common stock and the assumption of all
> outstanding M-Audio stock options, worth approximately another 325,000
> shares of Avid stock.
> 
> Avid Technology Inc. is best known for their development and manufacture
> of
> video editing hardware and software, but the company also owns
> Digidesign,
> a maker of professional digital audio production systems used in music,
> broadcast, multimedia and film, and SoftImage, a developer of
> professional-grade 3D animation, 2D cel animation, compositing and
> special
> effects software. M-Audio manufactures audio hardware and develops audio
> 
> software for professional and consumer markets in both the Mac and PC
> space.
> 
> Avid indicated that M-Audio will become a business unit of Digidesign,
> where it will continue to market its line of peripherals, sound cards,
> keyboard controllers and other products alongside Digidesign's own. Avid
> 
> President and CEO David Krall said that the acquisition will help his
> company bolster its investment in the home studio market segment, which
> he
> called "the fastest growing portion of our audio business, where we
> achieved roughly 40 percent year-over-year growth in Q2 of 2004."
> 
> The deal has already been approved by the boards of directors of both
> companies and has received antitrust clearance; it is expected to close
> before the end of August.
> 
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> 
> House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> 
> "I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and
> causes
> me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war,
> corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places
> 
> will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong
> 
> its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth
> is
> aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
> -Abraham Lincoln
> 
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the
> 
> rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually
> become
> visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> 
>   "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of
> 
> life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the
> beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club,
> party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to
> that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics

I thought it was tacky and pathetic display for something as respectable as
the Olympic opening ceremonies. Jeans and a fucking t-shirt. This isn't a

party!*

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, August 16, 2004 11:35 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics


2 hour DJ set. I missed it, did anyone see it, comments???

This post on tranceaddict.com conveys my feelings about this:

"Originally posted by Ground_0

I think what Tiesto did was amazing! Not what songs he played, or how
good/bad his skills were, but at work today and even a little yesterday,
people were asking me questions. They know I do my dj thing and enjoy
trance music, but most of them (No matter how many cds I give them) dont
have a way to experience the good stuff, the stuff that isin't played on
the radio here. So back to my point, they were all asking questions
about the songs, the dj, the way it works. These people have never had a
"Trance Experience" in their life, but as tiesto played his songs in the
backround of the ceremonies, they had that experience. And aperently
they liked it too, and these are people from many cultures, ages,
religion and beliefs.

One way or another it doesn't matter how well he did, because he did as
well as he had to. The international exposure to trance has just BLOWN
up and maybe you all can't see that yet, but I saw it first hand when I
went to work today.

Cheers Tiesto!!! I'll admit that you fuk up just like all the rest of
em, but you do a damn good job of spreading the lovely music to people
who would otherwise not experience it. You just opened the biggest door
for trance in general, I beleive, that may have ever been opened."

I'll post up a link to a video when I can find one.

Steve Osteen
http://www.tussinspace.com

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <20040815205750.GC3728@hubble>
Message-Id: <9CEA9912-EFD7-11D8-B89F-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam (long NRR)

On Sunday, August 15, 2004, at 01:57  PM, shawn allen wrote:

> quoth Starchild:
>>> Don't you think that it would be a lot easier to find war supporters
>>> who would say anything to keep a Democrat out of the White House than
>>> it would to make every living man that served under Kerry lie about
>>> what happened?
>>
>> I don't know. But I'd love to see the whole lot of them, for and
>> against, testifying on a witness stand under penalty of perjury and
>> let the chips fall where they may.
>
> So would I. Now here's how I look at it, and I'm wondering what your
> opinion is from this perspective: knowing what you know about how 
> *both*
> parties work in an election year, don't you think that if the
> Republicans had some confidence in the testimony of the "Swiftboat
> Veterans for Truth", they would support them more directly? I just find
> it really hard to believe that they wouldn't use this issue to its
> fullest political advantage if they really believed it were true.
> They've certainly stood behind much shakier issues in the past.

	Well, look what happened when the Republicans tried to remove 
President Clinton from office. The Democrats refused to do more than 
impeach him, and the public got the idea through the media that it was 
just a lot of partisan mudslinging. In fact there was abundant evidence 
that Clinton perjured himself, and encouraged his secretary Betty 
Currie and possibly his friend Vernon Jordan to perjure themselves on 
his behalf. He improperly got his then-girlfriend Gennifer Flowers a 
state job when he was Arkansas governor, bumping a more qualified black 
woman who was in line for it. He used Arkansas state troopers to drive 
him around and cover for him on his private liaisons. He used political 
influence to dodge the draft. Juanita Broaddrick credibly accused him 
of raping her at a nursing conference. There were a number of 
suspicious deaths, including those of White House counsel Vince Foster, 
former White House intern Mary Mahoney, former Clinton chief of 
security Jerry Parks, former Commerce Secretary Ron Brown, etc. And 
there was much, much more. Of course those latter things were not even 
touched by Congressional Republicans or the Bush campaign with a 
ten-foot pole, but they certainly could have been used, had there been 
a desire to report the truth, or to "use this issue to its fullest 
political advantage," as you put it.

	Given how even the limited stuff they did bring up in Clinton's case 
came back to bite them politically, it's not surprising that most of 
the Republicans are gun-shy and don't want to get involved with the 
Swift Boat veterans' claims.

> As far as whether or not Kerry's whole tour of duty in Vietnam was just
> a political move, that's a load of bullshit. Nobody volunteered for
> potentially fatal swiftboat missions on the Mekong Delta as part of a
> career move unless they were looking for a career in the military 
> (which
> Kerry obviously wasn't, if you believe everything you quoted in your
> previous message).

	I never said Kerry's entire time in Vietnam was a political move, but 
then again I don't discount the possibility that building a political 
career may have been a factor in his decision, even a primary one. Why 
do *you* think he went to Vietnam? Because he loved America so much? 
Because he believed in fighting communism? As previously noted in this 
thread, Kerry apparently did not deliberately volunteer for a dangerous 
Swift Boat mission -- he volunteered for what was one of the safest 
jobs in Vietnam, and the mission got switched two weeks later.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam (long NRR)

quoth Starchild:
> Why do *you* think he went to Vietnam? Because he loved America so
> much?  Because he believed in fighting communism?

I don't think either of us is qualified to speculate anyone's reasons
for enlisting in the armed forces.

> As previously noted in this thread, Kerry apparently did not
> deliberately volunteer for a dangerous Swift Boat mission -- he
> volunteered for what was one of the safest jobs in Vietnam, and the
> mission got switched two weeks later.

"Apparently" is the important word here--it's also silly for us to
speculate whether or not swift boat duty was as "dangerous" as anyone
(let alone Kerry) expected it to be at the time. Like Troy Sheets said,
I don't think this discussion's even worth debating anymore. I could
personally give two shits about what Kerry did in Vietnam; the fact of
the matter is that he went, and most other politicians didn't. I'm done
with this thread.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen

  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Avid Technology acquires M-Audio

At 03:13 PM 8/16/2004, you wrote:
>Or better yet, maybe now M-audio will wait until their drivers are finished
>before they release hardware...
>Or, all M-audio products will only work on Protools!

1. Huh.. non buggy software from Digi?

2. Probably.  Albeit Avid is the larger parent company I understand 
Digidesign itself to be valued in the $100 mil range before this 
acquisition.. This acquisition of M-Audio seems more like a buyout / 
protection maneuver on the surface at least. Despite what one thinks of 
M-Audio/Midiman gear (Digi gear/hardware ain't that much more pimp either) 
they have been gaining strong brand recognition and more in the market 
consistently through the years. Poof...

I'd say this is a narrowing of options available on the audio scene and not 
an expansion.

Best,
--Mike

Received: (qmail 96872 invoked from network); 17 Aug 2004 00:02:28 -0000
Message-ID: <20040817000224.81482.qmail@web60307.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 16 Aug 2004 17:02:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>
To: Karina <karina@hyperreal.org>, sfraves@hyperreal.org,
  sfraves-calendar@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040816154726.S39588@taz3.hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Archives: Q2-2004: What most drew you to the underground scene?

Well, I noticed that the drugs were far higher grade in the UG than
elsewhere.  hehehehe, just kidding :)

Hmm, well, I had come out of the rock scene, having been in bands for
years, and I was sick of the people in that scene- everybody always
trying to out-cool one another, trying to do as little work as
possible, and plans just never worked out quite right.  There was a lot
of inter-band rivalry and the venues just weren't good folks to deal
with.  The crowds were violent and hell, being in bands just sucks
sometimes, especially if you have a certain vision of what you want the
music to sound like and can't find a group of people that shares that
vision 100%.

So I started making dance music in about '96/97, after being hipped to
it by acts like Everything But The Girl and 'electronica' groups like
the Prodigy, Chemical Brothers, and Daft Punk.  I was totally outside
of the rave scene, living in Santa Cruz.  I didn't know a single raver.
 My first really great rave was CF NYE 99 (or 2000?).  I was struck by
the vibe, the friendly people, the mindblowing music, the in-depth
preparation and amazing setup of the venue.  The mystique of map points
and sneaking around into clandestine warehouse venues helped too, this
was something really exciting.

I was hooked big time. :)  Been a ravah ever since.  The funny thing
was, because I went straight from "MTV electronica" music into the deep
underground, I never had a trance/nrg period like most other ravers of
my era did.  *whew*, sidestepped that one!  ;)

GeorgeC
www.djorigami.com

--- Karina <karina@hyperreal.org> wrote:

> In all your experiences of the underground scene, what was the first
> thing 
> that drew you in? That first thing that made you feel alive and want
> more?

incredible vibe, openness of the people, and the phenomenal music.  IMO,
it=92s a rarity finding these three elements together outside of the
underground scene.  =20

people, and neither do we,"

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Posting

This is the first time I have posted when I wasn't promoting something 
in a really, really long time. It's sad since this was my first home in 
the scene. It's where I met many of my longest raver friends. A big part 
of it, I know, is that I'm not online all day anymore, and my writing is 
divided among many communities now. It's not just SFR that I've been 
lurking in, it's Friendster, Tribe, Ravers For Peace, Whirlygig, 
NYC-Raves, blah blah blah. And now I spend so much time between music 
stuff and fire stuff, friends, family, work, everything else, writing 
has gotten squeezed out. Battery's dying

Happy

Troy,

	When it comes to actual policy issues, John Kerry voted in the Senate  
to authorize the invasion of Iraq. He has also said he wants to send  
40,000 more troops to Iraq. And he, like Ralph Nader, wants to bring  
more countries into the war effort -- but of course Bush has already  
been trying to do that. What would Kerry or Nader do differently than  
Bush to get other countries more involved? They're rather short on  
details. Did Kerry offer any detailed advice at the time about how he  
thought the war should be executed that would have made a difference,  
or is he just playing Monday-morning quarterback?

	Meanwhile, Michael Badnarik of the Libertarian Party and David Cobb of  
the Green Party are the only major anti-war candidates. Both of them  
would withdraw U.S. troops from Iraq.

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - Did you complain about Clinton's broken promises* on how long  
the U.S. intervention in Bosnia would last, how much it would cost,  
etc.? Or is this just a partisan anti-Bush thing?

*"...the Clinton Administration set a twelve-month deadline for U.S.  
troops in Bosnia as it was selling the mission to Congress and the  
American people. President Clinton, Secretary of State Christopher,  
Secretary of Defense Perry, National Security Advisor Lake, and  
Chairman of the Joint Chiefs General Shalikashvili all assured Congress  
and the public that it was a twelve-month job. There were very early  
rumblings that this deadline wouldn't stick, but the one-year limit  
remained the Administration's official policy for eleven months. Days  
after winning re-election and with only one month to go before the  
deadline, President Clinton announced on 15 November 1996 that the U.S.  
would stay in Bosnia past the established deadline. He indicated U.S.  
willingness to participate in a stabilization force that would enable  
the ongoing reconstruction efforts. However, he again limited the U.S.  
commitment -- this time it was an additional eighteen months. This new  
time limit for participation in NATO's stabilization force (SFOR) again  
played a key role in securing congressional acquiescence. In the summer  
of 1997 the House expressed its frustration with the lingering Bosnia  
mission and voted to cut off funds for U.S. peacekeepers at the new  
deadline -- 30 June 1998. The Senate didn't mandate a cutoff of funds,  
but did adopt a nonbinding resolution, expressing their expectation  
that the president honor this second deadline. In the end, the Senate  
view prevailed; funds would not be cut off but they expected a June  
1998 end to the Bosnia mission. But the Senate's expectation was not  
met -- the president announced in mid-December 1997 that the troops  
would stay past the 30 June 1998 deadline. Senator John McCain said, 'I  
certainly hope they don't insult our intelligence again with another  
date certain [sic -- meaning another deadline].' They didn't; the  
president offered no new time limits on U.S. participation."

-from www.wcfia.harvard.edu/fellows/papers00-01/stambaugh.pdf

	But Kerry *did* disregard the UN's proposed deadlines on Iraq! =
He=20
voted to authorize Bush to invade without any requirement that those=20
deadlines be complied with. Kerry *has* to *say* he has a different way=20=

of doing things -- he's running against Bush, so he can't very well say=20=

that his way would be exactly the same. But the proof is in the=20
pudding, and when it comes to foreign policy on things like Iraq, I=20
fail to see major differences between them. Kerry's approach to world=20
affairs could even be potentially worse: He might sign the Kyoto treaty=20=

which would drain billions of dollars from the U.S. economy to fix a=20
theoretical problem that is not even proven to exist.

	The sorry state of that economy has less to do with who is =
president=20
than with what has been called the "permanent government" -- the=20
ongoing high levels of government spending, taxation, regulation,=20
bureaucracy, federal reserve phony money, etc. Of course any U.S.=20
president *could* address these problems if he chose, but there's no=20
indication that Kerry is prepared to do so any more than Bush has. In=20
the big picture, the approaches they offer are remarkably similar.

	Only Libertarian Michael Badnarik  ( http://www.badnarik.org ) =
is=20
offering a fiscally responsible and socially tolerant platform that=20
would seriously address the problem of America's huge, out-of-control=20
imperial government.

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] 3rd party candidates -- Was[sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam (long NRR) 

-------------------------------1092759889
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I agree with JBlaze. Out of all the democrats in the primary, Kerry was the  
one i favored the least (except for Lieberman, who is to his right), but I do  
feel we have a responsibility to put him in office and make bush go back to  
Crawford, Texas, where he will finally have the time to finish reading "My  
Little Goat" (see Fahrenheit 9/11).   

Yes, Starchild, Kerry  may really be "more of the same" and he's more 
conservative than I like. He  wouldn't represent major change from traditional US 
policy -- but he's not  George Bush. Maybe Kerry would be just a tool of the 
power structure, like any  other president we've had (except maybe Carter), but I 
feel that he at  least wants our system to continue, unlike Bush, who seems to 
want to run it  into the ground for how own personal gain and that of his 
friends. 
 
I'm wondering why Libertarians and other 3rd party candidates don't  
concentrate more on the local and regional level. I think they would get more  support 
if their efforts concentrated on the bottom and working up, rather than  at 
the top. School boards, rent boards, county supervisors, city councilmembers.  
After all, San Francisco came very close to having a Green mayor. That would  
build up the party, and they wouldn't be seen as mere spoilers or vanity  
candidates (like Nader). 
 
I had the pleasure of meeting Jim Gray, the Libertarian candidate for  
Senator. What an intelligent guy. He makes so much sense, and it would be great  to 
have him in office. But he's running against Barbara Boxer, and sorry Mr.  
Gray, but Senate seats are at a premium, and I don't want to hand Boxer's seat  
to her Republican opponent. 
 
In the last state general election, I voted for the Green candidate, Peter  
Camejo, over Gray Davis, but when the recall vote came up, I voted to keep 
Davis  because I didn't want the Republicans to gain momentum in their push for an 
 eventual  Schwarzenegger presidency. 
 
I realize that the 3rd party candidates won't be viable unless they're  
treated seriously and get media attention. It's a Catch 22. But until they're  
truly viable, they're going to be used as TOOLS by the Republican establishment.  
I saw on CNN the techniques used by Republicans to get people to vote for 
Nader  and it's truly disgusting. (Yes I know Nader isn't the Libertarian 
candidate,  but you can be sure that if Libertarian Michael Badnarik was going to get 
a  decent amount of votes, Republicans would be doing the same thing for  him.)
 
Judge Gray explained how, if Thomas Jefferson were here today, his views  
would be seen as Libertarian. Can we clone Jefferson? I'd vote for Jefferson  
over Kerry. Jefferson has name recognition. He would have a chance. Any  other 
3rd party candidate: I'd say, start at the bottom and build up. Don't be a  tool 
of the Bush/Cheney Empire. If a 3rd party wants to go for the gold, pick  
somebody who is already a big name.  What if Schwarzenegger ran as a 3rd  party 
candidate? Or John Mc Cain? They would have a fighting chance, but sorry,  
Michael Badnarik does not offer an alternative because nobody knows who he is. 
 
John aka JonnyR 

-------------------------------1092759889--

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics





here's something i posted to dcraves that night  :)

i don't know what he was wearing but i imagine it's what he usually wears
to dj ...

respectfully,
mary :)

                                
      To: dcraves@hyperreal.org 
                                
 Subject: tiesto wins the dj    
          olympics              
                                


sorry in advance to those of you who don't like tiesto, but i have to say i
was proud tonight that tiesto represented our culture at the olympics.  i
don't think any other dj could have pulled it off as successfully as he did
tonight.  he is, after all, the only dj in the world i know of who has sold
out a 25,000-capacity soccer stadium with only him on the bill (he played
an event once with about 10 other djs and everyone entering was asked whom
they came to hear; out of 25,000 people, 20,000 said they came to hear him,
so he thought why not do a show just for the people who want to hear him,
and he sold out the soccer stadium himself)

also, he plays mostly his own music, so he's got an incredibly attractive
"brand" - he's got tons of people who identify strongly with his signature
sound.  even if i didn't like his music, which actually i do, i'd have to
give him due respect for being able to do what he does on a level that no
one else is.

as i was watching the olympians from around the world come out country by
country tonight, it occurred to me that though i didn't know when tiesto
was supposed to play, perhaps the most logical time for him to play would
be during the opening ceremony which goes on for a few hours, and sure
enough, when i listened closely, it certainly sounded like techno pounding
in the background.  =)

and then for a few seconds near the end of the procession, i heard a few
measures of his remix of samuel barber's "adagio for strings" and i was
like, bravo!  that's him!  tiesto's playing the set of his life!  and i was
so proud.  :)  watching some of the people clapping in time to techno
thrilled me.  :)

(i would have loved it even more if it had been drum n bass, but maybe the
next olympics. :)

anyhow, i was happy and proud for him and think he deserves to enjoy his
successes.  he was decorated by the queen of holland for his cultural
contributions to his country and he seemed deeply moved by that (i found
some pictures of him receiving a medal from the mayor of his hometown on
behalf of the queen when i googled him recently and he looked surprised and
visibly moved), and i was touched by his apparent sincerity.

i know everyone doesn't agree that it's cool that tiesto got to play the
olympics, but i have to say it made me proud and happy for edm in general.
:)

have a wonderful weekend, everyone!

respectfully,
mary m :)

the Olympic opening ceremonies. Jeans and a fucking t-shirt. This isn't a
club - it's the Olympics. Look at other opening cermonies and the effort
that goes into them. To me this just conveyed that *you're in Greece -
let's
party!*

down
with her stage performances.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, August 16, 2004 11:35 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Tiesto @ Opening Ceremony of the Olympics


2 hour DJ set. I missed it, did anyone see it, comments???

This post on tranceaddict.com conveys my feelings about this:

"Originally posted by Ground_0

I think what Tiesto did was amazing! Not what songs he played, or how
good/bad his skills were, but at work today and even a little yesterday,
people were asking me questions. They know I do my dj thing and enjoy
trance music, but most of them (No matter how many cds I give them) dont
have a way to experience the good stuff, the stuff that isin't played on
the radio here. So back to my point, they were all asking questions
about the songs, the dj, the way it works. These people have never had a
"Trance Experience" in their life, but as tiesto played his songs in the
backround of the ceremonies, they had that experience. And aperently
they liked it too, and these are people from many cultures, ages,
religion and beliefs.

One way or another it doesn't matter how well he did, because he did as
well as he had to. The international exposure to trance has just BLOWN
up and maybe you all can't see that yet, but I saw it first hand when I
went to work today.

Cheers Tiesto!!! I'll admit that you fuk up just like all the rest of
em, but you do a damn good job of spreading the lovely music to people
who would otherwise not experience it. You just opened the biggest door
for trance in general, I beleive, that may have ever been opened."

I'll post up a link to a video when I can find one.

Steve Osteen
http://www.tussinspace.com
