For any of you laptop n****s out there...  Now that I've got me a super fancy laptop to run final scratch on...  I'm looking to get a PCMCIA soundcard so I can record while I'm playing.  I've already tested everything out and it all works great... except that the line in my laptop is retarded.  
 
Does anybody have any advice on what is the best solution to get a proper RCA in on a laptop.  I was looking at the Echo Indigo I/O but it looks a bit pricy for doing nothing but being able to record.  Does anybody have any experience with this card?  
 
More importantly does anybody have any other suggestions?  Obviously this is a niche market so its not like theres gonna be 100 different products to choose from.  All I need is a crystal clear RCA-in that isn't going to rob me of all my taco bell money.  I suppose a super-small USB thingy would work as well... does anybody have possible recommendations on that front?
 
It would be nice if I could get one that I could use cubase on and what not ...  but most importantly I need a high quality recording source.  I'm going to be playing .wav files from final scratch so I'd like to keep as much of that quality as I can....
 
keep it wet&hard...

> For any of you laptop n****s out there...  Now that I've got me a super fancy laptop to run final scratch on...  I'm looking to get a PCMCIA soundcard so I can record while I'm playing.  I've already tested everything out and it all works great... except that the line in my laptop is retarded.

> Does anybody have any advice on what is the best solution to get a proper RCA in on a laptop.  I was looking at the Echo Indigo I/O but it looks a bit pricy for doing nothing but being able to record.  Does anybody have any experience with this card?  
>  
> More importantly does anybody have any other suggestions?  Obviously this is a niche market so its not like theres gonna be 100 different products to choose from.  All I need is a crystal clear RCA-in that isn't going to rob me of all my taco bell money.  I suppose a super-small USB thingy would work as well... does anybody have possible recommendations on that front?
>  
> It would be nice if I could get one that I could use cubase on and what not ...  but most importantly I need a high quality recording source.  I'm going to be playing .wav files from final scratch so I'd like to keep as much of that quality as I can....
>

From sfraves-return-114797-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 17 17:22:09 2004

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Mime-Version: 1.0

In-Reply-To: <EF6173A1-F030-11D8-9247-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Kerry, Kyoto, Libertarianism, et al

quoth Starchild:
> Kerry's approach to world affairs could even be potentially worse: He
> might sign the Kyoto treaty which would drain billions of dollars from
> the U.S. economy to fix a theoretical problem that is not even proven
> to exist.

Ah, the Kyoto Protocol. Pro-business wonks and climate change deniers
just *love* to bash that one. Here's the full text of the Protocol, if
you'd care to read it:

<http://unfccc.int/cop4/resource/docs/cop3/l07a01.pdf>

But here's a paraphrasing of some of the goals outlined in Article 2:

- reducing emissions
- enhancing energy efficiency
- promoting sustainable development in forest management, agriculture
- promoting research, development, and increased use of new and
  renewable forms of energy
- eliminating subsidies of greenhouse gas emitting financial sectors
- limiting and reducing methane in waste management

124 countries have pledged to pursue these goals, many of which are
as equally developed as the US but not nearly as wealthy. If they can
afford to reduce their environmental impact, so can we. It's our moral
obligation to the earth as a producer of some 36% of the world's
man-made pollution.

Furthermore, climate change isn't theoretical; it's happening more
rapidly now that it's ever happened in the earth's history, and in
direct proportion to the rate of industrialization. There is much more
evidence pointing to the effects of greenhouse gas emissions than there
is to "cosmic rays", or periodic global climate change cycles. The
overwhelming majority of scientists that agree with the conclusions of
the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (on which the Kyoto
Protocol is based) aren't angry leftist hippies--they're *scientists*
that have based their findings on decades of rigorous study. I really
think you'd have to have at least a few screws loose to conclude, in the
face of their body of evidence, that the short-term financial wellbeing
of national industry is more important than the long-term sustainability
of the earth's environment.

> Only Libertarian Michael Badnarik  ( http://www.badnarik.org ) is 
> offering a fiscally responsible and socially tolerant platform that 
> would seriously address the problem of America's huge, out-of-control 
> imperial government.

There's something missing from the Libertarian party platform though.
What's more important to me than *fiscal* responsibility and social
*tolerance* is *social responsibility*. Government exists for more than
operational logistics; it exists to help its citizens. But free markets
and social responsibility are diametrically opposed. And when
politicians put the needs of corporations above those of their
constituency--which goes above and beyond the call of free market
economics--you can just forget about "responsibility" altogether.
Libetrarians should want Bush out of the white house just as much as
anyone else, if not for his egregious attacks on civil liberties, then
for his agricultural subsidies and import tariffs.

I know we've had this discussion before, but governmental regulation
exists (as a philosophy, not necessarily in practice) to protect people
from the effects of corporations that will do anything to make a buck.
Taxes exist (in part) to fund public services that protect people from
criminals and save them during emergencies, and social programs that
help people cope with everything from physical and mental illness to job
loss. Libertarians and Republicans alike prefer to slash taxes (and in
the case of Republicans, only for the rich) because they think that the
free market can provide all those things. But let me say this: no
corporation that's ultimately responsible to shareholders is fit to run
essential public services or social programs. Government programs are
allowed to run at a loss so that they won't have to stop providing;
corporations don't have that luxury. Obviously the federal beuracracy is
way out of hand, but there are better places to cut corners than, for
instance, unemployment benefits, housing programs, veteran care, and
middle class tax relief (all targets of the Republican Congress and
Bush's pen).

I may very well end up voting for David Cobb if I know that my vote
won't matter in California. But if this election is anywhere near as
close as 2000's, I won't hesitate to vote for Kerry. As a freelance web
developer, I find it difficult to pay for health insurance. I like
Kerry's plan to repeal Bush's tax cuts for the wealthiest Americans, and
use that money to fund a national healthcare program that covers people
like me. I like that he's fought pretty consistently for progressive
causes during his 18 years as a Senator. (He is, after all, "the most
liberal senator," which isn't saying much.) He's got a lifetime's more
experience than George Bush, and he has more international perspective
WRT everything from the economy to terrorism as a member of the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee. If there's one thing that can be said of
John Kerry, it's that he's one of the few politicians capable of
learning from experience. Republicans point to his changes in position
as "flip-flopping", but their own immutable stances, in the face of even
the most overwhelming evidence to the contrary, are their greatest
weakness. I don't want a leader with resolve to the point of being
stubborn or stupid; I want one that can compromise for the common good
and own up to his or her mistakes. The responsibility of the President
is to govern according to the wishes of the entire electorate, not just
the people that voted for him. Doing so requires the ability to
compromise, of which Bush is wholly incapable.

I really do think that this Bush will go down as one of the worst
presidents in our nation's history. And if he's re-elected on November
2nd because the general population is too ignorant to realize what he's
done to our country economically and socially, and how much the rest of
the world hates us because of his hair-brained policies, then I'm
getting the fuck out of here. I'm disgusted with our national lust for
huge things, from triple cheeseburgers to gas-guzzling Hummers. I'm sick
of the ethnic and racial divides that fester as a result of mutual
disrespect and cultural intolerance. I'm sick of religious
fundamentalism, the rejection of science, and the pervasiveness of
ideology in government. Nobody's practical anymore, nobody's willing to
compromise, everything is either black or white... but that isn't the
way the world works! Nations aren't "good" or "evil"; religious texts
aren't literal transcriptions dictating every facet of life; free
markets can't provide everything that everyone in society needs.

We can do much better than this. As the world's wealthiest and most
powerful nation, we could combat hunger, homelessness and disease in our
own country as well as abroad. We have the ability to develop renewable
energy sources that will power the technological revolution without
destroying the environment. We could even stop giving the Islamic world
reasons for wanting to kill us. But none of that will happen as long as
Bush is in the white house, because all he cares about is whether or not
he and his friends have gobs and gobs of money. These may not be the
highest priorities of the Democratic party either, but Libertarians
certainly won't go for it because social responsibility is inherently
inefficient. So until it's "safe" to vote Green, I'm voting Democrat.
It's simply a practical, intelligent compromise, given the alternatives.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From: matthew johnson <mpj_bay@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20040816154726.S39588@taz3.hyperreal.org>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Archives: Q2-2004: What most drew you to the underground scene?

This a story of my first party I posted a few months
back. 

One of many great experiences was the first party I
went to. 

I never liked the bar scene or drinking. I ran around
with a 2 foot mowhawk; pitting at punk shows and punk
rallies was my thing. 70's-80's. The punk thing got to
main stream for me and I hung low for a while. Cut my
hawk. Hiked around and rode my bike. Got back into
other things. One day my roomies asked me to go to a
rally in Sacramento on the capital step for a
demonstration, there were decks set up and DJ's
spinning. The music was called techno. I have old
records from back in the day and the funny thing is
that some techo sounded like house, some sounded like
drum and bass, some sounded like trace, breaks, acid
house, but back then it was called techno. As far as I
knew anyway.

After the demonstration my roomies said there was a
break-in warehouse party. Whatever the hell that
means. What is there to do in a warehouse? My
curiosity was peaked. I was into anything new and
different than the proposed norm. 

At this point in my life the only experience with
drugs was knowing that my hippy parents did so many
that I was turned off to the idea. You never want to
be like your parents right? When I was a tike mom told
me that if I ever wanted to try anything ever she
would get a hold of it and we could do it together.
"I've tried it all" she said. Boy that sounds like
fun. I had a few drinks over the years but didn't like
to drink. Clove and menthol cigs was all, what was I
thinking... Smoked reef a couple times but wasn't into
it back then.  

So we go to some dark ass ally in some sketch
neighborhood just outside of downtown sac. I start to
hear this low thump, thump, thump, thump, thump,
thump... We drive past, find a place to park. Walk up
to the warehouse, no line, no fee, no one even
watching the door. Walk through a tunnel of black
sheets and BAM sweat all over the place. Wicked music,
people dancing, some half naked. The back door of the
warehouse was open and a cool breeze was cooling off
the dance floor which was the entire warehouse. The
only lights were a strobe and a black light, oh yeh
and a smoke machine. No alcohol. I loved it. People
getting on dancing, having a great time and there was
no booze.   
Wicked energy, I started dancing. Felt like I was out
of my body. The night went on, sweating, dancing,
hands in the air. I didn't care about time, the night
could have gone on forever and I wouldn't have
noticed. After a while I thought it would be good to
find my roomies. I had my shirt off from dancing, the
warehouse was like a sauna. I found my roomies. We
started chatting. Both my roomies have been to parties
before so we we talked about how great it was. A
beautiful girl/woman came up to me. She had this thing
in her hand that looked like saturn. A metal ball with
rings around it. She told me to put my hand on top of
the ball, her hand was on the button holding this
contraption. I put my hand on the orb, she ran her
finger from my sweaty chest down to my belt line then
back up around my neck, leaned in and kissed me. The
orb created an electric link to whatever part of our
bodies touched and causes a little muscle spasm that
felt like a tiny euphoric massage. My whole face lit
up. I was in ecstasy. She walked away. The night
finally came to an end. We went home. The beutiful
thing was, I never saw the girl again. There was no
reason to exchange information because we were both
sharing a moment that was only appropriate for that
time in space. I did not do drugs and didn't need any.
The music, people, energy and visuals kept me high. I
WAS HOOKED. 

This community for me has always been part of a life
that proceeds the normal. We are one step ahead. We
think ahead. We act ahead. We love each other. We
create our beautiful surroundings. We know what is
right and wrong without authority. 

=)
~matt
aka dub

> that drew you in? That first thing that made you

Subject: [sfraves] 2x SFRCAL Update This Week

There will be two calendar updates this week, switching gears from my 
hospital trip; I will be updating the calendar throughout the majority 
this week. The first update will go out tonight, the second per the usual 
scheduled program. If you have any updates that you would like to be on 
tonight's event calendar, please publish the information by 9pm PST 
8/17/04; otherwise - feel free to update your event information or publish 
new event information per your usual routine. Questions? Feel free to 
email me @ karina@hyperreal.org

  SFRaves Calendar - FREE Promotions :)

Need a promotional resource? Try SFRaves! We've been in business for 12 
years and counting. The SFRaves calendar has been redesigned and is 
self-publishing. Please use this FREE resource for promotions of your 
events! OVER 4000 person reach!

Get Connected with SFR!. All information can be easily self-published on 
the calendar system. You can get started in 3 easy steps:

1) Register to create profile and account
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/add_person_form

2) Create your group/promoter/venue/label profile (if applicable)
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/groups/create_group_form

3) Add your Event to the Calendar
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/add_event_form

  SFRaves, part of a greater collection of rave related sites - is 
available @ http://www.sfraves.org

SFRaves is an electronic virtual community of ravers, networking together 
around the clock, sharing information and ideas, and even planning our own 
parties. The mailing list started in 1992 and has over 2500 members from 
all parts of the community and all parts of the world (although the focus 
of the discussion is on San Francisco). Below is information about SFRaves 
itself as well as information about the entire San Francisco scene.

We are also accessible via the original URL:

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf

The SFRaves Calendar is located @ 
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2

Subject: RE: [sfraves] tuition raised AGAIN

Tuition being raised is definitely a bad thing, but honestly, California
is still by far the best state for just about anyone to be able to get
an education in.  As a resident in Utah, the fee per credit hour is $194
and most students work jobs $7/hr and under since there is no work.  I
moved to California to get my resident status so I could go back to
school inexpensively... Although I failed in that by getting a corporate
job soon after moving here and getting to used to having money.  But now
I'm off back to school and I'm more than overjoyed to be in California
to get it.  A city with costs more like SF though still charges around
$120 a credit hour, like New York.  2 raises in 2 years is bad, I just
hope it doesn't show a continuing trend like this in California.

-Rayn

lots of people knew about Pakistani nuke technology before the first Iraqi war:

Britain 'knew about nuclear network'
By Allan Urry
BBC current affairs reporter


British intelligence knew about a nuclear smuggling network long before it 
became public knowledge at the start of this year, but did little to 
intervene, the BBC has been told.

X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook, Build 10.0.2616
In-Reply-To: <20040817184818.26406.qmail@web12105.mail.yahoo.com>
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1409
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Re: Kerry, Bush, Environment

What would probably best describe global warming in terms of hurricanes
would be either more or less hurricanes than normal and abnormally high
hurricanes in the off season.
http://www.cpc.noaa.gov/products/outlooks/hurricane.html discusses in
depth hurricane activity current and historical.

Besides global warming, one of the things the Kyoto treaty is trying to
protect against is things like Hypoxia in the Gulf of Mexico.
'http://www.nos.noaa.gov/products/pubs_hypox.html' Because of dumping in
the Mississippi river (not just stuff you'd consider bad like mercury,
lead and all the normal things that don't do a body good) but fertilizer
runoff etc.  After the flood season the river washes out a swath of
enriched water that causes algae to multiply so much that the water
becomes too heavily oxygenated and pushes all animal's in a 5000 sq mile
radius out of the area for a few months.  This has lead to higher shark
attacks along the coasts as well as forcing animals to find new habitats
in other area's.  While of course this study talks about the visiable
details, it makes sense that this much oxygen being released into the
lower atmosphere would also cause climate change in that area and as the
dead zone grows bigger each year may be a factor in speeding up the
swirling factor in tropical storms that may not have become a hurricane
without it.

Global warming is real.  I just think the term is badly used or not
explained easily enough for those who are not concerned about it in
their daily lives.  Its more than just a hotter winter or summer.  Its
about tidal change, higher water levels in both the ocean and the
atmosphere, changing climate maps that have been used for as long as
people lived in an area.  Shorter planting seasons, worse storms, longer
droughts.  The short term results could possibly be just as scary as
these 'catastrophic disasters' the movies predict.  With less salinated
water ocean fish, animals and plants start dying.  A marine eco-system
takes a lot longer to rebuild once its thrashed than one on land.  The
ocean covers 70% of our planet, most of our oxygen and storms come from
it.  For those that live costally in and outside the US a drop in fish,
or an increase in storms would be like a farmer having a drought as
their food and money supply is cut off.

It's important to care about environmental treaties, not because you're
a hippie or even because you drive an SUV.  Most environmental treaties
are looked at by the public as costing us too much money.  But what they
really focus on is private and publically held factories and companies
who get hassled less than a consumer on emissions.  I side with
libertarians on a lot of issues where government involvment really
isin't needed, but only in the case of private citizens.  I'm talking
about companies who only care about a bottom line, and find it cheaper
to pollute and pay a fine than to clean up their act.  This is when a
government works to protect its people in more ways than just
employment.  Companies that continue to pollute our air and water, car
companies that don't drive hybrids and 0 emission car production when
the technology is now somewhat affordable, etc..  These companies are
why treaties are needed.  They may produce a lot of jobs, but what is
the importance of just having a job when you're working to make the
world less livable for future generations.  Each individual can choose
how much a part of 'saving the environment' they want to be.  Companies
shouldn't have a choice since like government, they effect change on a
much larger scale than an average individual's pollution.  Once they
clean up their act, cleaner products trickle down to us and it is easier
for an individual at that point to care about the environment without
really even having to consiously care.

-Rayn

Reply to: anon-39483432@craigslist.org
Date: Mon Aug 16 01:06:13 2004


Saturday night, I was out with my buddies walking around on Sunset,
going from bar to bar, club to club, etc. You were, presumably, with
your girl friends. As we neared each other, none of us made eye contact.
It's as though we were trying not to look at each other. I sure as hell
was.=20

But because of this, I wasn't looking where I was going either, and
tripped on a crack in the pavement and tripped, falling forward, right
as you were passing by. My arms flailed about and tried to grab the
nearest sturdy thing to steady myself. That nearest thing ended up being
your rack.=20

Unfortunately, your breasts weren't steady nor sturdy enough, so I kept
falling. Along the way, your shirt and bra were torn off in the process.
Your knockers, exposed to the night air, bounced with delight and glee.=20

Almost immediately, you came down upon me, fists rained down hellfire
the likes of which I've never experienced. Your friends quickly joined
in, pummeling me, while my own friends stood back and watched, giggling
gayly as if their kindergarten classmate had just poohed his pants
during recess.=20

It was when you were pepperspraying the shit out of me that we locked
eyes for a moment. It was incredibly painful to keep my eyes open, due
to the intense sting from the pepperspray, but I noticed how goddamn
gorgeous your blue eyes were, and I think I noticed a moment of
hesitation, almost admiration, perhaps. A hint of a smile formed on your
face, and for a second, I thought you were going to kiss me, but then
you headbutted me directly into the sidewalk, rendering me unconscious.=20

This, however, did not stop you from kicking me in the side, spitting on
my face and stealing my wallet, while, yes, you were there, you know, my
friends continued laughing and whooping it up like a bunch of drunken
rednecks at a hoedown.=20

I had hoped to find your phone number scratched into my chest, along
with the many other scratches from your fingernails, but alas, when I
came to, nothing. Just blood and a few scattered teeth.=20

I sincerely hope you read this message because I think we had a
connection, you and I. I want to see where this might lead. As long as
it's not the ICU again.=20


this is in or around Hollywood
it's NOT ok to contact this poster with services or other commercial
interests

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Archives: Q2-2004: What most
  drew you to the underground scene?

--=====================_19959309==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 03:48 PM 8/16/2004, Karina wrote:
>In all your experiences of the underground scene, what was the first thing 
>that drew you in? That first thing that made you feel alive and want more?

I assume here that we are all talking about "raving?":)  Although we now 
call raves "parties," "underground events" and the like the common bond 
uniting this group even now is the experience of raving.

I've been dancing and DJing at parties both underground and mainstream for 
over thirty years.  Raving was, for me, a much different communal dance 
experience for me through I think the first "raves" were really at the Loft 
and the Paradise Garage in NYC.  Similar vibes.  That loss of self in the 
music and other dancers.  The experience of the other.  Raving was for me a 
life-transforming experience.

My first rave was a Wicked Full Moon many, many years ago.  That night was 
an epiphany for me -- a genuinely transformative experience of the highest 
order.  I learned so much that night.  It wasn't called PLUR then, but it 
was the same thing.  A new way of loving and respecting other dancers.  The 
sharing of a mystical bond.  The union of flesh and spirit.  I thought that 
night that I could spend an eternity with these people and be happy.

Prior to the Wicked FMRs in the early nineties my dancing and performing 
was limited almost entirely to the gay subculture.  I didn't want to dance 
with "straight" people.  In the seventies I went to some punk parties 
because I enjoyed the music and the electric charge of the mosh pit, but 
after spending my high school years in the most oppressively discriminative 
environment one could imagine I was overjoyed to be on a dancefloor with 
hundreds of people like me.  When the eighties came with the darkness of 
AIDS the gulf deepened again between mainstream "straight" society and the 
gay subculture.  Heterosexuals who were once open minded about sexual 
diversity, and even dabbled in same sex relationships themselves, turned 
their backs on us.  Afraid of "catching something."  One publisher I worked 
for -- "liberal" with a non-sexual discrimination policy in place on paper 
--  encouraged employees to bring spouses and significant others to yearly 
meetings in resort towns.  When I brought my lover, however, it was another 
matter.  When we came down to swim in the pool one afternoon everyone in 
the company left the pool.  All this was very hurtful.  So I became heavily 
involved again in gay liberation activities and ACT UP and deeply alienated 
from mainstream culture.

Thus, when a gay friend of mine suggested I attend a "mixed" party thrown 
on a beach and given by some house-head ravers from the UK I was very 
skeptical.  The house part of it sounded very appealing.  I knew what was 
happening with house, especially acid house, in England and the Wicked crew 
were fresh from that milieu.  But dancing with straight people....

That first night on the beach with Wicked and the early ravers here healed 
many wounds in my heart and soul.  These ravers were completely open and 
accepting;  loving and respectful; and such beautiful people inside.  I was 
again able to see humanity as a whole and not segments in conflict.  I came 
to appreciate women once more.  Raver women were much like the goddesses I 
knew in the sixties and early seventies.  And the men didn't seem concerned 
with sexual preferences.  It was all good, and I really touched the heavens 
that night.

The last successful Wicked FMR was over three years ago.  Below is an 
excerpt from a review I wrote right after another extraordinary evening on 
the beach.

Love,

Apollo

"When I heard of the Wicked FMR location -- that we were going back down
Highway 1 to those mystical days on the beach -- I was astonished and
elated.  It had been six years since a Wicked Full Moon.  I never thought
I'd dance on a beach near Santa Cruz to Wicked house music again.

But, I thought, can one have a renegade on those beaches now days without
being busted?  To help assure our success we made a special pre-dance ritual
to the great god Apollo and Pan, and I left a candle burning on the outside
altar when we left.  The gods rewarded us with a perfect night:  a radiant
full moon awesomely reflected on the ocean, cloudless sky, shining stars,
agreeable climate -- and absolutely no squad cars:)  I mean, the party went
off perfectly.

All of us driving down were from back in the day of the first Wicked FMRs.
We were so charged with anticipation.  Me, I got on a metaphysical roll when
we got out of the car and started walking down those familiar railroad
tracks, and I'm still in that place now.  Non-stop bliss, brothers and
sisters.

We arrived early to help with the set up.  Then power up at 2 AM and those
first few beats.  Markie!!!  A collective shout of joy went up from the
crowd.  The tribe was together again.  Ravers under a full moon.  It doesn't
get any better than this.

I wondered who would be there after all these years.  Familiar faces I
hoped, but I was also eager to see many newbies in the tribe too.  A tribe
without new blood dies.  Again, everything as one would hope.  Lots of old
friends and so many lovely new faces.  But the same eclectic mix as in the
old days.  Hippies young and old.  Costumes.  New school ravers.  Fire acts.
Drummers.  People swimming in the nude.  Hip hop kids.   And, to my joy,
many of you from sfraves.  I was really hoping some of you would experience
this thing that is so important to me -- I wanted to share it with you -- so
I'm very grateful to all of you who danced with us last night.  Ryan and his
girlfriend, Mutex, Becca, Usa (former list member and HK crew), and many
more --  every one of you made the night special for us.

The music -- WELL, it is Wicked.  Markie, Jeno and Garth are at their best
doing a full moon.  In this case, the house that Jack built was built on
sand.  Stronger than concrete to my mind.  Jeno, that sweet shy gifted man.
If you know him you know how hard it is to get him to smile.  This morning
he was one happy little boy.  And Garth dancing about in the DJ area.
People doing what they love, yes.

Visuals and special effects.  Hell, you have Mother Nature.  Nothing better.

My favorite thing is greeting the dawn with my tribe.  The morning star was
shining brightly.  The moon setting in the ocean.  Dawn breaks.  Flights of
birds.  Some bats whizzing around on the cliffs.  Freshness in the air.
Dancing and the beats as the sun comes up.  Then...you get to look into your
brothers' and sisters' eyes.  Really see them.  And what you see is a look
that is both far away and meditative, yet loving and open.  Immediate
connection.  At that point I took a walk on the beach.  Every person I met
smiled with that look and said simply:  "Good Morning."

We left at eight (before I wanted to, but I wasn't driving) and the party
was still going down with Garth's moving house music.

It was great fun walking back up the tracks with all the happy ravers.  Such
a feeling of unity, of shared fun.  One moment on that walk sticks in my
mind.  A beautiful hippy kid in a sarong was walking ahead of us.  He had
trouble keeping it on, and he didn't have much underneath.  So we shouted to
him that it was so hard for boys to keep their skirts on these days.  He
blushed bright red.  Then we caught up with him, and he looked at us with
that FMR dawn look and said, with much feeling:  "Good Morning."  We all
hugged.

For me, folks, this is what raving is all about.  These moments.  You
dancers.  The music.  And, the best, a full moon.  That's why I have not
stopped raving and dancing.  I never will.  And I hope, from the bottom of
my heart, that all of you have many moments like this as you grow into a
community that really is all races, all creeds, all ages -- dancing together
as one."


"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_19959309==.ALT--

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving and being a part of it all.

Posts like this make me happy and sad. Happy, because I know that others
out there feel what I do, but sad to know that I've missed so much. So
many experiences that I've missed because of invisible chains my head
locks me in. I sometimes feel that I'm alone and the whole "spirit of
raving" only exists in my head. Maybe I'm the only one DJ'ing sets to
myself everynight throwing my hands in the air only to realize it's only
me that felt it.

It seems that when I do go out I never find the "right crowd", the
"right party", or the "right music". Maybe they don't exist. Maybe it's
only in my head and I have yet to create it, again.

"You should feel what I feel..." Chemical Brothers - Star Guitar=20

Steve Osteen
www.tussinspace.com

At 03:00 PM 8/17/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:
>Posts like this make me happy and sad. Happy, because I know that others
>out there feel what I do, but sad to know that I've missed so much. So
>many experiences that I've missed because of invisible chains my head
>locks me in. I sometimes feel that I'm alone and the whole "spirit of
>raving" only exists in my head. Maybe I'm the only one DJ'ing sets to
>myself everynight throwing my hands in the air only to realize it's only
>me that felt it.

No, Steve, the spirit of raving lives on in many or our minds and 
hearts.  It was real.  And there are those still bangin' away trying to 
bring some of it back.


>It seems that when I do go out I never find the "right crowd", the
>"right party", or the "right music". Maybe they don't exist. Maybe it's
>only in my head and I have yet to create it, again.

Times change and I think we are living in a very cynical, dark era.  But it 
was in just such times that raving arose in the late eighties in the UK, 
and in SF in the nineties.  Some of us old timers may be jaded, and many 
have stopped going out.  The old raver house crowd, for example, just will 
not go to a party where there is a pat down and one can't have a proper smoke:)

But as in the early days of raving, people will become dissatisfied with 
the offerings and often aggressive vibe of the club scene.  Unfortunately, 
gentrification and urban "development" have greatly diminished the number 
of venues available for free-spirited raves.  Folks, however, tend to find 
a way to get what they need....

Love,

Apollo


>-----Original Message-----
>From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
>Sent: Tuesday, August 17, 2004 2:28 PM

User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Archives: Q2-2004: What most drew you to the underground scene?



Northern California had Wicked FMR and Southern California had Moontribe.

Both were occuring roughly the same time and were probably the peak 
raving expereinces we will ever see in our lifetimes...

I was lucky enough to be in socal for Moontribe.  Really life-altering
experiences, just like the FMR were, I'm sure.

Moontribe had the advantage though of much more dramatic, and isolated
desert locations that really added to the experience.  I really, honestly,
thought the aliens were going to land at one Moontribe party.  The dry
lakebeds made perfert landing spots, and we were focussed and sending
out so much energy into the universe...

-troy

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Press release from "Release":

"As some of you may have already heard, Release will no longer be promoting 
our events at 1015 Folsom. There are a number of factors regarding lack of 
appreciation and trust that are contributing to this decision and need not 
be detailed here. Suffice it to say that after over 10 years it is time for 
a change. At Release we pride ourselves on bringing the best talent and 
creating the best events, and we will continue to do so regardless of venue."



"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

If money is no object and you have a firewire port, Id go for this:

http://productsen.terratec.net/modules.php?op=modload&name=News&file=article

No midi but I love the sound quality from my terratec PCI sound card. Avoid
Creative cards btw...they are one of the most compatible cards on the
market, also one of the noisiest. Good luck!

From: DJ Pat [mailto:djpat@yahoo.com]

Subject: [sfraves] Need PCMCIA soundcard advice


For any of you laptop n****s out there...  Now that I've got me a super
fancy laptop to run final scratch on...  I'm looking to get a PCMCIA
soundcard so I can record while I'm playing.  I've already tested everything
out and it all works great... except that the line in my laptop is retarded.

Does anybody have any advice on what is the best solution to get a proper
RCA in on a laptop.  I was looking at the Echo Indigo I/O but it looks a bit
pricy for doing nothing but being able to record.  Does anybody have any
experience with this card?

More importantly does anybody have any other suggestions?  Obviously this is
a niche market so its not like theres gonna be 100 different products to
choose from.  All I need is a crystal clear RCA-in that isn't going to rob
me of all my taco bell money.  I suppose a super-small USB thingy would work
as well... does anybody have possible recommendations on that front?

It would be nice if I could get one that I could use cubase on and what not
...  but most importantly I need a high quality recording source.  I'm going
to be playing .wav files from final scratch so I'd like to keep as much of
that quality as I can....

keep it wet&hard...
XXX,
p a t

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: Kerry & Vietnam (long NRR)

-------------------------------1092804169
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

    As a senator I don't think you get to actually propose the terms in which 
why you vote for something or how you want it carried out, you just get to 
vote yay or nay. In addition to that as a senator you don't have access to all 
of the same information that the president does. When John Kerry says he voted 
for the war based on false information he was given and yet he also disagrees 
with the way the war was carried out and how the burden was not shared I don't 
think he is telling a lie. I think John Kerry was wrong to vote for the war 
and trust the Bush administration to carry it out justly, but that's him and 
obviously the majority of the other senators as well.  i don't think when you 
criticize a president for the way they carry out things, you can criticize the 
senators the same way just because they voted for it. when you vote for 
something you leave it in the hands of the person in power as to the way they carry 
it out. you can vote for something but still disagree with the way it's carried 
out. For example I don't chastise people for having simply voted for bush if 
they tell me they did. I was hanging out at this house party over in Alamo 
(you know by Danville) and they were all republicans there, one of the guys was 
running for state assembly, we talked about the whole Bush/Kerry ordeal of 
course he didn't agree with me but I got along with the guy. One of the things he 
said kind of struck me, he said that he supports Nader because "a vote for 
Nader is a vote for Bush" of course I told him that was shady politics but he 
didn't care. he basically admitted that he was an ego maniac and he wouldn't mind 
if the government really did have an imperialistic agenda, in fact he thought 
that would be "pretty cool". 
    Anyway the point is that I don't judge the type of President John Kerry 
is gonna be by his senate votes, I think that is very arbitrary and it's like 
playing "gotcha" politics. I'm willing to listen to him talk, listen to his 
ideas and then hold him up to what he says, I don't think he's lying. Bush is 
riding a faulty presidency, he didn't win the popular vote to begin with, he 
didn't do a good job, he was wrong about the war. Bush show's to be unintelligent 
in general by the way he talks and thinks, which unfortunately A LOT of 
Americans relate to him for his unintelligence because A LOT of Americans like bush 
are half wits. People who have  lots of confidence but little knowledge. 
People sympathize with Bush saying things like "aww poor guy got put in a bad 
situation and now all we can do is jump on him?" that's what they say. i hear it 
all the time. "poor George, he's only human" but that's not the point. just 
because George Bush is a half wit just like most the rest of America is, doesn't 
mean he should get to remain president after what he's done. Now I'm sure a lot 
of these third parties sound like a good idea to us here in San Francisco, 
and on SFR for that matter but try convincing that to Iowa, Kentucky, and West 
Virginia, it's not gonna happen. George Bush fucked up and in politics when you 
fuck up you need to be replaced. In order to replace him we need someone who 
can win, that person is John Kerry. It takes certain strategies and sacrifices 
in order to win something as big as the Precedency of the United States of 
America, some of those strategies and sacrifices are bound to make one seem 
similar to the current president. But, ultimately the object is to WIN and that's 
what John Kerry is doing. 
    For example, It would be like if Wal Mart bought out some other company 
like say Fry's electronics, then by some miscalculation this causes Wal Mart to 
loose half it's stocks, this is a very serious issue and someone has to go 
down for it, that person is the President of WalMart, he loses his job, and say 
a high standing store manager replaces him, say even that store manager was 
once in favor of buying out Fry's as well.... who fucking cares! This is not 
gotcha politics. The top dog has to go down, and the next heir has to lead the 
company in a new direction.  If in fact Kerry becomes a "bad" president, as bad 
as Bush like some of you are insinuating THEN i will definitely consider 
voting third party. THEN i think third party has a great chance of actually wining. 
AFTER both Republican and Democrats fail then it's time for the third party 
to step up and revolutionize and WIN i would LOVE to see that. But as of now, 
Kerry is our only chance to beat Bush and I'm sure as hell not rooting for him 
to fail because too many lives are at stake to be that self centered about 
politics.  - *keep bouncing*

In a message dated 08/17/2004 2:35:16 AM Pacific Daylight Time, 
sfdreamer@earthlink.net writes:
    But Kerry *did* disregard the UN's proposed deadlines on Iraq! He 
voted to authorize Bush to invade without any requirement that those 
deadlines be complied with. Kerry *has* to *say* he has a different way 
of doing things -- he's running against Bush, so he can't very well say 
that his way would be exactly the same. But the proof is in the 
pudding, and when it comes to foreign policy on things like Iraq, I 
fail to see major differences between them. Kerry's approach to world 
affairs could even be potentially worse: He might sign the Kyoto treaty 
which would drain billions of dollars from the U.S. economy to fix a 
theoretical problem that is not even proven to exist.

    The sorry state of that economy has less to do with who is president 
than with what has been called the "permanent government" -- the 
ongoing high levels of government spending, taxation, regulation, 
bureaucracy, federal reserve phony money, etc. Of course any U.S. 
president *could* address these problems if he chose, but there's no 
indication that Kerry is prepared to do so any more than Bush has. In 
the big picture, the approaches they offer are remarkably similar.

    Only Libertarian Michael Badnarik  ( http://www.badnarik.org ) is 
offering a fiscally responsible and socially tolerant platform that 
would seriously address the problem of America's huge, out-of-control 
imperial government.

For liberty,
                <<< Starchild >>>

>
>Almost immediately, you came down upon me, fists rained down 
>hellfire the likes of which I've never experienced. Your 
>friends quickly joined in, pummeling me, while my own friends 
>stood back and watched, giggling gayly as if their 
>kindergarten classmate had just poohed his pants during recess. 
>
>It was when you were pepperspraying the shit out of me that we 
>locked eyes for a moment. It was incredibly painful to keep my 
>eyes open, due to the intense sting from the pepperspray, but 
>I noticed how goddamn gorgeous your blue eyes were, and I 
>think I noticed a moment of hesitation, almost admiration, 
>perhaps. A hint of a smile formed on your face, and for a 
>second, I thought you were going to kiss me, but then you 
>headbutted me directly into the sidewalk, rendering me unconscious. 
>
>This, however, did not stop you from kicking me in the side, 
>spitting on my face and stealing my wallet, while, yes, you 
>were there, you know, my friends continued laughing and 
>whooping it up like a bunch of drunken rednecks at a hoedown. 
>
>I had hoped to find your phone number scratched into my chest, 
>along with the many other scratches from your fingernails, but 
>alas, when I came to, nothing. Just blood and a few scattered teeth. 
>
>I sincerely hope you read this message because I think we had 
>a connection, you and I. I want to see where this might lead. 
>As long as it's not the ICU again. 
>
>
>this is in or around Hollywood
>it's NOT ok to contact this poster with services or other 
>commercial interests
>
>

every Wednesday at The Top
424 Haight St. in the Lower Haight
10pm-2am / 21+ / $5

This week's special guests:
 
Andrew Phelan ( Olive Records / Thump Radio ~ SF )
 
Raised on Chicago's underground house scene, Andrew
has quickly made a name for himself in SF with his upbeat
blend of chunky, jazzy, Chicago-inspired house. He's played
at nearly every major venue in the city, is a regular on Thump
Radio, and has even mixed for XM Satellite Radio. Get ready
to dance as Andrew rocks The Top for the very first time!
 
Check the website for a full bio and some damn funky mixes.
http://djandrewphelan.com <http://djandrewphelan.com/> 
 
 
Bobby Valentine ( Guided Methods / Dufflebag ~ LA )
 
One half of LA's production duo Guided Methods, Bobby
keeps the energy high with an infectious mix of thumpy
deep house and tracky tech-house. Excellent stuff!
 
Check out a recent set on undergroundhouse.net:
http://www.undergroundhouse.net/ram/bobby_v.ram
 
 
+ residents Justin Martin & Sammy D (Classic / Roam)
 
http://www.rookrecords.com/JustinMartin.htm
http://www.rookrecords.com/Sammy_D.htm

featuring two LIVE PAs, by Lucas Rodenbush (aka EBE) from
Detroit's Transmat, and Christian Bloch from Berlin's Tresor. 
We're not affiliated, but it should be a night of great music.
Recommended!  Here's the details:
http://www.djcarceri.com/events.html

In a message dated 8/18/2004 4:17:59 AM Eastern Daylight Time, 
djjasonphilips@hotmail.com writes:
http://www.acidplanet.com/artist.asp?PID=415574&T=4401
good start, not bad
i do like mixing in that dubby vibe myself.
try some type of lead melloD
separate the drums and effect only one half of them
maybe find a dub/ragga hit/stab to add
add delay on horn, more reverb is nice too. (ie dj krush style nice)
get a vocal stab to put anywhere (rasta vibe BOH YA!)
bass line, like real slap slide bass guit, try spectrasonics trillogy (stylus 
is nice for adding quick break fills too)

i know thats alot of "pointers" but just some quick thoughts.
good job and keep it up!

one more...  the ohm boys delay its THE best for this style, just turn it on  
 =]

peace

jon

Message-ID: <20040818153200.10154.qmail@web41013.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 18 Aug 2004 08:32:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jessica McMahan <ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <004901c4848d$32b47940$6301a8c0@xanax>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] tuition raised AGAIN

Here, here!! I was soooo incredibly happy when I found out that tuition
in CA was as cheap as it is, despite the increases. I was paying over
$3K/year in Virginia JUST for tuition, not including some fees, books,
living, etc. I was also paying $175/credit in WV for classes. 

Paying $26/credit is nothing. If you have to, work more hours, take
fewer classes. I work FULL TIME to support myself and take 6 credits of
evening classes each semester. Yes, it'll take longer for my degree to
happen, but it makes the end point all that much more satisfying
knowing I did it ALL BY MYSELF. 

Don't use loans for community college. SERIOUSLY. It's a waste of
money. I'm in Loan Hell because of this, and this is jeopardizing my
financial aid future with a university. Save your loans for University,
where it will be even MORE expensive. Go ask the FinAid office about
the Board of Governer's Waiver. That has been the saving grace for me
through unemployment. They waive the per credi tuition charges. You
only have to pay a very small fee, like under $20 for the misc. fees.
OR talk to them about a work study program. 

Also, did you file your FAFSA, like a good student? If not, you missed
out. 

Jessica

--- Rayn McCormick <rayn@anubismedia.net> wrote:

> $194
> and most students work jobs $7/hr and under since there is no work. 
> I
> moved to California to get my resident status so I could go back to
> school inexpensively... Although I failed in that by getting a
> corporate
> job soon after moving here and getting to used to having money.  But
> now
> I'm off back to school and I'm more than overjoyed to be in
> California
> to get it.  A city with costs more like SF though still charges
> around
> $120 a credit hour, like New York.  2 raises in 2 years is bad, I
> just
> hope it doesn't show a continuing trend like this in California.

Subject: [sfraves] Radio (was Re: [sfraves] Release and 1015)

on a related note, Radio Free Berkeley is holding workshops on how to 
start a low-power radio station.  I've always thought it would be great 
to have a UG radio station for the 'scene'.

the workshop covers transmitter basics, equipment needs, and legal 
issues. It's $100 - $200 sliding scale.  I'm going to try to do the 
workshop when i'm not so goddamned busy.

http://www.freeradio.org/

-Philip-

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  VINTAGE - Saturday, 8/21 - Grandmaster Flash and 2 Bad Mice

EMUOR is proud to present "Vintage". A all age's event celebrating the 
Vintage sound of the yester years in a safe and secure indoor / outdoor 
venue with capacity over 2000. Fully permitted event, 21 + drinking area and 
on site secure parking. Vintage will be the kickoff event to EMUOR events 
that will be held every third Saturday of each month from 9pm to 5am, 
commencing in August. These events will be all ages and will feature 
national & international acts for all to enjoy. Vintage will be held at The 
Mandela center 1357 5th St. Oakland, Ca 94607.

The line-up is as follows:

Area 1

Grandmaster Flash
THE TURNTABLE LEGEND / ESSENTIAL / NEW YORK
www.grandmasterflash.com

The creator of the Quick Mix, he was the first person to change the 
arrangements of songs using duplicate copies of records and manually 
repeating the climatic part by rubbing the records back and forth. His Quick 
Mix style helped stretch the BREAK of the song and drive the crowd and all 
B-Boys & B-Girls wild with his live editing. Flashs CUTTING and 
SCRATCHING helped him become a pioneer for all turntablelist throughout the 
world. Come and see a legend at work for this special engagement.


2 Bad Mice
EMUOR / SM:)E / UNITED KINGDOM

Formed in 1991, 2 Bad Mice are widely attributed as among the first U.K. 
hardcore acts to begin incorporating breakbeats into electronic music. With 
countless tracks since the early 90s, such as Bombscare  The original 
breakbeat anthem to the globe, 2 Bad Mice tunes have been a staple in the 
electronic music scene for over 10 years. Now you can taste what started it 
all as one of the originators of the classic old school rave sound graces us 
on the decks.


Madame Mercury
(Broken Floor CD Tour)
EMUOR / Streetbeat Records

DJ Whatt
(Broken Floor CD Tour)
EMUOR / Streetbeat Records

DJ Ghost
Ghostribe Krew

Aaron Jae
Evil Breaks

DJ Bam
Evil Breaks / Invibe

Area 2

Tony
Tango / Nightshift / Detour

Jim Hopkins
EMUOR / Twitch Recordings

Joey Mazzola
Solmatic Records

Mike Frugaletti
Good Family Recordings

Alain Octavo
Feelgood Entertainment

Gabe Xavier
Versatile Entertainment

Area 3

Justin Martin
Classic / Buzzin Fly

Barclay Crenshaw
Intellect / Rook Records

Christian Martin
Dirty Bird / Lions Pub

Worthy
Dirty Bird / Audible Colors

Tickets will be a flat $25 and will be available at:

BPM 415-487-8680
Tweekin 415-626-6995
Skills 510-704-9876
Solid Grooves 408-248-6399
In Tha Mix 916-442-0499

and at www.emuor.com

For more information call the EMUOR line at 415-646-0566.



-------------

http://www.invibe.com/bam

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Radio (was Re: [sfraves] Release and 1015)

there were actually some cats who did this in New Mexico for a while.
I was not affiliated with them, at all, in any way, not even slightly,
but what they did was set up a very low-powered pirate station inside
a van. they put it on the same frequency as the most popular
bling-bling station in Albuquerque and drove up and down the city's
central boulevard (i.e., the main cruising strip) on Friday night
broadcasting Skinny Puppy.

like I say, I wasn't affiliated with them, in fact I had nothing to do
with it, but they tell me that Skinny Puppy sounds surprisingly good
coming out of a lowrider subwoofer.


G/dJsNdWv

brought them out..

RABBIT IN THE MOON
JOEY BELTRAM
THE MUTHA FUKIN NAZI LOOKING "SURGEON"

etc..

show not to be missed like none other..

it is worth seeing them if it is in a small venue.. They are the type of 
band that need a big ass stage and a nice big warehouse!!


Macadio

On Aug 19, 2004, at 11:00 AM, Steve Osteen wrote:

> Being a rock star (or a musician with annoying hair) has nothing to do
> with being qualified to make political commentary.

I agree somewhat with this in that it doesn't make you any *more* 
qualified to make political commentary than anyone else.


> Music/art has nothing
> to do with politics and shouldn't be mixed with politics.

now here, you're totally off.  music and art at its best has everything 
to do with the politics of its day.  read up on your history, and art 
history.

music is the most powerful medium in the world.  why do you think the 
RIAA/ClearChannel/FCC fucks are trying to control it so badly?   that 
you would even say such a thing ("music has nothing to do with 
politics") shows that they're succeeding in controlling it, and as a 
result, the politics of the day.

-philip-

Subject: [sfraves] The OMNI MUSIC FESTIVAL - Saturday, September 18th! 1 FULL SF City Block!! <bsp>

The collective efforts of EMUOR, Liquidvinyldjs.com, and BR Productions are 
extremely proud to bring you..

The OMNI MUSIC FESTIVAL 2004!
Uniting The Bay Area In a MASSIVE Music Festival Like No Other!
Saturday - September 18th, 2004!
1 FULL CITY BLOCK + Club Mighty in the city of San Francisco!
________________________________

OMNI Will be taking place @ the beautiful CLUB MIGHTY in San Francisco - and 
the ENTIRE City Block outside. (Utah St Between 15th and Alameda)!

Join us as we transform downtown San Francisco into a GIANT Musical 
Celebration!

All permits %100 Approved!
________________________________

OMNI - Definition: All; Universally..with the definition of such a word 
the collective efforts of EMUOR, Liquid Vinyl DJs, and BR Productions are 
proud to bring the OMNI musical festival.

On Saturday 18, 2004 join us for OMNI.an event that will energize the Bay 
Area like never before as it will unite the masses for a festival filled 
with good times, great vibes, and world class talent

.::AREA 1::.

RABBIT IN THE MOON (DJ SET + FULL VISUAL SET)
Tampa, Florida
R.I.T.M. is the most original electronic group in the world, with the 
release of their 12" singles, remix work, R.I.T.M. have established an 
enormous fan base, across the world, that continues to grow. A band that 
exists on many levels, they are enjoying there tenth year of attacking your 
senses and emotions. Their style of electronic music is timeless, but to 
truly understand this group is to see and hear them at OMNI.
With: VJ Tek OVT
Visuals / Chicago

FREAKY FLOW
Flashback CD Tour, Freakyflow.com, Toronto
Freaky Flow is still known as one of the most versatile and technically 
skilled producer/DJ's in North America, and still labeled Toronto's Jungle 
Scratchmaster by promoters, producers, and partygoers alike. Swarms of 
partiers may consistently be found huddled around the DJ booth when Flow is 
on the decks, watching his every move.

SIMPLY JEFF
Phenominal, Moonshine, BML, LA
Southern California's original Breakbeat mogul known globally as a 
DJ/Producer who displays an eclectic blend of dance music into a well 
rounded breakbeat sound has proven to rock any crowd no matter where he 
performs. He is an old school favorite but always staying fresh with the 
times by filling his crates with the tunes that make people loose control.

SHARAZ
941, Tommy Boy, POD, Sarasota FL.
Owner of 941, he has had 5 billboard charting hits and has produced tracks 
for Afrika Bambaattaa. This producer has been touted by many as a versatile 
individual who can produce with the best of them in any genre. Always filled 
with a crate filled with goodies, Sharaz has always brought it the way it 
should be and never disappoints his fans.

JOHN KELLEY
Moonshine, Funky Dessert Breaks, LA
DJ John Kelley learned his love for electronic music in the heyday of the LA 
underground scene of the early '90s. Kelley inherited the cultural spirit of 
the underground while being inspired by the ethos of some of the world's 
best DJs. Watching him play one can tell of all that has been given to him 
by his peers in the past.

ST. JOHN
Wild 94.9, House Nation, SF
With years of pumping up crowds across the bay area and on WILD 94.9. St. 
John brings his sound as only he can to OMNI. He will be touching us this 
night as only he can with his musical choice. We will all be entertained 
when we enter his playhouse.

DENISE
Sound Asylum, SF

FELIPE AVELAR
BR Productions, House Nation, Ammo Recordings, SF

CARLOS ALFONZO
BR Productions, Soop, Liquid Vinyl DJsKCRH 89.9FM, SF

DJ DOZA
BR Productions, Zapatistas, KCRH 89.9FM, SF

DJ GIRLIE
BR Productions, SpaceMonkey, SF



.::AREA 2::.

GEORGE ACOSTA
Georgeacosta.com, Miami, Florida
With over 15 years of experience as a DJ and producer, George has helped 
change and evolve trance from an underground movement to massive festival 
experiences throughout the world. George Acosta is probably Americas most 
unique DJ and has undoubtedly been a major force in shaping the sound of 
trance in Miami and beyond says fellow DJ Dave Ralph. George Acosta is 
Americas representative in the global Trance scene says Markus Schulz.

DJ CRAZE
Six Time World Champion, Cartel Recordings, Miami, Florida
Craze is a mad scientist who slices and dices beats into a breathtaking 
sonic concoction in his Miami laboratory and at events all over the world.  
When Craze is behind a set of 1200s and a mixer, he's on stage:  sometimes 
he's shy, sometimes he's cocky, but you will never hear him be anything 
short of absolutely magnificent.

DISCO D
Tommy Boy, New Orleans, Louisiana
To the press, he has been dubbed phenom, holder of the Ghettotech torch, 
devastatingly wicked & surreally filthy. To his fans, hes no less than 
legendary behind the decks, captivating audiences worldwide with 
distinguished blend of hard-hitting music and turtablist tricks. No matter 
who you ask, its apparent that this producer has made quite the impact.

JUJU
Cartel Recordings, Phutoro, Liquid V, San Francisco
Juju has been setting high standards being one of the first American Drum 
and Bass artists to be signed to multiple top notch UK labels. Ranked by 
many of the top international DJ's as the best US Drum and Bass producer. 
Juju has set the pace for international artist in the genre.

MADAME MERCURY
Broken Floor CD Tour, EMUOR, SF
Madame Mercury has a passion for breakbeats wich has birthed the development 
of her career globally with production work on numerous floor filling 
tracks, on labels from coast to coast and over seas, to her widely accepted 
global mix CDs. On tour now promoting her Broken Floor CD, with DJ Whatt, 
she is an act not to miss.

DJ WHATT
Broken Floor CD Tour, EMUOR, SF
Breaks, the word to him, mean more than just a broken beat or a way to 
describe a tune. The word means creativity, enjoyment and a good time. That 
is the mentality he has taken with all his production work accumulating over 
50 original and remix tracks at his early age. The collaboration with Madame 
Mercury on Broken Floor, exemplifies his mentality towards BREAKS.

MC SHARPNESS
Gasm, Taciturn, Substitution, Philadelphia

MC DUH
Groundscore, SF

DRAGN'FLY
Shaolin, Audio Metamorphosis, Sac

J-MARR
BR Productions, Liquid Vinyl DJs, KCRH 89.9, SF

TEK THREAT
BR Productions, SF

DJ ORIONZ
BR Productions, Next Level Promotions, SF

NICK NYQUIL
G-Zus Recordings, Sac



.::AREA 3::.

DJ UFO
Raver Baby, HTID, UK
As one of the most influential and hottest DJs/producers in the UK Hardcore 
scene, UFO is currently producing anthem after anthem exclusively for one 
the largest Hardcore labels around, Raver Baby. With his unique sound, he 
has been able to set himself apart from the norm all while taking his 
production to new heights. With hits like "New Year's Day", "Deep Inside", 
and "Punk", his records remain in demand with the world's top Hardcore DJs. 
This will be a rare appearance for DJ UFO here on the West Coast, so be 
ready to the upfront Hardcore!

DJ UPLIFT
Raw Elements, UK
Currently one of the fastest rising producers on the Hardcore circuit, 
Uplift is one of the leaders of the new school. With his label Raw Elements 
gaining popularity among Hardcore's elite, his material is quickly making 
the rounds as must have. With hits like "BRUTAL", "MIDNIGHT RESISTANCE", and 
the wildly popular "REVOLUTION" produced with Cloudskipper, the Raw Elements 
sound seems to be almost everywhere. As a DJ he has established himself a 
must-see, playing large events around the globe. This will be his only USA 
appearance this year, so do not miss it!

HOUSE O HOLICS (DARREN R. & GEORGE CENTENO)
Waxworks USA, Global Music, LA
Known all around the world for their ultra-energetic sound and crowd 
anthems, the House O Holics are synonymous with the American Hard House 
sound. With their widely accepted releases on Waxworks, Global Music, or 
even their self titled label House O Holics, their material is a staple in 
the crates of Hard DJs everywhere. With anthems like "GO CRAZY", "THE 
WEASEL", and "DA DRUM", their music has been rockin audiences around the 
world for years. Prepare for a very rare DJ set with these 2 very talented 
producers!

CLOUDSKIPPER
Raw Elements, KFA, SF
Widely accepted and viewed as one of the top Hardcore DJ's in the USA, 
Cloudskipper continues his mission to showcase upfront Hardcore to the 
masses. With his appearances all around the globe, including his recent tour 
of the UK and his very busy schedule here, it's no wonder why his popularity 
continues to soar. With his recent production efforts on labels like Raw 
Elements and KFA, his material is finding it's way into DJ's all around the 
world. Prepare for a set full of upfront and bangin material, brought to you 
only the way he can!

DJ TRONIC
Resistance Recordings, SF
Label owner, Producer, DJ, Promoter, Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not, DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.

NO LEFT TURN
K-12, Liquidvinyldjs, SF

SECOND BASE
HCFTP, SF

THE DOCTOR
Liquidvinyldjs, BR Productions, SF

RECLIPSE
BR Productions, SF

AUDIO 1
Scratchlab.com, SF

MC FADER
BR Productions, Reno

MERCEDES
Lake Tahoe, NV

AARON JAE
Evil Breaks, SF

ATHENA
Evil Breaks, Lake Tahoe

BISQUIK
Subcore, SF


.::AREA 4::.
21+ With Alcohol!!!
+ Your Favorite local DJs & Headliners providing the beats!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] tuition raised AGAIN

tuition is about $26/credit hour in New Mexico if you have residency.
(and it's free if you know how to pimp the system.) the community
college in Santa Fe is surprisingly good, too, at least the art
department is. I had a drawing teacher with two degrees from RISD and
a classmate who'd exhibited in galleries from New York to Tokyo (and
pretty much everywhere in between).


Giles Soundwave


On Wed, 18 Aug 2004 08:32:00 -0700 (PDT), Jessica McMahan
<ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Here, here!! I was soooo incredibly happy when I found out that tuition
> in CA was as cheap as it is, despite the increases. I was paying over
> $3K/year in Virginia JUST for tuition, not including some fees, books,
> living, etc. I was also paying $175/credit in WV for classes.
> 
> Paying $26/credit is nothing. If you have to, work more hours, take
> fewer classes. I work FULL TIME to support myself and take 6 credits of
> evening classes each semester. Yes, it'll take longer for my degree to
> happen, but it makes the end point all that much more satisfying
> knowing I did it ALL BY MYSELF.
> 
> Don't use loans for community college. SERIOUSLY. It's a waste of
> money. I'm in Loan Hell because of this, and this is jeopardizing my
> financial aid future with a university. Save your loans for University,
> where it will be even MORE expensive. Go ask the FinAid office about
> the Board of Governer's Waiver. That has been the saving grace for me
> through unemployment. They waive the per credi tuition charges. You
> only have to pay a very small fee, like under $20 for the misc. fees.
> OR talk to them about a work study program.
> 
> Also, did you file your FAFSA, like a good student? If not, you missed
> out.
> 
> Jessica
>

front of Club Mighty in San Francisco. That city block is UTAH Street 
between 15th and Alameda, which is HUGE by city standards. It's looking to 
be a great show, hope to see some of you guys out there!

Subject: [sfraves] The OMNI MUSIC FESTIVAL! Saturday, September 18th! 1 FULL CITY BLOCK - SF  <bsp>

The collective efforts of EMUOR, Liquidvinyldjs.com, and BR Productions are 
extremely proud to bring you..

The OMNI MUSIC FESTIVAL 2004!
Uniting The Bay Area In a MASSIVE Music Festival Like No Other!
Saturday - September 18th, 2004!
1 FULL CITY BLOCK + Club Mighty in the city of San Francisco!
________________________________

OMNI Will be taking place @ the beautiful CLUB MIGHTY in San Francisco - and 
the ENTIRE City Block outside. (Utah St Between 15th and Alameda)!

Join us as we transform downtown San Francisco into a GIANT Musical 
Celebration!

All permits %100 Approved!
________________________________

OMNI - Definition: All; Universally..with the definition of such a word 
the collective efforts of EMUOR, Liquid Vinyl DJs, and BR Productions are 
proud to bring the OMNI musical festival.

On Saturday 18, 2004 join us for OMNI.an event that will energize the Bay 
Area like never before as it will unite the masses for a festival filled 
with good times, great vibes, and world class talent

.::AREA 1::.

RABBIT IN THE MOON (DJ SET + FULL VISUAL SET)
Tampa, Florida
R.I.T.M. is the most original electronic group in the world, with the 
release of their 12" singles, remix work, R.I.T.M. have established an 
enormous fan base, across the world, that continues to grow. A band that 
exists on many levels, they are enjoying there tenth year of attacking your 
senses and emotions. Their style of electronic music is timeless, but to 
truly understand this group is to see and hear them at OMNI.
With: VJ Tek OVT
Visuals / Chicago

FREAKY FLOW
Flashback CD Tour, Freakyflow.com, Toronto
Freaky Flow is still known as one of the most versatile and technically 
skilled producer/DJ's in North America, and still labeled Toronto's Jungle 
Scratchmaster by promoters, producers, and partygoers alike. Swarms of 
partiers may consistently be found huddled around the DJ booth when Flow is 
on the decks, watching his every move.

SIMPLY JEFF
Phenominal, Moonshine, BML, LA
Southern California's original Breakbeat mogul known globally as a 
DJ/Producer who displays an eclectic blend of dance music into a well 
rounded breakbeat sound has proven to rock any crowd no matter where he 
performs. He is an old school favorite but always staying fresh with the 
times by filling his crates with the tunes that make people loose control.

SHARAZ
941, Tommy Boy, POD, Sarasota FL.
Owner of 941, he has had 5 billboard charting hits and has produced tracks 
for Afrika Bambaattaa. This producer has been touted by many as a versatile 
individual who can produce with the best of them in any genre. Always filled 
with a crate filled with goodies, Sharaz has always brought it the way it 
should be and never disappoints his fans.

JOHN KELLEY
Moonshine, Funky Dessert Breaks, LA
DJ John Kelley learned his love for electronic music in the heyday of the LA 
underground scene of the early '90s. Kelley inherited the cultural spirit of 
the underground while being inspired by the ethos of some of the world's 
best DJs. Watching him play one can tell of all that has been given to him 
by his peers in the past.

ST. JOHN
Wild 94.9, House Nation, SF
With years of pumping up crowds across the bay area and on WILD 94.9. St. 
John brings his sound as only he can to OMNI. He will be touching us this 
night as only he can with his musical choice. We will all be entertained 
when we enter his playhouse.

DENISE
Sound Asylum, SF

FELIPE AVELAR
BR Productions, House Nation, Ammo Recordings, SF

CARLOS ALFONZO
BR Productions, Soop, Liquid Vinyl DJsKCRH 89.9FM, SF

DJ DOZA
BR Productions, Zapatistas, KCRH 89.9FM, SF

DJ GIRLIE
BR Productions, SpaceMonkey, SF



.::AREA 2::.

GEORGE ACOSTA
Georgeacosta.com, Miami, Florida
With over 15 years of experience as a DJ and producer, George has helped 
change and evolve trance from an underground movement to massive festival 
experiences throughout the world. George Acosta is probably Americas most 
unique DJ and has undoubtedly been a major force in shaping the sound of 
trance in Miami and beyond says fellow DJ Dave Ralph. George Acosta is 
Americas representative in the global Trance scene says Markus Schulz.

DJ CRAZE
Six Time World Champion, Cartel Recordings, Miami, Florida
Craze is a mad scientist who slices and dices beats into a breathtaking 
sonic concoction in his Miami laboratory and at events all over the world.  
When Craze is behind a set of 1200s and a mixer, he's on stage:  sometimes 
he's shy, sometimes he's cocky, but you will never hear him be anything 
short of absolutely magnificent.

DISCO D
Tommy Boy, New Orleans, Louisiana
To the press, he has been dubbed phenom, holder of the Ghettotech torch, 
devastatingly wicked & surreally filthy. To his fans, hes no less than 
legendary behind the decks, captivating audiences worldwide with 
distinguished blend of hard-hitting music and turtablist tricks. No matter 
who you ask, its apparent that this producer has made quite the impact.

JUJU
Cartel Recordings, Phutoro, Liquid V, San Francisco
Juju has been setting high standards being one of the first American Drum 
and Bass artists to be signed to multiple top notch UK labels. Ranked by 
many of the top international DJ's as the best US Drum and Bass producer. 
Juju has set the pace for international artist in the genre.

MADAME MERCURY
Broken Floor CD Tour, EMUOR, SF
Madame Mercury has a passion for breakbeats wich has birthed the development 
of her career globally with production work on numerous floor filling 
tracks, on labels from coast to coast and over seas, to her widely accepted 
global mix CDs. On tour now promoting her Broken Floor CD, with DJ Whatt, 
she is an act not to miss.

DJ WHATT
Broken Floor CD Tour, EMUOR, SF
Breaks, the word to him, mean more than just a broken beat or a way to 
describe a tune. The word means creativity, enjoyment and a good time. That 
is the mentality he has taken with all his production work accumulating over 
50 original and remix tracks at his early age. The collaboration with Madame 
Mercury on Broken Floor, exemplifies his mentality towards BREAKS.

MC SHARPNESS
Gasm, Taciturn, Substitution, Philadelphia

MC DUH
Groundscore, SF

DRAGN'FLY
Shaolin, Audio Metamorphosis, Sac

J-MARR
BR Productions, Liquid Vinyl DJs, KCRH 89.9, SF

TEK THREAT
BR Productions, SF

DJ ORIONZ
BR Productions, Next Level Promotions, SF

NICK NYQUIL
G-Zus Recordings, Sac



.::AREA 3::.

DJ UFO
Raver Baby, HTID, UK
As one of the most influential and hottest DJs/producers in the UK Hardcore 
scene, UFO is currently producing anthem after anthem exclusively for one 
the largest Hardcore labels around, Raver Baby. With his unique sound, he 
has been able to set himself apart from the norm all while taking his 
production to new heights. With hits like "New Year's Day", "Deep Inside", 
and "Punk", his records remain in demand with the world's top Hardcore DJs. 
This will be a rare appearance for DJ UFO here on the West Coast, so be 
ready to the upfront Hardcore!

DJ UPLIFT
Raw Elements, UK
Currently one of the fastest rising producers on the Hardcore circuit, 
Uplift is one of the leaders of the new school. With his label Raw Elements 
gaining popularity among Hardcore's elite, his material is quickly making 
the rounds as must have. With hits like "BRUTAL", "MIDNIGHT RESISTANCE", and 
the wildly popular "REVOLUTION" produced with Cloudskipper, the Raw Elements 
sound seems to be almost everywhere. As a DJ he has established himself a 
must-see, playing large events around the globe. This will be his only USA 
appearance this year, so do not miss it!

HOUSE O HOLICS (DARREN R. & GEORGE CENTENO)
Waxworks USA, Global Music, LA
Known all around the world for their ultra-energetic sound and crowd 
anthems, the House O Holics are synonymous with the American Hard House 
sound. With their widely accepted releases on Waxworks, Global Music, or 
even their self titled label House O Holics, their material is a staple in 
the crates of Hard DJs everywhere. With anthems like "GO CRAZY", "THE 
WEASEL", and "DA DRUM", their music has been rockin audiences around the 
world for years. Prepare for a very rare DJ set with these 2 very talented 
producers!

CLOUDSKIPPER
Raw Elements, KFA, SF
Widely accepted and viewed as one of the top Hardcore DJ's in the USA, 
Cloudskipper continues his mission to showcase upfront Hardcore to the 
masses. With his appearances all around the globe, including his recent tour 
of the UK and his very busy schedule here, it's no wonder why his popularity 
continues to soar. With his recent production efforts on labels like Raw 
Elements and KFA, his material is finding it's way into DJ's all around the 
world. Prepare for a set full of upfront and bangin material, brought to you 
only the way he can!

DJ TRONIC
Resistance Recordings, SF
Label owner, Producer, DJ, Promoter, Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not, DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.

NO LEFT TURN
K-12, Liquidvinyldjs, SF

SECOND BASE
HCFTP, SF

THE DOCTOR
Liquidvinyldjs, BR Productions, SF

RECLIPSE
BR Productions, SF
