From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040819193011.GO3728@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <340D5A031E64C2468AF37960805A374501097E65@us1-mail16.pcle.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <340D5A031E64C2468AF37960805A374501097E65@us1-mail16.pcle.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Being a rock star (or a musician with annoying hair) has nothing to do
> with being qualified to make political commentary.

True enough. Though they aren't any more qualified than you or me, they
aren't any *less* either.

> Music/art has nothing to do with politics and shouldn't be mixed with
> politics.

Bzzzt, wrong. Music and politics are both equally valid forms of
expression, and they share a long history together. People that can
express their feelings in art as well as words should be applauded.

> I could care less what these electronic music artists think of current
> issues and anyone who does obviously isn't capable of thinking for
> themselves.

You probably *couldn't* care less, and that's the point. Most people
don't care about the issues at stake, and these musicians are using
their recognition to get people interested. Even if they disagree with
the message, maybe this campaign will actually persuade people to get
out and vote.

It's funny, Steve: you make an inflammatory offhand comment about Kerry
in Vietnam, decline to join the debate that ensues, then brush off the
whole thing as "politics" with a humorous craigslist post. You've
defended other people on the list that express conservative viewpoints
in the past, but now you denounce musicians that get involved in the
political process. So it sounds to me like you just disagree with their
message, but you don't have anything substantive to say in your own
defense so you just discourage any further discussion. So here's all I
ask: don't be a hypocrite. If you disagree with the message, explain
why; don't just write the whole discussion off as "politics". The two
parties have been doing that for ages, and it's damaged the public's
ability to engage in civil debate over very important issues.

When people are exposed to contrasting viewpoints, they can make up
their own minds and form their own opinions. When more people are
engaged in discussion, everyone wins. That's why it's good when
celebrities use their position in society to express their ideas. It
really doesn't matter what they have to say--they're just ordinary
citizens, after all. What matters is that they're getting people
thinking and talking about issues that affect them, and that allows them
to make more informed decisions when it comes time to vote.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

Interesting, my comments below:

-----Original Message-----
From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net]=20
Sent: Thursday, August 19, 2004 12:30 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Being a rock star (or a musician with annoying hair) has nothing to do
> with being qualified to make political commentary.

True enough. Though they aren't any more qualified than you or me, they
aren't any *less* either.

->>> Hard to say, I'm not familiar with your political background or
education, neither are you with mine. For all you know I could have a
degree in poly-sci(FYI I don't) and have studied it for years. I know
for a fact though that those musicians haven't.

> Music/art has nothing to do with politics and shouldn't be mixed with
> politics.

Bzzzt, wrong. Music and politics are both equally valid forms of
expression, and they share a long history together. People that can
express their feelings in art as well as words should be applauded.

->>> Sure, that's your opinion. I personally don't think art has
anything to do with politics and shouldn't. I always hated Rage against
the machine and the Beastie Boys for their simple attempts to spread
un-educated propaganda through their music. Same with MTV, music
television should be just that - music television. If I wanted politics
I would listen to NPR, CSPAN, or Fox news. I prefer the likes of Billy
Corgan who thought of music as too holy to be involed with such stuff.
Art is godly, politics is not. To me anyway.

> I could care less what these electronic music artists think of current
> issues and anyone who does obviously isn't capable of thinking for
> themselves.

You probably *couldn't* care less, and that's the point. Most people
don't care about the issues at stake, and these musicians are using
their recognition to get people interested. Even if they disagree with
the message, maybe this campaign will actually persuade people to get
out and vote.

->>> I doubt it. I've never met a single person that said they were
interesting in voting or politics after hearing a famous person promote
it. It's just a method for famous people to feel superior to "normal
people". "Oh, I'm Paul Van Dyk, so since I'm so famous I'll tell people
in another country to vote". Whatever.

It's funny, Steve: you make an inflammatory offhand comment about Kerry
in Vietnam,

->>> No I made a joke about a game using an overheard political comment.
If I really stood behind the comment I would have joined in on the
argument. But I did enjoy reading others ideas on the subject.

You've
defended other people on the list that express conservative viewpoints
in the past, but now you denounce musicians that get involved in the
political process.

->>> I'm not making political statements as a famous person to the press
and public. I'm writing small opinion e-mails to a small list of peers.
BIG DIFFERENCE.=20

 So it sounds to me like you just disagree with their
message,

->>> No, not really, I just find it disgusting that it's "popular" and
trendy to have a specific political opinion. I've always been one to
stay away from trendy stuff and make fun of those that follow what is
"cool".

When people are exposed to contrasting viewpoints, they can make up
their own minds and form their own opinions.

->>> Sure, the problem is, is that all I hear is the liberal view point
and how my country sucks, men are evil, and being white is a crime.

they're just ordinary citizens, after all. What matters is that they're
getting people thinking and talking about issues that affect them, and
that allows them to make more informed decisions when it comes time to
vote.

->>> But are they? Seems to me that they are just spreading more
propaganda and aren't really helping the process at all.

With respect,
Steve Osteen
www.tussinspace.com

> ->>> No, not really, I just find it disgusting that it's "popular" and
> trendy to have a specific political opinion. I've always been one to
> stay away from trendy stuff and make fun of those that follow what is
> "cool".

Making a political viewpoint "cool" is incredibly powerful.  I always
try to paint republicans as old and creepy, and Democrats and young,
fresh and energized.  People don't vote on issues, they vote on perception.
Making a political ideology "cool" is very important.  
 
> ->>> Sure, the problem is, is that all I hear is the liberal view point
> and how my country sucks, men are evil, and being white is a crime.

Now, come on.  this is just what the conservatives say the liberals
say.  Its simply not true.  There are so many liberal-minded people
on sfraves, can you look through the archives and find me one single post
where a liberal is saying these things?  Can you point to me where
Michael Moore, or any leading liberal has said such things?

I love my country.  I think the republicans that control it suck.  Men
are not evil... just certain men running the country are.  Being white
isn't a crime, but standing by idle while other white people engage
is criminal activity is.

> ->>> But are they? Seems to me that they are just spreading more
> propaganda and aren't really helping the process at all.

Well duh, you disagree with their viewpoint, so of couse you will see
it as propaganda and not helpful.

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

In-Reply-To: <340D5A031E64C2468AF37960805A374501097E73@us1-mail16.pcle.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4.2.1i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

quoth Steve Osteen:
> From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net] 
> True enough. Though they aren't any more qualified than you or me, they
> aren't any *less* either.
> 
> ->>> Hard to say, I'm not familiar with your political background or
> education, neither are you with mine. For all you know I could have a
> degree in poly-sci(FYI I don't) and have studied it for years. I know
> for a fact though that those musicians haven't.

Nobody with a degree in political science is more "qualified" to speak
about issues. Their area of expertise is the political *process*.

> > Music/art has nothing to do with politics and shouldn't be mixed
> > with politics.
> 
> Bzzzt, wrong. Music and politics are both equally valid forms of
> expression, and they share a long history together. People that can
> express their feelings in art as well as words should be applauded.
> 
> ->>> Sure, that's your opinion. I personally don't think art has
> anything to do with politics and shouldn't.

While it is my opinion that they should be applauded, it is a fact that
both art and politics are equally valid forms of expression, AND that
they have along history of entaglement.

> I always hated Rage against the machine and the Beastie Boys for their
> simple attempts to spread un-educated propaganda through their music.

So do you have anything to say about their positions?

> Same with MTV, music television should be just that - music
> television.

Heh, MTV was never really about the music. But where do you draw the
line? If MTV News only reported music-related news, they'd be just as
obligated to report the political positions of musicians as their tawdry
affairs and misadventures.

> If I wanted politics I would listen to NPR, CSPAN, or Fox news. I
> prefer the likes of Billy Corgan who thought of music as too holy to
> be involed with such stuff.  Art is godly, politics is not. To me
> anyway.

Sorry, I know you thought this would probably go undebated... but I have
to say it: art is not *inherently* godly. Art isn't even necessarily
emotional; it can be equally functional and practical (design, for
instance). Art can certainly be political, and who are you to tell
anyone that creates political art that it's not art just because it
isn't "godly"?

> I've never met a single person that said they were interesting in
> voting or politics after hearing a famous person promote it. It's just
> a method for famous people to feel superior to "normal people". "Oh,
> I'm Paul Van Dyk, so since I'm so famous I'll tell people in another
> country to vote". Whatever.

Urging people to vote isn't endorsing any particular stance, it's just
encouraging people to get involved. I really don't see the harm in that,
and I certainly don't see how you could construe it as part of a
superiority complex.

> It's funny, Steve: you make an inflammatory offhand comment about Kerry
> in Vietnam,
> 
> ->>> No I made a joke about a game using an overheard political
> comment.

I think you knew exactly what you were doing. You couldn't bring it up
in a real discussion, so you decided to just stick it at the end of an
innocuous email to poke fun at Kerry. As you said:

> If I really stood behind the comment I would have joined in on the
> argument. But I did enjoy reading others ideas on the subject.

It just begs the question: why would you say something that you can't
"really stand behind"?

> You've defended other people on the list that express conservative
> viewpoints in the past, but now you denounce musicians that get
> involved in the political process.
> 
> ->>> I'm not making political statements as a famous person to the
> press and public. I'm writing small opinion e-mails to a small list of
> peers.  BIG DIFFERENCE. 

Ah, but you're an artist, are you not? You didn't pose this as an issue
of celebrity vs. everyman, you posed it as artist/musician vs. anyone
else with a political perspective. I still don't see your point: why is
it not OK for celebrities to express their own opinions?

> So it sounds to me like you just disagree with their message,
> 
> ->>> No, not really, I just find it disgusting that it's "popular" and
> trendy to have a specific political opinion. I've always been one to
> stay away from trendy stuff and make fun of those that follow what is
> "cool".

Oh, so now it's "popular" or "trendy" to vote? GOOD!

> When people are exposed to contrasting viewpoints, they can make up
> their own minds and form their own opinions.
> 
> ->>> Sure, the problem is, is that all I hear is the liberal view
> point and how my country sucks, men are evil, and being white is a
> crime.

That's funny... it sounds to me like all you've ever heard is the
ultra-conservative view, that multiracial anti-American liberal
feminazis are taking over the nation! Give me a break. I love my
country, and I'm white. But that doesn't mean I can't criticize our
goverment or the white-male dominated corporate power structure.

> they're just ordinary citizens, after all. What matters is that
> they're getting people thinking and talking about issues that affect
> them, and that allows them to make more informed decisions when it
> comes time to vote.
> 
> ->>> But are they? Seems to me that they are just spreading more
> propaganda and aren't really helping the process at all.

Unless you can come up with a counterargument, you're just whining. Oh
shit, that's right: arguing IS whining, and there's no greater crime
than criticizing the President during a time of war! And our government
would NEVER propagandize their own policies... They're grate!

Hey you're right Steve, let's all just agree to disagree and never talk
about those nasty divisive "politics" again. This is a rave list, let's
all just pop a pill and be happy in our temporary autonomous zones,
oblivious to the suffering that goes on around us!

Cheerio,
--

country, and I'm white. But that doesn't mean I can't criticize our
goverment or the white-male dominated corporate power structure.

>>>> I never said that you couldn't. But don't just jump on the
bandwagon because it's popular to "fuck bush".

shit, that's right: arguing IS whining, and there's no greater crime
than criticizing the President during a time of war!

about those nasty divisive "politics" again.

>>>> I never said that either.

 This is a rave list, let's
all just pop a pill and be happy in our temporary autonomous zones,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Nobody with a degree in political science is more "qualified" to speak
> about issues. Their area of expertise is the political *process*.
> 
> >>>> If they had a degree in political science they wouldn't be making
> stupid statement like "re-defeat Bush". He legally won the election
> according the rules of our government. 

Wow, you really don't know anything about the election fraud in Florida,
do you? FWIW, George Bush was the first president to be appointed by the
Supreme Court, which is not, in fact, "according to the rules of our
government". The only reason he got away with it was that the American
media never bothered to report the scrubbing of voter roles, the no-bid
state contracts to DBT and Choicepoint, or the illegal manipulation of
ballots.

What's really sad is that most people STILL don't care to hear things
like this because they think it can't be true, that it's a liberal myth.
Well sorry, it IS true: Bush was defeated in the popular vote, and had
some 8,000 voters been allowed to vote, as was their right, he would
have lost by a much wider margin, thus rejecting him Florida's electoral
votes and the Presidency.

> > I always hated Rage against the machine and the Beastie Boys for
> > their simple attempts to spread un-educated propaganda through their
> > music.
> 
> So do you have anything to say about their positions?
> 
> >>>> I'm not sure of their positions and I don't care to hear it.

See? There it is again: apathy.

> Sorry, I know you thought this would probably go undebated... but I
> have to say it: art is not *inherently* godly. Art isn't even
> necessarily emotional; it can be equally functional and practical
> (design, for instance). Art can certainly be political, and who are
> you to tell anyone that creates political art that it's not art just
> because it isn't "godly"?
> 
> >>>>> To me it is. I believe that God gives us art, we humans are just
> a means of transmitting it. Political art is still art, I never said
> it wasn't. But artists that use it for political gain are just trying
> to capitalize on their talent OR utilize it as advertisement.

This isn't artists seeking political gain. It's a group of artists
endorsing a particular viewpoint. Doing so carries the very real risk
(as you've so deftly pointed out) of backlash from the public. It's not
necessarily good for any celebrity's career to express their personal
views, which makes it a relatively courageous action.

> >>>> Jokes aren't meant to be stood behind.

OK, whatever. So now you can deride others for expressing their
political opinions, and excuse anything you say as a "joke". How
convenient!

> Oh, so now it's "popular" or "trendy" to vote? GOOD!
> 
> >>>> No, it's popular for the youth culture to think trendy liberal
> view points are cool and to hate the US.

It's really amazing to me that people still think like this. Do you
really think we (liberals) would still be here if we hated our country?
This is exactly what I referred to when I said that conservatives think
it unbecoming to criticize the President; they just found a really
manipulative way to phrase it and never turned back.

> That's funny... it sounds to me like all you've ever heard is the
> ultra-conservative view, that multiracial anti-American liberal
> feminazis are taking over the nation! Give me a break.
> 
> >>>> I never said that.

I was actually just paraphrasing what you said: "my country sucks, men
are evil, and being white is a crime". It was an attempt to point out
how foolish that sounded, and I guess it went right over your head.
Sorry!

> I love my country, and I'm white. But that doesn't mean I can't
> criticize our goverment or the white-male dominated corporate power
> structure.
> 
> >>>> I never said that you couldn't. But don't just jump on the
> bandwagon because it's popular to "fuck bush".

What makes you think that I would say something like that because it's
"popular"? Did the thought even cross your mind that I could reach that
conclusion by actually studying his policies and their affects on our
country and the rest of the world?

> Unless you can come up with a counterargument, you're just whining. Oh
> shit, that's right: arguing IS whining, and there's no greater crime
> than criticizing the President during a time of war!
> 
> >>>> I never said that.

Again, I was embellishing on a common conservative viewpoint.

> Hey you're right Steve, let's all just agree to disagree and never
> talk about those nasty divisive "politics" again.
> 
> >>>> I never said that either.

I know you didn't. You suggested it though: by not participating in the
Kerry/Vietnam discussion then brushing off the whole issue as
"politics", then suggesting that artists shouldn't air their personal
opinions, you're in effect saying "let's just not talk about it". People
that paint "politics" as a dirty word tend not to have anything
substantive to contribute to the public discourse, so they try to
dissuade people from discussing it at all. People with genuine
convictions welcome the debate.

> >>>> Suffering? Who's suffering? BT sure isn't, neither is C.L., nor
> PVD.

So just because they're not suffering directly, they can't air their
concerns that other people are?

> >>>> Pop a pill? Sorry I can't find those.

Really? Then why did you just recently suggest that somebody get a legal
vicoden prescription online?

> >>>> Oh, can I call you? Maybe we should discuss in person over a bottle
> of delsym. Lets go to a rave together.

Sorry, I'll be in Europe for the next couple of weeks hating America.
Feel free to give me a call in a couple of weeks though!

> >>>> BTW I dislike Bush and think he's a terrible president.

I'm very glad to hear that.

Cheers,

Wow, you really don't know anything about the election fraud in Florida,
do you? FWIW, George Bush was the first president to be appointed by the
Supreme Court, which is not, in fact, "according to the rules of our
government". The only reason he got away with it was that the American
media never bothered to report the scrubbing of voter roles, the no-bid
state contracts to DBT and Choicepoint, or the illegal manipulation of
ballots.

>>>>> Bush won the electorial votes, Period. It is irrelevant that he
lost the popular vote. I've heard much propaganda on this subject on
both sides, but the fact is, is that it was decided on through a system
which has been in place for many years.

Again, I was embellishing on a common conservative viewpoint.

>>>> Stop assuming I'm conservative. I get insulted whenever you brand
me as such.

I know you didn't. You suggested it though: by not participating in the
Kerry/Vietnam discussion then brushing off the whole issue as
"politics", then suggesting that artists shouldn't air their personal
opinions, you're in effect saying "let's just not talk about it". People
that paint "politics" as a dirty word tend not to have anything
substantive to contribute to the public discourse, so they try to
dissuade people from discussing it at all. People with genuine
convictions welcome the debate.

>>>> No, I never said that artists shouldn't discuss politics, they just
shouldn't do it in a way that is taking advantage of their louder voice.

So just because they're not suffering directly, they can't air their
concerns that other people are?

>>>> So who is suffering again?

Really? Then why did you just recently suggest that somebody get a legal
vicoden prescription online?

>>>> NO! I never suggested that somebody get a prescription, I just made
a statement that Rush is stupid because he couldn't and got caught for
doing it illegally.

www.tussinspace.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

On 19 August 2004, shawn allen wrote:

> Wow, you really don't know anything about the election fraud in Florida,
> do you? FWIW, George Bush was the first president to be appointed by the
> Supreme Court, which is not, in fact, "according to the rules of our
> government". The only reason he got away with it was that the American
> media never bothered to report the scrubbing of voter roles, the no-bid
> state contracts to DBT and Choicepoint, or the illegal manipulation of
> ballots.

Nor did they report that DBT told the Fl. elections people that not
performing the validation (that they were contracted for and paid for,
4.3 Million in this case vs. 5700 for the previous firm) there would be
an abnormally high # of false positive matches.  i.e. many people would
be falsly denied their right to vote.  Since these were largly african
american folks, the fl. elections people (with the sec. of state at the
time, Katherine Harris, heading up Bush's campaign in Fl.; NO conflict
of interest there?) chose to skip the validation.  This resulted in
57,700 people stripped of the right to vote with a 95% error rate.

>
> What's really sad is that most people STILL don't care to hear things
> like this because they think it can't be true, that it's a liberal myth.
> Well sorry, it IS true: Bush was defeated in the popular vote, and had
> some 8,000 voters been allowed to vote, as was their right, he would
> have lost by a much wider margin, thus rejecting him Florida's electoral
> votes and the Presidency.

It was more than 8000 voters.  More like 55000.

> What makes you think that I would say something like that because it's
> "popular"? Did the thought even cross your mind that I could reach that
> conclusion by actually studying his policies and their affects on our
> country and the rest of the world?

Maybe the fact that he will likely be only the 2nd president in US
history to have a net job LOSS over the course of his term.  Even though
our population certainly isn't shrinking.  Seems like a tough thing to
do, actually.



http://www.jcthedj.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving and being a part of it all.

On Tue, 17 Aug 2004 15:00:42 -0700, Steve Osteen
<sosteen@pinnaclesys.com> wrote:
> Posts like this make me happy and sad. Happy, because I know that others
> out there feel what I do, but sad to know that I've missed so much. So
> many experiences that I've missed because of invisible chains my head
> locks me in. I sometimes feel that I'm alone and the whole "spirit of
> raving" only exists in my head. Maybe I'm the only one DJ'ing sets to
> myself everynight throwing my hands in the air only to realize it's only
> me that felt it.
> 
> It seems that when I do go out I never find the "right crowd", the
> "right party", or the "right music". Maybe they don't exist. Maybe it's
> only in my head and I have yet to create it, again.

threadjumping, johnny come lately style...

1 -- the spirit of raving is different from the spirit of music. if it
was all about the music we'd all be at home listening. the key to
finding the right crowd is to bring the right vibe. seek and ye shall
find.

2 -- the original question:
>In all your experiences of the underground scene, what was the first thing that
>drew you in? That first thing that made you feel alive and want more?

wasn't just one thing, it was a million things..."the synergistic
cocktail of drugs, music and people that together comprise a vibe" (or
something like that, I'm paraphrasing Simon Reynolds from memory and
it's not easy).

usual crazy visual stuff, and VJ TEK OVT will be providing the intense

they're just spinning the records instead of performing them. Hope that
makes sense. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

quoth Steve Osteen:
> Bush won the electorial votes, Period. It is irrelevant that he lost
> the popular vote. I've heard much propaganda on this subject on both
> sides, but the fact is, is that it was decided on through a system
> which has been in place for many years.

Erm yeah, so... what about all that disenfranchisement and election
fraud? That shit ain't propaganda, it's for real. The "system" used in
Florida is *not* the system that was put in place by the founding
fathers.

> Again, I was embellishing on a common conservative viewpoint.
> 
> >>>> Stop assuming I'm conservative. I get insulted whenever you brand
> me as such.

I didn't brand you as a conservative, I clearly said that I was
embellishing on a common conservative viewpoint that you repeated
("liberals hate America," etc.). Besides, you've called me a liberal...
I'm not insulted, but I'd at least prefer the term "progressive". ;)

> >>>> No, I never said that artists shouldn't discuss politics, they
> just shouldn't do it in a way that is taking advantage of their louder
> voice.

I don't get it then, what would please you? You originally said they
should be separate, that musicians specifically shouldn't discuss
politics because "art is godly" and politics is not. Besides speaking
academically about the political process, how do you propose artists
should be allowed to talk about politics? I was under the impression you
thought they just shouldn't.

> So just because they're not suffering directly, they can't air their
> concerns that other people are?
> 
> >>>> So who is suffering again?

I shouldn't need to persuade you, since you apparently dislike Bush as
well, but here are a few examples:

The poor, many of whom work multiple jobs to feed their families and
still can't afford decent housing, or healthcare for their children;
wrongly imprisoned detainees in US-controlled foreign prisons, without
access to legal representation; people that have lost their jobs as a
result of Bush's economic policies, then had their unemployment benefits
slashed at his behest; Iraqis, first ravaged by indiscriminant bombing,
then civil war and terrorism that we intentionally brought to them;
AIDS-ravaged Africans who are told--according to Bush's ideological
foreign aid policy--just not to have sex, rather than being given
condoms and taught how to practice it safely; the citizens of
communities diseased by unregulated chemical, agricultural and
industrial complexes; the elderly, who still can't afford prescription
meds because this administration allows drug companies to over-charge
within our own borders and *refuses* to allow re-importation from
countries where they're sold for much less.

Need I continue? Obviously there are many more suffering, but my point
is this: the Bush administration isn't doing shit to solve the issues
that plague our country or the rest of the world. In fact, he's making
many of them much *worse*.

> Really? Then why did you just recently suggest that somebody get a
> legal vicoden prescription online?
> 
> >>>> NO! I never suggested that somebody get a prescription, I just
> made a statement that Rush is stupid because he couldn't and got
> caught for doing it illegally.

Yeah, that's what I figured. Sorry, sarcasm doesn't come across so well
over email. :\

Cheers,
--

At 11:00 AM 8/19/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:
>Being a rock star (or a musician with annoying hair) has nothing to do
>with being qualified to make political commentary. Music/art has nothing
>to do with politics and shouldn't be mixed with politics. I could care
>less what these electronic music artists think of current issues and
>anyone who does obviously isn't capable of thinking for themselves.
>

You should look at a bit o history, Steve.  The arts and politics have been 
intertwined since the beginning of civilization.

Aristotle and Plato understood the power of music on human passions and 
action, and the uses and abuses of the arts in general in the commonweal.

Musicians have produced some of their most deeply moving music in response 
to the political climate. While composers working within repressive 
governments resorted to underground musical satires and hidden programs 
(for instance, the cryptic autobiographical programs in Shostakovich's 8th 
String Quartet), other composers, in contrast, felt free to dedicate major 
works to revolutionary political movements of their day (Beethoven's 
Eroica, and his opera Fidelio).

After WWI the Treaty of Versailles, recognizing the power of German 
military music and bands to move the national spirit, banned both military 
bands and marching music.

There is so much one could write several books:)  A collection of recent 
works discussing music and politics may be found 
here:  http://www.bomp.com/BompbooksPolitics.html

Love,

Apollo






"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

At 03:00 PM 8/19/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:
>Ok, I'll restate my comment:
>
>"No, it's popular for the youth culture to think trendy liberal view
>points are cool. It's also very popular to hate the US, their policies,
>and people these days."
>

I don't see any evidence that your statement is true.  Some propagandists 
would have one believe that anyone who disagrees with the current regime is 
unpatriotic.  But it is just this propaganda that is truly 
"unpatriotic."  American was founded on conflict and dissent.  The clear 
dangers I see to the Constitution these days are forces within the current 
administration and their corporate partners who would have us all marching 
to the same drum.

IMHO democracy can work only where there is a dialectic:  thesis + 
antithesis = synthesis.  Heathy debate between those with divergent 
viewpoints produces positive change.  The arts play an important role in 
this dialectic.

Love,

Apollo

At 04:50 PM 8/19/2004, shawn allen wrote:
>quoth Steve Osteen:
> > Bush won the electorial votes, Period. It is irrelevant that he lost
> > the popular vote. I've heard much propaganda on this subject on both
> > sides, but the fact is, is that it was decided on through a system
> > which has been in place for many years.
>
>Erm yeah, so... what about all that disenfranchisement and election
>fraud? That shit ain't propaganda, it's for real. The "system" used in
>Florida is *not* the system that was put in place by the founding
>fathers.

On that subject:

Suppress the Vote?
by Bob Herbert
Excerpted from The New York Times
Aug. 16 2004
State police officers have gone into the homes of elderly black voters in 
Orlando and interrogated them as part of an odd "investigation" that has 
frightened many voters, intimidated elderly volunteers and thrown a chill 
over efforts to get out the black vote in November.
The officers, from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, which reports 
to Gov. Jeb Bush, say they are investigating allegations of voter fraud 
that came up during the Orlando mayoral election in March.

Officials refused to discuss details of the investigation, other than to 
say that absentee ballots are involved. They said they had no idea when the 
investigation might end, and acknowledged that it may continue right 
through the presidential election.
"We did a preliminary inquiry into those allegations and then we concluded 
that there was enough evidence to follow through with a full criminal 
investigation," said Geo Morales, a spokesman for the Department of Law 
Enforcement.
The state police officers, armed and in plain clothes, have questioned 
dozens of voters in their homes. Some of those questioned have been 
volunteers in get-out-the-vote campaigns.
To read the entire article, please go to 
<http://64.4.36.250/cgi-bin/linkrd?_lang=EN&lah=76d721f8dda3a1f0a18678b60414e0b3&lat=1092941163&hm___action=http%3a%2f%2faction%2edscc%2eorg%2fct%2f8d1AHZY14B%2dh%2f>www.dscc.org/voter.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] thirty reasons to vote kerry

quoth Jonas R.:
> why do think Kerry will improve the situation.  and "anyone but bush"
> ideology just isn't good enough for me here.  Kerry's exit plan does
> not suggest improvement.

Kerry's strategy WRT Iraq involves "reaching out" to the nations that we
pissed off by rushing to war in the first place--in other words
explaining to the UN that without their help we're up shit creek. It's
going to take some humility, but that seems to be something that Kerry's
pretty good at projecting. He is a hawk (relatively speaking, of
course), but I think he realizes what needs to be done to get the rest
of the world back on our side.

As far as specific plans go for withdrawing troops, your guess is as
good as mine (or anyone's, for that matter). Until the situation over
there improves or we find international (and, more importantly, Middle
Eastern) troops to replace our own, we're stuck. It would be pretty
shitty to have gotten them into all this then just say, "OK, we're outta
here... you guys can handle all those terrorists we committed to
fighting 'on their own turf', right?"

> i support our troops never having to leave our soil.  i support
> self-defense.  fighting a war (or during the clinton admin. "conflict
> / police action") outside of our borders doesn't seem justified in any
> case.
>
> can anyone suggest a war / conflict / police action that the u.s. lead
> in the last 50 years where people were left better off?  i know i
> can't.

Sure... One could argue that Bosnia and Herzegovina's situation ain't
pretty, but it's definitely an improvement over three-way ethnic strife.
Afghanistan is somewhat better off--Karzai's no saint, but he seems
capable of restoring some rule in that country, weening the warlords off
poppy production and fostering local representative rule. And despite
the very real possibility that the Bush administration was instrumental
in recently removing him from power, UN peacekeepers did help restore
the rule of law after Jean-Bertrand Aristide's most recent overthrow in
Haiti.

But do we really need to wait until things get as bad as the Nazi
internment before we decide to intervene? For instance, do you think we
(or the UN) should do something to quell the ethnic cleansing in Darfur? 

I don't support pre-emptive war, but I do think we need to do
*something* to prevent the rest of the world from falling into
desperation. 

:\

just one more thing about the funniness of ali g and then we will continue with the regular story again:
 
ali g does a sketch where he goes and visits a man who is a veternarian (sp? animal doctor) and also, incidentally a vietnam vet. throughout the entire sketch, ali g gets the words "veternarian" and "veteran" confused, and this is very perplexing to the old veternarian who repeatedly explains the difference between the two. at one point, after a series of explanations, ali g asks the old man if  he'd always known he'd wanted to be a veteran. it is very funny :)

I'd rather have an unsure candidate than one that would commit to a course
of action before entering office and reviewing all the facts.  

Will Kerry do any better than Bush, I dunno, we'll have to see...

I for one, can't vote for someone who sent our soldiers to invade another
country, Iraq in this case, based on spotty or fictional inteligence.  Iraq
didn't present a clear and present danger to this country.  Afghanistan is
one thing, they were actually harbouring, and training terrorists, but there
was never any recent evidence, of WMD, or ties to Al Quida in Iraq.  I still
ask myself why we invaded Iraq, especially given the current state of
afghanistan.  

Bush is the president, and thus is responsible.  

My two cents

-j

> Afghanistan is somewhat better off--Karzai's no saint, but he seems
> capable of restoring some rule in that country, weaning the warlords off
> poppy production and fostering local representative rule.

Funny, because I'm getting info that is saying that the opiate trade is
booming specifically *because* the production from Afghanistan is up so
high...  In most areas of the country(US), heroin is still cheap as hell
because of this.  Before you ask, no, I cant cite sources.. as mine are
coming from friends and compatriots in the drug using population and harm
reduction institutes and needle exchange sites around the country (and in
others).

> I don't support pre-emptive war, but I do think we need to do
> *something* to prevent the rest of the world from falling into
> desperation.

Why is it our job?  Did we (the people) vote to be peacekeepers or
international police?  Seems to me that in order to be an effective
peacekeeping entity, we need to look between our own borders before we
trounce around the world telling others what is right and wrong.

Just my .02

-B

--part1_12c.497da88c.2e56e59a_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

     John Kerry was a medal winning, Vietnam vet, who later became a leader 
of a vet protest group against the war. He was obviously disgusted with what he 
went through over there. His famous quote from back the day, I'm sure you've 
all heard is (adressing congress authority) "How do you ask a man to be the 
last man to die for a mistake?" This being his most famous quote to his name, 
will stick to him forever. One would think he would make his best attempt to 
uphold this type of mentality within his Presidency and as commander in chief in 
times of war. With that quote being the most powerful and sincere statement 
he's ever been known for, how could he then ask another man to die for a mistake 
again? I mean I suppose it's fathomable for anyone to make an occasional 
mistake, but at least you know where his heart is. I cannot say the same for Bush. 

     They say whether he deserved his medals is speculative but how can you 
believe negative attacks against an upcoming presidential candidate when you 
know they are going to be biased? Presidential Candidates are very vulnerable to 
negative attacks so I'm willing to give them all a little leeway until I see 
some hard-core proof that would make them seem "unfit for command". Kerry 
actually did eventually give up the medals he won from his acts in vietnam, 
leaving them on the steps of the capital in a protest effort. Would Bush ever do 
anything as sincere as that? I think this shows he is a different kind of 
candidate. Another quote from Kerry that first caught my attention to him was when he 
said "Some people look at the way things are and ask why? I look at the way 
things never were and ask why not?" (not sure if that was the word for word 
quote but it's close)   
     I'm sure it sounds a bit confusing how a person can be a commanding War 
vet, then a commanding war protester, then vote yes in the senate for the 
invasion of Iraq, but then no to the funding of that war... But I bet you if you 
could sit with him for an hour and ask him those questions he could explain to 
you his reasoning very logically and thoughtfully. People have complex reasons 
for making complex decisions, we can all relate to this. If someone looked at 
all your decisions you've ever made in your lifetime, I'm sure a lot of them 
would seem very peculiar. The way I see it, John Kerry is a man who evolves 
with time and he is a man who listens to what the people want. Which is exactly 
what a Democratic President should be. He's a million times more sensible than 
Bush and as current events and intelligence change, so does his mind. He 
knows when it's time to retreat, when it's time to ask for help, when it's time to 
admit a mistake, and he knows when it's time to step up and overthrow an 
incompetent leader. To call him a "flip flopper" or "unsure" or "inconsistent" is 
an in-justice, if you jump to conclusions you can make anyone that you don't 
really know, seem terrible. First I'd ask you to really listen to him speak 
because I have many times and I always tend to agree, in general, given our 
current situation and choices, he usually seems to pick the right choice. Just      
  having Bush replaced, in itself, sends positive signals to the rest of the 
world, that we understand, that we care, that we as a massive, who vote 
democratically, do not condone what the Bush regime has done. John Kerry is a 
million times better than having a President who's main beliefs are "Stick to your 
guns" and "We've turned the corner, can't go back now!" That kind of thinking 
just makes me sick. 
     Just because John Kerry does not lean as far left as we would like him 
to, does not make him Bush the 3rd, or Bush light. Don't listen to what other 
people say about these guys, don't even listen to me... listen to these guys 
talk. Who's telling the truth? Who's more sincere? Who's reading palm cards? Who 
has an IQ of over 100?? You should see through them instinctually.    *keep 
bouncing*

--part1_12c.497da88c.2e56e59a_boundary--

quoth Bryan Oley:
> > Afghanistan is somewhat better off--Karzai's no saint, but he seems
> > capable of restoring some rule in that country, weaning the warlords
> > off poppy production and fostering local representative rule.
> 
> Funny, because I'm getting info that is saying that the opiate trade
> is booming specifically *because* the production from Afghanistan is
> up so high...  In most areas of the country(US), heroin is still cheap
> as hell because of this.

Well, I'm basing my statement entirely on a piece I heard on NPR the
other day that discussed how Karzai's administration was trying to stem
poppy production by encouraging farmers to grow other crops. It's slow
going, obviously; the Taliban banned heroin production when they were in
power, and it surged in popularity once they lost control of the
country. But from what I've heard, it sounds like they're making
progress. I could be totally wrong though :\

> Before you ask, no, I cant cite sources.. as mine are coming from
> friends and compatriots in the drug using population and harm
> reduction institutes and needle exchange sites around the country (and
> in others).

I guess any progress they've made is a very recent development. I
remember reading just a couple of months ago about heroin production
being completely out of hand since the fall of the Taliban.

> > I don't support pre-emptive war, but I do think we need to do
> > *something* to prevent the rest of the world from falling into
> > desperation.
> 
> Why is it our job?  Did we (the people) vote to be peacekeepers or
> international police?  Seems to me that in order to be an effective
> peacekeeping entity, we need to look between our own borders before we
> trounce around the world telling others what is right and wrong.

You're absolutely right. We have enough problems at home that need
addressing, and from the perspective of a taxpayer getting their money's
worth, it probably seems wrong to commit so many resources to solving
other peoples' issues. But I can't help thinking that it's wrong to
ignore serious human rights abuses (e.g., ethnic cleansing). That's why
I think it's important that we respect the UN, and allow them handle
catastrophes by pooling the member nations' resources. At the very
least, I think we should share that burden with other countries and
allow them to participate equally in the very complex process of
maintaining peace throughout the world.

Cheers,

> Well, I'm basing my statement entirely on a piece I heard on NPR the
> other day that discussed how Karzai's administration was trying to stem
> poppy production by encouraging farmers to grow other crops. It's slow
> going, obviously; the Taliban banned heroin production when they were in
> power, and it surged in popularity once they lost control of the
> country. But from what I've heard, it sounds like they're making
> progress. I could be totally wrong though :\

If its anything like what they(we) are trying to get done in Columbia, it
wont take hold effectively unless its forced (as under the Taliban).

Simply put, there is more money for farmers in poppies than in any other
single crop they can grow in that area.  That's why it boomed so much before
and now.

They may be making progress... hope they do..  but for now.. (IMHO) we just
created a bigger problem.

But I can't help thinking that it's wrong to
> ignore serious human rights abuses (e.g., ethnic cleansing).

Your right, no one should ignore ethnic cleansing.

>That's why
> I think it's important that we respect the UN, and allow them handle
> catastrophes by pooling the member nations' resources. At the very
> least, I think we should share that burden with other countries and
> allow them to participate equally in the very complex process of
> maintaining peace throughout the world.

It would be great if it worked this way, but we have "taken the lead" so
many times, that many times, when the US arrives, everyone else pretty much
stands back and lets us lead the way as far as resources etc..  That is of
course when we do ask for help..  That, and we have this bad habit of paying
to rebuild countries after we attack them.  Not only is that not our duty,
but it drains money better used for domestic issues. Of course, this argues
the point that we shouldnt attack if we dont plan on rebuilding.. but thats
another tangeant alltogether.

And if we ever were to do this, we would have to stop being hypocrites and
start the reform with our allies, many of whom have worse human rights
abuses than any other country we have pointed out needed "liberation from
tyrants".

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Need PCMCIA soundcard advice

I use a MOTU 828 with my laptop and traktor. I had to add a firewire pcmcia
(about $50.00) to the laptop. Many "multimedia" laptops these days already
have firewire. I've been using the 828 for years now. There's an 828 mkII
out now which is even nicer.

In addition to the M-audio firewire box already mentioned, there's also
a presonus firewire box, which is expensive but very high quality.

I think Yamaha and Roland also now have multichannel firewire products
as well.

If you want to go really compact (but missing the important balanced outputs
of the firewire boxen) there is also a multichannel PCMCIA audio card
available.

My suggestions:
	*make sure it's got balanced outputs -- less chance of computer
	 digi-noise and ground-loop noise from bleeding into your soundsystem.
	*make sure the headphone jack can get loud enough for "live DJing"
	 (the 828 works fine)
	* make sure you have at least 4 channels that can play simultaneously.
	  2 for the headphone/monitor, 2 for the mains.

-- Niels Mayer
    Corona del Mar, CA. (yeah, I'm out of SF, for good!).

     I think that the term propaganda, is used much too loosely or perhaps 
it's been given a much worse stigma than it's dictionary meaning. My editing 
teacher in film school once said that propaganda should not always be thought of 
as a negative term, as in "Nazi propaganda" like we always think of.

Here's what dictionary.com says - 
     1.      The systematic propagation of a doctrine or cause or of 
information reflecting the views and interests of those advocating such a doctrine or 
cause.
     2.      Material disseminated by the advocates or opponents of a 
doctrine or cause: wartime propaganda.

     So then sure Rage Against the Machine and sometimes Beastie Boys 
material would fall into this definition of "propaganda" but why not just let it be 
fair game? If you can say your political views, and rhyme and make music all at 
the same time then why not do it? So what if you have a bigger fan base than 
the president does? That's the whole point isn't it? People follow who they 
relate to, people who care enough to reach out using greater means of 
communication, oddly enough... are the ones who reach more other people. People do need 
to be reached.   
     I remember one day watching the movie "Better Living Through Circuitry" 
with my friends in Washington and part way through the movie one of my friends 
gets up and says he doesn't want to watch this "raver propaganda", I remember 
this same guy also says the movie "The Omega Code" was Christian propaganda. 
This guy was raised Jewish but actually did not seem to believe in anything.   
Not that that matters but maybe that might explain his attitude. Anyway If 
"Better Living Through Circuitry" is "raver propaganda"   "The Omega Code" is 
Christian propaganda and Rage Against The Machine and Beastie Boys are 
"political art propaganda" then... I mean aren't skateboarding movies "skater 
propaganda" and isn't ESPN "sports propaganda"   and wouldn't Playboy be "sex 
propaganda" or beautiful women propaganda?? Where do you draw the line? Why can't 
political views just be fair game? Why can't we just stop using the word propaganda 
unless someone is actually maliciously and purposefully trying to BRAINWASH 
people, knowing that they are not telling the whole truth or any truth at all 
like the Nazis did. I mean if you can convince people to agree with you based 
on what you believe to be the truth, then more power to you, if you do it with 
rhymes and guitars that's even better than being some bland politician, why 
all this criticism? I don't agree that politics in art are propaganda, but if 
they must be defined as such I think that we have over blown and created a false 
stigma upon what the word "propaganda" really means.    **keep bouncing**

--part1_128.4947685d.2e573eaf_boundary--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Need PCMCIA soundcard advice

quoth Niels P. Mayer:
> I use a MOTU 828 with my laptop and traktor. I had to add a firewire
> pcmcia (about $50.00) to the laptop. Many "multimedia" laptops these
> days already have firewire. I've been using the 828 for years now.
> There's an 828 mkII out now which is even nicer.

A lot of people use the 828. I've never laid my hands on one myself, but
it seems to me that you either love MOTU or you hate 'em. Same with
anything in audio, I guess.

> In addition to the M-audio firewire box already mentioned, there's
> also a presonus firewire box, which is expensive but very high
> quality.

I'd stay away from M-Audio unless you absolutely can't afford
anything else (they are the cheapest, after all). I've had bad luck with
some of their USB interfaces, particularly the Quattro USB. STEER CLEAR,
that thing sucks. As far as firewire goes, here's what I've been looking
at:

On of the cheapest in the lot is the Presonus Firepod, a 10x10 audio,
1x1 MIDI I/O rack mount for ~$600:
<http://www.presonus.com/firestation.html>

The new Edirol FA-101 is tiny, bus-powered, it has the same I/O as the
Firepod (w/2 combo jacks to the Firepod's 8), and it's still relatively
cheap ($500-600):
<http://edirol.com/products/info/fa101.html>

The RME Fireface has 8x8 balanced, 1x1 MIDI I/O, but their site says the
OS X drivers aren't yet available, it's rack-mount, and it's twice as
expensive as the Edirol (~$1500):
<http://www.rme-audio.de/english/firewire/ff800.htm>

Also in that price range ($1200-2000) is the Metric Halo Mobile I/O
2882, w/4 XLR ins, 4 line ins, 8 balanced outs and no MIDI. It's
available with or without built-in DSP:
<http://www.mhlabs.com/metric_halo/products/mio/2882/>

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Need PCMCIA soundcard advice


> 
> A lot of people use the 828. I've never laid my hands on one myself, but
> it seems to me that you either love MOTU or you hate 'em. Same with
> anything in audio, I guess.

Problem with the 828 is that it only does 48khz.  The 828-2 does do
96khz.
 
> > In addition to the M-audio firewire box already mentioned, there's
> > also a presonus firewire box, which is expensive but very high
> > quality.
> 
> I'd stay away from M-Audio unless you absolutely can't afford
> anything else (they are the cheapest, after all).

I have had great luck with with my M-audio Firewire 410.  Apparently, early 
driver sucked, but they have the bugs worked out now.  It works flawlessly on
my OS10.3 system.  Only 1 input stereo input, but it does do 96khz.
I much prefer firewire devices over USB1.1.  Latency will almost always
be better on a firewire device compared to a USB1.1 device.

The Firewire 410 also built for live laptop use... dual headphone outputs
with indepent volume control, Balanced inputs with gain and 48V phantom
power, all Firewire-bus powered.  Pretty blue LEDs.

-troy

From: JBlaze112@aol.com [mailto:JBlaze112@aol.com]=20
Sent: Friday, August 20, 2004 4:47 AM
To: apollo@speakeasy.org; Steve Osteen; dj.soundwave@gmail.com;
st_indigo@earthlink.net; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [skylab2000] rock the vote! (VRR)

=20

     I think that the term propaganda, is used much too loosely or
perhaps it's been given a much worse stigma than it's dictionary
meaning. My editing teacher in film school once said that propaganda
should not always be thought of as a negative term, as in "Nazi
propaganda" like we always think of.

Here's what dictionary.com says -=20
     1.     The systematic propagation of a doctrine or cause or of
information reflecting the views and interests of those advocating such
a doctrine or cause.
     2.     Material disseminated by the advocates or opponents of a
doctrine or cause: wartime propaganda.

     So then sure Rage Against the Machine and sometimes Beastie Boys
material would fall into this definition of "propaganda" but why not
just let it be fair game? If you can say your political views, and rhyme
and make music all at the same time then why not do it? So what if you
have a bigger fan base than the president does? That's the whole point
isn't it? People follow who they relate to, people who care enough to
reach out using greater means of communication, oddly enough... are the
ones who reach more other people. People do need to be reached. =20
     I remember one day watching the movie "Better Living Through
Circuitry" with my friends in Washington and part way through the movie
one of my friends gets up and says he doesn't want to watch this "raver
propaganda", I remember this same guy also says the movie "The Omega
Code" was Christian propaganda. This guy was raised Jewish but actually
did not seem to believe in anything.  Not that that matters but maybe
that might explain his attitude. Anyway If "Better Living Through
Circuitry" is "raver propaganda"  "The Omega Code" is Christian
propaganda and Rage Against The Machine and Beastie Boys are "political
art propaganda" then... I mean aren't skateboarding movies "skater
propaganda" and isn't ESPN "sports propaganda"  and wouldn't Playboy be
"sex propaganda" or beautiful women propaganda?? Where do you draw the
line? Why can't political views just be fair game? Why can't we just
stop using the word propaganda unless someone is actually maliciously
and purposefully trying to BRAINWASH people, knowing that they are not
telling the whole truth or any truth at all like the Nazis did. I mean
if you can convince people to agree with you based on what you believe
to be the truth, then more power to you, if you do it with rhymes and
guitars that's even better than being some bland politician, why all
this criticism? I don't agree that politics in art are propaganda, but
if they must be defined as such I think that we have over blown and
created a false stigma upon what the word "propaganda" really means.
**keep bouncing**




------_=_NextPart_001_01C486E3.B8D778EE--

At 11:20 AM 8/20/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:
>So why did we invade Germany in WW2 when it was Japan that attacked us?
>Was that wrong also?

Japan and Germany had a pact.  If Japan declared war with a another country 
Germany became involved automatically.

Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

the people over there.  PROVEN ethnic cleansing!  not
assumptions based on ill-advised intelligence.  there
IS a difference.  not a very good rebutle on your

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] thirty reasons to vote kerry

Are you just playing devil's advocate or pushing buttons for fun?  :-D

Saddam killed a lot of his enemies and his own people. It's part of a
regional conflict that's no-one else's business. It's not an issue of
right and wrong. We (or any other countries) do not and cannot get
involve with other regions' conflicts unless it's absolutely
neccessary. Though of course, right and wrong is relative, so is
neccessary military invlovement.

Why didn't we take the oil out right militarily? Because it'll turn
our action from defense (as a reaction to 9/11) to flat-out invasion
(for oil), which gives the international community legitimate reason
to turn against us, not to mention that the people of United States
would not have allowed such invasion in the first place.

We used terrorists as an excuse to invade another largely irrelevant
(to 9/11) country for oil. Or so that's what the movie says. That's an
"invasion", and we're subject to retailiation, UN punishments, and
make a whole lot of new enemies in the process.

The act of war is govern by international law. It sounds like an
oxymoron: if war can be governed by law, then there wouldn't be wars
in the first place. They cover anything from declaration of war,
weapon restrictions (namely chemical, nuclear, etc.) , to POW
treatments, etc. Obviously, these laws are violated al the time during
a war (by both sides). If you break these rules during a war and you
lose (best examples are Germany and Japan in WW2), you'll be subject
to severe penalties by the UN.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laws_of_war

Genocides and terrorism are special cases since they're not
technically act of war, because these acts target civilians.

In terms of reality, there's not much you can't do in a war, and you
can invade anyone you want for whatever reason you want, the catch is
how many more enemies you're willing to make and what price you're
willing to pay when you lose.

- Jeff

@ Progressions 1-YEAR ANNIVERSARY 
Heres the latest word from the Progression crew


The Bay Area's longest-running progressive monthly is back for another year
of musical madness! Featuring the finest in local progressive DJ's
pushing the edge of electronic music forward into San Francisco, PROGRESSION 
@
26MIX is gearing up to rock the 2004-2005 season.
But first, Progression is celebrating its 1-YEAR ANNIVERSARY, FRIDAY AUGUST
20TH featuring a 90-minute set from GUEST DJ KOROMA (AuraSF,
Koroma.com). Coming off a brilliant set at Qool last week and a highly 
acclaimed (and
highly booked!) summer, Koroma has been looking forward to playing for us
for awhile, and we're hugely excited that he'll be helping us celebrate
in fine, bangin' style!

So remember Friday, August 20th, from 6-10PM at 26MIX is PROGRESSION'S FIRST
BIRTHDAY BASH! We'll have cigars, birthday cake, and a drawing to enter
and win A FREE TICKET TO JOHN DIGWEED AT MEZZANINE ON FRIDAY SEPTEMBER 3RD!
Yep, you read that right. As Progression's birthday gift to you, the
loyal supporters of the SF scene, we're laying down a free ticket to the
return of the king! The drawing goes off at 9:00, and we hope to see you 
there.
So come by, have a drink, enjoy some cake, and be ready to dance your
ass off. Because Fall is coming, big things are on the horizon, and the
place to start off your Friday night is HERE!

At 11:59 AM 8/20/2004, Steve Osteen wrote:
>Well, I wanted to hear the counter argument to this. I now understand
>that Japan and Germany had a treaty along with the fact that Germany
>declared war on us. Thanks for educating me. Someone should tell Michael
>Savage this.
>
>See this is why I need to keep my mouth shut on politics.
>

No, Steve.  It's good to question things.  The world is a much more complex 
place than some would have us believe.  Decision-making would be simple if 
war was a conflict between "good and evil" as it is portrayed in the "Lord 
of the Rings" movies (not so black and white in the books).

After the bloodbaths of the twentieth century attempts were made to create 
some internal legal structures governing war.  The Germans were involved in 
preemptive warfare, as were the Japanese, for reasons that both countries 
believed were just.  Preemptive warfare, therefore, is now viewed as 
immoral and illegal.  Even prior to WWI and II there were many Christian 
theologians who believed the only moral war was one that was defensive.  I 
don't believe the United States should ever be involved in preemptive 
military action.  We're better than that, I hope....

Complexity.  Research is relatively easy these days.  Look at the history 
of Mesopotamia, now Iraq, and Persia, now Iran, and you get a much better 
understanding of what ancient forces are in play there.

History is grate.

Love,

Apollo




"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_14931099==.ALT--

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed



Military records support Kerry's account of Vietnam service


BY Joseph L. Galloway
Knight Ridder Newspapers


WASHINGTON - Military records back John Kerry's account of his service in 
Vietnam and have backed at least two of his accusers into a corner.

Kerry this week was forced to defend himself against accusations by a group 
of fellow Navy veterans of Vietnam that he was a liar and a coward. The 
charges were made in a book and in an attack ad that polls show have 
chipped away at Kerry's standing with veterans in three critical states - 
West Virginia, Wisconsin and Ohio.

More:  http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/9455159.htm?1c

Subject: RE: [sfraves] thirty reasons to vote kerry

Steve, 
With all due respect, we invaded Germany because Germany, Japan and Italy
were part of "The Axis" Alliance.  Hence an attack or declaration of war on
one, is considered an attack or declaration on all.  Subsequent to the
infamous attack of Pear Harbour, President Roosevelt, before a joint session
of congress asked for a declaration of war against Japan.  I think, about
the 11th or 12th of December, Germany, and eventually Italy declared war
upon the United States.  

Was it wrong to declare war on Japan, and assist the allies in the invasion
of Germany?  Absolutely not!  Remember, we were forced into WW2.  

All I was saying, was we were not attacked by Iraq.  There was no
intelligence linking Iraq to any terrorist groups.  In fact, I think it was
Powel, who stood up in front of the United Nations, and the world, and
stated that we had the goods, and that Iraq presented a Clear and Present
Danger not just to the US but to the world.  Where's the evidence, in fact,
the administration later countered these claims.  

We are in Iraq now, we cannot leave.  People are dying, and the country is
even more unstable then it was under it's former government.  IMO, bush is
responsible, and should not be re-elected, regardless of whether he knew the
intelligence was credible or not.

It's a simply matter of responsibility.  

A chance maybe to prove Godwin's Law.  =)

-j

So why did we invade Germany in WW2 when it was Japan that attacked us?
Was that wrong also?

-----Original Message-----
From: jarvik@betacaeli.com [mailto:jarvik@betacaeli.com]
Sent: Thursday, August 19, 2004 9:39 PM

Subject: RE: [sfraves] thirty reasons to vote kerry


I'd rather have an unsure candidate than one that would commit to a
course
of action before entering office and reviewing all the facts.  

Will Kerry do any better than Bush, I dunno, we'll have to see...

I for one, can't vote for someone who sent our soldiers to invade
another
country, Iraq in this case, based on spotty or fictional inteligence.
Iraq
didn't present a clear and present danger to this country.  Afghanistan
is
one thing, they were actually harbouring, and training terrorists, but
there
was never any recent evidence, of WMD, or ties to Al Quida in Iraq.  I
still
ask myself why we invaded Iraq, especially given the current state of
afghanistan.  

Bush is the president, and thus is responsible.  

My two cents

-j

Subject: [sfraves] Grandmaster Flash tore it up!!!  And he'll do it again tonight!

last night Flash tore it up!!!!

it was the most fun i've had listening to a hip hop DJ EVER.  that's right.  
i said EVER!  as in i've NEVER had that much fun listening to hip hop.

he pulled out every cut, every jam, every dope bangin joint i remember from 
back in the day!

and he'll do it again tonight at Vintage!  be there!!!!!

EMUOR is proud to bring you
Vintage
Saturday, August 21st

* ALL AGES *  ALL NIGHT FUN 9PM  5AM  *  FULLY PERMITTED  *  VIRGIN 
LOCATION *

Don't miss this all ages all night event celebrating the vintage sound of 
the yester years in a safe and secure venue with 2000+ capacity. Fully 
permitted event and on site parking. Vintage will be held and co-sponsored 
by the Mandela center located at 1357 5th St. Oakland, Ca 94607. Portion of 
the proceeds will benefit the Alliance for West Oakland Development.


ROOM 01.

Grandmaster Flash
THE TURNTABLE LEGEND / ESSENTIAL / NEW YORK
www.grandmasterflash.com

The creator of the Quick Mix, he was the first person to change the 
arrangements of songs using duplicate copies of records and manually 
repeating the climatic part by rubbing the records back and forth. His Quick 
Mix style helped stretch the BREAK of the song and drive the crowd and all 
B-Boys & B-Girls wild with his live editing. Flashs CUTTING and 
SCRATCHING helped him become a pioneer for all turntablelist throughout the 
world. Come and see a legend at work for this special engagement.


2 Bad Mice
EMUOR / SM:)E / UNITED KINGDOM

Formed in 1991, 2 Bad Mice are widely attributed as among the first U.K. 
hardcore acts to begin incorporating breakbeats into electronic music. With 
countless tracks since the early 90s, such as Bombscare  The original 
breakbeat anthem to the globe, 2 Bad Mice tunes have been a staple in the 
electronic music scene for over 10 years. Now you can taste what started it 
all as one of the originators of the classic old school rave sound graces us 
on the decks.

sure to bring warm clothes, blankets, etc.

Cannabass Presents: Lighta'
Sunday August 22nd, 2004

Free Outdoor Day Party on Treasure Island
1pm - till Wheneva'

Bring shit to BBQ. There is no grocery store on the island, so you must
bring all refreshments and supplies with you. There is a quicki-mart
there now which will sell munchies, but you must bring most things (like
beer) yourself from the mainland.

LIVE PA's

Andrew Phelan (djandrewphelan.com, Thump Radio, Olive Records) and

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Kerry military records

	Joseph Galloway sounds more like a flack for the Kerry campaign than a 
balanced reporter. Here is a bit more even-handed account:

		http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/4790712/

	I agree that it sounds like the records released by Kerry appear to 
generally correspond with the accounts given by him and his supporters 
of what he did in Vietnam. Those Swift Boat veterans who are saying 
something contradicted by the records need to explain, or their own 
credibility is going to take a hit.

	The articles sound however like all Kerry's war records have not been 
released, and that his campaign is playing games with at least one 
document, by saying it's a "private" medical record which "a reporter" 
could come to his campaign office and look at, but not make copies to 
take away.

	I don't understand why this one record documenting an injury to 
Kerry's elbow that happened decades ago would be a "private" record 
subject to this kind of restriction while the other records of his war 
injuries are not, unless someone is trying to hide something.

For liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Then try this:

<<Journalist Breaks Silence to Defend Kerry Against Swift Boaters

By E & P Staff
Published: August 21, 2004

NEW YORK A Chicago Tribune journalist who commanded a boat alongside John 
Kerry in Vietnam broke a 35-year silence on Saturday to say that stories 
told by Kerry's "Swift Boat" detractors are untrue.

William Rood of the Chicago Tribune wrote on the newspaper's Web site, 
"There were three swift boats on the river that day in Vietnam more than 35 
years ago -- three officers and 15 crew members. Only two of those officers 
remain to talk about what happened on February 28, 1969

"One is John Kerry ... who won a Silver Star for what happened on that 
date. I am the other.">>

Or that:

<<Ex-commander backs Kerry on Vietnam

By Carol Giacomo

PITTSBURGH (Reuters) - A journalist who commanded a boat alongside John 
Kerry in Vietnam has broken a
35-year silence to defend the Democratic presidential candidate against 
Republican critics of his military
service and integrity.

William Rood of the Chicago Tribune said the tales told by Kerry's 
detractors are simply untrue.>>

The story is breaking on the wire services as I type.

Love,

Apollo

At 01:39 AM 8/22/2004, Andrew Phelan wrote:
>This is all just a diversionary tactic to keep us away from discussing the
>real issues at the heart of the upcoming elections...
>
>-Andrew
>

I totally agree.  But we don't see these attack ads here.  They are only 
shown in the so-called "battleground" states and they appear to be having 
much impact if one believes the polls.  That's the way politics work in the 
US of A:  no complex issues, just dirt and soundbites.

The real fun begins next week when the Swift Boat Boys for Bush focus on 
Kerry's activities after he left Vietnam and his testimony about atrocities 
committed by our troops.

Personally, one of the reasons I thought Kerry might be a good Democratic 
candidate was that he told the truth about the heart of darkness that was 
Vietnam after he had served honorably.  His marketing execs, however, 
decided he should repackage himself as a John Wayne/Terminator dude and so 
we get some fool who looks like he's running for President of the VFW.  Now 
he's going to have to discuss the anti-war activist side.  I assume his ad 
men were prepared for this.

Love,

Apollo

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Drug war is a war on families

--=====================_7663018==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Drug war is a war on families
By Walter Cronkite

Sunday, August 08, 2004 -

In the midst of the soaring rhetoric of the recent Democratic National 
Convention, more than one speaker quoted Abraham Lincoln's first inaugural 
address, invoking "the better angels of our nature." Well, there is an 
especially appropriate task awaiting those heavenly creatures - a 
long-overdue reform of our disastrous war on drugs. We should begin by 
recognizing its costly and inhumane dimensions.

Much of the nation, in one way or another, is victimized by this failure - 
including, most notably, the innocents, whose exposure to drugs is greater 
than ever.

This despite the fact that there are, housed in federal and state prisons 
and local jails on drug offenses, more than 500,000 persons - half a 
million people! Clearly, no punishment could be too severe for that portion 
of them who were kingpins of the drug trade and who ruined so many lives. 
But by far, the majority of these prisoners are guilty of only minor 
offenses, such as possessing small amounts of marijuana. That includes 
people who used it only for medicinal purposes.

The cost to maintain this great horde of prisoners is more than $10 billion 
annually. And that's just part of the cost of this war on drugs: The 
federal, state and local drug-control budgets last year added up to almost 
$40 billion.

These figures were amassed by the Drug Policy Alliance, one of the foremost 
national organizations seeking to bring reason to the war on drugs and 
reduce substantially those caught in the terrible web of addiction.

There are awful tales of tragedy and shocking injustice hidden in those 
figures - the product of an almost mindlessly draconian system called 
"mandatory sentencing," in which even small offenses can draw years in prison.

Thousands of women, many of them mothers of young children, are included 
among those minor offenders. Those children left without motherly care are 
the most innocent victims of the drug war and the reason some call it a 
"war on families."

Women are the fastest-growing segment of the prison population, with almost 
80 percent of them incarcerated for drug offenses. The deep perversity of 
the system lies in the fact that women with the least culpability often get 
the harshest sentences.

Unlike the guilty drug dealer, they often have no information to trade for 
a better deal from prosecutors, and might end up with a harsher sentence 
than the dealer gets.

Then there are women like Kimba Smith, in California, who probably knew a 
few things but was so terrified of her abusive boyfriend that she refused 
to testify against him. (Those who agree to testify, by the way, frequently 
are murdered before they have a chance to do so.) Smith paid for her 
terrified silence with a 24-year sentence. Nonviolent first offenders, male 
and female, caught with only small amounts of a controlled substance 
frequently are given prison sentences of five to 10 years or more. As a 
result, the number of nonviolent offenders in the nation's prisons is 
filling them to overflowing, literally. The resulting overcrowding is 
forcing violent felons onto the streets with early releases.

The Drug Policy Alliance also points out other important areas of injustice 
in the present enforcement system. For instance, people of color - 
African-Americans and Latinos - are far more likely to be jailed for drug 
offenses than others. And college students caught in possession of very 
small amounts of illegal substances are denied student loans and even food 
stamps.

The Alliance and other organizations are working to reform and reframe the 
war on drugs. And they are finding many judges on their side, who are 
rebelling against this cruel system. We can expect no federal action during 
the congressional hiatus in activity ahead of the November elections, but 
it would be of considerable help if, across the country, campaigning 
politicians put this high on their promises of legislative action, much 
sooner than later.

Walter Cronkite has been a journalist for more than 60 years, including 19 
as anchor of the CBS Evening News.



"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
