Subject: [sfraves] more about Kerry's "heroism"

oh, these guys have definitely convinced me now


>http://www.confusionroad.com/article.php?article_id=3D259
>Viet Cong Veterans Denounce Kerry
>*/'Sampan Veterans For Truth' Call Kerry Unfit For Command/*
>
>U.S. - A group of Viet Cong veterans has launched a series of television=20
>ads denouncing Democratic Presidential nominee John Kerry as being a=20
>'liar' and an 'incompetent soldier' whose war record demonstrates his=20
>unfitness for the Presidency.
>
>The group calls itself 'Sampan Veterans For Truth,' after the small=20
>canoe-like boats, or sampans, they operated in the Mekong Delta while=20
>fighting against the U.S. during the Vietnam war. The advertisements blast=
=20
>Kerry for allegedly misleading the Navy and the American people about the=
=20
>battle in which he earned his Silver Star for heroism under fire.
>
>"John Kerry claimed that he was taking machine gun and mortar fire during=
=20
>the battle," says Viet Cong soldier Nguyen Dinh Vay in one commercial. "I=
=20
>know this is not true, because I was one of the men attacking him. My=20
>fellow soldiers and I were armed only with spears and harsh language. And=
=20
>we almost won."
>
>Nguyen goes on to say that Kerry's powerful swift boat did not face=20
>'hundreds' of Viet Cong, as the candidate claims, but "a few ragtag=20
>soldiers in sampans."
>
>"John Kerry, a war hero?" Nguyen asks rhetorically. "That's an insult to=20
>all of us who fought against him. If he was a hero, we'd have tried harder=
=20
>to kill him."
>
>The commercial then ridicules Kerry for his lack of skill in combat,=20
>insinuating that he was not worthy of being a Navy lieutenant, let alone=20
>President of the United States. "Among the Viet Cong, he was known as=20
>'Jittery Johnny' for his erratic behavior and inaccurate fire," says=20
>another Viet Cong veteran in the ad, Tran Binh Huong. "The sight of his=20
>swift boat was a sure sign that you were safe, because you knew that the=20
>American forces on board would be disorganized and impotent in battle.=20
>When we left the tunnels to go on hit-and-run missions, we used to kid=20
>each other by saying, 'be careful, or Jittery Johnny will get you!' Man,=20
>that one always killed me."
>
>"Who do you want leading your country in time of war," the ad concludes,=20
>"a proven wartime President =AD or Jittery Johnny?"
>
>Since the Sampan Veterans For Truth are all Vietnamese citizens who have=20
>never been to the United States, many observers are confused about why the=
=20
>group happens to be speaking out against Kerry during an election year=20
>thirty years after the war. Even more puzzling is the fact that the=20
>organization is concentrating its ads in key election swing states such as=
=20
>Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida.
>
>The group is technically a so-called '527' committee, or an independent=20
>political organization with no direct ties to any candidate. Kerry=20
>supporters, however, have accused the Bush administration of colluding=20
>with, and even financing, the group.
>
>"These accusations are utterly untrue," Nguyen said in a faxed response to=
=20
>the Kerry campaign's statements. "We are just a group of proud Viet Cong=20
>veterans who do not want our legacy tarnished by one man's self-serving=20
>lies. We want the truth to finally come out about John Kerry."
>
>"Or, as we like to call him, Jittery Johnny," he added.
>
>Nguyen did not explain how the group, which consists mostly of poor,=20
>elderly farmers living in remote Vietnamese villages, could afford the=20
>multimillion-dollar ad campaign, or where they plug in their fax machine.
>
>The Bush campaign denied any connection to the group. "We have absolutely=
=20
>nothing to do with the Sampan Veterans For Truth," said Bush campaign=20
>manager Ken Mehlman. "They are just a group of Americans =AD excuse me,=20
>Vietnamese =AD exercising their Constitutional right to express themselves.=
=20
>Apparently, in spite of the fact that they fought against us in the=20
>Vietnam War, they believe deeply in freedom =AD unlike /some/ people I=
 could=20
>mention."

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) More "real issues" -- millions of Americans in jail in bi-partisan "war on drugs"

	Look Gavin, I agree that when you hear somebody crying racism, =
the=20
accusation is misplaced more often than not. But it's a known fact that=20=

black cocaine users tend to favor the rock form of the drug (crack),=20
while whites are more likely to use the powder form. That's not a=20
slight against blacks -- personally I think coke is pretty much bad=20
news in either form -- just reporting the reality. Did you even read=20
the article? Looking at the results of the laws in question, it's=20
pretty obvious that blacks are getting the shaft. Is powder cocaine 100=20=

times worse than crack? Obviously not. So what possible motive is there=20=

for passing a law with that kind of disparity unless the goal is to put=20=

a lot of black people in jail (or go after drugs while keeping whites=20
out of jail)? I think they're just trying to carry out the Nixon=20
philosophy.*

	Not to mention that the "war on drugs" has been notoriously =
racist=20
from the beginning -- way before Harry Anslinger's scheme to raise=20
public fears about Mexicans by using the term "marijuana,"=20
establishment politicians were scaring people with tales of white women=20=

being seduced by Chinese men in San Francisco opium dens. For more=20
interesting drug war history, check out=20
http://www.adrugwarcarol.com/index.html ...

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

the fact that the whole problem is really the blacks. The key is to=20
devise a system that recognizes this while not appearing to."

>>>
>>>> From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
>>>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>> Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) More "real issues" -- millions of=20
>>>> Americans in jail in bi-partisan "war on drugs"
>>>> Date: Mon, 23 Aug 2004 16:35:14 -0700
>>>>
>>>> 	If you support "asset forfeiture" where the police can seize the=20=

>>>> property of people not even charged with any crime, let alone=20
>>>> convicted, are glad to see nearly 6 million Americans in jail or on=20=

>>>> probation or parole, and think the racial disparity in sentencing=20=

>>>> and "mandatory minimum" laws are a good thing, then by all means=20
>>>> vote for Kerry or Bush this November... Kerry even voted for the=20
>>>> racist law requiring crack cocaine users to be sentenced 100 times=20=

>>>> more harshly than powder cocaine users! (see details below)
>>>>
>>>> 	You can also read this article online at=20
>>>> http://www.counterpunch.org/cockburn08212004.html ...
>>>>
>>>> 				<<< Starchild >>>
>>>>
>>>> "A Libertarian president would order federal officials to cease and=20=

>>>> desist in harassing medical marijuana patients and would block=20
>>>> federal spending on the War on Drugs. Nonviolent drug offenders=20
>>>> would be released from federal prison, and each state would choose=20=

>>>> its own drug policy, just as each chose its own alcohol policy when=20=

>>>> alcohol Prohibition was repealed. Libertarians would hope and=20
>>>> expect most states to come around and severely reform their=20
>>>> policies to make them more humane and less at odds with the=20
>>>> Constitution and the American way of life."
>>>>
>>>> 	-Michael Badnarik, 2004 Libertarian candidate for president (=20
>>>> http://www.badnarik.org )
>>>>
>>>> COUNTERPUNCH
>>>> Weekend Edition
>>>> August 21 / 22, 2004
>>>>
>>>> "They Want Blood"
>>>> The Bi-Partisan Origins of the Total War on Drugs
>>>>
>>>> By ALEXANDER COCKBURN
>>>> and JEFFREY ST. CLAIR
>>>>
>>>> Kerry or Bush? How about the 5.9 million people here in the United=20=

>>>> States, under "the supervision" of the Justice system, either in=20
>>>> prison, in jail, of probation or parole. Will it make a difference=20=

>>>> to these         people--two million of them behind bars--which of=20=

>>>> the two sits in the Oval Office? No. Both Kerry, who misses no=20
>>>> chance of emphasizing how he was once a "prosecutor", and Bush,=20
>>>> pledge more cops, tougher penalties, and above all no let up in the=20=

>>>> War on Drugs which has thrown  millions into the American Gulag,=20
>>>> for ten, fifteen, 20-year sentences based on mandatory minimums and=20=

>>>> "enhancements" which a federal appeals court has now declared to=20
>>>> have flouted the Constitutional right to a fair trial before a jury=20=

>>>> of one's peers. Ever since the mid-1980s the War on Drugs has been=20=

>>>> a bipartisan affair. Come with us on a journey         back to the=20=

>>>> time when Tip O'Neill, liberal Democrat from Massachusetts, and=20
>>>> Ronald Reagan, colluded in a terrible new chapter of a war aimed at=20=

>>>> the poor, particularly ethnic minorities, and waged ever since the=20=

>>>> late nineteenth century and the attacks on  the Chinese laborers of=20=

>>>> California.  This is an excerpt from Dime's Worth of Difference:=20
>>>> Beyond the Lesser of Two Evils .
>>>>
>>>> In 1930 a new department of the federal government, the Bureau of=20=

>>>> Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, was       created under the=20
>>>> leadership of Harry Anslinger to carry out the war against drug=20
>>>> users. Anslinger, an avowed racist, was an adroit publicist and=20
>>>> became the prime shaper of American attitudes about drug addiction,=20=

>>>> hammering home his view that this was not a treatable addiction but=20=

>>>> a deviant urge that could only be suppressed by harsh criminal=20
>>>> sanctions.
>>>>
>>>> Anslinger's first major campaign was to criminalize the drug=20
>>>> commonly known at the time as hemp. But Anslinger renamed it=20
>>>> "marijuana" to associate it with Mexican laborers who, like the=20
>>>> Chinese before them, were unwelcome competitors for scarce jobs in=20=

>>>> the Depression. Anslinger claimed that marijuana "can arouse in=20
>>>> blacks and Hispanics a state of menacing fury or homicidal attack.=20=

>>>> During this period, addicts have perpetrated some of the most=20
>>>> bizarre and fantastic offenses and sex crimes know to police=20
>>>> annals."
>>>>
>>>> Anslinger linked marijuana with jazz and persecuted many black=20
>>>> musicians, including Thelonious Monk, Dizzy Gillespie and Duke=20
>>>> Ellington. Louis Armstrong was also arrested on drug charges, and=20=

>>>> Anslinger made sure his name was smeared in the press. In Congress,=20=

>>>> the drug czar testified that "coloreds with big lips lure white=20
>>>> women with jazz and marijuana".
>>>>
>>>> By the 1950s, amid the full blast of the Cold War, Anslinger was=20
>>>> working with the CIA to charge that the new-born People's Republic=20=

>>>> of China was attempting to undermine America by selling opium to US=20=

>>>> crime syndicates. (This took a great deal of chutzpah on the part=20=

>>>> of the CIA, whose planes were then flying opium from Chiang=20
>>>> Kai-Shek's bases in Burma to Thailand and the Philippines for=20
>>>> processing and export to the US.) Anslinger convinced the US Senate=20=

>>>> to approve a resolution stating that "subversion through drug=20
>>>> addiction is an established aim of Communist China".
>>>>
>>>> In 1951, Anslinger teamed with Democrat Hale Boggs to marshal=20
>>>> through Congress the first minimum mandatory sentences for drug=20
>>>> possession: two years for the first conviction for possession of a=20=

>>>> Schedule 1 drug (marijuana, cocaine), five to ten years for a=20
>>>> second offense, and ten to twenty for a third conviction. In 1956=20=

>>>> Anslinger once again enlisted the aid of Boggs to pass a law=20
>>>> calling for the death penalty to be imposed on anyone selling=20
>>>> heroin to a minor, the first linking of drugs with Death Row.
>>>>
>>>> This was Anslinger's last hurrah. Along with John Kennedy's New=20
>>>> Frontier cantered sociologists attacking Anslinger's punitive=20
>>>> philosophy. The tempo of the times changed, and federal money began=20=

>>>> to target treatment and prevention as much as enforcement and=20
>>>> prison. But the interim didn't last long. With the waning of the=20
>>>> war in Southeast Asia millions of addicted GIs came home to be=20
>>>> ambushed by Richard Nixon's War on Drugs program. Nixon resurrected=20=

>>>> Anslinger's techniques of threat inflation, declaring in Los=20
>>>> Angeles that "as I look over the problems of this country I see=20
>>>> that one stands out particularly: the problems of narcotics."
>>>>
>>>> Nixon pledged to launch a war on drugs, to return to the punitive=20=

>>>> approach and not let any quaint notions of civil liberties and=20
>>>> constitutional rights stand in the way. After a Nixon briefing in=20=

>>>> 1969, his top aide, H.R.       Haldeman noted in his diary: "Nixon=20=

>>>> emphasized that you have to face the fact that the whole problem is=20=

>>>> really the blacks. The key is to devise a system that recognizes=20
>>>> this while not appearing to." And the Democratic congress played=20
>>>> along.
>>>>
>>>> But for all of his bluster, Nixon was a mere prelude to the full=20
>>>> fury of the Reagan-Bush-Clinton years, when the War on Drugs became=20=

>>>> explicitly a war on blacks. The first move of the Reagan=20
>>>> administration was to expand the drug forfeiture laws, first passed=20=

>>>> in the Carter administration. In 1981 Reagan's drug policy advisors=20=

>>>> outlined a plan they thought would be little more than a good PR=20
>>>> sound bite, a public display of the required toughness. They=20
>>>> proposed allowing the Justice Department to seize real property and=20=

>>>> so-called "substitute property"--that is, legally acquired assets=20=

>>>> equal in value to illegal monetary gains. They also proposed that=20=

>>>> the federal government be permitted to seize attorney's fees that=20=

>>>> they suspected might have been paid for through drug proceeds. The=20=

>>>> Reagan plan was to permit forfeitures on the basis of a "probable=20=

>>>> cause showing" before a federal judge. This meant that seizures=20
>>>> could be made against people neither charged nor convicted, but=20
>>>> only suspected, of drug offenses.
>>>>
>>>> Contrary to the administration's expectations, this plan sailed=20
>>>> through Congress, eagerly supported by two Democratic Party=20
>>>> liberals, Senators Hubert Humphrey and Joe Biden, the latter being=20=

>>>> the artificer in the Carter era of a revision of the RICO statutes,=20=

>>>> a huge extension of the federal conspiracy laws. Over the next few=20=

>>>> years the press would occasionally report on some exceptionally=20
>>>> bizarre application of the new forfeiture provisions, such as the=20=

>>>> confiscation of a $25 million yacht in a drug bust that netted only=20=

>>>> a handful of marijuana stems and seeds. But typically, the press=20
>>>> ignored the essential pattern of humdrum seizures, which more often=20=

>>>> focused on such ordinary assets as houses and cars. For example, in=20=

>>>> Orange County, California, fifty-seven cars were seized in=20
>>>> drug-related cases in 1989 alone. "Even if only a small amount of=20=

>>>> drugs is found inside," an Orange County narcotics detective=20
>>>> explained, "the law permits seized vehicles to be sold by law=20
>>>> enforcement agencies to finance anti-drug law enforcement >>>> =
programs."
>>>>
>>>> In fact, the forfeiture program became a tremendous revenue stream=20=

>>>> for the police. =46rom 1982 to 1991, the US Department of Justice=20=

>>>> seized more than $2.5 billion in assets. The feds confiscated $500=20=

>>>> million in property in 1991 alone, and 80 percent of these seizures=20=

>>>> came from people who were never charged with a crime.
>>>>
>>>> On June 17, 1986 University of Maryland basketball star Len Bias=20
>>>> died, reportedly from an overdose of cocaine. As Dan Baum put it in=20=

>>>> his excellent book Smoke and Mirrors: the War on Drugs and the=20
>>>> Politics of Failure, "In life, Len Bias was a terrific basketball=20=

>>>> player. In death he became the Archduke Ferdinand of the Total War=20=

>>>> on Drugs." It was falsely reported that Bias had smoked crack=20
>>>> cocaine the night before his death. (He had, in fact, sniffed=20
>>>> powder cocaine and, according to the coroner, there was no clear=20
>>>> link between this usage and the failure of his heart.)
>>>>
>>>> Bias had just signed to play with the Boston Celtics and amid=20
>>>> Boston's rage and grief Speaker of the House Tip O'Neill, a=20
>>>> representative from Massachusetts, rushed into action. In early=20
>>>> July of that year he convened a       special meeting of the=20
>>>> Democratic Party leadership on the Hill: "Write me up some goddamn=20=

>>>> legislation," O'Neill ordered. "All anybody in Boston is talking=20
>>>> about is Len Bias. They want blood. If we move fast enough we can=20=

>>>> get out in front of the White House."
>>>>
>>>> The Reagan White House was moving fast itself. Among other things=20=

>>>> the Drug Enforcement Agency had been instructed to allow ABC News=20=

>>>> to accompany it on raids against crack houses. "Crack is the=20
>>>> hottest combat-reporting story to come along since the end of the=20=

>>>> Vietnam War", the head of the New York office of the DEA exulted.
>>>>
>>>> All this fed the congressional frenzy to write tougher laws. House=20=

>>>> Majority leader Jim Wright, the Texas Democrat, called drug abuse=20=

>>>> "a menace draining away our economy of some $230 billion this year,=20=

>>>> slowly rotting away the fabric of our society and seducing and=20
>>>> killing our young". Not to be outdone, South Carolina Republican=20
>>>> Thomas Arnett proclaimed that "drugs are a threat worse than=20
>>>> nuclear warfare or any       chemical warfare waged on any=20
>>>> battlefield".
>>>>
>>>> So the 1986 Anti-Drug Abuse Act was duly passed. It boasted 29 new=20=

>>>> minimum mandatory sentences. Up until that time in the entire=20
>>>> history of the Republic there had been only 56 minimum mandatory=20
>>>> sentences. The new law enacted a death penalty provision for drug=20=

>>>> "king pins" and prohibited parole for even minor possession=20
>>>> offenses. But the chief target of the bill was crack cocaine.=20
>>>> Congress established a 100-to-1 sentencing ratio between the=20
>>>> possession of crack and powder cocaine. Under this provision,=20
>>>> possession of five grams of crack carries a minimum sentence five=20=

>>>> years in federal prison. The same mandatory minimum is not reached=20=

>>>> for any amount of powder cocaine under 500 grams. John Kerry voted=20=

>>>> for the measure.
>>>>
>>>> The sentencing disparity in the 1986 law was based on faulty=20
>>>> testimony that crack was fifty times as addictive as powder=20
>>>> cocaine. Congress then doubled this ratio as a so-called "violence=20=

>>>> penalty". Yet there is no inherent difference between the drugs, as=20=

>>>> Clinton drug czar Barry McCaffrey was forced to admit. The federal=20=

>>>> Sentencing Commission, established by Congress to review sentencing=20=

>>>> guidelines, found that so-called "crack violence" was largely=20
>>>> attributable to the drug trade itself and has more to do with the=20=

>>>> setting in which crack is sold than the drug itself: crack is sold=20=

>>>> on the street, while powder cocaine is often vended by house calls.
>>>>
>>>> As Nixon and Haldeman would have approvingly noted, Tip O'Neill's=20=

>>>> new drug law was aimed squared at blacks, reminiscent of the early=20=

>>>> targeting of Chinese smoking opium rather than post-bellum ladies=20=

>>>> sipping their laudanum-laced tonics.
>>>>
>>>> In 1995 the US Sentencing Commission reviewed eight years of=20
>>>> application of this provision and found it to be undeniably racist=20=

>>>> in practice: 84 percent of those arrested for crack possession=20
>>>> where black, while only 10 percent were white and 5 percent=20
>>>> Hispanic. The disparity for trafficking arrests was even wider: 88=20=

>>>> percent blacks, 7 percent Hispanics and 4 percent whites. By=20
>>>> comparison, defendants arrested for powder cocaine possession were=20=

>>>> 58 percent white, 26 percent black and 15 percent Hispanic.
>>>>
>>>> In Los Angeles all twenty-four federal defendants in crack cases in=20=

>>>> 1991 were black. The Sentence Commission recommended to Congress=20
>>>> that the ratio should be one-to-one between sentences for offenses=20=

>>>> involving crack and powder cocaine, arguing that federal law allows=20=

>>>> for other factors to be considered by judges in lengthening=20
>>>> sentences (such as whether guns or violence was associated with the=20=

>>>> offense). But for the first time in its history the Congress=20
>>>> rejected the recommendations of the Sentencing Commission and=20
>>>> retained the 100-to-1 ratio. Clinton likewise declined the advise=20=

>>>> of his drug czar and his attorney general and signed the bill.
>>>>
>>>> One need only look at the racial make-up of federal prisons to=20
>>>> appreciate the consequences of the 1986 drug law. In 1983 the total=20=

>>>> number of prisoners in federal, state and local prisons and jails=20=

>>>> was 600,800. Of those, 57,975 (8.8 percent) were incarcerated for=20=

>>>> drug-related offenses. In 1993 the total prison population stood at=20=

>>>> 1.4 million, of whom 353,564-25.1 percent-were inside for drug=20
>>>> offenses. The Sentencing Project, a DC-based watchdog group, found=20=

>>>> that the increase was far from racially balanced. Between 1986 and=20=

>>>> 1991 the incarceration rate for white males convicted on drug=20
>>>> crimes increased by 106 percent. But the number of black males in=20=

>>>> prison for kindred offenses soared by a factor of 429 percent, and=20=

>>>> the rate for black women went up by an incredible 828 percent.
>>>>
>>>> The queen of the drug war, Nancy Reagan, said amid one of her=20
>>>> innumerable sermons on the issue: "If you're a casual drug user,=20
>>>> you're an accomplice to murder." In tune with this line of=20
>>>> thinking, the Democratic-controlled Congress moved in 1988 to=20
>>>> expand the crimes for which the federal death penalty could be=20
>>>> imposed. These included drug-related murders, and murders committed=20=

>>>> by drug gangs, which would allow any gang member to face the death=20=

>>>> penalty if one member of the gang was linked to a drug killing. The=20=

>>>> new penalties were inscribed in an update of the Continuing=20
>>>> Criminal Enterprises Act.
>>>>
>>>> Convictions under the new law between 1989 and 1996 were 70 percent=20=

>>>> white and 24 percent black. But 90 percent of the times the federal=20=

>>>> prosecutors sought the death penalty it was against non-whites: of=20=

>>>> these, 78 percent were black and the rest Hispanic. =46rom 1930 to=20=

>>>> 1972 (when the Supreme Court found the death penalty=20
>>>> unconstitutional), 85 percent of those given death sentences were=20=

>>>> white. When the federal death       penalty was reapplied in 1984,=20=

>>>> with the Anti-Drug Abuse Act, the numbers for black death penalty=20=

>>>> convictions soared. Of those on Death Row, both federal and state,=20=

>>>> 50 percent are black, although blacks constitute only 16 percent of=20=

>>>> the US population.
>>>>
>>>> Alexander Cockburn and Jeffrey St. Clair's new book on the 2004=20
>>>> elections, Dime's Worth of Difference: Beyond the Lesser of Two=20
>>>> Evils , is just out from AK Press/CounterPunch Books.
>>>>
>>>

>>> FREE! >>> =
http://messenger.msn.click-url.com/go/onm00200471ave/direct/01/

On Monday, August 23, 2004, at 08:57  PM, Doug Fraser wrote:

> oh, these guys have definitely convinced me now
>
>
>> http://www.confusionroad.com/article.php?article_id=3D259
>> Viet Cong Veterans Denounce Kerry
>> */'Sampan Veterans For Truth' Call Kerry Unfit For Command/*
>>
>> U.S. - A group of Viet Cong veterans has launched a series of=20
>> television ads denouncing Democratic Presidential nominee John Kerry=20=

>> as being a 'liar' and an 'incompetent soldier' whose war record=20
>> demonstrates his unfitness for the Presidency.
>>
>> The group calls itself 'Sampan Veterans For Truth,' after the small=20=

>> canoe-like boats, or sampans, they operated in the Mekong Delta while=20=

>> fighting against the U.S. during the Vietnam war. The advertisements=20=

>> blast Kerry for allegedly misleading the Navy and the American people=20=

>> about the battle in which he earned his Silver Star for heroism under=20=

>> fire.
>>
>> "John Kerry claimed that he was taking machine gun and mortar fire=20
>> during the battle," says Viet Cong soldier Nguyen Dinh Vay in one=20
>> commercial. "I know this is not true, because I was one of the men=20
>> attacking him. My fellow soldiers and I were armed only with spears=20=

>> and harsh language. And we almost won."
>>
>> Nguyen goes on to say that Kerry's powerful swift boat did not face=20=

>> 'hundreds' of Viet Cong, as the candidate claims, but "a few ragtag=20=

>> soldiers in sampans."
>>
>> "John Kerry, a war hero?" Nguyen asks rhetorically. "That's an insult=20=

>> to all of us who fought against him. If he was a hero, we'd have=20
>> tried harder to kill him."
>>
>> The commercial then ridicules Kerry for his lack of skill in combat,=20=

>> insinuating that he was not worthy of being a Navy lieutenant, let=20
>> alone President of the United States. "Among the Viet Cong, he was=20
>> known as 'Jittery Johnny' for his erratic behavior and inaccurate=20
>> fire," says another Viet Cong veteran in the ad, Tran Binh Huong.=20
>> "The sight of his swift boat was a sure sign that you were safe,=20
>> because you knew that the American forces on board would be=20
>> disorganized and impotent in battle. When we left the tunnels to go=20=

>> on hit-and-run missions, we used to kid each other by saying, 'be=20
>> careful, or Jittery Johnny will get you!' Man, that one always killed=20=

>> me."
>>
>> "Who do you want leading your country in time of war," the ad=20
>> concludes, "a proven wartime President =AD or Jittery Johnny?"
>>
>> Since the Sampan Veterans For Truth are all Vietnamese citizens who=20=

>> have never been to the United States, many observers are confused=20
>> about why the group happens to be speaking out against Kerry during=20=

>> an election year thirty years after the war. Even more puzzling is=20
>> the fact that the organization is concentrating its ads in key=20
>> election swing states such as Ohio, Pennsylvania and Florida.
>>
>> The group is technically a so-called '527' committee, or an=20
>> independent political organization with no direct ties to any=20
>> candidate. Kerry supporters, however, have accused the Bush=20
>> administration of colluding with, and even financing, the group.
>>
>> "These accusations are utterly untrue," Nguyen said in a faxed=20
>> response to the Kerry campaign's statements. "We are just a group of=20=

>> proud Viet Cong veterans who do not want our legacy tarnished by one=20=

>> man's self-serving lies. We want the truth to finally come out about=20=

>> John Kerry."
>>
>> "Or, as we like to call him, Jittery Johnny," he added.
>>
>> Nguyen did not explain how the group, which consists mostly of poor,=20=

>> elderly farmers living in remote Vietnamese villages, could afford=20
>> the multimillion-dollar ad campaign, or where they plug in their fax=20=

>> machine.
>>
>> The Bush campaign denied any connection to the group. "We have=20
>> absolutely nothing to do with the Sampan Veterans For Truth," said=20
>> Bush campaign manager Ken Mehlman. "They are just a group of=20
>> Americans =AD excuse me, Vietnamese =AD exercising their =
Constitutional=20
>> right to express themselves. Apparently, in spite of the fact that=20
>> they fought against us in the Vietnam War, they believe deeply in=20
>> freedom =AD unlike /some/ people I could mention."

Message-ID: <20040824171631.GN5142@atari.saturn5.com>
References: <5.1.0.14.0.20040823205644.029f4ec0@mail.microcinema.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <5.1.0.14.0.20040823205644.029f4ec0@mail.microcinema.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] more about Kerry's "heroism"


And More...

</troy>

-------------

KERRY DENIES PERFORMING GAY WEDDINGS ON SWIFT BOAT

One Million Anti-Kerry Boatmates March on Washington

Democratic nominee John Kerry today blasted a just-released attack ad in which a
new group of swift boat veterans accuse him of performing hundreds of gay
weddings on the boat he commanded during that conflict.

The ad, financed by a group calling itself Swift Boat Veterans For Truth About
Gay Weddings On Swift Boats, accuses Sen. Kerry of using his status as
commanding officer on his boat to perform gay weddings on an almost non-stop
basis.

According to one veteran who appears in the ad, Mr. Kerry stunned his boatmates
by announcing, 'I hereby declare this swift boat "The Love Boat."'

The veteran goes on to accuse Mr. Kerry of performing hundreds of gay weddings
'whether the sailors wanted to marry each other or not.'

The latest charges come at a critical juncture for the Kerry campaign, as over
one million anti-Kerry boatmates marched on Washington this weekend to express
their unbridled hatred of the Democratic nominee.

But Sen. Kerry came out swinging against the ads today, telling a Michigan
audience, 'It would have been impossible for me to declare my swift boat
"The Love Boat" because "The Love Boat" did not come on TV until 1977.'

Moments after Mr. Kerry's comment, the airwaves were blanketed with a new ad
financed by a group calling themselves Swift Boat Veterans For Truth About What
John Kerry Claims Did Or Did Not Happen On His Swift Boat.

In the ad, a veteran states: 'Okay, so maybe John Kerry didn't perform any
gay weddings, but it's a lot like something he would have done if given half
a chance.'




 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
tsheets@saturn5.com                                  <- You have found me   
http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/audio                 <- my .mp3 tracks
"I just don't have the discipline to be a hippie"    <- Homer J. Simpson

From: nwa <nwa420@gmail.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Spirit of Raving Archives: Q2-2004: What most drew you to the underground scene?

this has nothing to do with this question, but i just wanted to
mention that while waiting for the Kerry interview on The Daily Show, 
http://tinyurl.com/52bsa , i was watching Quentin Tarantino's
'Reservoir Dogs' and there was an exterior shot of the jewelry store
the gang was knocking off, and get this, it's called:

'Karina's Jewelry Wholesalers'

as far as the the 'scene' goes, i'll post on it later.

or not.

'where's the party, Officer?'

briefly, my first inkling that something was up came in the late
1980's through Mick Jone's followup crew to The Clash, Big Audio
Dynamite, (when i heard them sing, 'it's 1am let's go out to a Rave,'
that spoke *volumes* to me, since the paradigm @ the time was that the
party/bar/whatever was ending, not starting at that hour), but i was
in the marine corps @ the time and stationed in Barstow, so there
wasn't a whole fuck of a lot that i could do about it at the time, and
then i compounded the error by dropping out culturally until close to
the end of the decade.

My first underground, not counting the 3 years I was involved with
Studio 10 in NYC @ 10 Bleecker Street from 1979 to 1982, was the
Friday the 13th party in Sunnyvale held by the Enchanted Broccolli
Forest crew from Stanford in Sunnyvale at an old warehouse.

What grabbed my attention that night was the 'chill room.' but not for
the reason most people think.

As you all know, when you go to a club, no such place exists where you
can escape the driving thumpa thumpa thumpa noise and heat and do
nothing but be, and not only hear yourself think but actually interact
with other people.

That's the real threat to our leadership, the last thing they want is
for the populace to freely assemble and trade notes.

Plus, it drives down the sales of alcohol, and we can't have that.

Better to give them the illusion of freedom of assembly' via the drug
of Monday Night Football.

They may say it's the 'drugs' that they are trying to protect people
against, and that's why they passed The Rave Act, but that's a
damnable lie, they just don't want us to mingle, because if we do
that, then well, we might start to get a sense that not only are there
a *lot* of us that thiink and feel alike about certain things, but if
we keep going down this path, we might actually want to DO something
about it.

Like find someone to represent our interests.

If I was a current Congressman or Senator, that would scare the
bullshite right out of me, and I would go out of my way to 'divide and
conquer' this threat, which so far, they've done a great job of doing,
sadly.

then again, time is very much on our side, and ultimately we will
prevail, but it's going to take a long, long, long time.....

nwa

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Viet Cong Veterans Denounce Kerry 

--=====================_5519767==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Viet Cong Veterans Denounce Kerry

'Sampan Veterans For Truth' Call Kerry Unfit For Command

U.S. - A group of Viet Cong veterans has launched a series of television 
ads denouncing Democratic Presidential nominee John Kerry as being a 'liar' 
and an 'incompetent soldier' whose war record demonstrates his unfitness 
for the Presidency.

The group calls itself 'Sampan Veterans For Truth,' after the small 
canoe-like boats, or sampans, they operated in the Mekong Delta while 
fighting against the U.S. during the Vietnam war. The advertisements blast 
Kerry for allegedly misleading the Navy and the American people about the 
battle in which he earned his Silver Star for heroism under fire.

More:  http://www.confusionroad.com/article.php?article_id=259





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

Subject: [sfraves] bsp - Rare chance to see David Duriez sat. 8.28

International Superstar DJ/Producer David Duriez will be making his first
appearance to San Francisco in many years at the intimate Luna Lounge.

David Duriez transcends the boundaries of the industry, going a step
beyond the banal and delivering the real deal. He is an underground house
commando with a prowess for striking deep inside enemy lines: He has been
djing since the age of 13 and has been releasing music for the past 10
years.

Duriezs extensive and sought-after discography includes releases on
prestigious labels such as 2020Vision, Gourmet recordings, Ovum, Jinxx,
Stickman, Under The Counter, Robsoul Recordings, NRK, Afterhours,
Tronicsole, Pokerflat to name but a few, remixes (End Recordings, Serial,
F com, Defected etc) mix cd's (Club house / Bmg - Rocks Da House / Ucmg -
Doitas Brique Rouge / Magix,).

We're offering a limited number of VIP passes for this party. Sign up for
an opportunity to win. You'll be notified by Friday, August 27th.


http://www.sf-vibe.com/moov/index.html

Jonas

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection

--=====================_1779508==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Interesting...

Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection
The tech guru sees a "new economic system" in the unconscious cooperation 
embodied by Google links and Amazon lists

Updated: 8:00 p.m. ET Aug. 11, 2004

Howard Rheingold is on the hunt again. With his last book, Smart Mobs: The 
Next Social Revolution, in 2001, the longtime observer of technology trends 
made a persuasive case that pervasive mobile communications, combined with 
always-on Internet connections, will produce new kinds of ad-hoc social 
groups. Now, he's starting to take the leap beyond smart mobs, trying to 
weave some threads out of such seemingly disparate developments as Web 
logs, open-source software development, and Google.

More:  http://msnbc.msn.com/id/5671750/




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but instruments."
- Napoleon Bonaparte

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"



--=====================_1779508==.ALT--




From sfraves-return-115032-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Aug 26 20:08:03 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-115032-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 70507 invoked by uid 1103); 26 Aug 2004 20:08:02 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 70489 invoked from network); 26 Aug 2004 20:08:02 -0000
Message-ID: <20040826200756.12052.qmail@web21524.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 26 Aug 2004 13:07:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: Peter Rothman <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <6.1.2.0.2.20040826113707.02777ca0@localhost>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] ARR: Smart Raving Mobs (was NRR:  Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection)

Glad to see this book mentioned here as Howard is an
old friend of mine from the virtual reality days and
is an always insightful commentator on technology,
society, psychedelics, religion, and other stuff
generally.  

To bring this around to raves, mobile technology
offers a new paradigm for organizing parties and
rapidly bringing together communities of like minded
souls "on the fly."  We've all heard about flash mobs,
but why not use the same ideas to gather a few
dedicated dancers and heads at that perfect venue?  

I'm wondering if some people are already organizing
parties this way.  Instead of the hand-to-hand
marketing technique of lfiers pioneered by ravers and
party promoters, it might become phone-to-phone
marketing, although I think fliers are still far from
dead.  I'd be interested in working on any effort to
explore some of these ideas if anyone out there wants
to try it.

Peace,

Peter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ARR: Smart Raving Mobs (was NRR:  Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection)

If you include 3D environments viewed on a screen
(i.e. most video games) the creation of these worlds
is now a bigger industry than the film industry.  That
doesn't include the high end industrial and scientific
applications which have continued to be developed for
the past ten years.  

But I digress...

Peter

> To bring this around to raves, mobile technology
> offers a new paradigm for organizing parties and
> rapidly bringing together communities of like minded
> souls "on the fly."  We've all heard about flash mobs,
> but why not use the same ideas to gather a few
> dedicated dancers and heads at that perfect venue?  
> 
> I'm wondering if some people are already organizing
> parties this way.  Instead of the hand-to-hand
> marketing technique of lfiers pioneered by ravers and
> party promoters, it might become phone-to-phone
> marketing, although I think fliers are still far from
> dead.  I'd be interested in working on any effort to
> explore some of these ideas if anyone out there wants
> to try it.

best one was the outdoor renegade that was thought up at 10am
and had DDR as the headliner that night.  props to ryan for
getting that shit together.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ARR: Smart Raving Mobs (was NRR:  Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection)

Just because virtual reality didn't take off in the consumer market
doesn't mean that it hasn't changed our very existence :)  Virtual
Reality is huge.  From Flight training simulations that have probably
saved on actual flying time cutting back on greenhouse gas emmissions as
well as saving lives by running pilots through just about every
emergency they could run into, simulations for nuclear testing in both
military and non-military uses,  aerodynamic design testing, medical and
surgical procedure testing, search and rescue simulations, and of course
military and police training.  I'm not saying all applications of it are
good but it has changed many professions very existence and helped
simulate things that couldn't be tested before without enormous costs
and efforts.  Although I do really miss the video game side of it.

And if you weren't being sarcastic I apologize :)

-Rayn

On Thu, Aug 26, 2004 at 01:07:56PM -0700, Peter Rothman wrote:
> Glad to see this book mentioned here as Howard is an
> old friend of mine from the virtual reality days and
> is an always insightful commentator on technology,
> society, psychedelics, religion, and other stuff
> generally.
> 
> To bring this around to raves, mobile technology
> offers a new paradigm for organizing parties and
> rapidly bringing together communities of like minded
> souls "on the fly."  We've all heard about flash mobs,
> but why not use the same ideas to gather a few
> dedicated dancers and heads at that perfect venue?
> 
> I'm wondering if some people are already organizing
> parties this way.  Instead of the hand-to-hand
> marketing technique of lfiers pioneered by ravers and
> party promoters, it might become phone-to-phone
> marketing, although I think fliers are still far from
> dead.  I'd be interested in working on any effort to
> explore some of these ideas if anyone out there wants
> to try it.
> 
> Peace,
> 
> Peter

> > Howard Rheingold's Latest Connection
> > The tech guru sees a "new economic system" in the
> > unconscious cooperation
> > embodied by Google links and Amazon lists
> >
> > Updated: 8:00 p.m. ET Aug. 11, 2004
> >
> > Howard Rheingold is on the hunt again. With his last
> > book, Smart Mobs: The
> > Next Social Revolution, in 2001, the longtime
> > observer of technology trends
> > made a persuasive case that pervasive mobile
> > communications, combined with
> > always-on Internet connections, will produce new
> > kinds of ad-hoc social
> > groups. Now, he's starting to take the leap beyond
> > smart mobs, trying to
> > weave some threads out of such seemingly disparate
> > developments as Web
> > logs, open-source software development, and Google.
> >
> > More:  http://msnbc.msn.com/id/5671750/
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
> >
> > House Music 101:
> >
>http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
> >
> > "You are not thinking.  You are merely being
> > logical."
> > Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein
> >
> > "The government, which was designed for the people,
> > has got into the hands
> > of the bosses and their employers, the special
> > interests.  An invisible
> > empire has been set up above the forms of
> > democracy."
> > -Woodrow Wilson
> >
> > "In the eyes of empire builders, men are not men but
> > instruments."
> > - Napoleon Bonaparte
> >
> > "Music is prophecy, its style and economic
> > organization are ahead of the
> > rest of society. It makes audible the new world that
> > will gradually become
> > visible."
> > -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
> >
> >

At 04:07 PM 8/26/2004, Rayn McCormick wrote:

>Just because virtual reality didn't take off in the consumer market
>doesn't mean that it hasn't changed our very existence :)  Virtual
>Reality is huge.  From Flight training simulations that have probably
>saved on actual flying time cutting back on greenhouse gas emmissions as
>well as saving lives by running pilots through just about every
>emergency they could run into, simulations for nuclear testing in both
>military and non-military uses,  aerodynamic design testing, medical and
>surgical procedure testing, search and rescue simulations, and of course
>military and police training.  I'm not saying all applications of it are
>good but it has changed many professions very existence and helped
>simulate things that couldn't be tested before without enormous costs
>and efforts.  Although I do really miss the video game side of it.
>
>And if you weren't being sarcastic I apologize :)
>
>-Rayn

> > rapidly bringing together communities of like minded
> > souls "on the fly."  We've all heard about flash mobs,

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] techno @ LoveParadeSF

Thread-Index: AcSLxmKcKWLJlGVcRgaNHDaXI9tOpAABkOVw
From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "n n s" <nico@viberation.com>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] techno @ LoveParadeSF

Perhaps I should put a BSP in front of this but....

Tom Wax will be the headliner for the MFS float.  For those of you
unfamiliar with Tom, he was A&R at Harthouse.  He single handedly
invented the Frankfurt Techno scene.  If you are into German techno...
then you definitely don't wanna miss him.  He's probably got the longest
and most respectable discography in all of techno music.  DJs out there
might be familiar with names like AWeX, Arpeggiators, Microbots, DJ Tom
+ Norman.

He is hands down the best DJ I've ever seen, speaking in terms of
technique and programming.  But his true gift to us all has been the
nearly 20 years he has spent delivering the best techno possible.  In
addition to choosing the music that was released on Harthouse, he also
A&Rd for a number of other labels like Influence (the hard-techno label
of Talla's Technoclub outfit), Logic, Tetsuo, and his own label Phuture
Wax has become one of the most respected underground labels ever.  Even
tho he is oldskool compared to most of us (He became resident DJ at
technoclub in Frankfurt in '87) he's somehow managed to stay on the
cutting edge since day one. =20

Yeah I definitely should have put a BSP on this email =3D)

At any rate, in addition to the wet&hard DJs like Corvin Dalek, we will
also be featuring Eiven Major on our float.  For those of you unfamiliar
with Eiven's work...  he is well known for being the most "technoid" of
all of us wet&hard peoples.  If yer into Schranz and that sort of
sound...  you definitely don't wanna miss Eiven Major.  Its still
wet&hard... but I promise that you Schranz fans won't be disappointed.
Just take 1 part Chris Liebing and 3 parts sex and you've got Eiven
Major.  Definitely my personal favorite when it comes to wet&hard... if
you like techno... you don't wanna miss him. =20

And since wet&hard is based on techno... it wouldn't be a stretch to say
our whole float is techno.... =20

Its gonna be nice to have this much techno.  California (unfortunately)
isn't exactly the techno capital of the world.  Its gonna be nice to see
this many techno people playing at the same place.  I don't think I've
seen that too often on this side of the 'pond'....

The future is wet&hard...
XXX,
p a t

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ARR: Smart Raving Mobs (was NRR:  Howard  Rheingold's Latest Connection)

Data compression is also a huge thing which is why holographic data
mediums will finally make it affordable for the consumer market (after a
few gen's of course).  Like this thing:
http://www.optware.co.jp/english/what_040823.htm  I think things like a
holodeck are very far off, at least in terms of being able to physically
touch things, but food replicators are being worked on right now by
nasa.  Data jacks are just around the corner scarily.  The initial uses
aren't going to be of the submersion type of course, but more on the
side of helping paralyzed people control a robotic arm like it was a
real arm.  Other uses for this I see being possible of course are
military who has the budget to push technologies like this to the max
with flying aircraft either remotely or without a joystick in the
cockpit for quicker manouverability as well as other types of vehicles
and maybe 'mechs' which are getting closer and closer from their sci-fi
counterparts to science fact.  The science so far has shown that these
implants in monkeys are able to control a robotic arm like it was their
own as opposed to it just being an extension of their body.
http://www.newscientist.com/news/news.jsp?id=ns99996127

-Rayn

From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
To: "n n s" <nico@viberation.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: RE: [sfraves] techno @ LoveParadeSF
Date: Thu, 26 Aug 2004 17:43:20 -0700

Perhaps I should put a BSP in front of this but....

Tom Wax will be the headliner for the MFS float.  For those of you
unfamiliar with Tom, he was A&R at Harthouse.  He single handedly
invented the Frankfurt Techno scene.  If you are into German techno...
then you definitely don't wanna miss him.  He's probably got the longest
and most respectable discography in all of techno music.  DJs out there
might be familiar with names like AWeX, Arpeggiators, Microbots, DJ Tom
+ Norman.

He is hands down the best DJ I've ever seen, speaking in terms of
technique and programming.  But his true gift to us all has been the
nearly 20 years he has spent delivering the best techno possible.  In
addition to choosing the music that was released on Harthouse, he also
A&Rd for a number of other labels like Influence (the hard-techno label
of Talla's Technoclub outfit), Logic, Tetsuo, and his own label Phuture
Wax has become one of the most respected underground labels ever.  Even
tho he is oldskool compared to most of us (He became resident DJ at
technoclub in Frankfurt in '87) he's somehow managed to stay on the
cutting edge since day one.

Yeah I definitely should have put a BSP on this email =)

At any rate, in addition to the wet&hard DJs like Corvin Dalek, we will
also be featuring Eiven Major on our float.  For those of you unfamiliar
with Eiven's work...  he is well known for being the most "technoid" of
all of us wet&hard peoples.  If yer into Schranz and that sort of
sound...  you definitely don't wanna miss Eiven Major.  Its still
wet&hard... but I promise that you Schranz fans won't be disappointed.
Just take 1 part Chris Liebing and 3 parts sex and you've got Eiven
Major.  Definitely my personal favorite when it comes to wet&hard... if
you like techno... you don't wanna miss him.

And since wet&hard is based on techno... it wouldn't be a stretch to say
our whole float is techno....

Its gonna be nice to have this much techno.  California (unfortunately)
isn't exactly the techno capital of the world.  Its gonna be nice to see
this many techno people playing at the same place.  I don't think I've
seen that too often on this side of the 'pond'....

The future is wet&hard...
XXX,
p a t

>At 04:07 PM 8/26/2004, Rayn McCormick wrote:

>>Just because virtual reality didn't take off in the consumer market
>>doesn't mean that it hasn't changed our very existence :)  Virtual
>>Reality is huge.  From Flight training simulations that have probably
>>saved on actual flying time cutting back on greenhouse gas emmissions as
>>well as saving lives by running pilots through just about every
>>emergency they could run into, simulations for nuclear testing in both
>>military and non-military uses,  aerodynamic design testing, medical and
>>surgical procedure testing, search and rescue simulations, and of course
>>military and police training.  I'm not saying all applications of it are
>>good but it has changed many professions very existence and helped
>>simulate things that couldn't be tested before without enormous costs
>>and efforts.  Although I do really miss the video game side of it.

> > > dead.  I'd be interested in working on any effort

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seen the RubySkye Lineup Lately?

I saw Dimitri last year @ Ruby Skye, he was really awesome! Half way 
through his set I tired out on the dancefloor & went up the upstairs 
just after last call to find that the entire level was emptied out, so I 
got to listen to him finish his set with the mezzanine pretty much to 
myself, which felt very grandiose.

[Of course, this same night was when I came to the realization that 
people who come to big venues with a big name just to drink need some 
serious sense beaten into them.]

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Seen the RubySkye Lineup Lately?

I never notice many other people when the music is good.. the place can be 
so tightly packed that I have barely enough room to dance.. and I will 
always only notice the people around me and the DJ.  I think I learned to 
block out the swillers, in general.  I mean when it comes down to you and 
the music, who can really get between you and it?  One time I was there when 
Behrouz was spinning and I was on this comfy bed / stage thing with pillows 
right in front of the dj.. crowded house.. staring into this girls eyes at 
2am.. and the next time I looked up.. the room was empty and he was spinning 
for the two of us at 5am :)   Funny how that can happen.. that was luxury.. 
a bed, a girl, a dj, and all of RubySkye just to yourself :) Grandiose 
indeed - I wanna do it again.. lol.



SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

>From: "DJ Pat" <djpat@dj-pat.com>
>To: "n n s" <nico@viberation.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] techno @ LoveParadeSF
>Date: Thu, 26 Aug 2004 17:43:20 -0700
>
>Perhaps I should put a BSP in front of this but....
>
>Tom Wax will be the headliner for the MFS float.  For those of you
>unfamiliar with Tom, he was A&R at Harthouse.  He single handedly
>invented the Frankfurt Techno scene.  If you are into German techno...
>then you definitely don't wanna miss him.  He's probably got the longest
>and most respectable discography in all of techno music.  DJs out there
>might be familiar with names like AWeX, Arpeggiators, Microbots, DJ Tom
>+ Norman.
>
>He is hands down the best DJ I've ever seen, speaking in terms of
>technique and programming.  But his true gift to us all has been the
>nearly 20 years he has spent delivering the best techno possible.  In
>addition to choosing the music that was released on Harthouse, he also
>A&Rd for a number of other labels like Influence (the hard-techno label
>of Talla's Technoclub outfit), Logic, Tetsuo, and his own label Phuture
>Wax has become one of the most respected underground labels ever.  Even
>tho he is oldskool compared to most of us (He became resident DJ at
>technoclub in Frankfurt in '87) he's somehow managed to stay on the
>cutting edge since day one.
>
>Yeah I definitely should have put a BSP on this email =)
>
>At any rate, in addition to the wet&hard DJs like Corvin Dalek, we will
>also be featuring Eiven Major on our float.  For those of you unfamiliar
>with Eiven's work...  he is well known for being the most "technoid" of
>all of us wet&hard peoples.  If yer into Schranz and that sort of
>sound...  you definitely don't wanna miss Eiven Major.  Its still
>wet&hard... but I promise that you Schranz fans won't be disappointed.
>Just take 1 part Chris Liebing and 3 parts sex and you've got Eiven
>Major.  Definitely my personal favorite when it comes to wet&hard... if
>you like techno... you don't wanna miss him.
>
>And since wet&hard is based on techno... it wouldn't be a stretch to say
>our whole float is techno....
>
>Its gonna be nice to have this much techno.  California (unfortunately)
>isn't exactly the techno capital of the world.  Its gonna be nice to see
>this many techno people playing at the same place.  I don't think I've
>seen that too often on this side of the 'pond'....
>
>The future is wet&hard...
>XXX,
>p a t
>
>
>
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: n n s [mailto:nico@viberation.com]

From sfraves-return-115064-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Aug 27 20:40:57 2004

Subject: [sfraves] «HAPPY TOGETHER 3! Saturday, September 4th! 2000+ Capacity / 9pm-6am

««PRESALE TICKET UPDATE! $10 Presale Tickets have completely SOLD OUT at 
Solid Grooves in Santa Clara. $15 Presale Tickets will be instock by 3pm!

Tickets are starting to sell very quickly at all locations, be sure to get 
yours soon and guarantee your entry! Thanks and we look forward to seeing 
you at HT3 next weekend!

<<begin BSP>>

Yeah, we know. It's been almost 2 years since the last one. There hasn't 
been a single party we get asked more about, so here it is, the finale.. 
Liquidvinyldjs.com is unbelieveably proud to present:

HAPPY TOGETHER 3
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH 2004
LABOR DAY WEEKEND
ALL AGES | 9:00pm-6:00am
2000+ CAPACITY BAY AREA LOCATION!


We've taken great pride in putting together this once in a lifetime lineup! 
Prepare for one of the biggest hard lineups the West Coast has ever seen!


SCOTT BROWN
|| Evolution Records - Scotland || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
Considered by many around the world as Hardcore's #1 DJ and Producer, Scott 
Brown has achieved more in his career than many in any other genre. He's 
developed his Evolution Records label into what many reguard as the top 
Hardcore label in the world, along with releasing tracks with many of 
Hardcore's top Producers. With massive hits like "ELYSIUM", "NOW IS THE 
TIME", "TURN UP THE MUSIC", and "ICE COLD", chances are if you've been to a 
party in the past 10 years, you've heard his music. As a DJ, he is known for 
his rock solid skills on the decks, often building his sets into energetic 
frenzies that result in mayhem after it's all said and done! This will be 
Scott Brown's first Bay Area Appearance, please join us to make it 
memorable!

DJ HIXXY
|| RaverBaby / HTID / Bonkers - U.K. ||
>From his novice DJ days in 1991 to his International Hardcore Superstar 
status of today, Hixxy has worked long and hard making a name for himself in 
the Hardcore circuit. From his early releases "TOY TOWN" and "WANTING TO GET 
HIGH" to his current hits "TANTRIC" and his remix of "FALLING IN", Hixxy has 
enjoyed enormous success as a Producer. As a DJ, Hixxy helped launch the 
enormously popular "BONKERS" series on React, which continues to break sales 
records for Hardcore CD compilations. His mixes are known to be uplifting 
and energetic, so be ready as we bring Hixxy for a very rare USA appearance!

TOMMYKNOCKER
|| Traxtorm Records - Italy || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
As one of the fastest rising Hardcore producers today, we are extremely 
excited to bring you Tommyknocker for his first Bay Area Appearance. Hailing 
from Italy, his unique sound has been in demand by all of the world's top 
Hardcore DJs, with hard hittin' releases like "THE AFTERMATH", "REVOLUTION", 
and "DEMOLITION". He is also an accomplished DJ, playing huge events like 
Love Parade, Hellraiser, Megarave, and Masters of Hardcore. If you like your 
Hardcore rough and rugged, Tommyknocker is your man!

DELTA 9
|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is widely 
respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his early 
releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE", to his 
present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER", he 
continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has appeared all 
around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd control, 
often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to 
present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

DJ VENOM
|| Volume Productions / Topaz Records - Providence, RI || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Looked upon as one of the most talented Hard DJ's in America, Venom's style 
and persona are only comparible to his music: wild and crazy! He goes 
seamlessly from US Hard House to Hardcore in his mixes, as showcased on such 
top-selling CD compilations as his "RAISE THE VOLUME" series, his "STRAIGHT 
BANGIN" series, and the immensely popular "HOUSE BLEND VOLUME 7-8". From his 
jaw-dropping scratching to his crowd rockin stage displays, it's no wonder 
why Venom is in such huge demand all around the country. We are hyped to 
bring you DJ Venom's first Bay Area Appearance!


CLOUDSKIPPER
|| Raw Elements / KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The one, the only. Cloudskipper is widely recognized and respected as one of 
the top Hardcore DJ's in America. With his recent tour of the U.K. as well 
as his very busy touring here in North America, crowds all around the world 
continue to be amazed and captivated by his upfront Hardcore sets. Often 
immitated, never duplicated, Cloudskipper sets the bar other Hardcore DJ's 
will be trying to reach... next year.

DJ TRONIC
|| Resistance Recordings / Liquidvinyldjs.com / BeatSupreme.com ||
Label owner. Producer. DJ. Promoter. Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not. DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.


THE NICE GUYS [NO LEFT TURN & DJ REESE]
|| KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
When they're not out being nice somewhere, they're out getting drunk. All 
jokes aside, these two are starting to make waves in the Hardcore world, 
with their two upcoming releases on KFA, as well as other material released 
on Raw Elements and Bedlam. Prepare for the Nice Guys, dropping a 
not-so=nice set!

THE NATURAL DISASTERS [THE DOCTOR & RECLIPSE]
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The Doctor and Reclipse, forces in their own right come together to form the 
Natural Disasters. While they're not wrestlers, they drop some of the 
hardest hittin material in the Bay, ranging from DrumNBass to Hardcore to 
Gabber, these two will be shaking the dancefloor HARD!

J-MARR & CARLOS ALFONZO
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com / Soop Recordings / BeatSupreme.com || 
[/b]
Alright, the last time we had these two together during a set, they did more 
passing out of food than actually playing. While we can't promise the same 
feast, we can promise a rockin set that only these two can bring!

Make sure to get there early so you don't miss out on any of the action! The 
perfect event to end your summer right!

| Our capacity will be 2000+! One big ass room filled with the BIGGEST and

located in the IMMEDIATE BAY AREA.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Kerry's "heroism" + The Daily Show TONITE!!!

http://waxy.org/random/video/Daily_Show_-_John_Kerry_Interview.mov

Jokesters now the go-to guys for U.S. candidates

By JOHN DOYLE
Thursday, August 26, 2004 - Page R2

John Kerry can't do comedy. The world kind of knew that already, but Kerry can 
do bemused politician. This talent might help him in his television appearances. 
It is unlikely to help him change the minds of rabid Republicans who hate his 
stinking guts.

The Kerry-hatred went up a few notches recently and that's why Kerry made a 
surprise appearance on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart on Tuesday night. The 
Daily Show (seen in Canada on CTV, weeknights at 12:05 a.m.) is an American 
cable show, airing on Comedy Central, which spoofs the news. It looks like a 
news program, with its grand opening music signalling puffed-up commentary about 
important issues. But what follows in the show is drenched in irony. It 
simultaneously sends up TV news programs and current events. A good deal of its 
comedy is very childish. Bizarrely, it has become one of the most important 
programs on American television.

A lot of the American coverage of Kerry's appearance on The Daily Show compared 
it with Bill Clinton's appearance on The Arsenio Hall Show 12 years ago. In that 
appearance, Clinton played the saxophone and introduced the Elvis side of his 
personality. It worked wonders for his appeal. Since then, according to cliché, 
every American politician needs to appear on late-night TV in order to show his 
or her loose and funny side.

But Kerry's appearance was not about illuminating his goofy side. It was about 
establishing his integrity. The TV gig, which was only announced on Tuesday 
morning, was an important strategic move. He needed an opportunity to counter 
those people who claim that he exaggerated and lied about his service in Vietnam.

"I watch a lot of the cable news shows," Jon Stewart began, "so I understand 
that you were never in Vietnam."

"That's what I understand too, but I'm trying to find out what happened," Kerry 
deadpanned in response.

In the few minutes that Kerry was on The Daily Show, other subjects came up, but 
that exchange was the most important. And it goes it the heart of the craziness 
of the American political culture today. The presidential election is now less 
about the candidates than it is about the media who cover them. Fox News, the 
most popular cable news channel, has savaged Kerry. In order to challenge the 
perception that he lied and exaggerated, Kerry chose to appear on a comedy 
program that spoofs the news. It was actually designed to give him some integrity.

In the rest of the pseudo-interview, Jon Stewart stuck to his mockery of the 
American media, both print and television, that supports George W. Bush and 
relentlessly attacks Kerry.

"Are you the number one most liberal senator in the Senate?" he barked at Kerry. 
The candidate's answer was a bemused, "No."

As Stewart continued in his ironic tone, Kerry tried to deliver some simple 
statements about his platform and his criticisms of Bush. Twice, he succeeded. 
"Most Americans would like to have an intelligent conversation about the 
issues," he said to cheers from the studio audience. Later, speaking to the 
touchiest issue in the campaign, Kerry managed to get off a round of indignation 
about the war with Iraq. "You don't go to war because you want to," he said. 
"You go to war because you have to." The cheering that greeted that statement 
was cut off as the show went to a commercial.

After that, the chat, as wacky as it had been, went further into ridiculousness. 
There was an incomprehensible exchange about oil. Kerry then closed with a 
cutesy comment about the rigours of political campaigning. "You'd be amazed at 
the number of people who want to introduce themselves to you in the men's room. 
It's the most bizarre part of this entire thing." Then Kerry left the show with 
the trademark military salute.

Kerry is wrong about that. The "most bizarre part of this entire thing" is his 
need to appear on a spoof of the news to answer serious charges against him and 
get his message out. That tells you something about the insanity that has 
gripped the American media. Imagine if the leader of a Canadian political party 
decided, in the middle of an election campaign, to ignore Peter Mansbridge, 
Lloyd Robertson and Kevin Newman, and only do an appearance on This Hour Has 22 
Minutes.

Kerry needed to appear on The Daily Show because the American media itself has 
become ridiculous and he needs the endorsement of the jokers, not political 
pundits. The cable news shows that Jon Stewart mocks have become absurdly 
partisan. The print press is going through a period of self-flagellation as 
newspaper after newspaper apologizes and backtracks on its initial coverage of 
the need to go to war with Iraq.

There is no longer a mainstream media in the United States. Every outlet 
postures and preens. Comedy is now as important as political commentary. Only 
the jokers have integrity.

The last thing Kerry said, as he left The Daily Show, was a remark to Stewart. 
He said, "You do a great job." In that, Kerry was correct. It's sad, but true.

Dates and times may vary across the country. Please check listings or visit 
http://www.globeandmail.com/tv

--

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Ask your members of Congress to oppose the Universal National Service Act of 2003 (aka "THE DRAFT")!

--Apple-Mail-10--528449767
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	format=flowed

"What's called the Universal National Service Act of 2003 sits waiting 
ever so patiently until after the November election to quietly become 
the law of the land whereby ALL young Americans, upon turning 18, will 
be REQUIRED to serve for 2 years or 4,000 hours in military or civilian 
service.

"The legislation that sounds benign has the 'working' or 'short' title 
of "Reinstate Draft Bill". It will be, after all, easier to push it 
through Congress if everybody thinks "Universal National Service Act" 
means kids who turn 18 will be asked to man a food bank a few hours a 
month or deliver hot meals to seniors once in awhile. "What's wrong 
with that?" many would ask..."

(read the rest of the article at 
http://www.newswithviews.com/Mary/starrett52.htm )
--Apple-Mail-10--528449767--

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) Kerry still has unresolved issues with the truth

	I know most of you are probably sick of hearing about John Kerry =
and =20
Vietnam. The only reason I've posted so much about him and not Bush on =20=

here is because I doubt many people on this list are thinking of voting =20=

for Bush, but some of you may be thinking of voting for Kerry. If so, I =20=

hope you at least recognize he has repeatedly lied about the war record =20=

that he holds up as his main qualification for office (other than the =20=

fact that he is not Bush). If you already know he's been lying, the =20
following article will just confirm what you already know. But if you =20=

think that -- unlike George Bush -- Kerry was honest about what he was =20=

doing at that time of his life, the following may be educational.

Groove on,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Badnarik For President - A better choice. http://www.badnarik.org


http://www.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?pagename=3DJPost/JPArticle/=20
ShowFull&cid
=3D1093402928027&p=3D1006953079865

John Kerry's real 'band of brothers'
By MARK STEYN
=A0 =A0 =A0=A0
A few months back, I bought a DVD set of an old TV variety show, black =20=

and
white but digitally remastered. A bit too digitally remastered, as it =20=

turned
out. It would be ungallant to name the lady artiste in question, but in
several alarming close-ups it's all too clear she's come back from =20
lunch a
little the worse for wear, and in one scene she looks as if she's just =20=

been
woken up after sleeping in the park for a week.

Not her fault. The make-up guy was making her look good enough for 1960
monochrome UHF lines. He couldn't have foreseen that 40 years on they'd =20=

have
big-screen satellite TVs and DVD players and technology that would make =20=

that
little facial pimple look like Mount Krakatoa about to blow through your
screen.

That's what happened to John Kerry. For 25 years, he told The Boston =20
Globe,
The Washington Post, the United States Senate, and all manner of other
well-known saps about his covert Yuletide operations inside Cambodia
gun-running to anti-communists with his lucky CIA hat. To verify any of =20=

this
would have required a trip to specialist reference libraries, looking up
stuff on eye-straining microfiche, etc. So it was easier to let the old
blowhard yak away and just nod occasionally. Senator Kerry couldn't have
foreseen that Al Gore would invent the Internet, and there'd be this =20
Google
thingy, and all you'd have to do is tap in a few words and a nanosecond
later it would all be at your fingertips - veterans memoirs, Cambodian
history, declassified Johnson administration documents, previous Kerry
"stretchers" (as Mark Twain called them).

The Kerry campaign has now conceded that, by his own contemporaneous
account, the young lieutenant was nowhere near Cambodia in Christmas =20
1968
and, if he was ever on a covert gun-running operation across the border
during his four months in Vietnam, he seems to be the only rookie Swift =20=

boat
lieutenant to land in the territory and get entrusted with such a =20
mission,
and it was evidently so top secret that neither his commanding officers =20=

nor
the men on his own boat knew a thing about it.

Yet the grandees of the US media refuse to show any curiosity about any =20=

of
this, and they think anyone who does is a nut or part of the Republican
"smear machine." When it comes to this newfangled Internet business, =20
they
take the line of Walter Cronkite, the long-retired avuncular anchorman =20=

from
the pre-cable era. Last week, Walter huffed that "he finds that some =20
stories
published on the Web - scandals especially - play too fast and loose =20
with
the facts." As opposed to Walter, who doesn't play fast and loose mainly
because he doesn't produce any facts - not a single specific example - =20=

to
back up his assertion.

And playing fast and loose with the facts may be better than playing as =20=

slow
and tight with them as Walter and his chums do. Right now, some three or
four of his fellow Swift boat veterans back John Kerry, whereas some
hundreds of them oppose him. This in itself is surely rather =20
remarkable. But
Ron Brownstein of The Los Angeles Times deplores the "partisan venom" =20=

of the
election and compares the Swift boat veterans' anti-Kerry commercial to =20=

a
"snuff film." Get a grip, man. Have you ever seen a snuff film? Those
Islamist nutcakes were releasing one a week a couple of months back. =20
Sadly,
the news that some 80% of his fellow Swiftees do not accord Senator =20
Kerry
the same deference the media do is all too ickily "partisan" for Ron. =20=

Maybe
he'd find it all less beastly if he were to take up a position as social
secretary to a dowager duchess. As Lord Charteris, the Queen's courtier,
remarked of Fergie: "Vulgar, vulgar, vulgar." That's Brownstein on the
Swiftees.

So for two weeks, as the Swiftees exposed Kerry's Cambodian fantasies, =20=

the
networks and the "newspapers of record" were like Sherlock Holmes's dog =20=

that
didn't bark - or, in this case, the sheep that didn't baa. Now the =20
silence
of the lambs has been broken. The editorialists at The New York Times =20=

have
deigned to sully, belatedly, their hallowed pages with an =20
acknowledgment of
the existence of the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, if not the =20
substance of
their charges. And this is what the sniffy editorialists - or at least =20=

their
headline writer - have to say:

"Politics as usual."

Well, I should hope so. This is an election campaign, not a coronation -
though you may be confused on that point if you get your news from the =20=

Times
and the networks. Let us stipulate that the snoots at the Times are =20
right -
that the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth are a "Republican-financed group =20=

of
partisans." Just as the handful of Swift boat veterans prepared to =20
support
John Kerry are a Democrat-financed group of partisans. After all, it =20
seems
unlikely that they're picking up their own hotel bills and air fares as =20=

they
travel around the country as his loyal, if small, "band of brothers."

So both groups are "politically motivated." Good for them. That's what
multi-party democracy is all about. The New York Times and CBS News are =20=

also
"politically motivated." So is this column. It's a political column, and
it's "politically motivated." One day I'll start a ballet column, and =20=

that
will be balletically motivated.

So now that we've got all the preening patrician media snobbery out of =20=

the
way, would it be too much to expect so-called political journalists to
investigate Kerry's Cambodian stories? You know, the way they did when =20=

the
comparatively minor question arose of whether Bush was AWOL from his
National Guard base three decades ago. Boy, The New York Times loved =20
that
one:

February 4: "Military Service Becomes Issue in Bush-Kerry Race"

February 11: "The President's Guard Service"

February 13: "Seeking Memories of Bush at an Alabama Air Base"

February 15: "Still the Question: What Did You Do in the War?"

As the Times put it, "Mr. Bush himself also made the issue of military
service fair game by posturing as a swashbuckling pilot when welcoming a
carrier home from Iraq."

Well, the other feller made his military service fair game by posturing =20=

as a
swashbuckling Swift Boat lieutenant to the exclusion of the other 59 =20
years
and eight months of his life. The story now is not John Kerry's weird
secret-agent fantasies but the media's willingness to act as elite =20
guardians
of them. They're his real "band of brothers," happy to fish him out of =20=

their
water, even if their credibility sinks in the process.


---------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  The Antiwar Kerry
