Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 05:57 PM 8/28/2004, Starchild wrote:
>         Yeah, back then he was accusing most U.S. soldiers in Vietnam of 
> committing atrocities and says he committed them himself. And today he is 
> someone who was proud of his service in Vietnam, talks about it every 
> chance he gets, and supports the military.
>
>(cue Led Zepellin) "Wooo, he really makes me wonder..." o/"   8)
>
>                         <<< Starchild >>>


Personally, I'm not pushing any political agenda.  I lean more to the Green 
Party platform and last Presidential election I voted Green and have worked 
for local Green Party candidates.  IMHO, the Libertarian Party lacks 
compassion.  Although I would prefer to be living in the Old West, I'm 
not.  The current century requires checks on Darwinian capitalism to keep 
us from drowning in our own filth, and I believe with "freedom" comes many 
responsibilities.  I don't want to see American or other children 
starving;  I believe in free education;  excellent health care should be 
available to everyone...etc.  Compassion.

I'm disgusted with the current administration, but I'm realistic enough to 
see that a Green candidate has no chance to displace this ugly 
regime.  Everyone I know is voting against Bush;  but I find myself in the 
awkward and dishonest position of not really voting for anything.  Others 
feel the same.  At some point I think there will be more folks than the 
Democrats expect (in states like CA) who will just say "fuck it all."

One of the reasons I thought Kerry might be a good Democratic candidate was 
that he told the truth about the heart of darkness that was Vietnam after 
he had served honorably. That took real courage.   His marketing execs, 
however, decided he should repackage himself as a John Wayne/Terminator 
dude and so we get some fool who looks like he's running for President of 
the VFW.  The source of my own disillusionment begins here, after that 
"Kerry reporting for duty" convention bullshit.

I understand Swift Boat Kerry repositioned himself to battle in the milk, 
apple pie and guns states, but he can't assume that his support in the more 
"liberal" blue states will hold with this militaristic positioning.

As for atrocities, it has always been a good thing in the military to 
describe in great detail the "atrocities" committed by one's enemies;  it 
is really bad form to talk about the dirt one's own military shovels.  To 
be sure, atrocities, ie, violations of what we now call the Geneva 
Conventions but prior to that generally agreed upon rules of war, happen in 
every war.  Understand -- war is not a video game.  War unleashes the dark 
side of peoplekind.

Back in the Greek and Roman era it was commonplace to destroy whole cities, 
rape and pillage, and slaughter all the civilians.  As we moved into more 
"civilized" times, relatively speaking, these behaviours tended to be less 
acceptable.  One shouldn't, for example, kill innocent civilians.

WW I and II, however, brought with them the concept of total war.  Not only 
were industrial targets bombed by both sides, but civilian populations were 
targeted as well.  The firebombing of Dresden was more a mind-fucking 
tactic than military necessity;  same with our demonstrations of ultimate 
destruction in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Atrocities?

Let's take it to the field level.  I don't recall hearing that American 
troops indiscriminately killed German civilians in WW II.  We did, however, 
kill prisoners of war when in challenging military situations, as in the 
Battle of the Bulge.  So did the Germans.  After the war we tried the 
Germans for "war crimes against humanity," and, setting aside the horror of 
genocide and concentration camps, we did hold them accountable for their 
actions in dealing with resistance fighters behind their lines.  One German 
soldier killed by a resistance fighter, ten civilians would be randomly 
selected and shot.  There was evidence that some villages were destroyed, 
with women and children,  in response to resistance activities.  We now see 
the resistance fighters as heros, and we tried the Germans for war 
crimes.  Just, I think.

On to Vietnam.  Those who judged the Germans at Nuremburg, we Americans, 
found ourselves confronted by resistance fighters everywhere in 
country.  Our response was similar to the Germans, and even more barbaric 
at times.  Americans killed women and children;  burned villages;  and even 
cut off ears and other body parts and made necklaces with them.  There were 
clear elements of racism here.  Dark-skinned civilian folks were more 
easily machine-gunned than white Europeans in WW II.  Atrocities?  Yes, I 
think so.  Our national innocence was lost in Vietnam.  Our military was 
disgraced.  Our ideals and our flag went down the toilet.  Someone had to 
stand up for old-fashioned American values and people like Kerry, along 
with millions of students and concerned citizens, finally brought this 
shameful era in our history to an end.  That's patriotism, in my opinion.

Now our military is faced with a similar situation:  placed harms way in a 
country where the distinction between civilian and soldier is unclear, like 
Vietnam.  We have legal types in government who question the validity of 
the Geneva Conventions.  We are,  I believe, on the slippery slope to the 
heart of darkness again, and I wish to hell Kerry, who has a chance to win 
this election, would have the guts to confront these issues as well as 
things much more important than security at any cost:  rising poverty 
levels;  hungry kids;  an educational system in shambles;  environmental 
destruction;  and an unworkable health-care system to name a few.

Love,

Apollo

"You are not thinking.  You are merely being logical."
Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

"The government, which was designed for the people, has got into the hands 
of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

>little the worse for wear, and in one scene she looks as if she's just  
>been
>woken up after sleeping in the park for a week.
>
>Not her fault. The make-up guy was making her look good enough for 1960
>monochrome UHF lines. He couldn't have foreseen that 40 years on they'd  
>have
>big-screen satellite TVs and DVD players and technology that would make  
>that
>little facial pimple look like Mount Krakatoa about to blow through your
>screen.
>
>That's what happened to John Kerry. For 25 years, he told The Boston  
>Globe,
>The Washington Post, the United States Senate, and all manner of other
>well-known saps about his covert Yuletide operations inside Cambodia
>gun-running to anti-communists with his lucky CIA hat. To verify any of  
>this
>would have required a trip to specialist reference libraries, looking up
>stuff on eye-straining microfiche, etc. So it was easier to let the old
>blowhard yak away and just nod occasionally. Senator Kerry couldn't have
>foreseen that Al Gore would invent the Internet, and there'd be this  
>Google
>thingy, and all you'd have to do is tap in a few words and a nanosecond
>later it would all be at your fingertips - veterans memoirs, Cambodian
>history, declassified Johnson administration documents, previous Kerry
>"stretchers" (as Mark Twain called them).
>
>The Kerry campaign has now conceded that, by his own contemporaneous
>account, the young lieutenant was nowhere near Cambodia in Christmas  1968
>and, if he was ever on a covert gun-running operation across the border
>during his four months in Vietnam, he seems to be the only rookie Swift  
>boat
>lieutenant to land in the territory and get entrusted with such a  mission,
>and it was evidently so top secret that neither his commanding officers  
>nor
>the men on his own boat knew a thing about it.
>
>Yet the grandees of the US media refuse to show any curiosity about any  of
>this, and they think anyone who does is a nut or part of the Republican
>"smear machine." When it comes to this newfangled Internet business,  they
>take the line of Walter Cronkite, the long-retired avuncular anchorman  
>from
>the pre-cable era. Last week, Walter huffed that "he finds that some  
>stories
>published on the Web - scandals especially - play too fast and loose  with
>the facts." As opposed to Walter, who doesn't play fast and loose mainly
>because he doesn't produce any facts - not a single specific example -  to
>back up his assertion.
>
>And playing fast and loose with the facts may be better than playing as  
>slow
>and tight with them as Walter and his chums do. Right now, some three or
>four of his fellow Swift boat veterans back John Kerry, whereas some
>hundreds of them oppose him. This in itself is surely rather  remarkable. 
>But
>Ron Brownstein of The Los Angeles Times deplores the "partisan venom"  of 
>the
>election and compares the Swift boat veterans' anti-Kerry commercial to  a
>"snuff film." Get a grip, man. Have you ever seen a snuff film? Those
>Islamist nutcakes were releasing one a week a couple of months back.  
>Sadly,
>the news that some 80% of his fellow Swiftees do not accord Senator  Kerry
>the same deference the media do is all too ickily "partisan" for Ron.  
>Maybe
>he'd find it all less beastly if he were to take up a position as social
>secretary to a dowager duchess. As Lord Charteris, the Queen's courtier,
>remarked of Fergie: "Vulgar, vulgar, vulgar." That's Brownstein on the
>Swiftees.
>
>So for two weeks, as the Swiftees exposed Kerry's Cambodian fantasies,  the
>networks and the "newspapers of record" were like Sherlock Holmes's dog  
>that
>didn't bark - or, in this case, the sheep that didn't baa. Now the  silence
>of the lambs has been broken. The editorialists at The New York Times  have
>deigned to sully, belatedly, their hallowed pages with an  acknowledgment 
>of
>the existence of the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, if not the  substance 
>of
>their charges. And this is what the sniffy editorialists - or at least  
>their
>headline writer - have to say:
>
>"Politics as usual."
>
>Well, I should hope so. This is an election campaign, not a coronation -
>though you may be confused on that point if you get your news from the  
>Times
>and the networks. Let us stipulate that the snoots at the Times are  right 
>-
>that the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth are a "Republican-financed group  of
>partisans." Just as the handful of Swift boat veterans prepared to  support
>John Kerry are a Democrat-financed group of partisans. After all, it  seems
>unlikely that they're picking up their own hotel bills and air fares as  
>they
>travel around the country as his loyal, if small, "band of brothers."
>
>So both groups are "politically motivated." Good for them. That's what
>multi-party democracy is all about. The New York Times and CBS News are  
>also
>"politically motivated." So is this column. It's a political column, and
>it's "politically motivated." One day I'll start a ballet column, and  that
>will be balletically motivated.
>
>So now that we've got all the preening patrician media snobbery out of  the
>way, would it be too much to expect so-called political journalists to
>investigate Kerry's Cambodian stories? You know, the way they did when  the
>comparatively minor question arose of whether Bush was AWOL from his
>National Guard base three decades ago. Boy, The New York Times loved  that
>one:
>
>February 4: "Military Service Becomes Issue in Bush-Kerry Race"
>
>February 11: "The President's Guard Service"
>
>February 13: "Seeking Memories of Bush at an Alabama Air Base"
>
>February 15: "Still the Question: What Did You Do in the War?"
>
>As the Times put it, "Mr. Bush himself also made the issue of military
>service fair game by posturing as a swashbuckling pilot when welcoming a
>carrier home from Iraq."
>
>Well, the other feller made his military service fair game by posturing  as 
>a
>swashbuckling Swift Boat lieutenant to the exclusion of the other 59  years
>and eight months of his life. The story now is not John Kerry's weird
>secret-agent fantasies but the media's willingness to act as elite  
>guardians
>of them. They're his real "band of brothers," happy to fish him out of  
>their
>water, even if their credibility sinks in the process.
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

Subject: [sfraves] Enough about Kerry, for crying out loud

Let's examine the type of people who are CURRENTLY running our country

The lessor of two evils is always better....


http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story?id=6450422&pageid=rs.Home&pageregion=single7&rnd=1093654339982&has-player=true&version=6.0.12.872 
<http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story?id=6450422&pageid=rs.Home&pageregion=single7&rnd=1093654339982&has-player=true&version=6.0.12.872>

*The Curse of Dick Cheney

The veep's career has been marred by one disaster after another

*Extract:

Should George W. Bush win this election, it will give him the distinction 
of being the first occupant of the White House to have survived naming Dick 
Cheney to a post in his administration. The Cheney jinx first manifested 
itself at the presidential level back in 1969, when Richard Nixon appointed 
him to his first job in the executive branch. It surfaced again in 1975, 
when Gerald Ford made Cheney his chief of staff and then -- with Cheney's 
help -- lost the 1976 election. George H.W. Bush, having named Cheney 
secretary of defense, was defeated for re-election in 1992. The ever-canny 
Ronald Reagan was the only Republican president since Eisenhower who 
managed to serve two full terms. He is also the only one not to have 
appointed Dick Cheney to office.

This pattern of misplaced confidence in Cheney, followed by disastrous 
results, runs throughout his life -- from his days as a dropout at Yale to 
the geopolitical chaos he has helped create in Baghdad. Once you get to 
know his history, the cycle becomes clear: First, Cheney impresses someone 
rich or powerful, who causes unearned wealth and power to be conferred on 
him. Then, when things go wrong, he blames others and moves on to a new 
situation even more advantageous to himself.

"Cheney's manner and authority of voice far outstrip his true abilities," 
says Chas Freeman, who served under Bush's father as ambassador to Saudi 
Arabia. "It was clear from the start that Bush required adult supervision 
-- but it turns out Cheney has even worse instincts. He does not understand 
that when you act recklessly, your mistakes will come back and bite you on 
the ass."

Cheney's record of mistakes begins in 1959, when Tom Stroock, a Republican 
politician-businessman in Casper, Wyoming, got Cheney, then a senior at 
Natrona County High School, a scholarship to Yale. "Dick was the 
all-American boy, in the top ten percent of his class," Stroock says. "He 
seemed a natural." But instead of triumphing, Cheney failed. "He spent his 
time partying with guys who loved football but weren't varsity quality," 
recalls Stephen Billings, an Episcopalian minister who roomed with him 
during Cheney's freshman (and only full) year at Yale. "His idea was, you 
didn't need to master the material," says his other roommate, Jacob 
Plotkin. "He passed one psych course without attending class or studying, 
and he was proud of that. But there are some things you can't bluff, and 
Dick reached a point where you couldn't recover."


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Apollo,

	It sounds to me like your political agenda is to get people to =
vote=20
for Kerry. That's all right. It's OK to have an agenda.  8)  "If you=20
don't stand for something, you'll go for anything," as the saying goes.=20=

At least you've thought about things enough to have a viewpoint, and=20
you care enough to try to convince others to think the way you do.

	But as far as systems go, I'd rather have real "Darwinian =
capitalism,"=20
where you have a market ecosystem evolving toward something positive,=20
than "Monotheistic socialism" where government plays God. Competition=20
in the marketplace doesn't have to mean a lack of caring about other=20
people, in fact the opposite is more true. When businesses have to=20
compete with each other for your dollars, the customer is more likely=20
to experience positive, friendly service and sincere attention to her=20
needs. When you have to deal with a monopoly like a government agency,=20=

that's when you're more likely to encounter rude, condescending=20
attitudes and a lack of caring. Admittedly this can tend to be the case=20=

with large corporations also. I'm not a fan of corporations, and I=20
agree that they shouldn't have the status of persons under the law. But=20=

at least with them you have the choice of taking your business=20
elsewhere. With government, you're pretty much stuck.

	And I strongly disagree that the Libertarian Party lacks =
compassion.=20
It's easy to have "compassion" when you're relying on someone else to=20
coercively take and spend other peoples' money. That's not real=20
compassion. It's not compassionate to say "tax the wealthy," or "let's=20=

have another government program." Giving your *own* money to help=20
people, or volunteering your *own* time, now that is compassion.=20
Libertarians are trying to reduce the burden of government on people so=20=

that they have more time and money left over to help others after=20
providing for themselves and their own families.

	If you have any experience with non-profits, you probably know =
that=20
when there's an economic slump and people are earning less, charitable=20=

giving decreases. When people are doing better, they give more to=20
support organizations in their communities that are helping the poor,=20
making art, providing educational resources, etc. Reduce the amount=20
that the middle man (government) skims off the top, and there will be=20
more to go around. We don't need poverty pimps!

	I agree with most of your historical analysis. War is awful, and=20=

events like the bombing of Dresden and Hiroshima, and some of the=20
actions committed by U.S. government soldiers in Vietnam were=20
unnecessary atrocities. I don't like to refer to the U.S. as "our"=20
country any more however. I'm done with nationalism. My commitment is=20
to freedom, not to the United States. The U.S. government simply=20
happens to exercise control over that portion of the earth's surface in=20=

which I happen to live and spend most of my time. It is not "mine"; I=20
did not vote for the people running it. Though some governments are=20
clearly better than others, and the U.S. government allows more freedom=20=

than most, I view every existing state as fundamentally illegitimate=20
since they are all based on coercion.

	 Have you seen the flash animation at=20
http://www.isil.org/resources/introduction.swf ? That offers as good a=20=

look as anything at where I'm coming from.

Sincerely,
				<<< Starchild >>>

>
>
>
> Personally, I'm not pushing any political agenda.=A0 I lean more to =
the=20

> capitalism to keep us from drowning in our own filth, and I believe=20
> with "freedom" comes many responsibilities.=A0 I don't want to see=20
> American or other children starving;=A0 I believe in free education;=A0=20=

> candidate was that he told the truth about the heart of darkness that=20=

=20
> His marketing execs, however, decided he should repackage himself as a=20=

> John Wayne/Terminator dude and so we get some fool who looks like he's=20=

> running for President of the VFW.=A0 The source of my own=20
> disillusionment begins here, after that "Kerry reporting for duty"=20
> convention bullshit.=A0
>
> I understand Swift Boat Kerry repositioned himself to battle in the=20
> milk, apple pie and guns states, but he can't assume that his support=20=

> in the more "liberal" blue states will hold with this militaristic=20
> positioning.
>
> As for atrocities, it has always been a good thing in the military to=20=

> describe in great detail the "atrocities" committed by one's enemies;=A0=
=20
> it is really bad form to talk about the dirt one's own military=20
> shovels.=A0 To be sure, atrocities, ie, violations of what we now call=20=

> the Geneva Conventions but prior to that generally agreed upon rules=20=

> of war, happen in every war.=A0 Understand -- war is not a video =
game.=A0=20
> War unleashes the dark side of peoplekind.
>
> Back in the Greek and Roman era it was commonplace to destroy whole=20
> cities, rape and pillage, and slaughter all the civilians.=A0 As we=20
> moved into more "civilized" times, relatively speaking, these=20
> behaviours tended to be less acceptable.=A0 One shouldn't, for =
example,=20
> kill innocent civilians.
>
> WW I and II, however, brought with them the concept of total war.=A0 =
Not=20
> only were industrial targets bombed by both sides, but civilian=20
> populations were targeted as well.=A0 The firebombing of Dresden was=20=

> more a mind-fucking tactic than military necessity;=A0 same with our=20=

> demonstrations of ultimate destruction in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.=A0=20=

> Atrocities?
>
> Let's take it to the field level.=A0 I don't recall hearing that=20
> American troops indiscriminately killed German civilians in WW II.=A0 =
We=20
> did, however, kill prisoners of war when in challenging military=20
> situations, as in the Battle of the Bulge.=A0 So did the Germans.=A0 =
After=20
> the war we tried the Germans for "war crimes against humanity," and,=20=

> setting aside the horror of genocide and concentration camps, we did=20=

> hold them accountable for their actions in dealing with resistance=20
> fighters behind their lines.=A0 One German soldier killed by a=20
> resistance fighter, ten civilians would be randomly selected and=20
> shot.=A0 There was evidence that some villages were destroyed, with=20
> women and children,=A0 in response to resistance activities.=A0 We now =
see=20
> the resistance fighters as heros, and we tried the Germans for war=20
> crimes.=A0 Just, I think.

> everywhere in country.=A0 Our response was similar to the Germans, and=20=

made=20
> necklaces with them.=A0 There were clear elements of racism here.=A0=20=

for=20

At 06:05 PM 8/29/2004, Starchild wrote:
>Apollo,
>
>         It sounds to me like your political agenda is to get people to 
> vote for Kerry. That's all right. It's OK to have an agenda.  8)  "If you 
> don't stand for something, you'll go for anything," as the saying goes. 
> At least you've thought about things enough to have a viewpoint, and you 
> care enough to try to convince others to think the way you do.

My post reflected my own ambivalence about "voting" for Kerry.  As I stated 
quite clearly, I don't believe I'm voting for something good this time 
around, just voting against a disgusting regime.


>         But as far as systems go, I'd rather have real "Darwinian 
> capitalism," where you have a market ecosystem evolving toward something 
> positive, than "Monotheistic socialism" where government plays God.

Nothing is either/or, black or white.  Superior systems evolve from a 
conflict of opposing ideas.  A dialectic.  Neither capitalism as we know 
it, or socialism as it was, will take us into the future in my 
opinion.  Something better will evolve.

>  Competition in the marketplace doesn't have to mean a lack of caring 
> about other people, in fact the opposite is more true. When businesses 
> have to compete with each other for your dollars, the customer is more 
> likely to experience positive, friendly service and sincere attention to 
> her needs.

I have not found that to be true.  Especially when it comes to the 
environment.  But let's take a personal experience I had lately with 
Sears.  Bought a very expensive fridge a few years ago.  Thing died three 
weeks ago.  I call Sears and the customer service rep tried to sell me a 
"bet "warranty.  Give us $300 in advance, and if we can't repair it the 
money will go towards a new fridge.  Ha.  I tell her this is an 
emergency.  My food is going bad.  Best appointment I can get with a 
service rep is four days down the road.  Food rots and is tossed.  Rep 
comes.  Evaluates the situation.  Needs a $27.00 part he doesn't 
have.   This must be shipped from a warehouse in the East.  One week later, 
the part and rep arrives.  Part doesn't work.  Requires another part from 
another warehouse in the East.  Yet another week passes.  I'm fighting with 
Sears Corp at this point.  Have to buy a smaller fridge to keep basic 
necessaries.  Finally, after three weeks the fridge is working again.

What have I learned.  Higher worker productivity means fewer service reps 
in the field = my food rots while I try to get an overworked former IT guy 
now a fridge repair person for an appointment.  Consumer 
satisfaction?  Shit.  Inventory control on demand.  MBA decides to save 
some money by having parts strewn about all over the country.  I must 
suffer.  I could go on.  I'm happy your experiences with consumer products 
and service have been so positive.  In the past a Sears fridge would last 
twenty years, and the rep came the same day if there was a problem and had 
the parts to repair it.  But then, doctors came to your home and the 
pharmacy delivered.



>         If you have any experience with non-profits, you probably know 
> that when there's an economic slump and people are earning less, 
> charitable giving decreases. When people are doing better, they give more 
> to support organizations in their communities that are helping the poor, 
> making art, providing educational resources, etc. Reduce the amount that 
> the middle man (government) skims off the top, and there will be more to 
> go around. We don't need poverty pimps!

The statistics don't back up your assertion that charitable giving was up 
during our recession.  It was down.  And non-profit giving has nothing to 
do with the government skimming off the top.  Donations go directly to the 
charitable organizations, many of whom pay their execs fabulous salaries.


>         I agree with most of your historical analysis. War is awful, and 
> events like the bombing of Dresden and Hiroshima, and some of the actions 
> committed by U.S. government soldiers in Vietnam were unnecessary 
> atrocities. I don't like to refer to the U.S. as "our" country any more 
> however. I'm done with nationalism. My commitment is to freedom, not to 
> the United States. The U.S. government simply happens to exercise control 
> over that portion of the earth's surface in which I happen to live and 
> spend most of my time. It is not "mine"; I did not vote for the people 
> running it. Though some governments are clearly better than others, and 
> the U.S. government allows more freedom than most, I view every existing 
> state as fundamentally illegitimate since they are all based on coercion.

My commitment is to freedom also, but with the understanding that we are 
not free to kill others, steal from them, take away their pension funds by 
cooking the books, and trashing the environment to realize short-term 
profitability and personal gain.  Furthermore, states only exist as long as 
the people allow them to do so.  Neither you or I are coerced.  We assent 
to be governed.  Collectively.  Hitler didn't come into power because he 
got together some thugs with guns and coerced Germans into following him.

Bottom line -- I don't think most people really want freedom.  History 
clearly demonstrates this.  Sixty years ago most of Europe was not free.  I 
think there were five democracies in the world.  People have shown time and 
again that they prefer security to freedom, or at least the illusion of it.

As for me, if there were still some ungoverned, wild spaces left on this 
earth I would be packing my loincloths and heading for them.


>         Have you seen the flash animation at 
> http://www.isil.org/resources/introduction.swf ? That offers as good a 
> look as anything at where I'm coming from.


Yes, you posted it to this list before.

I'm finished with this.

Love,

Apollo


>On Saturday, August 28, 2004, at 08:07  PM, Apollo wrote:
>
>>At 05:57 PM 8/28/2004, Starchild wrote:
>>
>>         Yeah, back then he was accusing most U.S. soldiers in Vietnam of 
>> committing atrocities and says he committed them himself. And today he 
>> is someone who was proud of his service in Vietnam, talks about it every 
>> chance he gets, and supports the military.
>>
>>(cue Led Zepellin) "Wooo, he really makes me wonder..." o/"   8)
>>
>>                         <<< Starchild >>>
>>
>>
>>
>>Personally, I'm not pushing any political agenda.  I lean more to the 
>>Green Party platform and last Presidential election I voted Green and 
>>have worked for local Green Party candidates.  IMHO, the Libertarian 
>>Party lacks compassion.  Although I would prefer to be living in the Old 
>>West, I'm not.  The current century requires checks on Darwinian 
>>capitalism to keep us from drowning in our own filth, and I believe with 
>>"freedom" comes many responsibilities.  I don't want to see American or 
>>other children starving;  I believe in free education;  excellent health 
>>care should be available to everyone...etc.  Compassion.
>>
>>I'm disgusted with the current administration, but I'm realistic enough 
>>to see that a Green candidate has no chance to displace this ugly 
>>regime.  Everyone I know is voting against Bush;  but I find myself in 
>>the awkward and dishonest position of not really voting for 
>>anything.  Others feel the same.  At some point I think there will be 
>>more folks than the Democrats expect (in states like CA) who will just 
>>say "fuck it all."
>>
>>One of the reasons I thought Kerry might be a good Democratic candidate 
>>was that he told the truth about the heart of darkness that was Vietnam 
>>after he had served honorably. That took real courage.   His marketing 
>>execs, however, decided he should repackage himself as a John 
>>Wayne/Terminator dude and so we get some fool who looks like he's running 
>>for President of the VFW.  The source of my own disillusionment begins 
>>here, after that "Kerry reporting for duty" convention bullshit.
>>
>>I understand Swift Boat Kerry repositioned himself to battle in the milk, 
>>apple pie and guns states, but he can't assume that his support in the 
>>more "liberal" blue states will hold with this militaristic positioning.
>>
>>As for atrocities, it has always been a good thing in the military to 
>>describe in great detail the "atrocities" committed by one's enemies;  it 
>>is really bad form to talk about the dirt one's own military shovels.  To 
>>be sure, atrocities, ie, violations of what we now call the Geneva 
>>Conventions but prior to that generally agreed upon rules of war, happen 
>>in every war.  Understand -- war is not a video game.  War unleashes the 
>>dark side of peoplekind.
>>
>>Back in the Greek and Roman era it was commonplace to destroy whole 
>>cities, rape and pillage, and slaughter all the civilians.  As we moved 
>>into more "civilized" times, relatively speaking, these behaviours tended 
>>to be less acceptable.  One shouldn't, for example, kill innocent civilians.
>>
>>WW I and II, however, brought with them the concept of total war.  Not 
>>only were industrial targets bombed by both sides, but civilian 
>>populations were targeted as well.  The firebombing of Dresden was more a 
>>mind-fucking tactic than military necessity;  same with our 
>>demonstrations of ultimate destruction in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Atrocities?
>>
>>Let's take it to the field level.  I don't recall hearing that American 
>>troops indiscriminately killed German civilians in WW II.  We did, 
>>however, kill prisoners of war when in challenging military situations, 
>>as in the Battle of the Bulge.  So did the Germans.  After the war we 
>>tried the Germans for "war crimes against humanity," and, setting aside 
>>the horror of genocide and concentration camps, we did hold them 
>>accountable for their actions in dealing with resistance fighters behind 
>>their lines.  One German soldier killed by a resistance fighter, ten 
>>civilians would be randomly selected and shot.  There was evidence that 
>>some villages were destroyed, with women and children,  in response to 
>>resistance activities.  We now see the resistance fighters as heros, and 
>>we tried the Germans for war crimes.  Just, I think.
>>
>>On to Vietnam.  Those who judged the Germans at Nuremburg, we Americans, 
>>found ourselves confronted by resistance fighters everywhere in 
>>country.  Our response was similar to the Germans, and even more barbaric 
>>at times.  Americans killed women and children;  burned villages;  and 
>>even cut off ears and other body parts and made necklaces with 
>>them.  There were clear elements of racism here.  Dark-skinned civilian 
>>folks were more easily machine-gunned than white Europeans in WW 
>>II.  Atrocities?  Yes, I think so.  Our national innocence was lost in 
>>Vietnam.  Our military was disgraced.  Our ideals and our flag went down 
>>the toilet.  Someone had to stand up for old-fashioned American values 
>>and people like Kerry, along with millions of students and concerned 
>>citizens, finally brought this shameful era in our history to an 
>>end.  That's patriotism, in my opinion.
>>
>>Now our military is faced with a similar situation:  placed harms way in 
>>a country where the distinction between civilian and soldier is unclear, 
>>like Vietnam.  We have legal types in government who question the 
>>validity of the Geneva Conventions.  We are,  I believe, on the slippery 
>>slope to the heart of darkness again, and I wish to hell Kerry, who has a 
>>chance to win this election, would have the guts to confront these issues 
>>as well as things much more important than security at any cost:  rising 
>>poverty levels;  hungry kids;  an educational system in 
>>shambles;  environmental destruction;  and an unworkable health-care 
>>system to name a few.
>>
>>Love,
>>
>>Apollo
>>
>>
>>
>>

Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."

-Bob Dylan

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

At 07:52 PM 8/29/2004, Apollo wrote:
>At 06:05 PM 8/29/2004, Starchild wrote:
>
>
>>         If you have any experience with non-profits, you probably know 
>> that when there's an economic slump and people are earning less, 
>> charitable giving decreases. When people are doing better, they give 
>> more to support organizations in their communities that are helping the 
>> poor, making art, providing educational resources, etc. Reduce the 
>> amount that the middle man (government) skims off the top, and there 
>> will be more to go around. We don't need poverty pimps!
>
>The statistics don't back up your assertion that charitable giving was up 
>during our recession.  It was down.  And non-profit giving has nothing to 
>do with the government skimming off the top.  Donations go directly to the 
>charitable organizations, many of whom pay their execs fabulous salaries.
>

Sorry.  I misread this section of your post.  Too much multitasking these 
days.  I should read more carefully.  And yes, people do give more when 
they make more money.  One of the obvious reasons for this are the tax 
deductions available for charitable giving.   Seen this way, government 
incentivizes compassion.  Would this compassion exist without the tax break?:)

I do agree with some of the libertarian platform, but my major problem is 
with, again, compassion.  If we all lived in a society with shared, strong 
ethical beliefs and practices I think some competitive free-for-all might 
be in order.  We had less controls on business in the nineteenth and early 
twentieth centuries --  along with children working in factories, massive 
exploitation of workers, twelve-hour work days and seven day 
workweeks.  People, I think, don't live to work but work to live.  We seem 
to be moving back to the pre-union dark ages, tho these days workers wear 
Polo blue collars.  Without some checks and balances a few would have us 
all working like serfs again.

But ethics.  Religion as a motivational force is dead in the old industrial 
countries.  What "morality"  remains of the old codes is focused on sex and 
pleasure rather than greed and giving.

In business one finds the cost benefit analysis ethical structure.  For 
example, I will pay a fine of $1MM if I break a law and screw the consumer 
but I stand to make $30MM.  What to do?  I worked for a Fortune 100 
financial services corporation.  We violated the law, paid the fine, made 
the money until a cease and desist order was issued, and then sent some 
unreadable account update to the customers more in agreement with 
Regulation Z.  Enron and others moved even further.  Lies, deceit, and 
criminal activity are often rewarded in a Darwinian capitalist structure.

Private morality seems to have moved in that direction:  situational ethics 
founded on the belief that as long as I as an individual flourish virtually 
anything is permitted as long as I don't end up in jail.  The commonweal is 
secondary to the needs of often greedy individuals.  Take away whatever 
checks and balances are left and we all end up living in a very unpleasant 
jungle.

Love,

Apollo

>>

>>>after he had served honorably. That took real courage.   His marketing 
>>>execs, however, decided he should repackage himself as a John 
>>>Wayne/Terminator dude and so we get some fool who looks like he's 
>>>running for President of the VFW.  The source of my own disillusionment 
>>>begins here, after that "Kerry reporting for duty" convention bullshit.
>>>
>>>I understand Swift Boat Kerry repositioned himself to battle in the 
>>>milk, apple pie and guns states, but he can't assume that his support in 
>>>the more "liberal" blue states will hold with this militaristic positioning.
>>>
>>>As for atrocities, it has always been a good thing in the military to 
>>>describe in great detail the "atrocities" committed by one's 
>>>enemies;  it is really bad form to talk about the dirt one's own 
>>>military shovels.  To be sure, atrocities, ie, violations of what we now 
>>>call the Geneva Conventions but prior to that generally agreed upon 
>>>rules of war, happen in every war.  Understand -- war is not a video 
>>>game.  War unleashes the dark side of peoplekind.
>>>
>>>Back in the Greek and Roman era it was commonplace to destroy whole 
>>>cities, rape and pillage, and slaughter all the civilians.  As we moved 
>>>into more "civilized" times, relatively speaking, these behaviours 
>>>tended to be less acceptable.  One shouldn't, for example, kill innocent 
>>>civilians.
>>>
>>>WW I and II, however, brought with them the concept of total war.  Not 
>>>only were industrial targets bombed by both sides, but civilian 
>>>populations were targeted as well.  The firebombing of Dresden was more 
>>>a mind-fucking tactic than military necessity;  same with our 
>>>demonstrations of ultimate destruction in Hiroshima and Nagasaki.  Atrocities?
>>>
>>>Let's take it to the field level.  I don't recall hearing that American 
>>>troops indiscriminately killed German civilians in WW II.  We did, 
>>>however, kill prisoners of war when in challenging military situations, 
>>>as in the Battle of the Bulge.  So did the Germans.  After the war we 
>>>tried the Germans for "war crimes against humanity," and, setting aside 
>>>the horror of genocide and concentration camps, we did hold them 
>>>accountable for their actions in dealing with resistance fighters behind 
>>>their lines.  One German soldier killed by a resistance fighter, ten 
>>>civilians would be randomly selected and shot.  There was evidence that 
>>>some villages were destroyed, with women and children,  in response to 
>>>resistance activities.  We now see the resistance fighters as heros, and 
>>>we tried the Germans for war crimes.  Just, I think.
>>>
>>>On to Vietnam.  Those who judged the Germans at Nuremburg, we Americans, 
>>>found ourselves confronted by resistance fighters everywhere in 
>>>country.  Our response was similar to the Germans, and even more 
>>>barbaric at times.  Americans killed women and children;  burned 
>>>villages;  and even cut off ears and other body parts and made necklaces 
>>>with them.  There were clear elements of racism here.  Dark-skinned 
>>>civilian folks were more easily machine-gunned than white Europeans in 
>>>WW II.  Atrocities?  Yes, I think so.  Our national innocence was lost 
>>>in Vietnam.  Our military was disgraced.  Our ideals and our flag went 
>>>down the toilet.  Someone had to stand up for old-fashioned American 
>>>values and people like Kerry, along with millions of students and 
>>>concerned citizens, finally brought this shameful era in our history to 
>>>an end.  That's patriotism, in my opinion.
>>>
>>>Now our military is faced with a similar situation:  placed harms way in 
>>>a country where the distinction between civilian and soldier is unclear, 
>>>like Vietnam.  We have legal types in government who question the 
>>>validity of the Geneva Conventions.  We are,  I believe, on the slippery 
>>>slope to the heart of darkness again, and I wish to hell Kerry, who has 
>>>a chance to win this election, would have the guts to confront these 
>>>issues as well as things much more important than security at any 
>>>cost:  rising poverty levels;  hungry kids;  an educational system in 
>>>shambles;  environmental destruction;  and an unworkable health-care 
>>>system to name a few.
>>>
>>>Love,
>>>
>>>Apollo
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>On Saturday, August 28, 2004, at 11:53  AM, Apollo wrote:

Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

-Bob Dylan

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

having to walk 5 miles in the snow to get to school at the time, and they're=

to=20
get to school when you could simply just drive your Honda civic. Yet still=20
they are almost proud to have gone through that atrocity, and they will poin=
t=20

ways.

and was talking about how they have to train how to handle poisonous gasses.=

take off their gasmasks, and this stuff will burn their eyes and their lungs=

they have to hold their breath and run some sort of drill that is really=20
difficult and some of the guys just freak out and panic. A couple of guys ra=
n over=20
their own sergeant just to get out of the room. Anyway the tone of his voice=

while explaining this story was that of pride, it was obvious he felt that t=
his=20

that it is quite possible to be proud of having gone through an atrocity,=20
there's no reason to feel guilty about being there if you had no choice, the=

is going up the hierarchy someone actually does have that choice... and who=20
better to understand that choice than someone who's experienced first hand w=

the corruption of war feels like? Think about it.=A0=A0 *keep bouncing*

Subject: [sfraves] Love Parade SF

--=====================_2234052==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


The Love is Coming... Saturday, October 2, 2004

The world's largest electronic music festival and parade is coming to San 
Francisco on October 2, 2004. First held in Berlin in 1989, Loveparade San 
Francisco is expected to draw thousands of revelers to the Bay Area for a 
celebration of electronic music with a mission of fostering tolerance, 
respect and understanding between nations.
<http://www.loveparadesf.org>http://www.loveparadesf.org

The festivities kick off at 1pm in downtown San Francisco's financial 
district at Market and Beale Streets. The procession then heads along the 
scenic waterfront to 3rd Street, where it will then head to Terry Francois 
Blvd for a post-parade festival. This post-parade festival will run until 
approximately 9pm and will be composed of the floats and DJs that took part 
in the parade. See <http://www.loveparadesf.org/eventdetails.html>the Event 
Details section of the website.

Coming from out of town and need a place to stay or help getting around 
around? See the 
Accommodation<http://www.loveparadesf.org/accomandtransport.html> and 
Transportation section of the website and links to hotels offer discounted 
accommodation. Mention Loveparade when booking or use the links provided. 
You must book soon to get a discount!

More information has been posted to the website. 
<http://www.loveparadesf.org/faq.html>Click here to visit the FAQ section.

	I was also in the Army Reserves, and went through the tear gas=20=

training you describe. I think one sergeant stayed inside the room with=20=

a gas mask on to make sure we took off our masks and tried to follow=20
the drill. Most of them were outside, laughing at us when we came=20
running out gasping and wheezing, and/or doubled over vomiting, with=20
tears and snot running down our faces. It was definitely a miserable=20
experience. Yes I'm proud to have endured it, and to have made it=20
through basic training, though I certainly wouldn't want to repeat it.

	But it was hardly an atrocity. We were all volunteers, not =
draftees,=20
and could have dropped out of BT had we decided it was too much. Some=20
did. If I had been forced to commit atrocities against other unwilling=20=

human beings (or even worse, had I done it on my own initiative) I=20
would not be proud of it.

				<<< Starchild >>>

From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>

Sent: Monday, August 30, 2004 11:31 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Love Parade SF


>
> The Love is Coming... Saturday, October 2, 2004
>
> The world's largest electronic music festival and parade is coming to San
> Francisco on October 2, 2004. First held in Berlin in 1989, Loveparade San
> Francisco is expected to draw thousands of revelers to the Bay Area for a
> celebration of electronic music with a mission of fostering tolerance,
> respect and understanding between nations.
> <http://www.loveparadesf.org>http://www.loveparadesf.org
>
> The festivities kick off at 1pm in downtown San Francisco's financial
> district at Market and Beale Streets. The procession then heads along the
> scenic waterfront to 3rd Street, where it will then head to Terry Francois
> Blvd for a post-parade festival. This post-parade festival will run until
> approximately 9pm and will be composed of the floats and DJs that took
part
> in the parade. See <http://www.loveparadesf.org/eventdetails.html>the
Event
> Details section of the website.
>
> Coming from out of town and need a place to stay or help getting around
> around? See the
> Accommodation<http://www.loveparadesf.org/accomandtransport.html> and
> Transportation section of the website and links to hotels offer discounted
> accommodation. Mention Loveparade when booking or use the links provided.
> You must book soon to get a discount!
>
> More information has been posted to the website.
> <http://www.loveparadesf.org/faq.html>Click here to visit the FAQ section.
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] name the track

The original is a disco record.

Sweetness - "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life"
Label: Rams Horn Records
Catalog#: RAMSH 12-3180
Format: 12"
Country: Netherlands
Released: 1983

Or this....

Indeep - "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life"
Label: Sound Of New York
Catalog#: SNYL1
Format: 12"
Country: UK
Released: 1982
Note: All tracks mixed by Tony Humphries


I think these are both the same thing and I GUESS you could call them house. 
But it was straight up disco.

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Evil Breaks presents...DIRTY w/ TRONA - September 25th

Evil Breaks presents:
DIRTY

@ Shadow Lounge, 299 9th and Folsom
Friday, September 25th
$5 before 11pm, $10 after

Flyer:  http://www.invibe.com/dirty/dirty_800.jpg

Featuring:

Trona (Moonshine, i-lektrick (UK), www.tronaonline.com) North Carolina

Hailing from North Carolina, Trona is without a doubt one of the best and 
most established breakbeat producers the US has to offer. Although hes 
known throughout the southeast for his bass heavy and electro-funk 
selections, he is also one of the key players in the deep progressive arena 
which can be heard from his releases on Moonshine, his remix of Icelandic 
pop group Gus Gus, and his current collaborations with the west coast band 
Cirrus. Tronas first release on Moonshines GREEN imprint found a place in 
many dj charts overseas. His 2nd release Dangerous was to go even further 
by getting radio play by Whole Nine Yards Dark Globe. He ended 2003 with 
one of his most solid releases to date Rhythm Man (turn up) with the 
insanely brilliant Insanity to back the release. One can only expect the 
best that breakbeat has to offer when Trona is in performance.


Nubreaks.com article on Trona 
http://www.nubreaks.com/?dir=features/trfeat0608&section=trona_feature

Please click on the following link to sample the dirtiness that is Trona
http://www.nubreaks.com/audio/ram/Trona-AtmoDJ-Hi.ram

Also performing at this event:

Greg J (Funky Cactus Recordings, Skratchmatics, kidbippy.com)

Aaron Jae vs Athena (AaronJae.com/Evil Breaks/the Nubotz)

Influence vs dj Bam (In tha Mix/Evil Breaks/Invibe.com)

Thomas Kent vs Kris Kent (Ill Behavior/Modified)

M.O.D. (Evil Breaks)


Located at the Shadow Lounge (299 9th st @ Folsom) this event will be 21+ 
going strong from 9pm - 4am with tons of drinks and a suped up sound system. 
And once again Evil Breaks will be bringing you awesome talent at a very 
reasonable price.

$5 before 11pm / $10 after

From sfraves-return-115116-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 31 07:03:12 2004

X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.2.0
Date: Tue, 31 Aug 2004 00:03:09 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_47354792==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Police defend handling of illegal rave

--=====================_47354792==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


http://new.edp24.co.uk/content/news/story.aspx?brand=EDPOnline&category=News
&tBrand=EDPOnline&tCategory=news&itemid=NOED30%20Aug%202004%2016%3A50%3A43%3
A840

Police defend handling of illegal rave

EDWARD FOSS

30 August 2004 16:50

Norfolk police defended the way they dealt with an illegal rave on private
land which attracted hundreds of young partygoers.

And a senior officer said lessons learnt from the latest in a string of
similar outdoor events could feed into future policy for dealing with such
incidents.

The rave, held on the idyllic North Norfolk clifftop near Weybourne, led to
damage to gates, fields and the cliff edge. From the site, adjacent to the
Norfolk Coast Path, it was possible to see ex-Prime Minister John Major's
house, approximately a mile away on the hillside.

The irate farmer, whose land was crossed by hundreds of vehicles over the
weekend, said the incident had already cost him money in repairs and
possible loss of value of his crops, because he has been unable to harvest.

Similar parties have been held in the last few weeks across Norfolk,
including at Brancaster beach, Thetford Forest and Sandringham. All have
attracted police attention and local anger.

The police have been criticised by landowners for the way they have
responded to the events, but Supt Vaughan Mullender said officers had to
respond in a "proportionate and pragmatic way".

He said it was important to ensure public safety and to minimise disruption
and damage.

"We see what lessons can be learned and we learn from each of these
incidents," said Supt Mullender.

"We have to take that proportionate approach when dealing with these things
and look at all the surrounding circumstances."

Supt Mullender also said it was conceivable that the lessons learnt could
eventually lead to a change of policy.

He said officers reacted "very positively" to the Weybourne rave, which
police officially described as a 'party'.

"We are happy with the way it was dealt with," said Supt Mullender.

Jim Wilson, chairman of Norfolk Police Authority, said the issue was an
operational matter and it was not in the remit of the authority to comment.

But he added that such incidents were generally cases of management.

"Wherever possible the police manage these things in a way to try and
ameliorate the disturbance."

Mr Wilson said breaking up a party once scores or hundreds of people were
there would take an "awful lot" of manpower.

Up to 800 people were understood to have been at the Weybourne rave at its
height. The event started on Saturday morning and was continuing Monday
night.

John Perry-Warnes, county council representative on the police authority,
said he was very sorry that the landowner had experienced "considerable
inconvenience right in the middle of harvesting and cultivating".

He added that the rave had been "thoroughly well planned" and that the
organisers had "in a way outmanoeuvred us".

Farmer Clive Hay-Smith, who farms 1200 acres, felt better policing of the
rave in its very early stages could have prevented it going ahead.

"I do think they should have been jumped on earlier. The first group was
fairly small, it wasn't as if all these people turned up at once."

Mr Hay-Smith said some of the behaviour he had seen defied belief,
explaining that he had seen a father in a Mercedes dropping his daughter off
at the party and one of the ravers asking him what he was doing there ­ even
though he was on his own land.

He was also angry that he had been unable to harvest a neighbouring field of
barley over the weekend, which could now lose quality and therefore value in
the coming days.

"We were lined up to cut it on Saturday, but for health and safety reasons
we decided we just could not.

"I was worried there could have been someone out of it and asleep in the
field and they wouldn't hear the machinery coming.

"To be honest the whole thing is a mess, I can't tell you how angry I have
been ­ and all in a year when the harvest has been hard enough as it is."

However Mr Hay-Smith was determined to cut the remainder of his crop, about
100 acres, in the coming days.

Over the weekend, bemused walkers were greeted with a rag-tag gathering of
tents, cars, vans, music systems, a stack of giant speakers and empty cans
strewn on the ground as they made their way along the well-trodden coast
path.

Generally pleasant and polite, those attending the rave were mainly young,
aged either in their teens or 20s.

There was a certain amount of tidying being done on Monday afternoon, but
there were still plenty of cans, bottles, cigarette butts and other rubbish
lying across a large area.

The group who appeared to have organised the rave declined to comment, but
one raver, who identified himself simply as Will, said: "We're just having
fun, there's no houses that close by. What's the problem?"




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

Niels Bohr to Albert Einstein

of the bosses and their employers, the special interests.  An invisible 
empire has been set up above the forms of democracy."
-Woodrow Wilson

"The truth is where the truth is, and it's sometimes in the candy store."
-Bob Dylan

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

--- Gavin Varitech <nesound@hotmail.com> wrote:

> The original is a disco record.
> 
> Sweetness - "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life"
> Label: Rams Horn Records
> Catalog#: RAMSH 12-3180
> Format: 12"
> Country: Netherlands
> Released: 1983
> 
> Or this....
> 
> Indeep - "Last Night A DJ Saved My Life"
> Label: Sound Of New York
> Catalog#: SNYL1
> Format: 12"
> Country: UK
> Released: 1982
> Note: All tracks mixed by Tony Humphries
> 
> 
> I think these are both the same thing and I GUESS
> you could call them house. 
> But it was straight up disco.
>

> Gavin

Blank
..I am back in town after a nice ,long trip back to DC. Me and my boy =
straight tore it up @ Buzz, which was all we ever wanted to do. =
Subsequently, we are going to be brought back to open the main room next =
time!!! I am still basking in the afterglow....

Anyhoo - I'm keeping it brief for now. Still recovering from the trip - =
just wanted to say hi to y'all, and I am ecstatic to be back in the Bay =
Area. Finally some nice weather....

ez.

the song structure but with a bit more tribal percussion. I don't really 
recall the artist cause I don't really like that track.. it is more of a 
filler track but goes nicely cause of the percussion.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] *HAPPY TOGETHER 3! This Saturday, Sept. 4th! 2000+ Capacity / 9pm-6am

Yeah, we know. It's been almost 2 years since the last one. There hasn't 
been a single party we get asked more about, so here it is, the finale.. 
Liquidvinyldjs.com is unbelieveably proud to present:

HAPPY TOGETHER 3
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH 2004
LABOR DAY WEEKEND
ALL AGES | 9:00pm-6:00am
2000+ CAPACITY BAY AREA LOCATION!


We've taken great pride in putting together this once in a lifetime lineup! 
Prepare for one of the biggest hard lineups the West Coast has ever seen!


SCOTT BROWN
|| Evolution Records - Scotland || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
Considered by many around the world as Hardcore's #1 DJ and Producer, Scott 
Brown has achieved more in his career than many in any other genre. He's 
developed his Evolution Records label into what many reguard as the top 
Hardcore label in the world, along with releasing tracks with many of 
Hardcore's top Producers. With massive hits like "ELYSIUM", "NOW IS THE 
TIME", "TURN UP THE MUSIC", and "ICE COLD", chances are if you've been to a 
party in the past 10 years, you've heard his music. As a DJ, he is known for 
his rock solid skills on the decks, often building his sets into energetic 
frenzies that result in mayhem after it's all said and done! This will be 
Scott Brown's first Bay Area Appearance, please join us to make it 
memorable!

DJ HIXXY
|| RaverBaby / HTID / Bonkers - U.K. ||
>From his novice DJ days in 1991 to his International Hardcore Superstar 
status of today, Hixxy has worked long and hard making a name for himself in 
the Hardcore circuit. From his early releases "TOY TOWN" and "WANTING TO GET 
HIGH" to his current hits "TANTRIC" and his remix of "FALLING IN", Hixxy has 
enjoyed enormous success as a Producer. As a DJ, Hixxy helped launch the 
enormously popular "BONKERS" series on React, which continues to break sales 
records for Hardcore CD compilations. His mixes are known to be uplifting 
and energetic, so be ready as we bring Hixxy for a very rare USA appearance!

TOMMYKNOCKER
|| Traxtorm Records - Italy || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
As one of the fastest rising Hardcore producers today, we are extremely 
excited to bring you Tommyknocker for his first Bay Area Appearance. Hailing 
from Italy, his unique sound has been in demand by all of the world's top 
Hardcore DJs, with hard hittin' releases like "THE AFTERMATH", "REVOLUTION", 
and "DEMOLITION". He is also an accomplished DJ, playing huge events like 
Love Parade, Hellraiser, Megarave, and Masters of Hardcore. If you like your 
Hardcore rough and rugged, Tommyknocker is your man!

DELTA 9
|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is widely 
respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his early 
releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE", to his 
present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER", he 
continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has appeared all 
around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd control, 
often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to 
present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

DJ VENOM
|| Volume Productions / Topaz Records - Providence, RI || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Looked upon as one of the most talented Hard DJ's in America, Venom's style 
and persona are only comparible to his music: wild and crazy! He goes 
seamlessly from US Hard House to Hardcore in his mixes, as showcased on such 
top-selling CD compilations as his "RAISE THE VOLUME" series, his "STRAIGHT 
BANGIN" series, and the immensely popular "HOUSE BLEND VOLUME 7-8". From his 
jaw-dropping scratching to his crowd rockin stage displays, it's no wonder 
why Venom is in such huge demand all around the country. We are hyped to 
bring you DJ Venom's first Bay Area Appearance!


CLOUDSKIPPER
|| Raw Elements / KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The one, the only. Cloudskipper is widely recognized and respected as one of 
the top Hardcore DJ's in America. With his recent tour of the U.K. as well 
as his very busy touring here in North America, crowds all around the world 
continue to be amazed and captivated by his upfront Hardcore sets. Often 
immitated, never duplicated, Cloudskipper sets the bar other Hardcore DJ's 
will be trying to reach... next year.

DJ TRONIC
|| Resistance Recordings / Liquidvinyldjs.com / BeatSupreme.com ||
Label owner. Producer. DJ. Promoter. Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not. DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.


THE NICE GUYS [NO LEFT TURN & DJ REESE]
|| KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
When they're not out being nice somewhere, they're out getting drunk. All 
jokes aside, these two are starting to make waves in the Hardcore world, 
with their two upcoming releases on KFA, as well as other material released 
on Raw Elements and Bedlam. Prepare for the Nice Guys, dropping a 
not-so=nice set!

THE NATURAL DISASTERS [THE DOCTOR & RECLIPSE]
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The Doctor and Reclipse, forces in their own right come together to form the 
Natural Disasters. While they're not wrestlers, they drop some of the 
hardest hittin material in the Bay, ranging from DrumNBass to Hardcore to 
Gabber, these two will be shaking the dancefloor HARD!

J-MARR & CARLOS ALFONZO
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com / Soop Recordings / BeatSupreme.com || 
[/b]
Alright, the last time we had these two together during a set, they did more 
passing out of food than actually playing. While we can't promise the same 
feast, we can promise a rockin set that only these two can bring!

_____________________


| This will be our BIGGEST and BEST event to date! Better than Overload, 
Overload 2, Overload 3, Happy Together, and even Happy Together 2! Where 
will YOU be on September 4th??

| Happy Together 3 will be an ALL AGES EVENT running from 9:00pm-6:00am! 
Make sure to get there early so you don't miss out on any of the action! The 
perfect event to end your summer right!

| Our capacity will be 2000+! One big ass room filled with the BIGGEST and 
BEST Hard lineup Northern California has ever seen! The event will be 
located in the IMMEDIATE BAY AREA.

| Hard hittin audio provided by: HARDSCIENCE | Multi-Screen Screen Visual 
Display by: Connected Systems |

| Having a birthday within 2 weeks of September 4th? E-mail us at: 
djtronic@resistancerecordings.com and we'll add you to our special birthday 
celebration!


Ticket Info:

The first 50 Presale Tickets will be only $1.00![SOLD OUT!] That's right, 
first 50 Presale Tickets will be $1.00![SOLD OUT!] After those are gone, 
tickets will go up to $10.00. After those $10.00 Presales are gone, tickets 
will go up to $15.00. After those are gone, tickets will be available at the 
door. What's that mean? BUY A PRESALE TICKET - GUARANTEE YOUR ENTRY! Every 
event we've done has SOLD OUT, and we fully expect Happy Together 3 to SELL 
OUT!


Presale Tickets go on sale Wednesday, July 14th at the following locations:

SKILLS DJ WORKSHOP | BERKELEY :: 510.704.9876
SOLID GROOVES | SANTA CLARA :: 408.248.6399

"A new poll says that if the election were held today, John  Kerry would
beat President Bush by a double digit margin. The White House is  so
worried about this, they're now thinking of moving up the capture  of
Osama Bin Laden to next month."
-- Jay Leno

President Bush has  unveiled his first campaign commercial, highlighting
all of his  accomplishments in office. That's why it's a 60-second spot."
-- Jay  Leno

"President Bush says he has just one question for the American  voters,
'Is the rich person you're working for better off now than they  were
four years ago?'"
-- Jay Leno

"Kerry is well on his way to  reaching his magic number of 2,162. That's
the total number of delegates he  needs to win the Democratic nomination.
See, for President Bush it's  different. His magic number is only 5.
That's the number of Supreme Court  judges needed to win."
-- Jay Leno

"There was a scare in Washington  when a man climbed over the White
House wall and was arrested. This marks the  first time a person has
gotten into The White House unlawfully since  President Bush."
-- David Letterman

"The White House is now  backtracking from its prediction that 2.6
million new jobs will be created in  the U.S. this year. They say they
were off, by roughly 2.6 million  jobs.."
-- Jay Leno

"In Louisiana, President Bush met with over 15,000  National Guard
troops. Here's the weird part: nobody remembers seeing him  there."
-- Craig Kilborn

"President Bush said he was 'troubled' by gay  people getting married in
San Francisco. He said on important issues like  this the people should
make the decision, not judges. Unless of course we're  choosing a
president, then he prefers judges."
-- Jay Leno

"There  was an embarrassing moment in the White House earlier today.
They were  looking around searching for George Bush's military records.
They actually  found some old Al Gore ballots."
-- David Letterman

"The big story now  is that President Bush is coming under attack for
his service in the National  Guard. The commanding officers can't
remember seeing Bush between May and  October of '72. President Bush
said, 'Remember me? I'm the drunk guy.'"
--  Jay Leno

"On 'Meet the Press' yesterday President Bush was asked what he  would
do if he lost the election and Bush said, 'You mean like last  time?'"
-- Jay Leno

"This week, both John Kerry and Wesley Clark are  making campaign
appearance with the guys who saved their lives in Vietnam.  Meanwhile,
President Bush is campaigning with a guy that once took a math  test for
him."
-- Conan O'Brien

"President Bush released his new  $2.4 trillion federal budget. It has
two parts: smoke and mirrors."
-- Jay  Leno

"Bush admitted that his pre-war intelligence wasn't what it should  have
been. We knew that when we elected him!"
-- JayLeno

"As you  know President Bush gave his State of the Union Address,
interrupted 70 times  by applause and 45 times by really big words."
-- Jay Leno

"President  Bush said that American workers will need new skills to get
the new jobs in  the 21st century. Some of the skills they're going to
need are Spanish,  Chinese, and Korean, because that's where the jobs
went."
-- Jay  Leno

"President Bush wants to build a space station on the moon. And  from
the moon, he wants to launch people to Mars. You know what this  means.
He's drinking again."
-- David Letterman

"Former Treasury  Secretary Paul O'Neill has written a book about his
years with the Bush  Administration. He said that President Bush, while
at cabinet meetings is  disengaged, he's uninformed, distracted, he's
passive. And the Democrats are  saying to themselves "How can we possibly
beat this guy?"
-- David  Letterman

"The new Prime Minister of Spain has called the war in Iraq a  disaster,
and plans to bring his troops home as soon as possible. In  fact,
President Bush is so upset at Spain that he is now threatening to  close
down the border between Spain and the US."
-- Jay  Leno

"Homeland Security Director Tom Ridge has unveiled a new  color-coded
system to warn the public about different states of danger. Red  is the
highest state of alert, and it means that Dick Cheney is about to eat  a
mozzarella stick."
-- Conan O'Brien

"Dick Cheney finally  responded today to demands that he reveal the
details of the Enron meetings.  This is what he said. 'He met with
unnamed people, from unspecified  companies, for an indeterminate amount
of time, at an undisclosed location.'  Thank God he cleared that up." - -
Jay Leno

"Plans are being discussed  as to who will replace Dick Cheney if he has
to resign for health reasons.  It's not easy for President Bush. He can't
just name a replacement. He would  first have to be confirmed by the oil,
gas and power companies."
-- Jay  Leno

"President Bush spoke briefly to reporters before playing a round  of
golf in Crawford, Texas, earlier today. This raises the  question:
Shouldn't the guy who is really running the country and who has had  like
20 heart attacks be taking the vacation?"
-- Craig  Kilborn

"The White House has now released military documents they say  prove
George Bush met his requirements for the National Guard. Big deal,  we've
got documents that prove Al Gore won the election."
-- Jay  Leno
